content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀεὶ_μέν_1">, followed in 3 by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_νῦν_1">: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 689"> <title>Tr.</title> 689-691</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχρισα μὲν...κἄθηκα</quote> </cit> (n.): Lucian <title>Dialog. marin.</title> 8 <quote xml:lang="grc">πάλαι μὲν τὸ τῆς Ἰνοῦς παιδίον ἐπὶ τὸν Ἰσθμὸν ἐκομίσατε..., καὶ νῦν σὺ τὸν κιθαρῳδὸν...ἀναλαβὼν ἐξενήξω</quote>. The passage in <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 587">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 587</ref>—598 (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνωλόλυξα μὲν πάλαι...καὶ νῦν τὰ μάσσω μὲν τί δεῖ σ’ ἐμοὶ λέγειν;</quote>) is scarcely a true parallel,—the interval being so long. Plato has <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀεὶ μὲν</quote> followed by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτὰρ καὶ νῦν</quote> (<ref n="Plat. Prot. 335d"> <title>Prot.</title> 335 D</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτὰρ οὖν καὶ τότε</quote> (<ref n="Plat. Rep. 367e"> <title>Rep.</title> 367 E</ref>). Similarly I. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.107"> <title>Il.</title> 107</ref> ff. <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰεὶ τοι...καὶ νῦν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λαρτίου_1">, as in 380: but <quote xml:lang="grc">Λαερτίου</quote> in 101, and <quote xml:lang="grc"> Λαέρτου</quote> in 1393. <quote xml:lang="grc">Λαέρτης</quote> is the only Homeric form ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 87"> <title>Ph.</title> 87</ref> n.), but Eur. , like Soph. , uses all three. In Latin, <title>Laertius</title> or <title>Lartius</title> is usu. the adj. (<cit> <bibl n="Pl. Bac. 4.9">Plaut. <title>Bacch.</title> 4. 9. 22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">Ulixes Lartius</quote> </cit>), but, acc. to Priscian (7. 5, p. 303), could be also the name. The writing <quote xml:lang="grc">Λἀρτίου</quote> appears in all the editions from the Aldine to Brunck's; the coronis was first omitted by Schaefer (ed. 1810), on the ground that crasis is not marked within a word. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεῖράν_ἁρπάσαι_2">, to <emph> snatch</emph> (by vigilant and subtle craft) some <emph>means of attacking</emph> foes,—some moment when foes can be taken at a disadvantage. For the objective gen. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐχθρῶν_2">, cp. <ref n="Diod. 14.80">Diod. Sic. 14. 80</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καιρὸν εὔθετον εἰς τὴν τῶν πολεμίων ἐπίθεσιν</quote>: for </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁρπάσαι_2">, Plut. <title>Philop.</title> 15 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁρπάσας τὸν καιρόν</quote>: Xen. <title>An.</title> 4. 6. 11 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ ἐρήμου ὄρους..κλέψαι τι..καὶ ἁρπάσαι φθάσαντας</quote>. Like the verb (<quote xml:lang="grc">πειρᾶν τῆς πόλεως</quote>, Her. 6. 82), <quote xml:lang="grc">πεῖρα</quote> often denotes an enterprise against an enemy (Thuc. 3. 20, etc.).—Not, ‘to forestall (or baffle) some attempt <emph>by</emph> a foe.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θηρώ_2"> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μενον_2"> with inf.: cp. Eur. <title>Helen.</title> 63 <quote xml:lang="grc">θηρᾷ γαμεῖν με</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat"> ib.</foreign> 545 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅς με θηρᾶται λαβεῖν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκηναῖς_ναυτικαῖς_3">. Each chief has his quarters at the place on the shore of the bay where his own ships are drawn up. The plural here is probably poetical, denoting the tent of Ajax only, and not also those of his followers. We have the sing. of <quote xml:lang="grc">σκηνή</quote> at 218 and 796, the plur. at 754 and 985; and in 754 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπὸ σκηναῖσι</quote> is precisely equivalent to <quote xml:lang="grc">σκηνῆς ὕπαυλον</quote> in 796. So, too, the plur. of <quote xml:lang="grc">κλισία</quote> in 192, and the sing. in 1407.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάξιν_ἐσχάτην_4">. While Odysseus was stationed at the middle point of the Greek camp, the posts of danger and honour at the eastern and western ends respectively were held by Achilles and Ajax,—<quote xml:lang="grc">τοί ῥ) ἔσχατα νῆας ἐΐσας | εἴρυσαν, ἠνορέῃ πίσυνοι καὶ κάρτεϊ χειρῶν</quote> (<title>Il.</title> 11. 8 f.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυνηγετοῦντα_5">: his keen scrutiny suggests a hunter; as his sagacity suggests a hound (8). We can speak of a dog ‘hunting,’ but a Greek would hardly have said <quote xml:lang="grc">κύων κυνηγετεῖ</quote>. The transition from one image to the other is natural and easy.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μετρούμενον_5">, with the eyes. In Attic the midd. is rare, except as=‘to have measured out to one,’ [Dem.] or. 34 § 37: but it is frequent in later poetry, as <ref n="Apollon. 1.724">Apoll. Rh. 1. 724</ref>, <ref n="Mosch. 2.157">Mosch. 2. 157.</ref>Nauck holds that <quote xml:lang="grc">μετρούμενον</quote> could denote only literal measurement (as with a foot-rule). But its figurative sense—as denoting a mental process of examination and comparison— is exactly illustrated by the use of <quote xml:lang="grc">συμμετρεῖσθαι</quote> in the sense of ‘to <emph>compute</emph>’ ( <ref n="Hdt. 4. 158"> Her. 4. 158</ref>, etc.). Cp. also Lat. <foreign xml:lang="lat">metiri (oculis, auribus</foreign>, etc.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νεοχάρακτα_6">, newly imprinted on the sandy soil. The tent was close to the sea (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφαλος</quote>, 192). Ajax had gone out in the past night, and come back at dawn. All the footprints are fresh; but Odysseus has to make out whether the <emph> more</emph> recent lead to or from the tent. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτ_ἔνδον_7">. Either <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote> can be used in an indirect question introduced by <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ</quote> : <ref n="Plat. Gorg. 462d">Plat. <title>Gorg.</title> 462 D</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρωτᾷς εἰ οὐ καλή μοι δοκεῖ εἶναι</quote>: <ref n="Plat. Theaet. 163d"> <title>Theaet.</title> 163 D</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βουλόμενος ἐρέσθαι εἰ..μὴ οἶδεν</quote>. The same rule holds when the indirect question is alternative (‘whether...or <emph>not</emph>’), and the second part of it is introduced by <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴτε</quote> (as here), or by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤ</quote>. <ref n="Plat. Crat. 425b">Plat. <title>Crat.</title> 425 B</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴτε κατὰ τρόπον κεῖται εἴτε μή, οὕτω θεᾶσθαι</quote> : <ref n="Plat. Rep. 451d"> <title>Rep.</title> 451 D</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκοπῶμεν εἰ ἡμῖν πρέπει ἢ οὔ</quote>. When a writer uses <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote> in one such question, and then <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ</quote> in another, the motive of the change may be his wish to mark (by <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ</quote>) a negative <emph>fact</emph> (or what he conceives as such): <ref n="Antiph. 5.14">Antiphon or. 5 § 14</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ δεῖ ὑμᾶς ἐκ τῶν τοῦ κατηγόρου λόγων τοὺς νόμους καταμανθάνειν, εἰ καλῶς ὑμῖν κεῖνται ἢ μή, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῶν νόμων τοὺς τοῦ κατηγόρου λόγους, εἰ ὀρθῶς καὶ νομίμως ὑμᾶς διδάσκει τὸ πρᾶγμα ἢ οὔ</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκφέρει_7">: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς τέλος ἐξάγει</quote>: ‘brings <emph>out</emph>,’ as from a labyrinth, to the desired goal. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 98"> <title>O. C.</title> 98</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξήγαγ’ εἰς τόδ’ ἄλσος</quote> </cit>, (your guidance) ‘hath <emph>led me home</emph> to this grove.’ <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 66b">Plat. <title>Phaedo</title> p. 66 B</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κινδυνεύει τοι ὥσπερ ἀτραπός τις ἐκφέρειν ἡμᾶς</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote: κινδυνεύει τοι ὥσπερ ἀτραπός τις ἐκφέρειν ἡμᾶς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυνὸς_Λακαίνης_8">. According to Aristotle, the Laconian dogs were crossbred with foxes (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἀλώπεκος καὶ κυνὸς οἱ Λακωνικοί</quote>, <title>Hist. Anim.</title> 8. 28, p. 607 <emph>a</emph> 3). He describes them as a small breed, with long nostrils and keen scent (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσων οἱ μυκτῆρες μακροί, οἷον τῶν Λακωνικῶν κυνιδίων, ὀσφραντικά</quote>: <title>Gener. Anim.</title> 5. 2, p. 781 <emph>b</emph> 9). They were the best hunting dogs, as Pindar testifies, fr. 106: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπὸ Ταϋγέτοιο μὲν Λάκαιναν | ἐπὶ θηρσὶ κύνα τρέφειν</quote> [<foreign xml:lang="lat"> v.l.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρέχειν</quote>] <quote xml:lang="grc">πυκινώτατον ἑρπετόν</quote>. The Molossian dog is often associated with the Laconian ( <ref n="Hor. Epod. 6. 5">Hor. <title> Epod.</title> 6. 5</ref> <title>Molossus aut fulvus Laco:</title> <title> G.</title> 3. 405 <title>Velocis Spartae catulos acremque Molossum</title>); but Aristotle tells us that the Molossian breed had no special merit for sporting purposes; its best product was the large sheep-dog. The chief points common to the Laconian and Molossian breeds were courage and pertinacity (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρία</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">φιλοπονία</quote>, <title>Hist. An.</title> 9. 1, p. 608 <emph>a</emph> 31).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔρινος_8"> is nom., not gen. (from <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔρις</quote>). It is true that <quote xml:lang="grc"> εὔρις</quote> occurs in <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1093">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1093</ref>, and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄρρινες</quote> in <ref n="Xen. Hunt. 3. 2">Xen. <title>Cyn.</title> 3. 2</ref>; while <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔρινος</quote> (from <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥίς</quote>) occurs only in late Greek, as Babrius 43. 8 <quote xml:lang="grc">σκύλαξιν εὐρίνοις</quote>: Aelian <title>N. A.</title> 2. 15 <quote xml:lang="grc">δίκην εὐρίνου κυνός</quote>, etc. (In <ref n="Apollon. 3.1299">Apoll. Rh. 3. 1299</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐΰρινοι</quote> is not from <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥίς</quote>, but from <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥινός</quote>,—‘of good leather.’) But the form is correct in itself; such alternatives were frequent (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">σύζυγος</quote> by the side of <quote xml:lang="grc"> σύζυξ</quote>, etc.); and three points here recommend the nominative. (1) The order of the words <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις</quote>. (2) The idiom, consonant with tragic style, by which the epithet of the hound is transferred to <quote xml:lang="grc">βάσις</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Her. 450">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 450</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γραίας ὄσσων..πηγάς</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 1351"> <title>Phoen.</title> 1351</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λευκοπήχεις κτύπους χεροῖν</quote>. (3) The fact that <quote xml:lang="grc">βάσις</quote>, with no epithet, would be somewhat weak. Libanius (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 350 A.D. ) took <quote xml:lang="grc"> εὔρινος</quote> as nom., vol. 4. p. 1065 <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρίνῳ βάσει τὸ λανθάνον ἀνιχνεύοντες</quote>. The genitive was understood by the schol. on v. 7, and by Manuel Palaeologus or. 6. 331 (<quote xml:lang="grc">λάκαιναι κύνες· εὔρινας ταύτας εἶπε Σοφοκλῆς</quote> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυγχάνει_9">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤν</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 46"> <title>El.</title> 46</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στάζων_ἱδρῶτι_10">. Some think that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱδρῶτι</quote> refers to <quote xml:lang="grc">κάρα</quote> only, and that <quote xml:lang="grc">στάζων χέρας ξιφοκτόνους</quote> is equivalent to <quote xml:lang="grc">στάζων αἵματι χέρας</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1422"> <title>El.</title> 1422</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοινία δὲ χεὶρ | στάζει θυηλῆς Ἄρεος</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 41">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 41</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἵματι | στάζοντα χεῖρας</quote>. Certainly <quote xml:lang="grc">ξιφοκτόνους</quote> suggests the blood upon his hands. But the integral phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">στάζων ἱδρῶτι</quote>, must surely go with <quote xml:lang="grc">χέρας</quote> no less than with <quote xml:lang="grc">κάρα</quote>. The hands are bathed in sweat <emph>and</emph> in blood. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παπταίνειν_11">, from meaning ‘to glance timidly’ around, passes into the sense of looking about anxiously <emph> for</emph> someone or something ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.115"> <title>Il.</title> 17. 115</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παπταίνων Αἴαντα</quote>), and so comes to denote restless search, as in <ref n="Pind. O. 1">Pind. <title>O.</title> 1. 114</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηκέτι πάπταινε πόρσιον</quote>, <ref n="Pind. P. 3"> Pind. <title>P.</title> 3. 22</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παπταίνει τὰ πόρσω</quote>. Here, the notion of moving <emph>forward</emph> in a wary quest is assisted by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴσω_11">. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔργον_12">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">opus est:</foreign> 852: <ref n="Eur. El. 1372"> <title>El.</title> 1372</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐννέπειν_δ_12">: here <quote xml:lang="grc">δὲ</quote> =<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλά</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 85"> <title>Ant.</title> 85</ref> n.: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 94."> <title>Ph.</title> 94.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτου_χάριν_12">. Athena already knows his motive (36); but this touch of divine irony is dramatically useful by giving the cue for his statement. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σπουδὴν_τήνδ_13">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσπούδασας περὶ τούτου</quote>. This periphrasis, more elegant than that with <quote xml:lang="grc">ποιεῖσθαι</quote>, is much used by the poet; thus <quote xml:lang="grc">τίθεσθαι πρόνοιαν</quote> (536), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιστροφήν</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OT 132"> <title>O. T.</title> 134</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">τάφον</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1447), <quote xml:lang="grc"> φόνον</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 542"> <title>O. C.</title> 542</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">μῆκος λόγων</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1139), <quote xml:lang="grc"> λησμοσύναν</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 151"> <title>Ant.</title> 151</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">συγγνωμοσύνην</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1265"> <title>Tr.</title> 1265</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_Ἀθάνας_14">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1225"> <title>El.</title> 1225</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ φθέγμ’, ἀφίκου</quote>; (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φιλτάτης_θεῶν_14">: as he says in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 134"> <title>Ph.</title> 134</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">Νίκη τ’ Ἀθάνα Πολιάς, ἣ σῴζει μ’ ἀεί</quote>. In <ref n="Hom. Od. 20.47"> <title>Od.</title> 20. 47</ref> she says to him, <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὰρ ἐγὼ θεός εἰμι, διαμπερὲς ἥ σε φυλάσσω | ἐν πάντεσσι πόνοις</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἂν_ὅμως_15">. The general sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄποπτος</quote> here is, ‘far from my sight’; the question is whether this means, (1) ‘seen only at a distance,’ ‘dimly seen’; or (2) ‘unseen.’ I formerly preferred the first view, for which we may compare <ref n="Soph. Phil. 467"> <title>Ph.</title> 467</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">πλοῦν μὴ )ξ ἀπόπτου μᾶλλον ἢ )γγύθεν σκοπεῖν</quote>, ‘to watch the weather near our ship, rather than from afar.’ But I now feel two difficulties which it involves. (1) The emphasis on voice and thought—<quote xml:lang="grc">φθέγμα, φώνημα, ξυναρπάζω φρενί</quote>—is so strong as to imply that he does not <emph>see</emph> her, even at a distance. (2) There can be no doubt that she was visible to the audience. She was probably on the <quote xml:lang="grc">θεολογεῖον</quote>,—a sort of platform, which projected from the wings, at the back of the proscenium, and close to its upper edge. If, then, Odysseus spoke of her as ‘seen only afar,’—a dim vision in the clouds,—the effect would be scarcely happy for the spectators, whose eyes could measure the actual distance between goddess and hero. On the other hand, there would seem nothing strange in her remaining invisible to him. In the <title>Hippolytus</title>, Aphroditè speaks the prologue, and was certainly visible to the spectators; but not to Hippolytus, who says, <quote xml:lang="grc">κλύων μὲν αὐδήν, ὄμμα δ’ οὐχ ὁρῶν τὸ σόν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυναρπάζω_φρενί_16"> expresses the thrill of instant recognition, as the voice falls distinctly (<quote xml:lang="grc">εὐμαθὲς</quote>) on his ear; it also suggests the emotion of joy. For the verb, cp. Simylus (a poet of the Middle Comedy) <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Stobaeus <title>Flor.</title> 360. 4. 14 <quote xml:lang="grc">κριτὴν τὸ ῥηθὲν δυνάμενον ξυναρπάσαι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κώδωνος_Τυρσηνικῆς_17">. The trumpet meant here was in form like the Roman,—straight, gradually increasing in diameter, and ending in a bell-shaped aperture (<quote xml:lang="grc"> κώδων</quote>). ‘Tyrrhenian,’ a frequent epithet of the trumpet ( <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 567">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 567</ref>, <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 1377">Eur. <title>Phoen.</title> 1377</ref>, <ref n="Verg. A. 8. 526">Verg. <title>Aen.</title> 8. 526</ref>, etc.), perhaps means no more than that the instrument was first brought to Europe by Tyrrhenian pirates,—the <quote xml:lang="grc">λῃστοσαλπιγκταί</quote> of Menander (frag.incert. 399). The Tyrrheni, according to a tradition for which Herodotus is the earliest witness (1. 94), were of Lydian origin; and the bronze trumpet may have been a Lydian invention (see <title>Dict. Ant.</title> ‘Tuba’). Homer mentions the trumpet only in similes, as when the voice of Achilles is likened to it ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.219"> <title>Il.</title> 18. 219</ref>, etc.). But the Greeks must have had it as early at least as the time of the Dorian conquest, to judge from the legends heard by Pausanias at Argos (2. 21, § 3), where there was a shrine of <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀθηνᾶ Σάλπιγξ</quote>.—See Appendix.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπέγνως_18"> with partic. (<quote xml:lang="grc">κυκλοῦντ’</quote>) of the act <emph>observed</emph>, as <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 8. 1. 33">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 8. 1. 33</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέγνως δ’ ἂν..οὐδένα οὔτε ὀργιζόμενον.. οὔτε χαίροντα</quote>. For slightly different uses of <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐπιγιγνώσκω</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 960">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 960</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 1296.">Soph. <title>El.</title> 1296.</ref> Remark </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὖ_18"> as 2nd syll. of 3rd foot, referring to the word before it: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 95">cp. 95</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 166"> <title>Ant.</title> 166</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 723."> Ant. 723.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάσιν_κυκλοῦντ_19">, moving round and round, going backwards and forwards in the attempt to make out the footprints,—like a hound questing about for the scent. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 226"> <title>Ant.</title> 226</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁδοῖς κυκλῶν ἐμαυτὸν εἰς ἀναστροφήν</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 632">Eur. <title> Or.</title> 632</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖ σὸν πόδ’ ἐπὶ συννοίᾳ κυκλεῖς</quote> (‘pacing to and fro in meditation’), | <quote xml:lang="grc">διπλῆς μερίμνης διπτύχους ἰὼν ὁδούς;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷ_σακεσφόρῳ_19">: <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.219"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 219</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴας δ’ ἐγγύθεν ἦλθε φέρων σάκος ἠΰτε πύργον</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">χάλκεον, ἑπταβόειον</quote>,—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, made by stitching together seven layers of ox-hide, and then covering the outer face with plates of bronze. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 576">Cp. 576</ref>: <cit> <bibl n="Ov. Met. 13. 2"> Ovid <title>Met.</title> 13. 2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">clypei dominus septemplicis Aiax.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄσκοπον_21">, inconceivable,—of unimaginable horror: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 864"> <title>El.</title> 864</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄσκοπος ἁ λώβα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχει_περάνας_21">=a perfect ( <ref n="Soph. OT 577"> <title>O. T.</title> 577</ref> n.): the double acc., as with <quote xml:lang="grc">δρᾶν, ποιεῖν</quote>, etc. (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1324">cp. 1324</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴργασται_21">, instead of repeating <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχει περάνας</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 54"> <title>O. T.</title> 54</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς εἴπερ ἄρξεις τῆσδε γῆς, ὥσπερ κρατεῖς</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρανές_23">, ‘clear,’ like the cognate <quote xml:lang="grc">τορόν</quote> (rt. <quote xml:lang="grc">τερ, τρα, τε‐τραίνω</quote>, to pierce). The adj. <quote xml:lang="grc">τρανής</quote> is not elsewhere extant, but <quote xml:lang="grc">τρανῶς</quote> is used by Aesch. ( <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1371">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1371</ref>) and Eur. ( <ref n="Eur. El. 758">Eur. <title>El.</title> 758</ref>). The form <quote xml:lang="grc">τρανός</quote> was current in later Greek; the earliest instance seems to be Halic. Dionys. (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 25 B.C.) <title>De Comp. Verborum</title> c. 22 <quote xml:lang="grc">τρανὴν καὶ καθαρὰν δύναμιν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλώμεθα_23">: this fig. sense, with ref. to uncertainty (‘to be at sea,’ as we say), belongs nowhere else to this verb, but often to <quote xml:lang="grc">πλανᾶσθαι</quote> ( <ref n="Hdt. 6. 37"> Her. 6. 37</ref>, etc.; <title>Hipp. Ma.</title> 304 C <quote xml:lang="grc">πλανῶμαι μὲν καὶ ἀπορῶ ἀεί</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θελοντής_24">. The form <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐθελοντής</quote> occurs in Herodotus, Thucydides, Xenophon, and the Orators, as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐθελοντήρ</quote> does in <ref n="Hom. Od. 2.292."> <title>Od.</title> 2. 292.</ref>On the other hand <quote xml:lang="grc">θελοντής</quote> is cited only from Porphyrius (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 270 A.D. , see Lobeck, <title>Phryn.</title> 7) and Hierocles (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 450 A.D. ), <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> <title>Flor.</title> 75. 14 (p. 449. 20). Similarly <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐθελήμων</quote> is the form used by Plato (<ref n="Plat. Crat. 406a"> <title>Crat.</title> 406 A</ref>), while the earliest authority for <quote xml:lang="grc">θελήμων</quote> is <ref n="Apollon. 2.557">Apoll. Rhod. 2. 557</ref>. In tragic iambics <quote xml:lang="grc">θέλω</quote> was naturally preferred, on metrical grounds, to <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐθέλω</quote>, though the latter occurs in tragic anapaests (as <ref n="Soph. OT 1303"> <title>O. T.</title> 1303</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 145"> <title>Ph.</title> 145</ref>). If <quote xml:lang="grc">θελοντής</quote> were found in a passage where metre <emph>required</emph> it, the rarity of the form would not justify its rejection. But where, as here, aphaeresis was available, it is surely more probable that the poet wrote <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐθελοντής.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπεζύγην_24">, as if the task were a yoke under which he placed himself: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1025"> <title>Ph.</title> 1025</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλοπῇ τε κἀνάγκῃ ζυγείς</quote> (n.): <ref n="Aesch. PB 108">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 108</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάγκαις ταῖσδ’ ὑπέζευγμαι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατηναρισμένας_26">: for <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐναρίζω</quote> ‘to slay’ (properly with the further notion of ‘despoiling’) cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1733"> <title>O. C.</title> 1733</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 94."> <title>Tr.</title> 94.</ref>From the cognate form <quote xml:lang="grc">κατεναίρομαι</quote> we have <quote xml:lang="grc"> κατήναρες</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 871."> <title>Ant.</title> 871.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_χειρὸς_26">, by a human hand. The military sense, ‘at close quarters’ ( <title>H.</title> 7. 2. 14 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνέβαλον καὶ ἐκ χειρὸς ἐμάχοντο</quote>), is less fitting here.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοῖς_ἐπιστάταις_26">: cp. fr. 873 <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοῖσιν ὅπλοις</quote>. The idiom occurs in the <title> Iliad</title> (as 8. 24),—sometimes with <quote xml:lang="grc">σύν</quote> added (as 14. 498), a form of it found also, though not often, in later poetry ( <ref n="Eur. Ion 32">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 32</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτῷ ξὺν ἄγγει</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπιστάταις_26">, ‘overseers,’ ‘masters’ or ‘guardians’ of them; as a warrior is <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπλων ἐπιστάτης</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 379">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 379</ref>), and a rower, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρετμῶν</quote> ( <title> Helen.</title> 1267). Cp. Eur. fr. 188. 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">σκάπτων, ἀρῶν γῆν, ποιμνίοις ἐπιστατῶν</quote>. The herdsmen being dead, there was no one who could identify the assailant. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶς_τις_28">. The deed was found out at dawn. Common rumour at once pointed to Ajax. Then the <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὀπτήρ</quote> (29) informed Odysseus, who reached the tent of Ajax very soon after the latter's return; as is shown by 296—304 compared with 91—113.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέμει_28">: cp. Galen 7. 582 (Kühn) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν αἰτίαν</quote>.—The corrupt </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρέπει_28"> may have come from the gloss on <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκείνῳ..νέμει</quote> which occurs in some of the later MSS., <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς αὐτὸν τρέπει</quote>. This is one of the few instances (like <ref n="Soph. Ant. 386"> <title>Ant.</title> 386</ref> and 831) where a true reading, lost in L, has been preserved in other MSS. Cp. crit. notes on 44, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 61."> Ant. 61.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τις_29"> placed before its noun: 1163: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 519."> <title>Ph.</title> 519.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀπτὴρ_29">, a scout; cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 14.261"> <title>Od.</title> 14. 261</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀπτῆρας δὲ κατὰ σκοπιὰς ὤτρυνα νέεσθαι</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Seven 36">Aesch. <title> Theb.</title> 36</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκοποὺς δὲ κἀγὼ καὶ κατοπτῆρας στρατοῦ | ἔπεμψα</quote>. In <title>Suppl.</title> 185, however, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀπτῆρες</quote> are ‘eye-witnesses,’—the usual sense of the word in Attic prose. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεδία_30"> is the acc. describing the ground traversed (as we can say, ‘to walk the earth’): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 845">cp. 845</ref>: <ref n="Aesch. PB 708">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 708</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">στεῖχ’ ἀνηρότους γύας</quote>: <title>Helen.</title> 598 <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς τήνδε βάρβαρον χθόνα</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Call. Dian. 103">Callim. <title>Hymn. Dian.</title> 193</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφοίτα | παίπαλά τε κρημνούς τε</quote> </cit> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νεορράντῳ_30"> (as in 828), ‘newly sprinkled’ with blood: a compound suggested to the poet by the frequent use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥαίνω</quote> in that connection; as <ref n="Hom. Il. 12.430"> <title>Il.</title> 12. 430</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπάλξιες αἵματι φωτῶν | ἐρράδατ’</quote>: <ref n="Pind. I. 7">Pind. <title>I.</title> 7. 50</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥαίνων φόνῳ πεδίον</quote>.—When thus seen, Ajax was in the act of driving the animals that still lived to his tent: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πηδῶντα_30"> describes his wild gestures of triumph. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φράζει_κἀδήλωσεν_31">: the first verb refers to the announcement, ‘I have seen Ajax,’—the second, to a statement with more detail,—as to the direction in which he was going, etc. For historic pres. followed by aor., cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 406"> <title>Ant.</title> 406</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ πῶς ὁρᾶται κἀπίληπτος ᾑρέθη;</quote> </cit> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατ_ἴχνος_32">: cp. Plat. <title>Rep.</title>p. 410 B <quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ ταὐτὰ ἴχνη ταῦτα διώκων</quote>. Similarly <quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ πόδας τινός</quote>, ‘at his heels’ ( <ref n="Hdt. 9. 89"> Her. 9. 89</ref>, etc.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σημαίνομαι_32">, midd., assure myself about them, identify them, by the indications observed. Cp. <ref n="Xen. Hunt. 6. 22">Xen. <title>Cyn.</title> 6. 22</ref>(of hounds): <quote xml:lang="grc">αἱ δ’ ἐπειδὰν λαμπρὰ ᾖ τὰ ἴχνη,...ἐνσημαινόμεναι, ὅρους τιθέμεναι ἑαυταῖς γνωρίμους, ταχὺ μεταθεύσονται</quote>. <cit> <bibl n="App. BC 4.4.19">Appian <title>Bell. Civ.</title> 4. 19</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σημηνάμενοι τὸ γιγνόμενον εἶναι σύμβολον ἐκ θεοῦ</quote> </cit>. Aelian <title>N. A.</title> 7. 48 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄστροις αὐτὰς</quote> (the cities) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσημαίνετο</quote>. Oppian <title>Cyneg.</title> 1. 454 <quote xml:lang="grc">μυξωτῆρσι κύνες δὲ πανίχνια σημήναντο</quote>. </gloss>

data.quote:
σημηνάμενοι τὸ γιγνόμενον εἶναι σύμβολον ἐκ
							θεοῦ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ἐκπέπληγμαι_33">: ‘as to other tracks’—viz., those of the cattle which Ajax had driven to the tent—he is bewildered.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτου_33">, as the context shows, is right: he cannot imagine who had made these tracks. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπου_33"> (cr. n.) would mean that, in the line of footprints made by Ajax, some were missing, which Odysseus did not know where to find. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καιρὸν_34">, adv., as 1316: <title>Helen.</title> 479 <quote xml:lang="grc">καιρὸν γὰρ οὐδέν’ ἦλθες</quote>: <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 23">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 23</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀωρίαν ἥκοντες</quote>. But <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς καιρὸν</quote> in 1168.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τά_οὖν_34">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">οὖν</quote> in the first of two such clauses, cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1049"> <title>O. T.</title> 1049</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴτ’ οὖν ἐπ’ ἀγρῶν εἴτε κἀνθάδ’ εἰσιδών</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔβην_ὁδόν_36">, ‘came into the path,’—placed myself on the route by which Ajax must pass.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυναγίᾳ_36">. Though we may conveniently render, ‘A watcher friendly to thy chase,’ the dat. seems really to depend on the whole idea, <quote xml:lang="grc">φύλαξ πρόθυμος</quote> (a zealous watcher in the interest of thy chase), rather than on the adj. only; though in <title>H.</title> 2. 3. 40 we have <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ πρόθυμοι τῇ πόλει γεγενημένοι</quote>. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 355"> <title>O.C.</title> 355</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φύλαξ δέ μοι <note anchored="true" place="inline" resp="RCJ" xml:lang="eng">(vulg. <foreign xml:lang="grc">μου</foreign>mou</note> | πιστὴ κατέστης</quote> </cit>.—The Doric form of <quote xml:lang="grc">κυναγία</quote> is supported by L here, as by the MSS. generally in <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 109">Eur. <title> Hipp.</title> 109</ref>: while in <ref n="Eur. Ba. 339">Eur. <title> Bacch.</title> 339</ref> the MSS. favour <quote xml:lang="grc"> κυνηγίαις</quote>, and the Doric form was restored by Matthiae. Attic Tragedy used <quote xml:lang="grc">κυναγός, κυναγία, κυνηγετεῖν, κυνηγέτης</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_καί_38">, in eager question: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 44">cp. 44</ref>, 48: <ref n="Eur. El. 314"> <title>El.</title> 314</ref> n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_καιρὸν_38">=<quote xml:lang="grc">καιρίως</quote> , <title>O.T.</title> 325 n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_39">, ‘know that’: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 117"> <title>Ph.</title> 117</ref> n.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοι_39">, ethic dat. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_τί_40">, ‘wherefore?’ Cp. <title>O.T.</title> 766, 1027, 1144.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾖξεν_40">, trans., as <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1427">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1427</ref> ff. <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὰ βόστρυχον αὔραν</quote>.. | .. <quote xml:lang="grc">κύκλῳ | πτερίνῳ...ᾄσσων</quote>, ‘agitating’ the air with a fan. Eur. Itis not impossible to take <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾖξεν</quote> as intrans. (‘broke forth <emph>in</emph> violence’); but it would be very harsh.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσλόγιστον_40"> is an epithet proper to the <emph> violence</emph>, transferred to the <emph>hand</emph> which wrought it; ‘reasoning amiss,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘irrational,’ ‘insensate.’ <ref n="Soph. Aj. 229">Cp. 229</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παραπλήκτῳ χερί</quote>. An exact parallel to this active sense is afforded by <ref n="Aristot. Rh. 2.8.4">Arist. <title>Rhet.</title> 2. 8. 4</ref>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ πεπαιδευμένοι</quote> are called <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐλόγιστοι</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘<emph>reflecting</emph>,’ ‘prudent.’ In its passive sense, <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσλόγιστον</quote> would mean that the deed is ‘inexplicable’: cp. Anaximenes <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> <title> Eclog.</title> 2. 8. 17 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ γὰρ δυσλόγιστον τοῦ βίου τοῖς ἀνθρώποις τύχην προσαγορεύομεν</quote>, ‘we give the name of chance to that element in life which men find hard to explain.’ But here the agent's frenzy is more in point than the observer's perplexity.—Some take </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσλόγιστον_40_2"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_40">: ‘for what unintelligible reason?’ But this enfeebles the sense and mars the rhythm. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαρυνθεὶς_41">, incensed, vexed, as <title>O.T.</title> 781: cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρύς</quote> in 1017.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπλων_41">, causal gen.: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 269"> <title>Tr.</title> 269</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν ἔχων χόλον</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Phil. 327"> <title>Ph.</title> 327</ref> n. For the adj. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀχιλλείων_41">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀχιλλέως</quote>, cp. <title>O.T.</title> 267 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ Λαβδακείῳ παιδί</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_δῆτα_42">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, why, in that case, did he attack <emph>cattle</emph>, rather than the men who had awarded the arms?</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπεμπίπτει_42">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 185">cp. 185</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ποίμναις πίτνων</quote>, and 374 f.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τήνδε_βάσιν_42">, a cognate acc. (as if the verb were <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεμβαίνει</quote>): cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 305">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 305</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πήδημα κοῦφον ἐκ νεὼς ἀφήλατο</quote>. ( <ref n="Soph. Trach. 339">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 339</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ με τήνδ’ ἐφίστασαι βάσιν</quote>, is different: see n. there.) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ὑμῖν_43">: so 366 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ἀφόβοις με θηρσὶ δεινὸν χέρας</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1092">cp. 1092</ref>, 1315. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_καὶ_44">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 38">cp. 38</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_Ἀργείοις_44">: <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς</quote> here marks the intention of Ajax (which was frustrated): cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 58"> <title>Ph.</title> 58</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλεῖς δ’ ὡς πρὸς οἶκον</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἂν_ἐξεπράξατ_45">: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ λέγε βούλευμα, φησίν· οὐ γὰρ ἦν βούλευμα ἀλλὰ πρᾶγμα, εἰ κατημέλησα ἐγώ</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 555"> <title>Ph.</title> 555</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐ μόνον βουλεύματα</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἔργα δρώμεν’</quote>. The answer is more forcible than if the poet had written <quote xml:lang="grc">κἂν ἐξέπραξέ <emph>γ’</emph> </quote>: see on <ref n="Soph. Phil. 105"> <title>Ph.</title> 105</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 985"> Ph. 985</ref> , <ref n="Soph. El. 408."> <title>El.</title> 408.</ref>—The midd. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐκπράσσομαι</quote> is rare; in <ref n="Hdt. 7. 158"> Her. 7. 158</ref> it means ‘to avenge’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">φόνον</quote>). Cp. <title> O.T.</title> 287 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπραξάμην</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποίαισι_46"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The datives denote manner (or attendant circumstance), and refer to <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ βούλευμ’...ἦν</quote> in 44. ‘What were these daring schemes, what was this rash confidence, with which he planned the attack?’—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘How could he possibly have conceived such a mad enterprise?’ For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταῖσδε_46"> combined with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποίαισι_46_2">, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1204"> <title>Ph.</title> 1204</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖον ἐρεῖς τόδ’ ἔπος;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νύκτωρ_47"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote>: an answer to the last question:—he relied on darkness, and on craft; and none shared his secret. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_καὶ_48">: 38 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρέστη_48">, came close to us: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 748"> <title>Tr.</title> 748</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ δ’ ἐμπελάζεις τἀνδρὶ καὶ παρίστασαι;</quote> <ref n="Soph. El. 295"> <title>El.</title> 295</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βοᾷ παραστᾶς</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_δὴ_49">, ‘already’: <title>O.C.</title> 31 n.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δισσαῖς_πύλαις_49">, the tentdoors of the two chiefs, Agamemnon and Menelaüs. (Cp. <ref n="Paus. 4. 19. 2">Paus. 4. 19. 2</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν σκηνὴν τὴν στρατηγίδα</quote>.) The phrase is equivalent, of course, to <quote xml:lang="grc">δισσῶν στρατηγῶν πύλαις</quote>. 721 <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατήγιον</quote>, n. But, since there were two tents and two entrances, <quote xml:lang="grc">δισσαῖς</quote> is strictly the epithet of <quote xml:lang="grc">πύλαις</quote>|: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the literal sense is, ‘two doors of chiefs.’ If the two chiefs had shared the same tent, so that only one entrance could be meant by <quote xml:lang="grc">πύλαις</quote>, then, indeed, <quote xml:lang="grc">δισσαῖς</quote> could be explained only as referring to the subst. implied in <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατηγίσιν</quote>,—‘the tent-door of two chiefs,’= <quote xml:lang="grc">δισσοστρατηγίσιν πύλαις</quote>. But such a use of <quote xml:lang="grc">δισσαῖς</quote> seems impossible. Could <quote xml:lang="grc">δισσὰ ἀδελφῶν ἅρματα</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>) mean, ‘a chariot belonging to two brothers’? </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_πῶς_50">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> prefixed to interrogative words, see on <title>O.C.</title> 263.—Join </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπέσχε_50"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φόνου_50">. The word </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαιμῶσαν_50"> is Homeric: <ref n="Hom. Il. 13.77"> <title>Il.</title> 13. 77</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">περὶ δούρατι χεῖρες ἄαπτοι | μαιμῶσιν</quote>. Cp. Lycophron 1171 <quote xml:lang="grc">μαιμῶν κορέσσαι χεῖρα διψῶσαν φόνου</quote>,—a reminiscence, partly of this v., and partly of one of an unknown poet (<quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν τραγικῶν τις</quote>, Athen. 10. p. 433 F), frag. adesp. 96, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴσχειν κελεύω χεῖρα διψῶσαν φόνου</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγώ_51">, an expression of divine majesty and power; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 69">cp. 69</ref>, 85.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσφόρους_51">, hard to bear up against: her hand is heavy upon him. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 643">Cp. 643</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύσφορον ἄταν</quote>: <title>O.T.</title> 87 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ δύσφοῤ</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the woes of Thebes: <ref n="Eur. El. 144"> <title>El.</title> 144</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν δυσφόρων</quote>, miseries. Besides this sense, the only other in which the word occurs is, ‘hard to carry about,’ ‘moving with difficulty,’ as Plat. <title> Tim.</title>p. 74 E <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵνα μὴ δύσφορα τὰ σώματα ἀπεργάζοιντο</quote> (‘unwieldy’). A scholiast wrongly took <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσφόρους</quote> here as=<quote xml:lang="grc">κακῶς φερομένας, παραφόρους</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘led astray,’ ‘misguided.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνώμας_52">, opinions, beliefs,—here, the fancies or illusions of madness. There is a certain irony in the word. Some editors strangely prefer the conjecture </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λήμας_52">,—as if the goddess had afflicted him with sore or weak eyes ( <title>Plut.</title> 581 <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρονικαῖς λήμαις...λημῶντες τὰς φρένας</quote> ).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_χαρᾶς_52"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνώμας_52_2">: his eyes, under Athena's spell, see his human foes in the cattle whom he slays or torments; these fancies are the fancies of (or connected with) his baneful <emph>joy</emph> in his imaginary triumph. For the adj., cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 888"> <title>El.</title> 888</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θάλπει τῷδ’ ἀνηκέστῳ πυρί</quote> (n.).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπείργω_52">, placing a comma after the verb, and another after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαλοῦσα_52">,—a punctuation which is found in the Aldine. But (1) the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">χαρᾶς</quote> is then attenuated to that of ‘<emph>hoped-for</emph> vengeance,’—whereas, as <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀνηκέστου</quote> shows, it clearly denotes the frantic joy which Ajax actually felt; and (2) the order of words is then less natural. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρός_ποίμνας_53">=<quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ποίμνας τε</quote>: for <quote xml:lang="grc">τε</quote> misplaced, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 654">cp. 654</ref>: <title>O.T.</title> 258 n. As distinguished from herds of oxen, <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖμναι</quote> are flocks of sheep and goats; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 63">cp. 63</ref>, 297, 374. But the word <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖμναι</quote> is also used more vaguely to denote both herds and flocks (42, 300): and in 1061 we find even <quote xml:lang="grc">μῆλα καὶ ποίμνας</quote>, ‘sheep and cattle.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύμμικτά_φρουρήματα_53">: confused, unshared, spoil-charges of herdsmen, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘the confused droves, your unshared spoil, guarded by herdsmen.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λείας_53"> is a defining gen., denoting that in which the <quote xml:lang="grc">φρουρήματα</quote> consisted; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βουκόλων_53"> is a possessive gen. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 681"> <title>El.</title> 681</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἑλλάδος | πρόσχημ’ ἀγῶνος</quote>, the pride of Greece (possessive gen.), consisting in a festival (defining gen.): so <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 183"> Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 183</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καρδίας κλυδώνιον | χολῆς</quote> (defining gen.). Others prefer to take <quote xml:lang="grc">λείας</quote> as a partitive gen. (‘forming part of the spoil’),—less fitly, I think. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄδαστα_54">: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.125"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 125</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ τὰ μὲν πολίων ἐξεπράθομεν, τὰ δέδασται</quote>. At v. 26 the word <quote xml:lang="grc">λείας</quote> is used to denote the slaughtered animals generally. Sheep and oxen were alike <quote xml:lang="grc">λεία</quote> in the large sense, as having been taken from the foe, but the <emph> oxen</emph> are more especially so-called, because they were to be shared among individual chiefs or others, while the <emph>flocks</emph> were kept for the public maintenance. With </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄδαστα_54_2"> here, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 146">cp. 146</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λοιπή</quote>, and 175 <quote xml:lang="grc">πανδάμους</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔκειρε_φόνον_55">. <foreign xml:lang="grc">κείρειν φόνον</foreign>=to <emph>cause</emph> bloodshed <emph>by hewing</emph>; as <quote xml:lang="grc">τυφλοῦν ἕλκος</quote>=‘to inflict a blinding wound’ ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 972"> <title>Ant.</title> 972</ref> n.), <quote xml:lang="grc">τρῶσαι φόνον</quote>=‘to deal a deathwound’ ( <title>Suppl.</title> 1205).—Note the <quote xml:lang="grc">παρήχησις</quote> in <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἔκειρε—πολύκερων</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 528">cp. 528</ref>, 1112: <ref n="Soph. OT 370"> <title>O. T.</title> 370</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολύκερων_φόνον_55">, a slaughter of many horned creatures, like <quote xml:lang="grc">χερόπλακτοι...δοῦποι</quote> (631 ff.), <quote xml:lang="grc">αὔχημα εὔιππον</quote>, a glory consisting in good horses ( <ref n="Soph. OC 711"> <title>O. C.</title> 711</ref> n.), <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιμφάρματοι ἅμιλλαι</quote>, contests of swift chariots (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1062 f. n.).— The accent of <quote xml:lang="grc">πολύκερων</quote> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 64">cp. 64</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔκερων</quote>) is acc. to the rule that adjectives in <quote xml:lang="grc">‐ως</quote> follow the Attic 2nd decl. of nouns in <quote xml:lang="grc">‐ως</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">‐ων</quote>, which can be proparoxytone if the <quote xml:lang="grc">ω</quote> in the last syll. is immediately preceded by <quote xml:lang="grc">ε</quote>, or separated from it only by a liquid: thus <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀξιόχρεως, βαθύγεως, ἵλεως, φιλόγελως</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥαχίζων_56">, here in a general sense, ‘hewing down’; properly, to cut through the spine (<quote xml:lang="grc">ῥάχις</quote>), to cleave in twain; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 299">cp. 299</ref>: <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 426">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 426</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπαιον, ἐρράχιζον</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀδόκει_μὲν_56"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: properly, <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀδόκει ἔστι μὲν ὅτε..., ἔστι δὲ ὅτε</quote>: but <quote xml:lang="grc">μὲν</quote> is misplaced (as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 279"> <title>Ph.</title> 279</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρῶντα μὲν ναῦς</quote>, and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1136 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρῶν μὲν ἀπάτας</quote>); and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔστι δὲ</quote> is omitted. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 603"> <title>O. T.</title> 603</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο μέν</quote>, balanced in 605 by <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτ’ ἄλλο</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοιτῶντ_59">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Seven 661"> Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 661</ref>(boasts) <quote xml:lang="grc">φλύοντα σὺν φοίτῳ φρενῶν</quote>. For the plur. <quote xml:lang="grc">νόσοις</quote> <ref n="Soph. Aj. 338">cp. 338</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νοσήμασι</quote> : <ref n="Eur. Orest. 270">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 270</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μανιάσιν λυσσήμασι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὤτρυνον_εἰσέβαλλον_60">. Hermann supported his conjecture, <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἐρινύων ὤτρυνον</quote> (cr. n.), by the remark that the asyndeton in the traditional text implies an agitation of mind unsuitable to the goddess. But it rather expresses the vehemence with which the frenzy sent by her drove Ajax onward. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 288">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 288</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ λύσσα καὶ μάταιος ἐκ νυκτῶν φόβος | κινεῖ, ταράσσει</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_κακά_60">. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1611">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1611</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς Δίκης ἐν ἕρκεσιν</quote>. Here it is the epithet <quote xml:lang="grc">κακά</quote> which marks the figurative sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕρκη</quote>: as dirges are <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕμνοι ἄλυροι</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. Alc. 447">Eur. <title>Alc.</title> 447</ref>), and the eagle of Zeus is <quote xml:lang="grc">πτηνὸς κύων</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. PB 1022">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 1022</ref>). For the similar use of other words denoting nets or toils, see on <ref n="Eur. El. 1476"> <title>El.</title> 1476</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρκυστάτοις</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἄπειτ_ἐπειδὴ_61">: this harsh combination of sounds (as we should think it) is not rare; thus <ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 1100">Ar. <title>Eccl.</title> 1100</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἄπειτ’ ἐπειδὰν τῆσδ’ ἀπαλλαγῶ</quote>: <title>Vesp.</title> 1322 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπειτ’ ἐπειδὴ )μέθυεν</quote>: <title>Plut.</title> 695 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπειτ’ ἐπειδὴ μεστὸς ἦν</quote>: [Dem. ] or. 59 § 89 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπειτ’ ἐπειδὰν πεισθῇ</quote>. Similarly <ref n="Eur. Orest. 238">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 238</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως ἐῶσί σ’</quote>: <title>Helen.</title> 1292 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢν γυνὴ γένῃ</quote>: <title>I. T.</title> 1339 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦμεν ἥμενοι</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλώφησεν_61"> implies only respite or alleviation, not cure: cp. <ref n="Thuc. 6. 12">Thuc. 6. 12</ref>§ 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπὸ νόσου μεγάλης καὶ πολέμου βραχύ τι λελωφήκαμεν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 554">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 554</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πόνου_61">: the simple gen. is usual with <quote xml:lang="grc">λωφᾶν</quote>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedrus 251c"> <title>Phaedr.</title> 251 C</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λωφᾷ..τῆς ὀδύνης</quote> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὖ_62">, ‘in their turn’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1088">cp. 1088</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 601."> <title>Ant.</title> 601.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρας_64">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνθρώπους</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Aj. 243">cp. 243</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δαίμων | κοὐδεὶς ἀνδρῶν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔκερων_64">, since the oxen were his most conspicuous prizes: there is a bitter irony in the epithet. For the accent, <ref target="cl55">see on 55</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_σοὶ_66">, to thee <emph>also</emph> (as I myself have seen it): cp. <ref n="Plat. Phaedo 64c">Plat. <title>Phaed.</title> 64 C</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐὰν ἄρα καὶ σοὶ ξυνδοκῇ ἅπερ καὶ ἐμοί</quote>. Seyffert writes <quote xml:lang="grc">καί σοι</quote> (as if the sense were, ‘I will <emph>further</emph> show thee’): but this is plainly wrong.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δείξω_περιφανῆ_66">, ‘will show thee <emph> openly</emph>’ (instead of allowing it to remain hidden in the tent): cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1366"> <title>El.</title> 1366</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἳ ταῦτά σοι δείξουσιν, Ἠλέκτρα, σαφῆ</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 81">Cp. 81</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">περιφανῶς..ἰδεῖν</quote>.—We might, indeed, take <quote xml:lang="grc">περιφανῆ</quote> as a mere epithet, ‘this signal, notable, frenzy’; but in the actual context the other view is preferable.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θροῇς_66">, ‘proclaim’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 785">cp. 785</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OC 597"> <title>O. C.</title> 597</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶς τοῦτό γ’ Ἑλλήνων θροεῖ</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδὲ_ἄνδρα_68">, lit., ‘do not receive (or take) the man as a calamity,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, ‘do not apprehend harm from his coming.’ There is a light touch of half-playful irony in the words with which the goddess reassures her favourite. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 138">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 138</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἐμοὶ | τόνδ’ ἐξεγεῖραι ξυμφορὰ γενήσεται</quote>. <ref n="Hdt. 6. 61">Hdt. 6. 61</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς γονέας συμφορὴν τὸ εἶδος αὐτῆς ποιευμένους</quote>. Similarly <ref n="Hom. Il. 21.39"> <title>Il.</title> 21. 39</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ δ’ ἄρ’ ἀνώϊστον κακὸν ἤλυθε δῖος Ἀχιλλεύς</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 379"> <title>O. T.</title> 379</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρέων δέ σοι πῆμ’ οὐδέν</quote>. —Whitelaw (<title>Translation</title>, p. 440) takes the constr. to be, <quote xml:lang="grc">μίμνε</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲ συμφορὰν δέχου</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἄνδρα</quote>,—‘Bravely await, expecting no mischance, | His coming,’— <quote xml:lang="grc">διὰ μέσου</quote> construction ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1279"> <title>Ant.</title> 1279</ref> f., n.). A difficulty in this view is that </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέχου_68"> must then have definitely the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">προσδέχου</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποστρόφους_68">, proleptic: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 791"> <title>Ant.</title> 791</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ καὶ δικαίων ἀδίκους φρένας παρασπᾷς</quote>. Here the adj. is equiv. to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποστρέψασα</quote>,— ‘I will avert, and (thereby) hinder.’— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπείρξω_εἰιδεῖν_68">, without <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote>: as <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴργω</quote> takes the simple inf. in <ref n="Soph. OT 129"> <title>O. T.</title> 129</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1407"> <title>Ph.</title> 1407</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1257."> <title>Tr.</title> 1257.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗτος_71">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 89">cp. 89</ref>, 1047: <ref n="Soph. OC 1627"> <title>O. C.</title> 1627</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ οὗτος οὗτος Οἰδίπους, τί μέλλομεν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὲ_τὸν_71"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: in a peremptory call of this kind, the acc. regularly stands first; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1228">cp. 1228</ref>, and see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 441"> <title>Ant.</title> 441</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὲ δή, σὲ τὴν νεύουσαν κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰχμαλωτίδας_71">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰχμαλώτων</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 222"> Eur. <title>Or.</title> 222</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀδελφῇ χειρί</quote> (a sister's hand); <title>I. A.</title> 1306 <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐναῖς βασιλίσι</quote> (the bed of a king).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπευθύνοντα_71">, lit. ‘straightening out,’ here, binding behind the back: <ref n="Soph. OT 1154"> <title>O. T.</title> 1154</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ὡς τάχος τις τοῦδ’ ἀποστρέψει χέρας</quote>; <ref n="Hom. Od. 22.189"> <title>Od.</title> 22. 189</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν δὲ πόδας χεῖράς τε δέον θυμαλγέϊ δεσμῷ | εὖ μάλ’ ἀποστρέψαντε διαμπερές</quote>. So Achilles deals with his captives, <ref n="Hom. Il. 21.30"> <title>Il.</title> 21. 30</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆσε δ’ ὀπίσσω χεῖρας ἐϋτμήτοισιν ἱμᾶσιν</quote>. <ref n="Hom. Od. 3.5">Hom. <title> Od.</title> 3. 5. 22</ref> <quote xml:lang="lat">retorta tergo bracchia libero.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_δρᾷς_74">..; Odysseus is brave, but reasonably reluctant to face a raging maniac who hates him (1336).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδαμῶς_κάλει_74">. The omission of <quote xml:lang="grc">σφ’</quote> (cr. n.) seems undesirable here; though it could be defended (see <ref n="Soph. Phil. 801"> <title>Ph.</title> 801</ref> n.). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 496">Cp. 496</ref> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἀρεῖ_75">; lit., ‘Wilt thou not be patient in silence, and forbear to win the name of coward?’ Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1183"> <title>Tr.</title> 1183</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ θᾶσσον οἴσεις μηδ’ ἀπιστήσεις ἐμοί;</quote> ‘Give me thy hand at once —disobey me not!’ <ref n="Soph. OT 637"> <title>O. T.</title> 637</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εἶ σύ τ’ οἴκους σύ τε, Κρέον, κατὰ στέγας</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ τὸ μηδὲν ἄλγος εἰς μέγ’ οἴσετε;</quote> ‘Come, go thou into the house...and forbear to make much of a petty grief.’ See Appendix.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σῖγ_ἀνέξει_75">: cp. fr. 618 <quote xml:lang="grc">σύγγνωτε κἀνάσχεσθε σιγῶσαι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δειλίαν_ἀρεῖ_75">, ‘win,’ ‘acquire,’ the reputation of cowardice: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 924"> <title>Ant.</title> 924</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν δυσσέβειαν εὐσεβοῦσ’ ἐκτησάμην</quote> (n.): <title>I. T.</title> 676 <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ δειλίαν γὰρ καὶ κάκην κεκτήσομαι</quote>. The fut. midd. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀροῦμαι</quote> occurs in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 460"> <title>O. C.</title> 460</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σωτῆρ’ ἀρεῖσθε</quote> </cit>, and <ref n="Pind. P. 1">Pind. <title>P.</title> 1. 75</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρέομαι.. μισθόν</quote>. The fut. act. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρεῖς_75"> has better MS. authority here; but is (I am now convinced) wrong. It could mean only, ‘<emph>raise</emph> thy cowardice,’ in the sense, ‘allow thy coward fears to rise,’—a very forced one. Further, there is no other example of a fut. act. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρῶ</quote> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="α_75">. See note in Appendix on the Future and Aorist forms from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀείρω, αἴρω, ἄρνυμαι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔνδον_μένων_76">: for the personal constr. (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρκείτω αὐτὸν ἔνδον μένειν</quote> ), <ref n="Soph. Aj. 635">cp. 635</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 547"> <title>Ant.</title> 547</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρκέσω θνῄσκους ἐγώ</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 1061"> <title>O. T.</title> 1061</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅλις νοσοῦσ’ ἐγώ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_γένηται_77">; ‘lest <emph>what</emph> happen?’ So <title>Suppl.</title> 543 <quote xml:lang="grc">νεκροὺς δὲ ταρβεῖτ’ εἰ κρυβήσονται χθονί; | τί μὴ γένηται; μὴ κατασκάψωσι γῆν | ταφέντες ὑμῶν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνὴρ_77">, emphatic, a <emph>man</emph> indeed; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1238">cp. 1238</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἆρ’ Ἀχαιοῖς ἄνδρες εἰσὶ πλὴν ὅδε;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐχθρός_γε_78">. Odysseus refrains from replying that Ajax was then sane, but now is frenzied. ‘Yes,’ he answers, ‘my foeman,—as he is still.’ That enmity, he means, will <emph>now</emph> be more dangerous than ever. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔκουν_ἥδιστος_79">..; The goddess suggests the vulgar sentiment of mankind, not as approving it, but, as it were, to test the disposition of Odysseus; who passes it by in silence, and afterwards repudiates it by his action. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμοὶ_μὲν_80">: the particle merely throws a slight stress on the pronoun: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 11"> <title>Ant.</title> 11</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονοῦντα_γὰρ_82">: ‘yes, for...’: the <quote xml:lang="grc">γὰρ</quote> of assent, <ref n="Soph. OT 1117"> <title>O. T.</title> 1117</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξέστην_82"> with acc., as meaning ‘avoid’: <ref n="Dem. 20.10">Dem. or. 20 § 10</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδένα πώποτε κίνδυνον ἐξέστησαν</quote> (a phrase which occurs also in or. 23 § 76): Plat. <title>Phileb.</title>p. 43 A <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ γὰρ ὑπεκστῆναι τὸν λόγον ἐπιφερόμενον τοῦτον</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">βούλομαι</quote> (‘to elude the brunt of this argument’). Cp. <ref n="Thuc. 2. 88">Thuc. 2. 88</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδένα ὄχλον...ὑποχωρεῖν</quote> (‘to face any numbers’). But <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξίστασθαι</quote> takes a <emph> dat.</emph> when it means to ‘make place for’ (672), or ‘give way to’ ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1053">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 1053</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲ_νῦν_83"> refers to <quote xml:lang="grc"> οὐκ</quote> in 82: ‘even as it is (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> though he is insane) thou hast no reason to fear him, since he will not see thee.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀφθαλμοῖς_αὐτοῖς_84">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, with eyesight as good as ever. Odysseus forgets, or ignores, the promise of Athena that she would <emph> avert</emph> from him the eyes of Ajax (69 f.). She now renews the assurance in a stronger form. Ajax shall, in respect to him, be <emph> blind.</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεδορκότα_85"> properly implies <emph>keen</emph> , <emph>bright</emph> vision: <title>Suppl.</title> 409 <quote xml:lang="grc">δεδορκὸς ὄμμα</quote> (with Tucker's note). Chrysippus <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Gellius 14. 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔντονον καὶ δεδορκὸς βλέπουσα</quote> (said of Justice), which Gellius renders, <foreign xml:lang="lat">luminibus oculorum acribus.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γένοιτο_86"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote>: cp. <ref n="Hdt. 5. 9"> Her. 5. 9</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γένοιτο δ’ ἂν πᾶν ἐν τῷ μακρῷ χρόνῳ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέντἂν_86">, a crasis frequent in Attic prose ( <ref n="Dem. 1.26">Dem. or. 1 § 26</ref>, Plat. <title>Rep.</title>p. 375 D, etc.). Here <quote xml:lang="grc">μέντοι</quote> expresses reflective assent (‘well, certainly’), as so often in Plato (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, Plat. <title>Soph.</title>p. 245 B <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀληθέστατα μέντοι λέγεις</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοῦ_86">, not <quote xml:lang="grc">θεᾶς</quote>,—the generalising masc.: <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 297">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 297</ref>(ref. to Athena), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλθοι· κλύει δὲ καὶ πρόσωθεν ὢι θεός</quote>. So <ref n="Soph. Ant. 463">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 463</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις</quote>), <ref n="Soph. Trach. 151">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 151</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">αὑτοῦ</quote>), <ref n="Soph. El. 145">Soph. <title> El.</title> 145</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς</quote>), <ref n="Soph. El. 771">Soph. El. 771</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc"> πάσχοντι</quote>), <ref n="Soph. El. 1026">Soph. El. 1026</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγχειροῦντα</quote>), <ref n="Soph. El. 1105">Soph. El. 1105</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἄγχιστον</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μένοιμ_ἄν_88">. Among its many shades of meaning, the opt. with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote> sometimes expresses; as here, what the speaker feels that he <emph>must</emph> do; cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1108"> <title>Ant.</title> 1108</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧδ’ ὡς ἔχω στείχοιμ’ ἄν</quote> (n.). See below, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 186."> Ant. 186.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤθελον_ἂν_88">, as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1278"> <title>Ph.</title> 1278</ref>, and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1239 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἂν..ἐβουλόμην</quote>: so <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠθέλησα</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote> , <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 427, <ref n="Soph. OT 1348"> <title>O. T.</title> 1348</ref>, and <quote xml:lang="grc">εἱλόμη<*> ἄν</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 734."> <title>Tr.</title> 734.</ref>For <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤθελον</quote> without <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote>, see 1400.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτὸς_τυχεῖν_88">, to be clear of the peril: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 504"> <title>Ph.</title> 504</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτὸς ὄντα πημάτων</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1260 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴσως ἂν ἐκτὸς κλαυμάτων ἔχοις πόδα</quote>: fr. 657. 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτός εἰσι τῶν κακῶν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗτος_89">: 71.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Αἴας_89">. When a proper name of the 3rd declension comes from a stem ending in <quote xml:lang="grc">αντ</quote> (as <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἰαντ</quote>), the Attic vocative ends in <quote xml:lang="grc">α—ς</quote>: so <quote xml:lang="grc">Θόας, ἄκουσον</quote> , <title>I. T.</title> 1436. The Homeric vocative of <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴας</quote> is always <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἶαν</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">α^</quote>) —formed on the analogy of the voc from stems in <quote xml:lang="grc">οντ</quote>, as <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρέον</quote> (stem <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρεοντ</quote>). The vocatives <quote xml:lang="grc">Πουλυδάμα</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 12.231"> <title>Il.</title> 12. 231</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">Λαοδάμα</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 8.141"> <title>Od.</title> 8. 141</ref>) are exceptions, due perhaps to a sense that here the ending <quote xml:lang="grc">‐αν</quote> might suggest an accusative.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_συμμάχου_89">: there is a terrible irony in this, since he had angered her by rejecting her aid in battle (774).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Διογενὲς_τέκνον_91">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Seven 127">Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 127</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ Διογενὲς φιλόμαχον κράτος</quote> (Athena): <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 350">Eur. <title>Cycl.</title> 350</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ Παλλάς, ὦ δέσποινα, Διογενὲς θεά</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Ion 465">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 465</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παῖς ἁ Λατογενής</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρέστης_92">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 117">cp. 117</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στέψω_92">, ‘crown,’ in the fig. sense of ‘honouring with gifts’: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 457"> <title>El.</title> 457</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως τὸ λοιπὸν αὐτὸν ἀφνεωτέραις | χερσὶ στέφωμεν ἢ τανῦν δωρούμεθα</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 431"> <title>Ant.</title> 431</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χοαῖσι..τὸν νέκυν στέφει</quote>. (In later Greek, <quote xml:lang="grc">στεφανοῦν</quote> is said of any <foreign xml:lang="lat">honorarium</foreign>; as <ref n="Plut. Tim. 16">Plut. <title>Timol.</title> 16</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν..ἄνθρωπον ἐστεφάνωσαν.. δέκα μναῖς</quote>.) Here, the word may refer more esp. to <emph>hanging up</emph> trophies in Athena's temple (Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 278 <quote xml:lang="grc">λάφυρα δᾴων δουρίπηχθ’ ἁγνοῖς δόμοις | στέψω</quote>,— where, however, the text is doubtful: cp. <title>Agam.</title> 577 ff.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαφύροις_92"> (rt. <quote xml:lang="grc">λαβ</quote>), spoils <emph>taken</emph> from the enemy, a poetical word, used by Xenophon. The epithet </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παγχρύσοις_92"> suggests votive gifts (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναθήματα</quote>) of golden vessels. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκεῖνο_94"> marks (better than <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο</quote> would have done) the somewhat abrupt change of subject. Athena treats Ajax as one whose thoughts can be turned at pleasure in any new direction.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔγχος_94">, ‘sword’; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 287">cp. 287</ref>, 658, 907, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1236"> <title>Ant.</title> 1236</ref>; synonymous with <quote xml:lang="grc">ξίφος</quote> (10, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 231"> Ant. 231</ref> , <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1034"> Ant. 1034</ref>), and <quote xml:lang="grc">φάσγανον</quote> (834, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 899"> Ant. 899</ref>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὖ_94">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 18">cp. 18</ref>.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_στρατῷ_94">, ‘<emph>on</emph>’ them,—denoting an encounter at close quarters; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 97">cp. 97</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_μή_96">, where (after the negative) <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ μὴ οὐ</quote> would be normal; so <ref n="Soph. OT 1387"> <title>O. T.</title> 1387</ref> f., <ref n="Soph. Ant. 443"> <title>Ant.</title> 443</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 348"> <title>Ph.</title> 348</ref> f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾔχμασας_χέρα_97">; The exact sense seems to be, ‘hast thou <emph>used</emph> an <emph>armed</emph> hand upon them?’ The acc. <quote xml:lang="grc">χέρα</quote> is analogous, though not precisely similar, to the cognate accusative in <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰχμάσαι τάδε</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Trach. 355"> <title>Tr.</title> 355</ref>, ‘to do those deeds of arms’), and <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰχμὰς αἰχμάσσουσι</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 4.324"> <title>Il.</title> 4. 324</ref>), ‘they will wield spears.’ The fact that </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_97"> stands with dat., and not with acc., shows that the phrase cannot mean, ‘hast thou <emph>armed</emph> thy hand <emph>against</emph> them?’ —Musgrave's </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾕμαξας_97">, though specious, is coarser; there is a keen edge in the reference of <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾔχμασας</quote> to the prowess of a warrior. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥστ_98"> (‘so that’) is far better here than <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς</quote> (‘know that..’, 39); and is the more forcible because <quote xml:lang="grc">γε</quote> is absent (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 45">cp. 45</ref> n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Αἴαντ_98"> (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐμέ</quote>) adds a certain majesty to the vaunt; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 864">cp. 864</ref>: as when Achilles says ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.240"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 240</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἧ ποτ’ Ἀχιλλῆος ποθὴ ἵξεται υἷας Ἀχαιῶν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_σὸν_99">, ‘thy saying’; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1401">cp. 1401</ref>: but in 1313, ‘thy interest.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανόντες_ἀφαιρείσθων_100">. The grim irony is like that of <ref n="Soph. OT 1273"> <title>O. T.</title> 1273</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν σκότῳ</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀψοίαθ’</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OC 1377"> <title>O. C.</title> 1377</ref>(they are to <emph>die</emph>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵν’ ἀξιῶτον τοὺς φυτεύσαντας σέβειν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 310"> <title>Ant.</title> 310</ref>(after a like threat) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵν’ εἰδότες τὸ κέρδος ἔνθεν οἰστέον | τὸ λοιπὸν ἁρπάζητε</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1110"> <title>Tr.</title> 1110</ref>(Deianeira shall perish) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵν’ ἐκδιδαχθῇ πᾶσιν ἀγγέλλειν κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἄμ_100">, emphatic: the arms which, when Achilles was dead, belonged by right to Ajax. Schol.: <quote xml:lang="grc">καλῶς τὰ ἐμὰ ἔφη, οὐχ ἃ δεῖ με λαβεῖν, ὡς ἰδίων ἀπεστερημένος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶεν_101"> (‘so far so good’) marks that the speaker is about to pass to a new point; <ref n="Soph. OC 1308"> <title>O. C.</title> 1308</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 534"> <title>El.</title> 534</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1308."> <title>Ph.</title> 1308.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_δὴ_101">: here <quote xml:lang="grc">γάρ</quote> (‘now’) merely prefaces the question; <quote xml:lang="grc">δή</quote>=‘then,’ ‘in the next place.’ Cp. <title>I. T.</title> 576 <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δ’ ἡμεῖς οἵ τ ἐμοὶ γεννήτορες; | ἆρ’ εἰσίν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῦ_ἕστηκεν_101">; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 314">Cp. 314</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OT 1442"> <title>O. T.</title> 1442</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵν’ ἕσταμεν | χρείας</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 375"> <title>Tr.</title> 375</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ ποτ’ εἰμὶ πράγματος;</quote> <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1145 <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυμφορᾶς ἵν’ ἕσταμεν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοι_101">, ethic dat.: <ref n="Soph. OC 81"> <title>O. C.</title> 81</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ βέβηκεν ἡμὶν ὁ ξένος;</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘Do we find ourselves alone?’) For the double question, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 983">cp. 983</ref> f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὐπίτριπτον_103">, ‘accursed’; cp. the imprecation, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιτριβείης</quote> ( <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 1530">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 1530</ref>, <title> Thesm.</title> 557). Others explain it, from the sense ‘rubbed down,’ as ‘practised in trickery,’ ‘knavish’ (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">περίτριμμα, ἄλημα</quote>, etc.). <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Pl. 275">Ar. <title>Plut.</title> 275</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς σεμνὸς οὑπίτριπτος</quote> </cit>: Andoc. or. 1 § 99 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ συκοφάντα καὶ ἐπίτριπτον κίναδος</quote>. <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 430">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 430</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πυκνότατον κίναδος</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">σόφισμα, κύρμα, τρίμμα, παιπάλημ’ ὅλον</quote>. Here </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κίναδος_103"> is acc.: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 118">cp. 118</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 444"> <title>Ph.</title> 444</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξήρου_ὅπου_103">, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐστί</quote>: a frequent ellipse after <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπου</quote> (890, <ref n="Soph. OT 926"> <title>O. T.</title> 926</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 318"> <title>Ant.</title> 318</ref>). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 33">Cp. 33</ref> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔγωγ_104">. In favour of omitting the colon after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔγωγ’</quote>, it has been urged that, if it remains, the goddess seems to accept the description just given of her favourite; and that it would better become her to reply merely, ‘I mean Odysseus, thy foe.’ But she is displaying the insanity of Ajax, and has already received his fierce vaunts with the irony of seeming approval.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ὀδυσσέα_104">, with synizesis: cp. <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 913">Eur. <title>Phoen.</title> 913</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σφάξαι Μενοικέα τόνδε</quote>: [Eur. ] <title>Rhes.</title> 977 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπειτ’ Ἀχιλλέα Θέτιδος κ.τ.λ.</quote> But synizesis is not applied by Sophocles to <quote xml:lang="grc">Ὀδυσσέα</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1220"> <title>Ph.</title> 1220</ref>, to <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀχιλλέα</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 331"> <title>Ph.</title> 331</ref> and 358, or to <quote xml:lang="grc"> Θησέα</quote> in <ref n="Soph. OC 1055"> <title>O. C.</title> 1055</ref> and 1630. Here Nauck writes <quote xml:lang="grc">Ὀδυσσῆ</quote>, a form found in <title>Rhes.</title> 708; cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 439">Eur. <title>El.</title> 439</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀχιλῆ</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνστάτην_104">, ‘adversary’: a word not extant elsewhere. It comes from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνίστασθαι</quote> as=‘<emph>to stand in the way</emph>’ of a person or thing, ‘oppose,’ ‘resist.’ For the literal sense, see <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 3.8">Lysias or. 3 § 8</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐθύς με τύπτειν ἐπεχείρησεν· ἐπειδὴ δὲ αὐτὸν ἠμυνάμην ἐνστάς</quote> </cit> (‘when <gloss>I stood up to him</gloss> and repelled him’), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔβαλλέ με λίθοις</quote>: for the fig. sense, <ref n="Thuc. 8. 69">Thuc. 8. 69</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤν τις ἐνιστῆται τοῖς ποιουμένοις</quote>. Hence in logic, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνστασις</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">instantia</foreign>, ‘objection’ (cp. <ref n="Isoc. 5.39">Isocr. or. 5 § 39</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνστῆναι τοῖς εἰρημένοις</quote>). In <title>Etym. M.</title> p. 625. 25 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνστάτης</quote> (quoted from this passage) is loosely explained as=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντιστάτης</quote>. </gloss>

data.quote:
εὐθύς με τύπτειν ἐπεχείρησεν· ἐπειδὴ δὲ αὐτὸν
							ἠμυνάμην ἐνστάς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥδιστος_105">, most welcome; cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 929"> <title>El.</title> 929</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κατ’ οἶκον, ἡδὺς οὐδὲ μητρὶ δυσχερής</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κίον_στέγης_108">, lit., ‘a pillar of the domestic roof.’ As <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεὺς ἑρκεῖος</quote> is the god of the household ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 487"> <title>Ant.</title> 487</ref> n.), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑρκεῖος στέγη</quote> is a poetical phrase for the house.
