In such a phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">στέγη</quote> could mean either (<emph>a</emph>) ‘<emph> roof</emph>,’ or (<emph>b</emph>) generally, ‘<emph>building.</emph>’ Here, it probably means ‘roof’; as is suggested by the fact that, in Homer, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕρκος</quote> sometimes denotes the enclosure of the <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐλή</quote>, open to the sky ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 22.442"> <title>Od.</title> 22. 442</ref>, etc.): in using <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑρκεῖος</quote>, then, as=‘domestic,’ the poet may have felt that <quote xml:lang="grc">στέγη</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">tectum</foreign>, would make the sense clearer. This is also suggested by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κίον_108">: see <ref n="Eur. Her. 1006">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 1006</ref>, where the roof of the house falls in, breaking one of the <quote xml:lang="grc"> κίονες</quote> (called also <quote xml:lang="grc">λάϊνοι ὀρθοστάται</quote> , <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 979 f.) which supported it:—<quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς κίονα | νῶτον πατάξας, ὃς πεσήμασι στέγης | διχορραγὴς ἔκειτο κρηπίδων ἔπι</quote>. Cp. also <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 897">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 897</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑψηλῆς στέγης | στῦλον ποδήρη</quote> (‘of a lofty roof | A strong-based pillar’; Kennedy).—I now prefer this view to that which takes <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑρκεῖος στέγη</quote> as=‘the <emph> building</emph> of an <emph>enclosure</emph>’; <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign> an <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐλή</quote>, open to the sky, within the house;—the <quote xml:lang="grc">κίων</quote> being then one of the columns of a peristyle surrounding this court, as in the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρωνῖτις</quote> of an ordinary Greek dwelling.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεθεὶς_κίον_108">: the regular preparation for a flogging: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aeschin. 1.59">Aeschin. or. 1 § 59</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δήσαντες πρὸς τὸν κίονα αὐτὸν...ἐμαστίγουν</quote> </cit> . <ref>Lysias fr. 52 § 4</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάλιν πρὸς τὸν κίονα αὐτὸν μαστιγοῦν δήσαντας</quote>. Hypereides <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Pollux 3. 80. So <cit> <bibl n="Pl. Bac. 4.7">Plaut. <title>Bacch.</title> 4. 7. 24</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">abducite hunc intro atque astringite ad columnam fortiter.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
abducite hunc intro atque astringite ad
							columnam fortiter.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_κίονι_108">, was thus the usual phrase; but Artemidorus (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 160 A.D. ) <title> Oneirocr.</title> 1. 78 has <quote xml:lang="grc">προσδεθεὶς κίονι ἔλαβε πληγὰς πολλάς</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 240">Cp. 240</ref>.—<quote xml:lang="grc">κίων</quote> is masc. in Herodotus Attic. uses it in both genders (fem. 1. 92, masc. 4. 184). With Pindar it is always fem.; and usually so in the <title>Odyssey</title>, but not always; in <ref n="Hom. Od. 8.66"> <title>Od.</title> 8. 66</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς κίονα μακρὸν ἐρείσας</quote>, the masc. has a metrical motive, but not in 19. 38, <quote xml:lang="grc">κίονες ὑψόσ’ ἔχοντες</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐργάσει_109">. In v. 107 she continued his sentence; here, feigning keener alarm, she interrupts it.—Nauck reads </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐργάσῃ_109"> (aor.), depending on <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὶν ἄν</quote>: which not only is weaker, but requires <quote xml:lang="grc">δήσας</quote> instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">δεθεὶς</quote> in 108. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὶν_θάνῃ_110">. After <quote xml:lang="grc">θανεῖν γὰρ αὐτὸν οὔ τί πω θέλω</quote> (106), we should have had <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὶν ἂν φοινιχθῇ</quote>. But the emphasis on <quote xml:lang="grc">μάστιγι πρῶτον νῶτα φοινιχθεὶς</quote> serves to excuse the presence of <quote xml:lang="grc">θάνῃ</quote>,—added, for the sake of greater clearness, after the long interval. So in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1130"> <title>Tr.</title> 1130</ref>Hyllus says of Deianeira, <quote xml:lang="grc">τέθνηκεν</quote>, and then in 1133 Heracles, <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴμοι· πρὶν ὡς χρῆν σφ’ ἐξ ἐμῆς θανεῖν χερός;</quote> where the stress on <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἐμῆς</quote> similarly palliates the illogical form of the sentence.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοινιχθεὶς_110">: <ref n="Eur. Hec. 153">Eur. <title> Hec.</title> 153</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοινισσομένην αἵματι</quote> . <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 320">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 320</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καταξαίνειν τὸν ἄνδρα τοῦτον εἰς φοινικίδα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰκίσῃ_111">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1153"> <title>O. T.</title> 1153</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ δῆτα, πρὸς θεῶν, τὸν γέροντά μ’ αἰκίσῃ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χαίρειν_ἐφίεμαι_112">. It seems best to suppose that the constr. is <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφίεμαι χαίρειν δε</quote>, ‘It is my injunction that thou have thy will in all else.’ Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1054"> <title>O. T.</title> 1054</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅντιν’ ἀρτίως | μολεῖν ἐφιέμεσθα</quote>: where the acc. similarly belongs to the inf. There is no example of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφίεμαί τινα</quote> (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τινι</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ποιεῖν τι</quote>: though we find in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1221"> <title>Tr.</title> 1221</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοσοῦτον δή σ’ ἐπισκήπτω</quote>, like <quote xml:lang="grc">κελεύω τινά τι</quote>. Nor does the sense here require that <quote xml:lang="grc">σε</quote> should be the object of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφίεμαι</quote>.—Remark the objection to rendering <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφίεμαι</quote> here ‘I <emph> desire</emph>’: when the verb has that sense, with an inf., its subject is the same as that of the inf.: <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1315"> <title>Phil.</title> 1315</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν δέ σου τυχεῖν ἐφίεμαι</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκουσον</quote>. Further, the sense, ‘enjoin,’ ‘command,’ better suits the insane <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕβρις</quote> of Ajax.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χαίρειν_τἄλλα_112">, to have her pleasure, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, to have her commands obeyed, in all other things: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφίεμαί σε εἰς τὰ ἄλλα κελεύειν μοι καὶ χαίρειν ὡς πειθομένου μου</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺ_οὖν_114">: for this use of <quote xml:lang="grc">οὖν</quote> with pron. and imperat., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 961">cp. 961</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OT 669"> <title>O. T.</title> 669</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δ’ οὖν ἴτω</quote> : <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 185">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 185</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δ’ ἐδίωκον κἀβόων</quote>. | <quote xml:lang="grc">ΔΙ. οἱ δ’ οὖν βοώντων.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέρψις_δρᾶν_114">: the inf. (with art. added, as oft., <ref n="Soph. OC 47"> <title>O. C.</title> 47</ref> n.) is in apposition with <quote xml:lang="grc">τέρψις ἥδε</quote>: ‘since this is thy pleasure,—even to do (thus).’ Instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τέρψις σοι τὸ δρᾶν τόδε</quote>, the defining pron. has been assimilated to <quote xml:lang="grc">τέρψις</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 483"> <title>Tr.</title> 483</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥμαρτον, εἴ τι τήνδ’</quote> (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τόδ’</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁμαρτίαν λέγεις</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρῶ_φείδου_114"> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: the asyndeton adds vigour to the command: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 811">cp. 811</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χωρῶμεν, ἐγκονῶμεν</quote>: 844 <quote xml:lang="grc">γεύεσθε, μὴ φείδεσθε</quote>: 988 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴθ’, ἐγκόνει, σύγκαμνε</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Hec. 1044">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 1044</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄρασσε, φείδου μηδέν.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδὲν_114">, adv.: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_114"> =<quote xml:lang="grc">τούτων ἅ</quote>: so <ref n="Eur. Med. 400">Eur. <title> Med.</title> 400</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φείδου μηδὲν ὧν ἐπίστασαι</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτο_ἐφίεμαι_116">. The emphasis on <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο</quote> warrants the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote>, which often, indeed, comes third in a sentence, or even later; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 169">cp. 169</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OT 485"> <title>O. T.</title> 485</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅ τι λέξω δ’ ἀπορῶ</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. PB 399">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 399</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δακρυσίστακτον ἀπ’ ὄσσων ῥαδινῶν δ’ εἰβομένα ῥέος</quote>: Eur. fr. 776 <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινόν γε, τοῖς πλουτοῦσι τοῦτο δ’ ἔμφυτον</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁρᾷς_118">..</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὴν_ἰσχὺνὅση_118">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 103">cp. 103</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὴν_ἰσχὺν_118">: for the absence of a second art., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 664">cp. 664</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ βροτῶν παροιμία</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 10"> <title>Ant.</title> 10</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐχθρῶν κακά</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_ηὑρέθη_119">, ‘who could have been found?’ the potential aor. indic. with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 502"> <title>Ant.</title> 502</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόθεν κλέος γ’ ἂν εὐκλεέστερον | κατέσχον</quote>...; <ref n="Dem. 37.57">Dem. or. 37 § 57</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς ἂν..ἐγώ τί σε ἠδίκησα;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προνούστερος_119">. The Homeric Ajax, though not subtle in thought or speech, has robust good sense: as Hector says ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.288"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 288</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἶαν, ἐπεί τοι δῶκε θεὸς μέγεθός τε βίην τε | καὶ πινυτήν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρᾶν_καίρια_119">: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Shak. AWW 1.2.26">Shakesp. <title>All's Well</title> 1. 2. 26</bibl> <quote xml:lang="eng">He did look far | Into the service of the time, and was | Discipled of the bravest.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
He did look far | Into the service of the
							time, and was | Discipled of the bravest.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγὼ_μὲν_121">: <quote xml:lang="grc">μὲν</quote> merely emphasizes the pron.: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 455">cp. 455</ref>, <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 1. 4. 12">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 1. 4. 12</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ μὲν οὐκ οἶδα. <emph>ἔμπας</emph> </quote>, followed by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καίπερ_121"> and a participle; <ref n="Hom. Il. 24.523"> <title>Il.</title> 24. 523</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλγεα δ’ ἔμπης | ἐν θυμῷ κατακεῖσθαι ἐάσομεν, ἀχνύμενοί περ</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 563">Cp. 563</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄτῃ_συγκατέζευκται_123">: the more ordinary word would have been <quote xml:lang="grc">συνέζευκται</quote>, but metre has prompted the double compound, which recurs only in later Greek. The <quote xml:lang="grc">κατά</quote> adds the idea of a constraining force: cp. Plutarch <title>Camill.</title> 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς ἀγάμους λόγοις τε πείθοντα καὶ ζημίαις ἀπειλοῦντα συγκαταζεῦξαι</quote> (<emph>constrain into</emph> marriage with) <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῖς χηρευούσαις γυναιξί</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 1389">Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 1389</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἵᾳ ξυμφορᾷ συνεζύγης</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Andr. 98">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 98</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">στερρόν τε τὸν ἐμὸν δαίμον’ ᾧ συνεζύγην</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲν_τούτου_124"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> The <quote xml:lang="grc">σωφροσύνη</quote> of Odysseus finds similar expression at 1365 (<quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἐνθάδ’ ἵξομαι</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴδωλ_σκιάν_126">. As unreal as phantoms; as unsubstantial as shadows. Cp. fr. 12 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνθρωπός ἐστι πνεῦμα καὶ σκιὰ μόνον</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴδωλον ἄλλως</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸς_128">: as Ajax had done more than once (766—775). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄγκον_129">, ‘pomp,’ <ref n="Soph. Trach. 817."> <title>Tr.</title> 817.</ref>Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Shak. MV 1.1">Shakesp. <title>Merch.</title> 1. 1. 124</bibl> <quote xml:lang="eng">showing a more swelling port | Than my faint means would grant continuance.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
showing a more swelling port | Than my faint
							means would grant continuance.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρῃ_129">, ‘take upon thee,’ ‘assume’: subjunct. of 1st aor. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠράμην</quote> (not of 2nd aor. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠρόμην</quote>, which would have </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="α_129">). The sense of <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἠράμην</quote> is usu. ‘to take up’ or ‘take upon one,’ rarely ‘to win,’ which is the regular sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠρόμην</quote>. See Appendix on 75.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρῃς_129"> (from 1st aor. act. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦρα</quote>) has inferior MS. authority, and is also less suitable in sense: it would mean, ‘lift up,’ ‘exalt.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βρίθεις_130">, ‘art weighty,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘powerful’: cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 3"> Pind. <title>N.</title> 3. 40</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">συγγενεῖ δέ τις εὐδοξίᾳ μέγα βρίθει.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μακροῦ_130">, extensive, ‘large’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 825">cp. 825</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1217"> <title>Tr.</title> 1217</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χάριν βραχεῖαν πρὸς μακροῖς ἄλλοις διδούς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλούτου_βάθει_130">: cp. Tyrtaeus fr. 12. 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">πλουτοίη δὲ Μίδεω καὶ Κινύρεω βάθιον</quote> (so Camerarius: <quote xml:lang="grc">μάλιον</quote> G. M. Schmidt): <ref n="Pind. O. 13">Pind. <title>O.</title> 13. 63</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βαθὺν κλᾶρον</quote> (‘a rich domain’): <title>Suppl.</title> 555 <quote xml:lang="grc">βαθύπλουτον χθόνα</quote> (referring to soil): Eur. fr. 453 <quote xml:lang="grc">Εἰρήνα βαθύπλουτε</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Call. Cer. 114">Callim. <title>Cer.</title> 114</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν βαθὺν οἶκον</quote> </cit> (‘opulent’): Aelian <title>V. H.</title> 3. 18 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν εἰρήνῃ τε διάγειν καὶ πλούτῳ βαθεῖ</quote>. Indeed, <quote xml:lang="grc">βαθύς</quote> could be said (like <quote xml:lang="grc">παχύς</quote>) of a rich <emph>man</emph>: <ref n="Xen. Ec. 11. 10">Xen. <title>Oec.</title> 11. 10</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βαθεῖς τε καὶ ἐρρωμένους ἄνδρας</quote>, ‘men of substance and power.’—The feeble <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάρει_130"> (cr. n.) was prompted by <quote xml:lang="grc">βρίθεις</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμέρα_131">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 475">cp. 475</ref> : <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 8">Pind. <title>P.</title> 8. 95</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπάμεροι· τί δέ τις; τί δ’ οὔ τις; σκιᾶς ὄναρ | ἄνθρωπος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐπάμεροι· τί δέ τις; τί δ’ οὔ τις; σκιᾶς ὄναρ
							| ἄνθρωπος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλίνει_131">: the image is from depressing the scale of a balance: <ref n="Hom. Il. 19.223"> <title>Il.</title> 19. 223</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὴν κλίνῃσι τάλαντα | Ζεύς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀνάγει_131">: so <ref n="Soph. Phil. 866"> <title>Ph.</title> 866</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀνάγει κάρα</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1158"> <title>Ant.</title> 1158</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τύχη γὰρ ὀρθοῖ καὶ τύχη καταρρέπει | τὸν εὐτυχοῦντα τόν τε δυστυχοῦντ’ ἀεί</quote>. Eur. fr. 420 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾷς τυράννους διὰ μακρῶν ηὐξημένους | ὡς μικρὰ τὰ σφάλλοντα, καὶ μἴ ἡμέρα | τὰ μὲν καθεῖλεν ὑψόθεν, τὰ δ’ ἦρ’ ἄνω</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακούς_133"> (which has needlessly been suspected, cr. n.) is interpreted by vv. 127 ff., and more immediately by the contrast with <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς σώφρονας</quote>: it means those who, like Ajax, are led into <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσσέβεια</quote> by overweening self-reliance or pride. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Τελαμώνιε_παῖ_134">: <ref n="Hom. Il. 13.67"> <title>Il.</title> 13. 67</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Τελαμώνιον υἱόν</quote>. The followers of Ajax call upon him to come forth from his tent, —where, for some days previously, he had remained in sullen seclusion (194 f.), —and to refute this dire rumour of his onslaught on the cattle. Surely it is a malignant slander. Or is it possible that some angry deity has driven him to such a deed? Assuredly it is abhorrent from his own nature.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Σαλαμῖνος_134"> (defining gen.)..</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάθρον_134">, the pedestal, or firm seat, consisting of Salamis. The island itself is the <quote xml:lang="grc"> βάθρον</quote>: this is clear from 859 f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ γῆς ἱρὸν οἰκείας πέδον | Σαλαμῖνος, ὦ πατρῷον ἑστίας βάθρον</quote>. Just so in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1000"> <title>Ph.</title> 1000</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως ἂν ᾖ μοι γῆς τόδ’ αἰπεινὸν βάθρον</quote>, ‘while I have this craggy Lemnos beneath my feet.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_ἀγχιάλου_134">: for the place of the second epithet, see n. on <ref n="Soph. OT 1199"> <title>O. T.</title> 1199</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰν γαμψώνυχα παρθένον | χρησμῳδόν</quote>. While </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_ἀμφιρύτου_134"> would suggest to an Athenian the narrow strait, so familiar to his sight, which divides Salamis from the Attic mainland, the second epithet, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγχιάλου_134">, would, as it were, turn his eyes seaward, inviting him to look forth from the shore of Salamis itself towards the Saronic Gulf. Each adjective lends a touch to the picture. This is thoroughly Greek. See, for instance, <title>I. A.</title> 164 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμολον ἀμφὶ παρακτίαν ψάμαθον Αὐλίδος ἐναλίας</quote>, the sandy <emph>sea-shore</emph> of Aulis <emph>by the waves</emph>: <title> Helen.</title> 400 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπ’ οἶδμα πόντιον γλαυκῆς ἁλός</quote>,—where the blue expanse, the surge, and the depths beneath it (<quote xml:lang="grc">πόντιον</quote>) are all suggested.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχων_134">: cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 4">Pind. <title> N.</title> 4. 48</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴας Σαλαμῖν’ ἔχει πατρῴαν</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὲ_ἐπιχαίρω_136">: for the acc., expressing the object of joy, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1314"> <title>Ph.</title> 1314</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥσθην πατέρα τὸν ἀμὸν εὐλογοῦντά σε</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 1339">Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 1339</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς γὰρ εὐσεβεῖς θεοὶ | θνῄσκοντας οὐ χαίρουσι</quote>: <title>Rhes.</title> 390 <quote xml:lang="grc">χαίρω δέ σ’ εὐτυχοῦντα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πληγὴ_Διὸς_137"> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 279">cp. 279</ref>), suggested by his long inaction (194 f.). Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 12.37"> <title>Il.</title> 12. 37</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Διὸς μάστιγι δαμέντες.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζαμενὴς_137">, ‘vehement’; a word not found in <title> Il.</title>or <title>Od.</title>, but which occurs in <title>Hom. hymn. Merc.</title> (307), and is frequent with Pindar; thus fr. 231 <quote xml:lang="grc">τόλμα..ζαμενής.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγος_κακόθρους_137">, like <ref n="Soph. Trach. 791"> <title>Tr.</title> 791</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσπάρευνον λέκτρον</quote>, <ref n="Soph. OT 518"> <title>O. T.</title> 518</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βίου..τοῦ μακραίωνος</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 709">cp. 709</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπιβῇ_137"> with acc. is rare; but cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1299"> <title>O. T.</title> 1299</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ς’, ὦ τλῆμον</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">προσέβη μανία</quote>; <ref n="Eur. Andr. 491">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 491</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔτι σε, πότνια</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">μετατροπὰ τῶνδ’ ἔπεισιν ἔργων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεφόβημαι_139">, a form found in <ref n="Hom. Il. 10.510"> <title>Il.</title> 10. 510</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">πεφοβημένος</quote>), and often in Attic prose; it is emphatic (=‘thoroughly scared’).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πτηνῆς_139"> here suggests timorous flight; cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.778"> <title>Il.</title> 5. 778</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρήρωσι πελειάσιν ἴθμαθ’ ὁμοῖαι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄμμα_πελείας_139">, since fear or anguish is seen in the eye; cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 527"> <title>Tr.</title> 527</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφινείκητον ὄμμα νύμφας</quote> (n.). <ref n="Soph. OC 729"> <title>O. C.</title> 729</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρῶ τιν’ ὑμᾶς ὀμμάτων εἰληφότας | φόβον νεωρῆ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_νυκτὸς_141">, thus placed at the beginning of the sentence, indicates the time to which the whole following statement refers. As the rumours began only at daylight, the reference is, in strictness, to the moment denoted by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιβάντ’ — ὀλέσαι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπὶ_δυσκλείᾳ_141">, <emph>for</emph>, <emph>tending to</emph>, our disgrace; cp. <ref n="Hdt. 1. 68"> Her. 1. 68</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ κακῷ</quote>, <ref n="Hdt. 4. 164"> Her. 4. 164</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ διαφθορῇ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_λειμῶν_144">, the plain ‘wild with horses,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, on which great numbers of horses (out at pasture) disport themselves. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.221"> <title>Il.</title> 20. 221</ref>Erichthonius, son of Dardanus, is described as keeping great droves of horses on the moist meadow-lands near the lower spurs of Ida: <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ τρισχίλιαι ἵπποι ἕλος κάτα βουκολέοντο</quote>. Sophocles used the word <quote xml:lang="grc">καρπομανής</quote> (fr. 591), doubtless in a sense parallel with that of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑλομανής</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘abounding in fruit’: and the sense which he attached to <quote xml:lang="grc">λειμὼν ἱππομανής</quote> was probably <quote xml:lang="grc">λειμὼν ὃς μαίνεται ἵπποις</quote> rather than <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ᾧ ἵπποι μαίνονται</quote>. But the idea of <emph>wild abundance</emph> would naturally, in this case, be blended with that of the horses <emph>frisking</emph> or <emph>galloping</emph> in freedom on the plain. Hence the difference made by the verbal analysis which we prefer is not one which much affects the picture. —See Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βοτὰ_λείαν_145">: a hendiadys, =<quote xml:lang="grc">βοτὰ δορίληπτα</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 36"> <title>El.</title> 36</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀσπίδων τε καὶ στρατοῦ</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">στρατοῦ ὡπλισμένου</quote>): <ref n="Eur. Ba. 919">Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 919</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Θήβας καὶ πόλισμ’ ἑπτάστομον</quote>. We might, indeed, understand <quote xml:lang="grc">βοτὰ</quote> of the sheep, and <quote xml:lang="grc">λείαν</quote> of the oxen (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 53">cp. 53</ref> n.): but that seems less fitting here. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λοιπὴ_145">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἄδαστος</quote>. <ref target="cl53">See on 53</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἴθωνι_σιδήρῳ_145">, the Homeric phrase ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 4.485"> <title>Il.</title> 4. 485</ref>, <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.473"> Il. 7. 473</ref>, <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.372"> Il. 20. 372</ref>). This epithet, ‘flashing,’ is given also to other objects of bright metal, as a <quote xml:lang="grc">λέβης</quote> or a <quote xml:lang="grc">τρίπους</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.123"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 123</ref>, <ref n="Hom. Il. 24.233"> Il. 24. 233</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ψιθύρους_148">: <ref n="Pind. P. 2">Pind. <title> P.</title> 2. 75</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷα ψιθύρων παλάμαις</quote> (the arts of slanderers) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕπετ’ αἰεὶ βροτῶν</quote>. (<title>Ep. Rom.</title> i. 30 <quote xml:lang="grc">ψιθυριστάς, καταλάλους</quote>.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶσιν_Ὀδυσσείς_148">. L has <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντων ὀδυσσεύς</quote>, and it is possible that (as Nauck thinks) the poet wrote <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντων Ὀδυσεύς</quote>. (Euripides has that Homeric form in anapaests, <ref n="Eur. Hec. 143"> <title>Hec.</title> 143</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥξει δ’ Ὀδυσεὺς ὅσον οὐκ ἤδη</quote>.) But it seems improbable, seeing that the short form occurs nowhere else in Sophocles, though he uses the name some twenty-five times. On the other hand, a transcriber might easily have written the gen. <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντων</quote> after <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦτα</quote>, by mistake for the less usual dative. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔπειστα_151"> has the best authority here, but is otherwise known only from Aristotle. In <title>Eth. N.</title> 7. 10 (p. 1151 <emph>b</emph> 10) <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔπειστος, ὅταν τύχῃ, ἔσται ὁ ἐγκρατής</quote>, it means, ‘easy to persuade,’ as opp. to <quote xml:lang="grc">δύσπειστος</quote>. But in another place ( <quote xml:lang="grc">αριστ. περὶ ἀτόμων γραμμῶν</quote>, p. 969 <emph>b</emph> 22), the words <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔπειστον ὅτι ἀνάγκη κ.τ.λ.</quote> mean, ‘it is easy to <emph>show</emph>,’ etc. As we can say, <quote xml:lang="grc">πείθω τινά τι</quote>, it is natural that <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔπειστος</quote> should be capable of both senses. Here </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔπειστα_151_2"> will be, ‘things of which it is easy to persuade the hearer.’ It has more point than </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔπιστα_151">, since it implies the skill of the calumniator. Cp. fr. 786 <quote xml:lang="grc">ταχεῖα πειθὼ τῶν κακῶν ὁδοιπορεῖ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_λέξαντος_152">, not, of course, Odysseus, but simply the man from whom <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ κλύων</quote> heard the story. The slander <cit> <quote xml:lang="lat">mobilitate viget, viresque acquirit eundo</quote> <bibl n="Verg. A. 4.175">(<title>Aen.</title> 4. 175)</bibl> </cit>. As it spreads and gains in strength, the spiteful joy of each new hearer is greater than that of his informant. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄχεσιν_καθυβρίζων_153">: for the dat., cp. <ref n="Hdt. 1. 212"> Her. 1. 212</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τριτημορίδι τοῦ στρατοῦ κατυβρίσας</quote>: <ref n="Paus. 4. 27. 3">Paus. 4. 27. 3</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καθυβρίσαντες τῶν Διοσκούρων τῇ θυσίᾳ</quote>. Similarly <ref n="Hdt. 3. 37"> Her. 3. 37</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ ἀγάλματι κατεγέλασε</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῶν_ψυχῶν_154">, those <quote xml:lang="grc">διοτρεφεῖς βασιλεῖς</quote> like Ajax, who, in the true Homeric spirit, are conceived as <quote xml:lang="grc">μεγάθυμοι, μεγαλόψυχοι</quote> above common men.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱεὶς_154"> with gen., like other verbs of ‘aiming at’: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1034"> <title>Ant.</title> 1034</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοξεύετ’ ἀνδρὸς τοῦδε</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 51">Eur. <title>Cycl.</title> 51</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥίψω πέτρον σου.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁμάρτοις_154"> (cr. n.), the original reading in L, seems better, as being simpler and clearer, than </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁμάρτοι_154">, though <quote xml:lang="grc">τις</quote> could, of course, be easily supplied from the next clause.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατὰ_ἐμοῦ_154">: for the separation of <quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ</quote> from its case, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 969">cp. 969</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἔχονθ_157">, the rich or great: <title> Suppl.</title> 240 <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δ’ οὐκ ἔχοντες καὶ σπανίζοντες βίου</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς τοὺς ἔχοντας κέντρ’ ἀφιᾶσιν κακά</quote>. So <ref n="Eur. Alc. 57"> <title>Alc.</title> 57</ref>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_φθόνος_157">. Cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 8">Pind. <title> N.</title> 8. 22</ref>(of <quote xml:lang="grc">φθόνος</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅπτεται δ’ ἐσλῶν ἀεί, χειρόνεσσι δ’ οὐκ ἐρίζει</quote>. Trag.incert. frag. 547. 12 (ed. Nauck) <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς γὰρ τὸ</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">λαμπρὸν ὁ φθόνος βιάζεται</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">λιάζεται</quote> Wecklein). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πύργου_ῥῦμα_159">, <emph>protection</emph>, garrison, for the city walls: <ref n="Soph. OT 56"> <title>O. T.</title> 56</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς οὐδέν ἐστιν οὔτε πύργος οὔτεναῦς | ἔρημος ἀνδρῶν μὴ ξυνοικούντων ἔσω</quote>. For <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥύεσθαι</quote>, ‘to defend,’ said with ref. to a town, cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.403"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 403</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρύετο Ἴλιον Ἕκτωρ</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 72"> <title>O. T.</title> 72</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τήνδε ῥυσαίμην πόλιν</quote>.—Not, ‘tower of defence.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μετὰ_160"> expresses <emph>alliance</emph>, and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπό_160">, <emph>service</emph>; but there is no stress on the difference of relationships.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρθοῖθ_160">, have a fair course, be prosperous: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 675"> <title>Ant.</title> 675</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν δ’ ὀρθουμένων | σῴζει τὰ πολλὰ σώμαθ’ ἡ πειθαρχία</quote> (n.).—Some suppose an allusion to building. The small stones, filling the interstices, keep the large stones in their places: <title>Legg.</title> p. 902 E <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ γὰρ ἄνευ σμικρῶν τοὺς μεγάλους φασὶν οἱ λιθολόγοι λίθους εὖ κεῖσθαι</quote>. ‘Great without small Make a bad wall,’ Donaldson, <title>New Crat.</title> § 455. The simple words do not warrant this fancy. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τούτων_γνώμας_163">, maxims, precepts, <emph> concerning</emph> these things. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προδιδάσκειν_163"> properly implies <emph>gradual</emph> teaching ( Plat. <title>Gorg.</title>p. 489 D, <quote xml:lang="grc">πραότερόν με προδίδασκε</quote>), and is fitting here because the truths are elementary. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιούτων_164">, ‘so foolish,’ referring to <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς ἀνοήτους</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 218">cp. 218</ref>, 251, 562, 929.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπαλέξασθαι_164">: this form is quoted by Hesychius from the poet's lost <title>Hipponoos</title> ( Soph. fr. 282). In <ref n="Soph. OT 171">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 171</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλέξεται</quote> is a fut.: which, like this aor., seems to come from a stem <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλεκ</quote> rather than from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλεξ</quote> (whence the pres. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλέξω</quote>): see n. there. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_ἄφωνοι_167">. The most probable account of this passage is that </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δ_167"> should be inserted after <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰγυπιὸν</quote> in 169 (cr. n.). ‘We can do nothing without thee;—<emph>no</emph> (we are helpless), <emph>for</emph>, when they have escaped thine eye, they chatter like flocking birds; <emph>but</emph> (<quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote>) terrified by the mighty vulture, perchance they will suddenly cower,’ etc. Note these points:—</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλὰ_167"> prefaces a confirmation of the statement just made in a <emph>negative</emph> form (165 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν σθένομεν</quote>): cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 307"> <title>El.</title> 307</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν οὖν τοιούτοις οὔτε σωφρονεῖν, φίλαι</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’ εὐσεβεῖν πάρεστιν, ἀλλ’ ἔν τοι κακοῖς | πολλή )στ’ ἀνάγκη κἀπιτηδεύειν κακά</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλὰ_γὰρ_167"> is elliptical; ‘No (we can do nothing), <emph>for</emph>’ etc.: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 223"> <title>El.</title> 223</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἐν γὰρ δεινοῖς οὐ σχήσω κ.τ.λ.</quote>, ‘but (ye speak in vain), for’ etc.: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 155"> <title>Ant.</title> 155</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὅδε γὰρ δὴ</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">χωρεῖ</quote>, ‘but (let us cease), <emph>for</emph>’ etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέγαν_ὑποδείσαντες_167">, which allows the words <quote xml:lang="grc">μέγαν αἰγυπιὸν</quote> to <emph> begin</emph> the clause describing the sudden discomfiture of the foes, gives those words a signal force and spirit. They become much tamer, if, deleting <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποδείσαντες</quote> and the stop after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγέλαι</quote>, we place a comma after <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰγυπιόν</quote>, and govern it by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποδρᾶσαι</quote> supplied from </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπέδραν_167">.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑποδείσαντες_167"> refers to the foes of Ajax (and not, as the schol. took it, to the birds), there is a change from simile to metaphor: the ‘vulture’ is Ajax. This is quite in the manner of Sophoclean imagery: cp. n. on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 117"> <title>Ant.</title> 117</ref> ff.— For other views, see Appendix.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτε_δὴ_167">, epic, ‘when now,’ ‘when at length,’ <ref n="Hom. Od. 2.314"> <title>Od.</title> 2. 314</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’ ὅτε δὴ μέγας εἰμί.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπέδραν_167_2">, for <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀπέδρασαν</quote> ( <ref n="Thuc. 1. 128">Thuc. 1. 128</ref>), like the poetical <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔβαν, ἔσταν, ἔτλαν</quote>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰγυπιὸν_167">, an Homeric image: <ref n="Hom. Od. 22.302"> <title>Od.</title> 22. 302</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δ’, ὥς τ’ αἰγυπιοὶ γαμψώνυχες ἀγκυλοχεῖλαι | ἐξ ὀρέων ἐλθόντες ἐπ’ ὀρνίθεσσι θόρωσι.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάχ_ἂν_167"> can mean only ‘perchance’: we cannot take <quote xml:lang="grc">τάχα</quote> separately, as=‘swiftly’; </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξαίφνης_167"> should be taken with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πτήξειαν_167">, notwithstanding Alcaeus fr. 27, which the poet clearly had in mind, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπταζον ὥστ’ ὄρνιθες ὦκυν | αἴετον ἐξαπίνας φάνεντα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σιγῇ_ἄφωνοι_167">: <quote xml:lang="grc">σιγῇ</quote> implies motionless awe; cp. <ref n="Pind. P. 4">Pind. <title>P.</title> 4. 57</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπταξαν δ’ ἀκίνητοι σιωπᾷ</quote>. Cp. too the Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκὴν ἐγένοντο σιωπῇ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_σε_172">..; The Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ ῥα</quote> is sometimes interrogative ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.446"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 446</ref>), but occurs also where there is no question (12. 164 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ ῥά νυ</quote>). <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ ῥα</quote> is interrogative in <ref n="Pind. P. 9"> Pind. <title>P.</title> 9. 40</ref>, <ref n="Pind. I. 7">Pind. <title> I.</title> 7. 3</ref>: but not in <ref n="Pind. P. 11">Pind. <title>P.</title> 11. 38.</ref>This </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_172"> is not the contracted form of the <emph>disjunctive</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἠέ_172"> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.378"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 378</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠέ ...ἦ</quote>), which was not used in direct question.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ταυροπόλα_172">=<quote xml:lang="grc">Ταυροπόλος</quote>: for the form, cp. <ref n="Pind. O. 3">Pind. <title>O.</title> 3. 26</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Λατοῦς ἱπποσόα θυγάτηρ</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Ion 1478">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 1478</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Γοργοφόνα</quote>. There were two cults of Artemis, originally quite distinct. (1) The <quote xml:lang="grc">Ταυροπόλος</quote> was a goddess who rules over bulls,—one of the numerous attributes of Artemis in her relation to wild animals: cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰπόλος, ἱπποπόλος, οἰοπόλος</quote>. A Macedonian silver coin (from Amphipolis) shows her riding on a prancing bull, and carrying a torch in either hand. On another coin she appears (with the inscr. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ΤΑΥΡΟΠΟΛΟΣ</quote>) carrying two torches, and with the horns of a bull growing out of her shoulders: these horns were meant to suggest the crescent moon. The cult of the Tauropolos was purely Greek, and had nothing fierce or cruel about it. (2) The cult of Artemis <quote xml:lang="grc">Ταυρική</quote> (or <quote xml:lang="grc">Ταυρώ</quote>) had orgiastic elements; it was of Asiatic origin, and belonged to a primitive stage of natureworship. The ritual was a bloody one, and in early times involved human sacrifice. This was the Artemis whose cult was said to have been brought to Brauron in Attica, from the Tauric Chersonese, by Iphigeneia and Orestes.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Διὸς_172">, (daughter) of Zeus: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1302">cp. 1302</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Λαομέδοντος</quote>. But the art. (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ</quote>) is prefixed to <quote xml:lang="grc">Διὸς</quote> in 401, 450. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μεγάλα_173"> refers primarily to the <emph> strength</emph> and <emph>loudness</emph> of the popular rumour (198 f.); but also suggests dread or horror, as when impious words are called <quote xml:lang="grc">μεγάλοι λόγοι</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1350"> <title>Ant.</title> 1350</ref>). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 226">Cp. 226</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ μέγας μῦθος.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μᾶτερ_ἐμᾶς_173">: as <quote xml:lang="grc">πειθαρχία</quote> is <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς εὐπραξίας μήτηρ</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Seven 224">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 224</ref>), etc. The boldness is somewhat like that of <ref n="Soph. OT 157">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 157</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ χρυσέας τέκνον Ἐλπίδος, ἄμβροτε Φάμα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πανδάμους_βοῦς_175">, because they were still common property, <quote xml:lang="grc">λεία ἄδαστος</quote>: <ref target="cl54">see on 54</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_που_176">, ‘I ween’: a phrase frequent in this play; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 382">cp. 382</ref>, 622, 850, 1008: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 846."> <title>Tr.</title> 846.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νίκας_χάριν_176">, on account of some victory (given by her to Ajax) which brought her no <quote xml:lang="grc">καρπός</quote>, no reward; </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤ_ἐνάρων_176">, <emph>either</emph>, it may be, because she was disappointed of spoils; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτ_ἀδώροιςἐλαφαβολίαις_176">, <emph>or</emph> by reason of deer-slaying after which he made no <quote xml:lang="grc">δῶρα</quote> to her. The general cause, denoted by <quote xml:lang="grc">νίκας.. χάριν</quote>, is divided into two special cases; (1) a victory in <emph>war</emph>; (2) a victory in <emph>hunting.</emph> [This is simpler than to suppose that <quote xml:lang="grc">νίκας..χάριν</quote> refers to the withholding of a <emph> public</emph> offering,—which Ajax ought to have made on behalf of those who fought under his command; and that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνάρων</quote> refers to a private vow, which he had made on his own account. On this view, <emph>three</emph> different causes would be indicated; and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ που</quote> in 176 would be disjunctive,—‘<emph> either</emph>, I ween,’—as it is in <ref n="Hom. Od. 13.234."> <title>Od.</title> 13. 234.</ref>]</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νίκας_χάριν_176_2">=<quote xml:lang="grc">νίκας..ἀκαρπώτου χάριν</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 793"> <title>Ant.</title> 793</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">νεῖκος ἀνδρῶν ξύναιμον</quote>): cp. <title>I. T.</title> 566 <quote xml:lang="grc">κακῆς γυναικὸς χάριν ἄχαριν ἀπώλετο</quote>. <title> Legg.</title> p. 853 D <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν δὴ χάριν οὐκ ἐπίχαριν λέγοιμ ἂν..νόμον</quote>. (Others take <quote xml:lang="grc">χάριν</quote> as acc. of respect with <quote xml:lang="grc">ψευσθεῖσα</quote>: ‘disappointed <emph>as to</emph> the tribute,’ etc.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤ_ῥα_176">: the <emph>disjunctive</emph> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ</quote> (or <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἠέ</quote>) is rarely thus followed by <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥα</quote>. (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 172">Cp. 172</ref> n.) For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_εἴτε_176">, cp. <ref n="Eur. Alc. 114">Eur. <title>Alc.</title> 114</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ Λυκίας | εἴτ’ ἐπὶ τὰς ἀνύδρους | Ἀμμωνίδας ἕδρας.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλυτῶν_176">: cp. the Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">κλυτὰ τεύχεα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ψευσθεῖσα_176"> with gen.: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1382">cp. 1382</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 712"> <title>Tr.</title> 712</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ τι μὴ ψευσθήσομαι | γνώμης</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀδώροις_ἐλαφαβολίαις_176">: for the causal dat., cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1127"> <title>Tr.</title> 1127</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς γε πρόσθεν ἡμαρτημένοις</quote> (n.). Those who retain the MS. reading </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δώροις_176"> understand: ‘deceived either <emph>by gifts</emph> of spoils (promised, but not given), or in regard to slaying of deer.’ (Nauck, reading the genitive <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐλαφαβολίας</quote>, take <quote xml:lang="grc">δώροις</quote> with that also.) But this is awkward. And, in support of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀδώροις_176">, it should be noted that Sophocles elsewhere also has co-ordinated a causal dat. with a partic. (or adj.) of causal force, like <quote xml:lang="grc">ψευσθεῖσα</quote> here. See <ref n="Soph. Trach. 239"> <title>Tr.</title> 239</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΔΗ. εὐκταῖα φαίνων, ἢ )πὸ μαντείας τινός; ΛΙ. εὐχαῖς</quote> (‘for a vow’). <ref n="Soph. OC 333"> <title>O. C.</title> 333</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΟΙ. πότερα πόθοισι; ΙΣ. καὶ λόγων γ’ αὐτάγγελος</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλαφαβολίαις_176">: Artemis the huntress (<quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀγροτέρα</quote>) was especially <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἐλαφηβόλος</quote>: see on <ref n="Soph. OC 1092"> <title>O. C.</title> 1092</ref> f., and cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 213"> <title>Tr.</title> 213</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄρτεμιν Ὀρτυγίαν ἐλαφαβόλον</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_179">..*</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_179">..; The reading of the MSS., <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>ἢ</emph> χαλκοθώραξ <emph>ἤ</emph> τιν’ Ἐνυάλιος</quote>, was explained by supposing that <quote xml:lang="grc">χαλκοθώραξ</quote> meant Ares, as distinguished from Enyalios (so the schol. here). How the second </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤ_179"> should be corrected, is uncertain. (1) In favour of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μή_179">, it may be noted that the interrogative <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote> is often followed, as here, by <quote xml:lang="grc">τις</quote>, and that its tone of tentative suggestion is just in place. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 9.405"> <title>Od.</title> 9. 405 f.</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ μή τίς σεο μῆλα βροτῶν ἀέκοντος ἐλαύνει; ἦ μή τίς σ’ αὐτὸν κτείνει δόλῳ ἠὲ βίηφι;</quote> </cit> <ref n="Soph. OC 1502"> <title>O. C.</title> 1502</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή τις Διὸς κεραυνός, ἤ τις ὀμβρία | χάλαζ’ ἐπιρράξασα;</quote> (2) Another possibility is </gloss>

data.quote:
ἦ μή τίς σεο μῆλα βροτῶν ἀέκοντος ἐλαύνει; ἦ
							μή τίς σ’ αὐτὸν κτείνει δόλῳ ἠὲ βίηφι;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δή_179">, as=‘then’ (to make a last guess). (3) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοί_179"> would be fitting, indeed, but would require us to suppose that the second <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤ</quote> in the MSS. is an inadvertent repetition of the first, not a corruption of some word like itself. (4) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴ_179"> has also been suggested. But the implied construction, <quote xml:lang="grc">μομφὰν ἔχων, εἴ τιν’</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">εἶχεν</quote>), would be too harsh. (5) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_179"> is condemned by the fact that with Sophocles this interrogative <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ</quote> regularly stands first in its clause; only a vocative sometimes precedes it: see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1281."> <title>Ant.</title> 1281.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἐνυάλιος_179"> is in the <title>Iliad</title> either the War-god (2. 651), seemingly identical with Ares, or an epithet of Ares (17. 211 <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄρης | δεινὸς ἐνυάλιος</quote>). Like <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἐνυώ</quote>, the word is of uncertain (possibly Thracian) origin. The mention of this deity has a two-fold fitness here; (1) on account of the reference in 178 to Artemis Agrotera; for, acc. to Pollux 8. 91, the Athenian Polemarch made annual offerings <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀρτέμιδἰ Αγροτέρᾳ καὶ τῷ Ἐνυαλίῳ</quote>: (2) because in the island-home of Ajax there was a <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἱερόν</quote> of Enyalios, founded by Solon to commemorate the victory by which Athens wrested Salamis from the Megarians ( <ref n="Plut. Sol. 9">Plut. <title>Sol.</title> 9</ref>). Further, Enyalios is here supposed to have helped Ajax; whereas Ares usually favoured the Trojans (cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.38"> <title>Il.</title> 20. 38</ref>). As to the Attic relationship between the two deities, see Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μομφὰν_ἔχων_180">=<quote xml:lang="grc"> μεμφόμενος</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1069">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1069</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἓν μὲν πρῶτά σοι μομφὴν ἔχω</quote>: so <ref n="Aesch. PB 445">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 445</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέμψιν οὔτιν’ ἀνθρώποις ἔχων.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνοῦ_δορὸς_180">, causal gen.: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 41">cp. 41</ref> n., and <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.93"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 93</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’ ἄρ’ ὅ γ’ εὐχωλῆς ἐπιμέμφεται οὔθ’ ἑκατόμβης.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνοῦ_180"> here=‘making common cause with him,’ ‘allied’; cp. <ref n="Eur. Tro. 58">Eur. <title>Tro.</title> 58</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς σὴν ἀφῖγμαι δύναμιν, ὡς κοινὴν λάβω</quote>. (The word may have been suggested by <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.309"> <title>Il.</title> 18. 309</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνὸς Ἐνυάλιος</quote>, though there the sense is, ‘The war-god is impartial.’)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐννυχίοις_μαχαναῖς_180">, by devices against Ajax in the night,—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, by impelling him to the nocturnal onslaught.—This seems to be the only instance in Tragedy (except <ref n="Aesch. Seven 132">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 132</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μαχανᾷ</quote>) where the Doric form of a word from the st. <quote xml:lang="grc">μηχαν</quote> has good support from our MSS. But this fact does not warrant G. Wolff's view that the form in <quote xml:lang="grc">η</quote> was alone used by the tragic dramatists.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐτείσατο_180">, not <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐτίσατο</quote>, was the Attic spelling in the poet's age: see Meisterhans, <title>Gramm. Att. Inschr.</title>, § 43. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρενόθεν_γ_183">, by the prompting of thine own mind,—if it had not been deranged by some god. Schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴκοθεν</quote> (=in virtue of <emph>thine own</emph> qualities), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπὸ οἰκείας γνώσεως</quote>. The emphasis given by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_183"> shows that this is the meaning.—Not <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπ’ ἀριστερὰ φρενόθεν</quote> (as=<quote xml:lang="grc">φρενῶν</quote>), ‘to the leftward of thy mind’: nor, ‘went from good sense (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπὸ φρενῶν</quote>) into folly.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπ_ἔβας_183">, deviating from the right course: <ref n="Aesch. PB 883">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 883</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξω δὲ δρόμου φέρομαι λύσσης | πνεύματι μάργῳ</quote>. Theognetus (a poet of the New Comedy), <quote xml:lang="grc">Φάσμα</quote> fr. 1. 7 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπαρίστερ’ ἔμαθες, ὦ πονηρέ, γράμματα</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘to your misfortune’). Schneid. cp. Ennius <title>Annales</title> 208 <quote xml:lang="lat">Quo vobis mentes, rectae quae stare solebant | Antehac, dementes sese flexere viai?</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόσσον_183">: the only example, except <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 140">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 140</ref>, of this form in Tragedy.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πίτνων_183">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστε πίτνειν</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 752"> <title>Ant.</title> 752</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ κἀπαπειλῶν ὧδ’ ἐπεξέρχει θρασύς;</quote> (‘doth thy boldness run to open threats?’) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥκοι_ἂν_186">, ‘will’ (or ‘must’) ‘come’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 88">cp. 88</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μένοιμ’ ἄν</quote>. The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γὰρ_186"> here refers to a thought implied in the last sentence:—‘You would never have done this thing of your own nature; (and if you have done it <emph>in madness</emph>, that proves nothing against your nature,) <emph>for</emph> heavensent madness cannot be helped; only, may the gods avert the evil rumour!’— <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘may it prove to be false.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ζεὺς_Φοῖβος_186">. Both gods are averters of evil, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλεξίκακοι, ἀποτρόπαιοι</quote>. But Zeus is invoked with especial fitness as being the source of mysterious voices and rumours ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 8.250"> <title>Il.</title> 8. 250</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα πανομφαίῳ Ζηνὶ ῥέζεσκον Ἀχαιοί</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑποβαλλόμενοι_188">. The midd. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποβάλλεσθαι</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">παισίον</quote>) was said of a woman who ‘secretly put to her breast’ the child of another, and passed it off as her own: <title>Thesm.</title> 564 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς δούλης τεκούσης ἄρρεν, εἶτα σαυτῇ | τοῦθ’ ὑπεβάλου, τὸ σὸν δὲ θυγάτριον παρῆκας αὐτῇ</quote>. Cp. below, 481. Hence the metaphor here,—‘falsely suggesting’ stories, <emph>laying to thy charge</emph> things which thou hast not done. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλέπτουσι_μύθους_189">, tell crafty tales: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1137">cp. 1137</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 57"> <title>Ph.</title> 57</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τόδ’ οὐχὶ κλεπτέον</quote>, ‘this must not be represented falsely’: <ref n="Soph. El. 37"> <title>El.</title> 37</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλέψαι..σφαγάς</quote> , <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> to effect by stealth. Also <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 56 <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγῳ κλέπτοντες</quote>. The participle </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑποβαλλόμενοι_189"> closely coheres with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλέπτουσι_189">, and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μύθους_189"> depends on both.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_βασιλῆς_189">, the Atreidae. For the nom. in <quote xml:lang="grc">‐ῆς</quote>, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 690"> <title>El.</title> 690</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βραβῆς</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_τᾶς_190"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote>: supply <quote xml:lang="grc">βασιλῆς</quote> (or <quote xml:lang="grc"> ‐εὺς</quote>) from the last clause.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀσώτου_190">, profligate, worthless.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Σισυφιδᾶν_190">. Anticleia, the mother of Odysseus, was said to have been with child by Sisyphus when she married Laertes: hence <ref n="Soph. Phil. 417"> <title>Ph.</title> 417</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὑμπολητὸς Σισύφου Λαερτίῳ</quote>, the son of Sisyphus, bought (with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕδνα</quote>) by Laertes: see n. there, and on <ref n="Soph. Phil. 625."> <title>Ph.</title> 625.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μή_ἄναξ_191">. If </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μ_191"> be sound, it can be only the acc.: an elision of <quote xml:lang="grc">μοι</quote> is impossible (see <ref n="Soph. OC 1436"> <title>O. C.</title> 1436</ref>, n. in Appendix). And <quote xml:lang="grc">με</quote> could be explained only as depending on the phrase </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὰν_ἄρῃ_191">, as meaning, ‘win an evil repute, to my injury’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">μή με διαβάλῃς, αὐτὸς διαβαλλόμενος</quote>): cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 123"> <title>El.</title> 123</ref> ff. <quote xml:lang="grc">τάκεις..οἰμωγὰν ..Ἀγαμέμνονα</quote>. But this is certainly forced; and, though the Chorus afterwards speak of themselves as involved in their chief's peril (252 ff.), that thought is less fitting here.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μ_191_2">. The syllables <quote xml:lang="grc">μή, μή μ’</quote> answer metrically to <quote xml:lang="grc">μομφὰν</quote> in 180, and we should thus have to suppose that </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήμή_ἄναξ_191"> represents <foreign xml:lang="meter">--u-</foreign>. Such an hiatus seems a very doubtful one for tragic lyrics: otherwise the suggestion would be welcome, as <quote xml:lang="grc">μή, μή</quote> is supported by <ref n="Soph. OC 210"> <title>O. C.</title> 210</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή, μή μ’ ἀνέρῃ</quote>. Morstadt's remedy, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_ὦναξ_191">, (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">μή, μή μ’, ἄναξ, ἔθ’</quote>,) has found much favour, and is satisfactory in itself; but it does not account for the origin of the vulgate.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλισίαις_ἔχων_191">. The sense required is, ‘keeping thy face hidden in the tent’: so that <quote xml:lang="grc"> κλισίαις</quote> is a locative dat. The adv. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧδ_191"> helps to suggest the idea of ‘hidden.’ The objections to the version, ‘keeping thine eyes fixed <emph>on</emph> the tents,’ are, (1) that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχων</quote> could not well stand for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέχων</quote>, and (2) that the seclusion of Ajax <emph> within</emph> his tent is not then expressed.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρῃ_191"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="α_191"> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">λώβαν</quote> in 181), from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠράμην</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 129">cp. 129</ref>, and see Appendix on 75. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνα_193">, the prep., with anastrophe, as=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάστηθι</quote>: the hiatus as in <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.247"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 247</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἄνα, εἰ μέμονάς γε.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπου_ποτέ_193">, ‘wheresoever,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> in whatever spot within the dwelling. The change of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποτὲ_193"> to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποτὶ_193"> (on which see <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1214"> <title>Tr.</title> 1214</ref> n.) introduces a strange phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">στηρίζει πρὸς σχολῇ</quote>. The simple dat. (of circumstance) is clearly right.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγωνίῳ_σχολᾷ_193"> seems to mean, ‘battlepause,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, rest from battle. Other explanations are: (1) <quote xml:lang="grc">σχολή</quote> which causes an <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγών</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">discrimen</foreign>); because, while Ajax rests, <emph>his foes</emph> are perilously active. Now, if the Chorus assumed that <title>Ajax</title>, while absent from battle, had been employed in other effort, then, indeed, they might call his rest <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγώνιος σχολή</quote>, ‘a strenuous rest,’ like <foreign xml:lang="lat">otium negotiosum.</foreign> But it seems impossible that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγώνιος σχολή</quote> should mean merely, his ‘perilous’ or ‘critical’ rest,—made so by the acts of others. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄταν_φλέγων_195">, ‘kindling a flame of ruin high as heaven,’ Whitelaw. Cp. <title>Suppl.</title> 808 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴϋζε δ’ ὀμφὰν οὐρανίαν</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc"> οὐρανομήκη</quote>: and see n. on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 418."> <title>Ant.</title> 418.</ref>This is more forcible here than, ‘inflaming the <emph>heaven-sent</emph> plague’ (=<quote xml:lang="grc"> θείαν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 186">cp. 186</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτάρβητα_196">, neut. pl. as adverb. I keep this, the reading of the MSS., as Wecklein and Bellermann do. Dindorf strikes out </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧδ_196"> (unwarrantably), and writes </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτάρβητος_196">. In an epode, the strophic test is absent, and the logaoedic metre admits of Dindorf's reading. There is, however, a point in favour of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτάρβητα_196_2"> which deserves to be noted; viz., that the adverbial neut. pl., though it has no special relation to verbs of <emph>motion</emph>, is, in fact, very often joined with such verbs; and that the phrase </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτάρβητα_ὁρμᾶται_196"> is therefore thoroughly consonant with poetical usage. See (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> ) <ref n="Soph. OT 883"> <title>O. T.</title> 883</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπέροπτα πορεύεται</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OC 1695"> <title>O. C.</title> 1695</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτοι κατάμεμπτ’ ἔβητον</quote>: <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.75"> <title>Il.</title> 17. 75</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκίχητα διώκων | ἵππους</quote>: <ref n="Pind. O. 7">Pind. <title>O.</title> 7. 45</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βαίνει..ἀτέκμαρτα</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1740"> Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 1740</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπαρθένευτ’ ἀλωμένα</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Ba. 435">Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 435</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἄκρανθ’ ὡρμήσαμεν</quote>. For the hiatus at the end of the verse, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 425">cp. 425</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χθονὸς μολόντ’ ἀπὸ | Ἑλλανίδος</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐανέμοις_196">, with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="α_196"> (not </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="α_196_2">, as if Doric for <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐηνέμοις</quote>): so probably in fr. 342 <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐανέμου λίμνας</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 19.432"> <title>Od.</title> 19. 432</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πτύχας ἠνεμοέσσας.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάσσαις_196">: <ref n="Soph. OC 673"> <title>O. C.</title> 673</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χλωραῖς ὑπὸ βάσσαις</quote> (n.): <ref n="Hom. Il. 21.449"> <title>Il.</title> 21. 449</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἴδης ἐν κνημοῖσι πολυπτύχου ὑληέσσης</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καγχαζόντων_198">. Dindorf writes </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καχαζόντων_198">, on the ground that the form <quote xml:lang="grc">καγχάζω</quote> was not Attic. (His further change of <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντων</quote> into <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁπάντων</quote> is merely for the sake of equalising this v. with 197 f.) The main facts are these. 1. Aristophanes uses <quote xml:lang="grc">καχάζων</quote> once ( <ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 849"> <title>Eccl.</title> 849</ref>), and also the noun <quote xml:lang="grc">καχασμῶν</quote> (<title>Nub.</title> 1073). 2. It is true that <quote xml:lang="grc">καγχάζω</quote> cannot be proved by metre from any verse earlier than that of Babrius (100. 8 <quote xml:lang="grc">καγχάσας</quote>), and Paulus Silentiarius (6th cent.) in <title>Anth. Pal.</title> 6. 74. 3 (<quote xml:lang="grc"> καγχάζουσα</quote>). 3. On the other hand the MSS. have <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνεκάγχασε</quote> in <ref n="Plat. Rep. 337a">Plat. <title> Rep.</title> 337 A</ref>, and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνακαγχάσας</quote> in <ref n="Plat. Euthyd. 300d"> <title>Euthyd.</title> 300 D</ref>; forms, be it noted, which carry their own commendation, since, in the compound with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνά</quote>, the nasal (<quote xml:lang="grc">γ</quote> before <quote xml:lang="grc">χ</quote>) makes pronunciation easier. 4. Lastly, there is the analogy of the Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc"> καγχαλάω</quote>. Surely, then, there is no reason to doubt that Sophocles could have used <quote xml:lang="grc">καγχάζω</quote> if he found it metrically convenient.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαρυάλγητα_198">. I follow the MSS. in leaving the hiatus (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 196">cp. 196</ref>), which here has the special justification of a pause, making it needless to write <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρυαλγήτως</quote> with Dindorf. That the scholiast in L, like the MSS., had the neut. pl., appears from his paraphrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρέα καὶ ἀλγεινά</quote>. Some editors prefer to write </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαρυάλγητ_198">, which is also metrically possible. The sense is, ‘<emph>fraught with</emph> heavy pain’ to <emph> us</emph>; the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλγος</quote> is not the bitter indignation felt by the Greeks. The word occurs only here: and <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρυαλγής</quote> is post-classical.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕστακεν_198">, ‘stands fixed’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1084">cp. 1084</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="vαὸς_ἀρωγοὶ_201">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, rendering service in it; Ajax addresses them as <quote xml:lang="grc">γένος ναΐας ἀρωγὸν τέχνας</quote> (356). The <title>Iliad</title> (2. 557) assigns twelve ships to Ajax. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γενεᾶς_202">: for the gen., cp. <ref n="Plat. Prot. 316B">Plat. <title>Prot.</title> 316B</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀπολλοδώρου υἱός, οἰκίας μεγάλης.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χθονίων_Ἐρεχθειδᾶν_202">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπὸ</quote> with ref. to descent, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 193"> <title>Ant.</title> 193</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παίδων τῶν ἀπ’ Οἰδίπου</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χθονίων_202"> here. (Cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 948"> <title>O. C.</title> 948</ref> n.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τηλόθεν_204"> instead of <quote xml:lang="grc"> τηλοῦ</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 315"> <title>Tr.</title> 315</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γέννημα τῶν ἐκεῖθεν</quote> (n.). It goes with <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ..οἴκου</quote>, not with <quote xml:lang="grc">κηδόμενοι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠμοκρατὴς_205"> denotes the rugged, massive, untamed strength of Ajax, and is meant to suggest a contrast with his present affliction; so 548 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠμοῖς..νόμοις</quote>, 885 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠμόθυμος</quote>, 931 <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὠμόφρων</quote>. (The word was absurdly taken by some to mean, ‘with strong shoulders,’—as the <title>Iliad</title> mentions his <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρέας ὤμους</quote>, 3. 227.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θολερῷ_206"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">θολός, ὁ</quote>, mud), ‘turbid,’ with ref. to his clouded mind: cp. <ref n="Hdt. 4. 53"> Her. 4. 53</ref>(of a river) <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥέει τε καθαρὸς παρὰ θολεροῖσι</quote>. So <ref n="Aesch. PB 885">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 885</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θολεροὶ δὲ λόγοι παίουδ’ εἰκῇ | στυγνῆς πρὸς κύμασιν ἄτης</quote>,—words turbid with passion.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χειμῶνι_206">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1194">Soph. <title> Ph.</title> 1194</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλύοντα χειμερίῳ | λύπᾳ</quote> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1460 <quote xml:lang="grc"> χειμαζομένῳ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νοσήσας_206">, ‘stricken’: this aor., in the ‘ingressive’ sense (‘<emph>fell</emph> ill’), is frequent in Attic: <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> <ref n="Thuc. 1. 138">Thuc. 1. 138</ref>§ 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">νοσήσας τελευτᾷ τὸν βίον</quote>: Plat. <title> Tim.</title>p. 84 C <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν..νοσήσῃ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_ἡμερίας_208">; ‘And what heaviness (heavy trouble) has the past night <emph>received in exchange</emph> for the (already grievous) fortune of the day?’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνήλλακται_208"> in a midd. sense; cp. Diod. frag. 60 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγένετο βασίλισσα ἰδιωτικῆς ἑστίας ἐξηλλαγμένη ἡγεμονίαν</quote>. The fact that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤλλαγμαι</quote> has more often a passive sense in Attic is quite compatible with such an exceptional use; thus Antiphon can say, <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν πλοῦν πεποιημένος</quote> (<ref n="Antiph. 5.21">or. 5 § 21</ref>), and <quote xml:lang="grc">τετιμωρημένος ἑαυτόν</quote> ( <quote xml:lang="grc">β. β.</quote> § 8). But it is more doubtful whether such a notion as <quote xml:lang="grc">μοίρας, πράξεως</quote>, or <quote xml:lang="grc"> καταστάσεως</quote> can here be supplied with <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἡμερίας</quote>. The parallels adduced are such as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ἑῴα, ἡ ἑωθινή, ἡ ὀψία, ἡ πρωΐα, τὴν θερείην</quote> (‘in summer,’ <ref n="Hdt. 1. 189"> Her. 1. 189</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν χειμερινήν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">id.</foreign> 1. 202). There was indeed a tendency in Greek idiom to make substantives out of fem. adjectives; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> to use the fem. adj. alone, whenever the subst. (such as <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆ, ὁδός, ὥρα, μοῖρα, δίκη</quote>) could readily be understood. And that tendency must be considered here.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἠρεμίας_208">, ‘stillness,’ though possible, is very feeble. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐμαρίας_208"> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">εὐμαρείας</quote>), which Nauck adopts, is directly contrary to the sense; for, even <emph>before</emph> the dread rumour arose, the Chorus had been disquieted by the long seclusion and inaction of Ajax (194 f.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμμορίας_208">, without some further definition (such as <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς πρὶν</quote>), would be too vague. And the words </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νὺξ_ἥδε_208"> suggest that there was some mention of <emph>day.</emph> On the whole, the traditional reading, though difficult, is less open to objection than any remedy which has been proposed.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φρυγίου_Τελεύταντος_210">. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 331">Cp. 331</ref>: 488. Similar examples confirm this reading: fr. 796 <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀλφεσίβοιαν ἣν ὁ γεννήσας πατήρ</quote> (it is improbable that Sophocles wrote <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀλφησίβοιαν</quote> ): <ref n="Aesch. Seven 488">Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 488</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἱππομέδοντος σχῆμα</quote>: <title>Suppl.</title> 889 <quote xml:lang="grc">Παρθενοπαῖος, εἶδος ἐξοχώτατος</quote>. ( <ref n="Aesch. Seven 547">Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 547</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">Παρθενοπαῖος Ἀρκάς</quote>, is rejected by many critics.) Indeed, such license was not strictly confined to proper names, to judge by <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 1049">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 1049</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φαιοχίτωνες</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέχος_211">, concubine, <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὁμευνέτις</quote> (501): being <quote xml:lang="grc">δουριάλωτος</quote>, she is <quote xml:lang="grc">δούλη</quote> (489). Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 360"> <title>Tr.</title> 360</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρύφιον ὡς ἔχοι λέχος</quote> (Iolè).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σε_ἀνέχει_211">: lit., ‘having conceived a love for thee, he <emph>upholds</emph> thee,’—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘he is constant in his affection for thee’: so <ref n="Eur. Hec. 123">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 123</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βάκχης ἀνέχων λέκτρ’ Ἀγαμέμνων</quote>, ‘constant to’ her bed. (In <ref n="Soph. OC 674">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 674</ref>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν οἰνῶπ’ ἀνέχουσα κισσὸν</quote> is the common reading, we should probably read <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν οἰνωπὸν ἔχουσα κισσόν</quote>.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπείποις_213">, ‘hint,’ ‘give a clue’: they do not yet surmise, from her words in 205—207, with what terrible fulness of detail she can speak. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγω_214">, subjunct.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανάτῳ_ἴσον_214">: <ref n="Soph. OC 529"> <title>O. C.</title> 529</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θάνατος μὲν τάδ’ ἀκούειν</quote>. In the <title>Creusa</title>, fr. 332, Sophocles used <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰσοθάνατον</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ πάνυ ἀνεκτόν</quote>, acc. to Pollux 6. 174. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μανίᾳ_γὰρ_216">: notice the <quote xml:lang="grc">γάρ</quote> in two successive clauses ( <ref n="Eur. El. 180"> <title>El.</title> 180</ref> n.): here it prefaces the statement ( <ref n="Soph. OT 277"> <title>O. T.</title> 277</ref> n.).— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμὶν_216">, ethic dat.: <ref n="Soph. El. 272."> <title>El.</title> 272.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νύκτερος_216">, adverbial: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 930">cp. 930</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάννυχα καὶ φαέθοντ’ ἀνεστέναζες</quote>. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.497"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 497</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠερίη δ’ ἀνέβη</quote>. The word is irregularly placed, as if the speaker had meant to designate Ajax by <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ κλεινὸς</quote> only, and had then added <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴας</quote>: for similar irregularities, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 693"> <title>El.</title> 693</ref> f., n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπελωβήθη_216">, a somewhat rare pass. aor.: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 330"> <title>Ph.</title> 330</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξελωβήθην</quote> : <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 473c">Plat. <title>Gorg.</title> 473 C</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λώβας..λωβηθείς</quote> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιαῦτ_218">, introducing the ground for the statement; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 164">cp. 164</ref> n.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἱμοβαφῆ_218">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 95">cp. 95</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔβαψας ἔγχος εὖ..;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρηστήρια_218">, with tragic pathos, since the word denoted holy sacrifices to the gods (properly, before consulting an oracle): <ref n="Aesch. Seven 230">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 230</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σφάγια καὶ χρηστήρια | θεοῖσιν ἔρδειν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 645">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 645</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παιᾶνα τόνδ’ Ερινύων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνέρος_ἀγγελίαν_221">: for the objective gen., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 998">cp. 998</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 11"> <title>Ant.</title> 11</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μῦθος.. φίλων</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἴθονος_221">, ‘fiery’; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1088">cp. 1088</ref>: <ref n="Aesch. Seven 448">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 448</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴθων..λῆμα</quote>: in v. 147 the word is applied to a bright sword. This inflexion (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴθωνος</quote>) occurs elsewhere only in <ref n="Hes. WD 361">Hes. <title>Op.</title> 361</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴθονα λιμόν</quote> (Bergk's correction of the MS. <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴθοπα</quote>), a reading which is made certain by <cit> <bibl n="Aeschin. 3.184">Aeschin. or. 3 § 184</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λιμόν τ’ αἴθωνα κρατερόν τ’ ἐπάγοντες Ἄρηα</quote> </cit>, and <cit> <bibl n="Call. Cer. 68">Callim. <title>Hymn. Cer.</title> 68</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμβαλε λιμόν, | αἴθωνα, κρατερόν</quote> </cit>: where the fig. sense of the epithet is ‘fierce.’</gloss>

data.quote: λιμόν τ’ αἴθωνα κρατερόν τ’ ἐπάγοντες Ἄρηα

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἴθοπος_221"> is impossible here, as in the verse of Hesiod; it could refer only to complexion. Cp. Eustathius p. 862. 10 <quote xml:lang="grc">φέρεται αἴθων βοῦς καὶ σίδηρος καὶ ἄνθρωπος καὶ λέων· αἴθοψ δὲ οὐδεὶς αὐτῶν λέγοιτ’ ἄν, ἀλλὰ τοὔνομα οἴνῳ μέλανι ἐπιτίθεται</quote>. The variant was doubtless due, in both passages, to the rarity, for <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴθων</quote>, of the inflexion with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ο_221">: which is illustrated by the dat. pl. <quote xml:lang="grc">νήφοσι</quote> in Theognis 481, and by such alternative forms of the gen. as <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴσονος, Ἀκταίονος</quote>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄτλατον_φευκτάν_221">, unendurable, <emph>and yet</emph> one from which there is no escape: for <quote xml:lang="grc"> οὐδέ</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ οὐ</quote>, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 132"> <title>El.</title> 132</ref>, <ref n="Eur. El. 1034."> El. 1034.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῶν_Δαναῶν_225"> are clearly not the Greek <emph>chiefs</emph> (<quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ μεγάλοι βασιλῆς</quote>, 189), but the Greek army at large. It is the popular fury that the Salaminians are now thinking of: in 228 <quote xml:lang="grc"> περίφαντος..θανεῖται</quote> alludes to public stoning, the <quote xml:lang="grc">λιθόλευστον Ἄρη</quote> of v. 253.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλῃζομέναν_225">, noised abroad by them: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 659"> <title>Tr.</title> 659</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλῄζεται θυτήρ</quote>, he is <emph>rumoured</emph> to be sacrificing; and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1268 <quote xml:lang="grc">κλῃζόμενοι | πατέρες</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_μῦθος_226">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 173">cp. 173</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ μεγάλα φάτις</quote> (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀέξει_226">, <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὔξει</foreign>, increases by diffusing it. (Not, ‘exaggerates.’) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περίφαντος_228">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1311">cp. 1311</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανεῖν προδήλως</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παραπλάκτῳ_229">, frantic: <ref n="Eur. Her. 935">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 935</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γέλωτι παραπεπληγμένῳ</quote>. The adj. is more usually <quote xml:lang="grc">παραπλήξ</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 40">Cp. 40</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσλόγιστον..χέρα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συγκατακτὰς_229">, slain in a confused heap, cattle and men together. (In <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1089">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1089</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">συγκατέκτανον</quote>=‘<emph>helped</emph> to slay.’) For the nonthematic aor., cp. <ref n="Soph.
