Trach. 38">Soph. <title> Tr.</title> 38</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔκτα</quote> (n.).— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κελαινοῖς_229"> here suggests both the dark, gleaming metal, and the dark stains of blood upon it. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 856">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 856</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κελαινὰ λόγχα</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξίφεσιν_230">, poet. plur.: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 4">Pind. <title>P.</title> 4. 242</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Φρίξου μάχαιραι</quote> </cit> : <ref n="Eur. Ion 192">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 192</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅρπαις</quote> (the scimitar of Perseus). The dat. <quote xml:lang="grc">ξίφεσιν</quote>, following <quote xml:lang="grc">χερί</quote>, defines the instrument used (slain by the hand with the sword): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 310">cp. 310</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄνυξι συλλαβὼν χερί</quote>. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hel. 373">Eur. <title>Helen.</title> 373</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄνυχι..γένυν | ἔδευσε φοινίαισι πλαγαῖς</quote> </cit> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱππονώμας_230">, ‘guiding horses,’ refers to <emph> riding</emph> in both the other places where it occurs ( <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 1399">Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 1399</ref>, of Hippolytus; <title>Nub.</title> 571, of Poseidon Hippius). Here, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βοτῆρας_230">, closely following </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βοτά_230">, must mean the herdsmen who tended the sheep and oxen (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις</quote>, 27). It would be forced, then, to suppose that <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἱππονώμας</quote> means ‘<emph>tending</emph> horses,’—with ref. to the horses of the Greeks on the <quote xml:lang="grc">λειμὼν ἱππομανής</quote> (143 f.). That would be as if one said, ‘the cattle, and their herdsmen, who <emph>also</emph> tended horses.’ Herdsmen in charge of great flocks and herds, on a wide plain, and near a watchful foe, might well be mounted. It is no objection— and least of all, in an Attic tragedy— that the Homeric <emph>warrior</emph> does not ride. —The reading <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱππονώμας</quote>, instead of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱππονόμους_230"> (‘horse-feeding’), is made certain by metre (v. 245), and is confirmed by the first hand in L (cr. n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρα_233">, ‘then,’ marks her new perception: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 927">cp. 927</ref>, 934, 1026: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1172"> <title>Tr.</title> 1172</ref>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤλυθε_233">. This form, not used by Aesch. , occurs only here in Soph. ; Eur. has it not only in lyrics ( <ref n="Eur. Orest. 813">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 813</ref>, etc.), but also in dialogue ( <ref n="Eur. El. 598">Eur. <title>El.</title> 598</ref> , <ref n="Eur. Tro. 374">Eur. <title>Tro.</title> 374</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_235"> (neut.), instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἧς</quote>, since </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποίμνην_235"> is a ‘noun of multitude’; cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1070"> <title>O. C.</title> 1070</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄμβασις, οἳ κ.τ.λ.</quote> (n.). Then </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὴν_μὲν_235"> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποίμνην</quote>) follows <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν</quote>, as it might have followed <quote xml:lang="grc">ἧς</quote>: cp. <ref n="Thuc. 1. 2">Thuc. 1. 2</ref>§ 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς γῆς ἡ ἀρίστη</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 5 § 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν πλεῖστον τοῦ βίου</quote>. Finally, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_δὲ_235"> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">βοτὰ</quote>) refers to <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν</quote>.—The antithesis to <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν <emph>μὲν</emph> </quote> is given by <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ <emph>δέ</emph> </quote>, not (as some have thought) by <quote xml:lang="grc">δύο <emph>δ’</emph> </quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔσω_235">, ‘within the house,’ refers to all the incidents that followed his arrival (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἤλυθε</quote>). Schneidewin wrongly joins </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔσω_σφάζε_235"> (‘stach tot’), comparing <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1343">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1343</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πέπληγμαι καιρίαν πληγὴν ἔσω</quote>. But <quote xml:lang="grc">σφάζε</quote> denotes ‘cutting the throat,’ not ‘stabbing’; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 298">cp. 298</ref>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπὶ_γαίας_235">, where they stood upon the floor; as distinguished from those animals which he <emph>caught up</emph> and rent asunder.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλευροκοπῶν_235">, slashing at their sides with his sword: a compound like <quote xml:lang="grc">θαλαττοκοπεῖν</quote> ( <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 830">Ar. <title>Eq.</title> 830</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">μετεωροκοπεῖν</quote> ( <ref n="Aristoph. Peace 92"> Ar. <title>Pax</title> 92</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀργίποδας_237">: for the rt. ARG, denoting ‘brightness,’ and its derivatives, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 670"> <title>O. C.</title> 670</ref> n. As Ajax purposed to <emph>flog</emph> Odysseus (110), the ram which suffers that fate here might naturally be identified with him. The first ram, which is beheaded at once, might then represent Agamemnon; and Menelaüs would here be ignored. On this view, however, there is a discrepancy with verses 97—110, since both the Atreidae are there supposed to be dead, while Odysseus has still to suffer. Here one ram (Agamemnon) is slain, and the other (Odysseus) flogged, in rapid succession.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεφαλὴν_ἄκραν_238">. He first shears off the head; then, still holding it, while the carcass drops to the ground, cuts off the end of the tongue; and next hurls both head and tongue from him. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκρα γλῶσσα</quote> can mean the extremity, the tip, of the tongue, as in <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 9">Theocr. 9. 30</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ γλώσσας ἄκρας</quote> </cit>: so in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 748"> <title>Ph.</title> 748</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκρον πόδα</quote> is the heel. It could not mean, ‘the tongue from the roots,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">γλῶσσαν πρυμνήν</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.292"> <title>Il.</title> 5. 292</ref>).—It was customary to cut out the tongues of animals slain for sacrifice, and to offer them separately ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 3.332"> <title>Od.</title> 3. 332</ref>: <ref n="Aristoph. Peace 1060">Ar. <title> Pax</title> 1060</ref>). But I doubt whether there is any reference here to the sacrificial custom; the act of Ajax rather expresses merely fierce hatred of a slanderer. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥιπτεῖ_239"> has the support of the MSS., not only here, but also in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 131"> <title>Ant.</title> 131</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 780."> <title>Tr.</title> 780.</ref>In the latter place, it is confirmed by Athenaeus p. 65 F, for he has <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιπτοῦντα</quote> in his paraphrase. <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιπτεῖν</quote>, used only in pres. and impf., was current in Attic ( <ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 507"> Ar. <title>Eccl.</title> 507</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιπτεῖτε χλαίνας</quote>). It has good authority in <ref n="Thuc. 5. 103">Thuc. 5. 103</ref>§ 1 (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναρριπτοῦσι</quote>), and <title> Cyneg.</title> 9. 20 (<quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιπτοῦσι</quote>). In Tragedy it is nowhere required by metre; and Elmsley (on <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 150">Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 150</ref>) supposes that the tragic poets used only <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥίπτω</quote>. No difference of sense between <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιπτέω</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥίπτω</quote> can be clearly shown; though it has been fancied that <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιπτέω</quote> implies the frequency or vehemence of the act (<foreign xml:lang="lat">iacto</foreign> as compared with <foreign xml:lang="lat">iacio</foreign>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρθὸν_δήσας_239">: <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, making the animal stand on its hind legs, with its forefeet lashed <emph>up</emph> to the pillar—as if they were the hands of a human prisoner.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κίονι_239">, lit., ‘<emph>at</emph> a pillar,’ a dat. of place (cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 174"> <title>El.</title> 174</ref> n.); not, ‘<emph>to</emph> a pillar’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς κίονα</quote>, <ref n="Eur. El. 108"> El. 108</ref> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱπποδέτην_ῥυτῆρα_241">, a leathern strap or thong, belonging to the harness of a horse,—such as the reins of a bridle ( <ref n="Soph. OC 900"> <title>O. C.</title> 900</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σπεύδειν ἀπὸ ῥυτῆρος</quote>), or driving-reins ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 16.475"> <title>Il.</title> 16. 475</ref>, where see Leaf). Hesiod <title> Scut.</title> 308 <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥυτὰ χαλαίνοντες</quote>, ‘slackening the reins.’ Ajax makes a <quote xml:lang="grc">διπλῆ μάστιξ</quote>, a whip with two thongs, by doubling the strap. Cp. <ref n="Aeschin. 2.157">Aeschin. or. 2 § 157</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λαβὼν ῥυτῆρα μαστιγοίην αἰχμάλωτον</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λιγυρᾷ_242">, Homeric: <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.532"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 532</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μάστιγι λιγυρῇ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὰ_ῥήμαθ_243">, like <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀνειδίζων ὀνείδη</quote>: see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 759"> <title>Ant.</title> 759</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεννάσεις.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δαίμων_243">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1258"> <title>O. T.</title> 1258</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λυσσῶντι δ’ αὐτῷ δαιμόνων δείκνυσί τις· | οὐδεὶς γὰρ ἀνδρῶν οἳ παρῆμεν ἐγγύθεν</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤδη_κρᾶτα_245">. The reading of the best MSS., both here and in the strophe (221 f.), can be retained, if in the strophe we make the slight change of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνδρὸς_245"> to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνέρος_245">. If, on the other hand, we strike out </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοι_245"> here, then we must also change </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρᾶτα_245"> to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάρα_245">, or else, keeping <quote xml:lang="grc">κρᾶτα</quote>, change </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐδήλωσας_245"> in 221 to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔδειξας_245"> or </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔφηνας_245">. (The impf. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐδήλους_245"> would be unsuitable.) Here </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοι_245_2"> is quite in place, as introducing the comment. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤτοι_245">, as a correction of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤδη τοι</quote>, is doubly impro bable, since <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤδη</quote> is emphatic, and <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἤτοι</quote> would be somewhat weak. See Appendix.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρᾶτα_κρυψάμενον_245">, in token of grief and shame. Plat. <title>Phaedo</title>p. 117 C <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγκαλυψάμενος ἀπέκλαιον ἐμαυτόν</quote>: <ref n="Aeschin. 2.111">Aeschin. or. 2 § 111</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τά γε δὴ καταγέλαστα παντελῶς, ἐφ’ οἷς οἱ συμπρέσβεις ἐνεκαλύψαντο</quote>. <cit> <bibl n="Liv. 4.12">Liv. 4. 12</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">Multi ex plebe spe amissa..capitibus obvolutis se in Tiberim praecipitaverunt.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
Multi ex plebe spe amissa..capitibus obvolutis
							se in Tiberim praecipitaverunt.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποδοῖν_ἀρέσθαι_245">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 481">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 481</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εὔκοσμον αἴρονται φυγήν</quote>: [Eur. ] <title> Rhes.</title> 54 (<quote xml:lang="grc">νυκτέρῳ πλάτῃ</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴρεσθαι φυγήν</quote>. The verb here means, ‘to take up,’ ‘betake oneself to’; not ‘to win,’ ‘secure’: see Appendix on 75. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλοπὰν_245">, cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1499"> Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1499</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξέκλεπτον ἐκ δόμων πόδα</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θοὸν_249">, properly the epithet of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰρεσίας_249">, is transferred to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζυγὸν_249"> (cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 794"> <title>Ant.</title> 794</ref> n.): <quote xml:lang="grc">ζυγὸν ἕζομαι</quote>, as <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 183">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 183</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σέλμα..ἡμένων</quote>, <ref n="Eur. Orest. 956">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 956</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρίποδα καθίζων</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναῒ_μεθεῖναι_249">, ‘to let the ship go,’— <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡνίας</quote>, or the like, being understood. Cp. Eur. fr. 779 <quote xml:lang="grc">κρούσας δὲ πλευρὰ πτεροφόρων ὀχημάτων | μεθῆκεν</quote> (‘he let his horses go’)<quote xml:lang="grc">· αἱ δ’ ἔπταντ’ ἐπ’ αἰθέρος πτυχάς</quote>. The elliptical use of <quote xml:lang="grc">μεθιέναι</quote>, with dat., in this sense, seems to be rare: but it is parallel with that of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφιέναι</quote> as=<foreign xml:lang="lat">indulgere</foreign> (<foreign xml:lang="lat"> e.g.</foreign> <ref n="Plat. Rep. 388E">Plat. <title>Rep.</title> 388E</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν τις ἐφιῇ..γέλωτι</quote>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοίας_251">: 164 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρέσσουσιν_251">, ‘ply,’—properly, to ply the oar; then, to put anything in lively motion; <ref n="Soph. Ant. 158"> <title>Ant.</title> 158</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μῆτιν ἐρέσσων</quote>, ‘revolving’ thoughts in the mind. Cp. the elegiac poet Dionysius <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Athen. p. 669 A <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰρεσίῃ γλώσσης ἀποπέμψομεν εἰς μέγαν αἶνον</quote> (‘by our <emph>swift strains</emph> will we waft him to the haven of fame’).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δικρατεῖς_Ἀτρεῖδαι_251">, the two princely Atreidae: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 390">cp. 390</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τούς τε δισσάρχας..βασιλῆς</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OC 1055"> <title>O. C.</title> 1055</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς διστόλους | ...ἀδελφὰς</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the two journeying sisters; and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 17 n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεφόβημαι_252">: 139 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λιθόλευστον_Ἄρη_252">, a violent death by stoning; cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 36"> <title>Ant.</title> 36</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> φόνον..δημόλευστον</quote>. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1616">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1616</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δημορριφεῖς..λευσίμους ἀράς</quote>. When, as here, <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄρης</quote> stands for the notion of a ‘violent death,’ it always, of course, implies an onslaught; as in <ref n="Soph. OC 1679">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1679</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτῳ μήτ’ Ἄρης | μήτε πόντος ἀντέκυρσεν</quote> (death in battle, or by drowning): <ref n="Aesch. PB 860">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 860</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θηλυκτόνῳ | Ἄρει δαμέντων</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, by the onslaught of murderous women. (In <ref n="Pind. P. 11">Pind. <title>P.</title> 11. 36</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χρονίῳ σὺν Ἄρει</quote> is best taken, with Gildersleeve, as =‘by tardy help of Ares.’) The initial A is long here (answering to the penult. of <quote xml:lang="grc">συγκατακτὰς</quote> in 230), as in 614, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 139">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 139</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 96.">Soph. <title>El.</title> 96.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεφόβημαι_252_2">, but is felt also as a cognate acc. to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυναλγεῖν_252"> (like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλγος ἀλγῶ</quote>), and could be, further, an acc. of the inner object with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυπείς_252"> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 24.420"> <title>Il.</title> 24. 420</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕλκεα... ὅσσ’ ἐτύπη</quote>): it is one of those cumulative constructions which Greek idiom (esp. in poetry) favours. Note that a simple inf. after <quote xml:lang="grc">φοβοῦμαι</quote> usu. denotes what one is afraid <emph>to do</emph> ( <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 46">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 46</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοβοῦμαι δ’ ἔπος τόδ’ ἐκβαλεῖν</quote>), but can also denote what one fears <emph>to suffer</emph>: Plat. <title>Phaedo</title>p. 68 E <quote xml:lang="grc">φοβούμενοι..ἡδονῶν στερηθῆναι</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἶσ_ἄπλατος_252">, a fate such that no one can <emph> approach</emph> him, or stand at his side, without being involved in his doom. The Nemean lion is <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄπλατον θρέμμα</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1093."> <title>Tr.</title> 1093.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαμπρᾶς_στεροπῆς_257"> go with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λήγει_257">, not with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾄξας_257">: they stand first, because they express the foremost thought,—viz., that the violence of his frenzy is past. ‘Attended by the lightning-flash no more, the storm in his soul is subsiding, after a sharp outburst (<quote xml:lang="grc">ᾄξας ὀξύς</quote>), like the wind of the south.’ A key to these much-discussed verses may be found, I think, in a passage which seems to have been overlooked. The Greeks had observed that, when the <quote xml:lang="grc">Νότος</quote> was a stormy wind, it was accompanied by clouds; but, when gentler, by a clear sky: <title> Problem.</title> 26. 20 (p. 942 <emph>a</emph> 34) <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ νότος, ὅταν μὲν ἐλάττων ᾖ, αἴθριός ἐστιν, ὅταν δὲ μέγας, νεφώδης</quote>. The mood of Ajax is now once more becoming <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴθριος</quote>, like the milder south-wind; lately it was like a fierce storm from the south, and <quote xml:lang="grc">νεφώδης</quote>, dark with the clouds from which the <quote xml:lang="grc">στεροπή</quote> of his madness was flashing. Compare the description of the mad Ajax by Arctînus in the <title> Iliupersis</title> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Eustath. p. 859. 47), <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄμματά τ’ ἀστράπτοντα βαρυνόμενόν τε νόημα</quote>.— For other views of this passage, and the attempts to amend it, see Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἰκεῖα_πάθη_260">, those which one brings on himself: so <ref n="Eur. El. 215"> <title>El.</title> 215</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκείας εἰς ἄτας | ἐμπίπτεις.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παραπράξαντος_260">, having acted ‘at the side,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘having had a hand in the matter,’—‘having contributed to the result.’ This sense nowhere else belongs to <quote xml:lang="grc">παραπράσσω</quote> (which in <ref n="Hdt. 5. 45"> Her. 5. 45</ref> means ‘to do something beyond’ one's proper task, and in <ref n="Plut. Agis 16">Plut. <title>Agis</title> 16</ref>‘to exact unjustly’); but for the force of the prep., cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">παραίτιος</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 910">Aesch. <title> Ch.</title> 910</ref>, etc.), as=‘partly the cause.’— Not, ‘having done <emph> amiss</emph>’ (=<quote xml:lang="grc">παραβάντος</quote>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑποτείνει_260">: lit., ‘lays to’ (or ‘beneath’) the mind: [Dem. ] or. 13 § 19 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς ἐλπίδας ὑμῖν ὑποτείνων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέπαυται_263">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ Αἴας τῆς νόσου</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 279">cp. 279</ref>. The subject to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐτυχεῖν_263"> is rather <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμᾶς</quote> than <quote xml:lang="grc"> αὐτόν</quote>: the thought is, <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκῶ ὅτι εὐτυχοῖμεν ἄν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 87"> <title>O. T.</title> 87</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγω γὰρ καὶ τὰ δύσφοῤ, εἰ τύχοι | κατ’ ὀρθὸν ἐξελθόντα, πάντ’ ἂν εὐτυχεῖν</quote>. In the omission of the subject to the inf., as in <quote xml:lang="grc"> πέπαυται</quote> and in <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ κακοῦ</quote>, there is a shade of reticence which suits the recent sense of horror in the speaker's mind.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρούδου_γὰρ_263"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: the gen. is not absol., but depends on </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγος_263">. Cp. fr. 346 <quote xml:lang="grc">μύχθου γὰρ οὐδεὶς τοῦ παρελθόντος λόγος</quote>. Their thought is that, if he is himself again, his value to the Greeks will plead for pardon of his frenzy. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πότερα_265"> is used, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">πότερον</quote>, to avoid an anapaest, as in 460, and <ref n="Soph. OC 333."> <title>O. C.</title> 333.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοινὸς_κοινοῖσι_267"> mean strictly, ‘a partner among partners,’ =<quote xml:lang="grc">κοινωνὸς ἐν κοινωνοῖς</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 239"> <title>O. T.</title> 239</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήτ’ ἐν θεῶν εὐχαῖσι μήτε θύμασιν | κοινὸν ποεῖσθαι</quote>. Similarly kinsfolk can be termed <quote xml:lang="grc">κοινοί</quote>, as sharers in a common lineage ( <ref n="Soph. OT 261"> <title>O. T.</title> 261</ref> n.). The iteration, <quote xml:lang="grc">κοινὸς ἐν κοινοῖς</quote>, emphasises the idea of mutual sympathy: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 467">cp. 467</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μόνος μόνοις</quote> (and 1283 <quote xml:lang="grc">μόνος μόνου</quote>), 620 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄφιλα παρ’ ἀφίλοις</quote>, and n. on <ref n="Soph. Trach. 613."> <title>Tr.</title> 613.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_διπλάζον_268">, intrans., ‘that which is double’ (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰσάζω</quote>, ‘to be equal’): but the verb is trans. in Andoc. or. 4 § 11 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν φόρον..διπλάσειεν</quote>, unless we should there read <quote xml:lang="grc">διπλασιάσειεν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_νοσοῦντος_269"> (gen. abs.) is an easy and specious conjecture, yet </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_νοσοῦντες_269"> is better; because (1) it gives a rhetorical antithesis to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτώμεσθα</quote> which suits her point; and (2) it suggests the identity of their interest with that of Ajax. The figurative sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">νοσεῖν</quote> is often found in juxtaposition with the literal, as in <ref n="Soph. OT 60"> <title>O. T.</title> 60</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νοσεῖτε πάντες, καὶ νοσοῦντες, ὡς ἐγὼ | οὐκ ἔστιν ὑμῶν ὅστις ἐξ ἴσου νοσεῖ</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτώμεσθα_269">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> we are worse off than before: the word is a forcible one (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 384">cp. 384</ref>), but occurs elsewhere also where the sense is only comparative: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 17"> <title>Ant.</title> 17</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’ εὐτυχοῦσα μᾶλλον οὔτ’ ἀτωμένη</quote>: cp. <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 314. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πῶς_ὅπως_270">. The language here, to which groundless exception has been taken (cr. n.), expresses the musing wonder of simple minds. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἷσιν_κακοῖς_272">=<quote xml:lang="grc">κακοῖς ἐν οἷς εἴχετο</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1144">cp. 1144</ref>: <ref n="Hdt. 9. 37"> Her. 9. 37</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τούτῳ τῷ κακῷ ἐχόμενος</quote>. The antecedent <quote xml:lang="grc">κακοῖς</quote> is drawn into the relative clause, though here its case is not thereby affected: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 404"> <title>Ant.</title> 404</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θάπτουσαν ὃν σὺ τὸν νεκρὸν | ἀπεῖπας</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονοῦντας_272"> is far better than the <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βλέποντας_272">: it hints what is meant by the vague </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοῖς_272"> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀνέπνευσε_274">: after the actual cessation (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔληξε_274">), a brief space is still needed to permit <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναπνοή</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.382"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 382</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνέπνευσαν κακότητος</quote>: and n. on <ref n="Soph. OC 1113"> <title>O. C.</title> 1113</ref> f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεῖνος_275">, we might have looked for <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτός</quote>: but the former has been preferred, because it better marks the antithesis between Ajax and his friends.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶς_275">, adverbial: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 386"> <title>Ph.</title> 386</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόλις γάρ ἐστι πᾶσα τῶν ἡγουμένων.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλήλαται_275">: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1045"> <title>Tr.</title> 1045</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">συμφορὰς</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">οἵαις.. ἐλαύνεται</quote> (n.). For the emphatic perf., cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 64."> <title>El.</title> 64.</ref>Here it expresses that complete prostration has <emph>at once</emph> followed the return of sanity: cp. Plat. <title>Phaedo</title>p. 80 D <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ δὲ ψυχὴ..ἀπαλλαττομένη τοῦ σώματος εὐθὺς διαπεφύσηται καὶ ἀπόλωλεν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἆῤ_277">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρ’ οὐ;</quote> <ref n="Soph. OT 822"> <title>O. T.</title> 822</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρ’ ἔφυν κακός;</quote> <ref n="Soph. El. 614."> <title>El.</title> 614.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὶς_τός_277">=<quote xml:lang="grc">διπλᾶ</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.213"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 213</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρὶς τόσσα..δῶρα</quote>: <ref n="Eur. El. 1092">Eur. <title>El.</title> 1092</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δὶς τόσως</quote> (‘in double measure’).— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_ἁπλῶν_277">: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 619">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 619</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">χάρις</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἁπλῆς διπλῆ</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέδοικα_ἥκῃ_278">. Though </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥκει_278"> is tenable (‘I fear that it certainly has come’), </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥκῃ_278"> seems better, since there is still a real uncertainty and anxiety in their minds. See on <ref n="Eur. El. 580."> <title>El.</title> 580.</ref>(</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥκοι_278">, which was the common reading, is of course impossible here.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πῶς_γάρ_278">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλως ἔχει;</quote> Normally, <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς γάρ</quote> follows a negative statement, as in <ref n="Eur. El. 911"> <title>El.</title> 911</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ αὖ σύ· πῶς γάρ;</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἔδρασας</quote>): while <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς γὰρ οὔ</quote> follows an affirmative, as <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1307 <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶσθα μὲν τἀνθένδε, πῶς γὰρ οὔ;</quote> The use of <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς γάρ</quote> here is thus peculiar, though the sense is clear.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_πεπαυμένος_278"> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The fact that despair has succeeded to frenzy argues that he is under the spell of some angry god. When the malady passed away, his mind ought to have recovered a healthy tone. They had already hinted at a <quote xml:lang="grc">θεία νόσος</quote> as a possibility (186).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδέν_τι_278">: <ref n="Eur. Andr. 1234">Eur. <title> Andr.</title> 1234</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδέν τι λίαν</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Alc. 522">Eur. <title>Alc.</title> 522</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέν τι μᾶλλον οἶδα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἐχόντων_281"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> : <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς</quote> marks the point of view to be taken: the gen. abs. presents the state of the facts as the condition under which one's opinion must be formed. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. PB 760">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 760</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς τοίνυν ὄντων τῶνδέ σοι μαθεῖν πάρα</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Med. 1311">Eur. <title>Med.</title> 1311</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς οὐκέτ’ ὄντων σῶν τέκνων φρόντιζε δή</quote> . <ref n="Thuc. 7. 15">Thuc. 7. 15</ref>§ 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς..τῶν στρατιωτῶν..μὴ μεμπτῶν γεγενημένων οὕτω τὴν γνώμην ἔχετε</quote>. <ref n="Xen. Anab. 1. 3. 6">Xen. <title>An.</title> 1. 3. 6</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐμοῦ οὖν ἰόντος ὅπῃ ἂν καὶ ὑμεῖς, οὕτω τὴν γνώμην ἔχετε</quote>. See also below, <ref target="cl904">904</ref>, <ref target="cl981">981</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_γάρ_282">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">γάρ</quote> in question, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 161"> <title>Ph.</title> 161</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 327"> Ph. 327</ref> , <ref n="Soph. Phil. 651."> Ph. 651.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσέπτατο_282">, as if winged to its aim by the god; <ref n="Aesch. PB 644">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 644</ref>(the heaven-sent trouble) <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅθεν μοι σχετλίᾳ προσέπτατο</quote> : <ref n="Eur. Alc. 420">Eur. <title>Alc.</title> 420</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐκ ἄφνω κακὸν τόδε | προσέπτατ’</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τύχας_282"> depends on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δήλωσον_282">. The change to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τύχαις_282">, dependent on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυναλγοῦσιν_282"> (cr. n.), is not only groundless, but injures the rhythm of the verse. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεῖνος_γὰρ_285">: here <quote xml:lang="grc">γὰρ</quote> merely prefaces the narrative ( <ref n="Soph. OT 277"> <title>O. T.</title> 277</ref> n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄκρας_νυκτός_285">, as the context shows, means here, ‘at dead of night.’ The only other instance of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκρος</quote> so used (natural though the use is) seems to be <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 2">Theocr. II. 36</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc"> <l>τυρὸς δ’ οὐ λείπει μ’ οὔτ’ ἐν θέρει οὔτ’ ἐν ὀπώρῃ </l> <l>οὐ χειμῶνος ἄκρω</l> </quote> </cit> (‘depth of winter’). Elsewhere <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκρα νύξ</quote> means either (1) the beginning of night, nightfall, as in Aratus 775 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκρῃ νυκτί</quote>: or (2) the verge between night and dawn, as <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 308 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκρόθι νυκτός</quote>. In Theophrastus <title>De Sign. Pluv.</title> 1. § 2 (p. 389 ed. Wimmer) the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκρόνυχοι ἀνατολαί</quote> of stars are their risings <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν ἅμα δυομένῳ ἀνατέλλῃ</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ ἄστρα</quote>), <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> soon after sunset, at nightfall. The sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκρέσπερος</quote> varies like that of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκρα νύξ</quote>. In Hippocr. <title>Epidem.</title> 7. 653 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκρέσπερος φρίκη</quote> is a chill at the <emph> approach</emph> of evening (as Galen <title>Exeg.</title> p. 418 explains); while in <ref n="Nic. Ther. 25">Nicander <title>Ther.</title> 25</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκρέσπερος</quote> is explained by the schol. as=‘at the <emph>close</emph> of evening,’ ‘at nightfall.’ The latter is the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκρᾳ σὺν ἑσπέρᾳ</quote> in Pindar <title>P.</title> 11. 10. [In <title>H. A.</title> 9. 34, p. 619 <emph> b</emph> 21, the words <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄχρις ἑσπερίου</quote> have been conjecturally changed to <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν ἀρχέσπερον</quote>, from Athen. p. 353 B; or to <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν ἀκρέσπερον</quote>: the sense required is ‘at nightfall.’] </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαμπτῆρες_286">. These were braziers, raised on stands, in which pine-wood was burned, at once for light and for heat ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 19.64"> <title>Od.</title> 19. 64</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φόως ἐμὲν ἠδὲ θέρεσθαι</quote>). <ref n="Hom. Od. 18.307"> <title>Od.</title> 18. 307</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτίκα λαμπτῆρας τρεῖς ἵστασαν ἐν μεγάροισιν</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄφρα φαείνοιεν· περὶ δὲ ξύλα κάγκανα θῆκαν</quote>, | .. <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ δαΐδας μετέμισγον</quote>. As Helbig remarks (<title>Das Hom. Epos</title> p. 78), the smoke thus caused explains why the Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">μέγαρον</quote> is sometimes called <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰθαλόεν</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.414"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 414</ref>, <ref n="Hom. Od. 22.239"> <title>Od.</title> 22. 239</ref>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔγχος_287">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 95">cp. 95</ref> .</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξόδους_ἕρπειν_287">: cp. <ref n="Thuc. 1. 15">Thuc. 1. 15</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκδήμους στρατείας .. οὐκ ἐξῄεσαν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κενάς_287">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, with no apparent object; cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1054"> <title>El.</title> 1054</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θηρᾶσθαι κενά</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄκλητος_289">, is defined by the two clauses in apposition with it, <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔθ’ ὑπ’ ἀγγέλων κληθείς, οὔτε σάλπιγγός του κλύων</quote>. Here the double </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτε_289"> is more emphatic than a double <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέ</quote>: with the latter, the sense would be, ‘uncalled, <emph>and not</emph> summoned,’ etc. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 391"> <title>Tr.</title> 391</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐμῶν ὑπ’ ἀγγέλων | ἀλλ’ αὐτόκλητος</quote>. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 838">Aesch. <title> Cho.</title> 838</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥκω μὲν οὐκ ἄκλητος, ἀλλ’ ὑπάγγελος</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφορμᾷς_289">, intrans., as in <ref n="Thuc. 4. 78">Thuc. 4. 78</ref>§ 5 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ τῆς Μελιτίας ἀφώρμησεν</quote> (‘he started’): </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεῖραν_289"> is cogn. acc.; cp. Plat. <title>Parm.</title>p. 135 D <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ὁρμὴ ἣν ὁρμᾷς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σάλπιγγος_289">: a non-Homeric trait; <ref target="cl17">see on 17</ref>. Cp. fr. 357 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀσάλπιγκτον ὥραν</quote> = <quote xml:lang="grc">μέσην νύκτα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶς_στρατός_289">. Cp. the phrases <quote xml:lang="grc">περὶ πρῶτον ὕπνον</quote> ( <ref n="Thuc. 2. 2">Thuc. 2. 2</ref>§ 1), <quote xml:lang="lat">nocte concubia</quote> ( <ref n="Liv. 25. 9">Liv. 25. 9</ref>§ 8). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑμνούμενα_292">, <quote xml:lang="lat"> decantata.</quote> Schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀεὶ θρυλούμενα ὑπὸ πάντων ἀνθρώπων καὶ κοινά</quote>. Plat. <title>Rep.</title>p. 549 D <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἄλλα δὴ ὅσα καὶ οἷα φιλοῦσιν αἱ γυναῖκες περὶ τῶν τοιούτων ὑμνεῖν</quote>. <title>Phorm.</title> 3. 2. 10 <quote xml:lang="lat">cantilenam eandem canis.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γυναιξὶ_292"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 476">Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 476</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γυναικὶ γὰρ σιγή τε καὶ τὸ σωφρονεῖν | κάλλιστον</quote>. In <ref n="Aristoph. Lys. 514">Ar. <title>Lys.</title> 514</ref> f. the Attic wife describes a like incident: <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δέ σοι ταῦτ’ ; ἦ δ’ ὃς ἂν ἁνήρ· | οὐ σιγήσει; κἀγὼ )σίγων.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κόσμον_292">: cp. fr. 61. 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">αἷς κόσμος ἡ σιγή τε καὶ τὰ παῦρ’ ἔπη</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθοῦς_294">, literally, ‘having perceived’ hismood.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐσσύθη_294">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσύθη</quote>, an epic license allowed in narrative. Cp. <title>Theog.</title> 183 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπέσσυθεν</quote> (3rd pl.). <quote xml:lang="grc"> συθείς</quote> occurs in <ref n="Soph. OC 119"> <title>O. C.</title> 119</ref>, and <quote xml:lang="grc">συθῶμεν</quote> <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1724: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσύθη</quote> in <title>Helen.</title> 1302 (lyr.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰς_πάθας_295">: briefly described by Athena, 55—60. The Chorus knew no details (230 f.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τύχας_295"> (cr. n.) is a weaker <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> The fem. <quote xml:lang="grc">πάθη</quote> occurs also in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 979"> <title>Ant.</title> 979</ref> and <ref n="Soph. OC 7."> <title>O. C.</title> 7.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κύνας_βοτῆρας_297">: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς ποιμενικοὺς κύνας· οὐ γὰρ ἀναιρεῖ κατὰ τὴν σκηνὴν ἄνθρωπον.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔερον_297"> is a certain emendation of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εύκερων_297">, which was doubtless due to a reminiscence of v. 64. (Bellermann, who retains <quote xml:lang="grc"> εὔκερων</quote>, refers it to the horns of the rams; while Prof. Campbell, who also keeps it, says, ‘The word describes all the cattle, small and great, excepting the bulls, which have been mentioned separately.’) The form <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔερος</quote> (Attic for <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔειρος</quote>). from <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶρος</quote>, ‘wool,’ occurs in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 675"> <title>Tr.</title> 675</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">οἰὸς εὐέρου</quote>) and is proved by metre in <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 121.">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 121.</ref>The mention of the shepherd's dogs is naturally followed by that of the sheep. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὐχένιζε_298"> (a word not elsewhere found in classical Greek) means here, ‘beheaded,’ by a blow on the <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐχήν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">cervix</foreign>), or hinder part of the neck. (Cp. <ref n="Pind. P. 2">Pind. <title>P.</title> 2. 93</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπαυχένιον .. ζυγόν</quote>.) The Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">δειρορομεῖν</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 21.89"> <title>Il.</title> 21. 89</ref>, etc.) may have suggested <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐχενίζειν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνω_τρέπων_298">, turning the heads of the victims upwards, so as to expose the throats to the sword. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.459"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 459</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐέρυσαν μὲν πρῶτα καὶ ἔσφαξαν καὶ ἔδειραν</quote>: where <quote xml:lang="grc"> αὐέρυσαν</quote> is now explained as = <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀv‐vέρυσαν</quote>, by assimilation for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀν‐vερ</quote>, ‘they <emph>lifted up</emph>’ the heads of the victims (not <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐ ἔρυσαν</quote>, ‘drew back,’ as it was formerly taken): see Leaf <foreign xml:lang="lat">ad loc.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔσφαζε_298"> (235), cut the <quote xml:lang="grc">σφαγή</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">iugulum.</foreign> The whole neck is <quote xml:lang="grc">τράχηλος</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">collum.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀρράχιζε_298">: <ref target="cl56">see on 56</ref> .</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεσμίους_298">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 239">cp. 239</ref> ff.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥστε_298">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς</quote>, an epic use frequent with Aesch. and Soph. : <ref n="Soph. OC 343">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 343</ref>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φῶτας_298">, here opposed, as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρας</quote> is in 64, to <quote xml:lang="grc"> θῆρας</quote>: sometimes <quote xml:lang="grc">φώς</quote> is opp. to <quote xml:lang="grc">θεός</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.98"> <title>Il.</title> 17. 98</ref> etc.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπᾴξας_301"> is not a certain reading here; but (despite the fact that the first hand in L wrote <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀπᾶξας</quote>) it has, on the whole, at least as good authority as </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπᾴξας_301">. The latter makes good sense enough, ‘rushing <emph>away</emph> from me’; but <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπᾴξας</quote>, expressing the sudden rush <emph>forward</emph>, as if towards something which had suddenly caught his attention, adds a picturesque touch which is absent from the other reading. For this sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπό</quote> in comp., cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπάγω</quote>, etc. The third possibility, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπᾴξας_301">, would properly denote a rush <emph>onwards</emph> in a direction which had already been taken; and is thus less fitting here.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκιᾷ_τινὶ_301">: Tecmessa, of course, followed Ajax to the door, but Athena was invisible to her: <ref target="cl15">see on 15</ref>. Ajax seemed to speak with some phantom,—some creature of his brain.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγους_ἀνέσπα_301">; the phrase denotes the abrupt, spasmodic manner in which his words were jerked forth. They were wild and incoherent (21—116). Cp. Plat. <title>Theaet.</title>p. 180 A <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ ἐκ φαρέτρας ῥηματίσκια αἰνιγματώδη ἀνασπῶντες ἀποτοξεύουσι</quote>. Menander <quote xml:lang="grc">*(παπιζομένης</quote> fr. 7 <quote xml:lang="grc">πόθεν τούτους ἀνεσπάκασιν οὗτοι τοὺς λόγους;</quote> <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 903">Ar. <title>Ran.</title> 903</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν δ’</quote> (Aeschylus) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνασπῶντ’ αὐτοπρέμνοις</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">‐ους</quote>?) | <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς λόγοισιν κ.τ.λ.</quote>, (where the idea is that of tearing up trees by the roots; but the use of <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀνασπᾶν</quote> in ref. to a bold style is suggestive). Eustathius p. 679. 61 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ μόνον ἐπὶ φυτῶν τὸ ἀνασπᾶν λέγεται, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἐπὶ ἀλαζονείας, ὡς δηλοῖ τὸ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ λόγους ἀνέσπα</quote> .</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀτρειδῶν_κάτα_301">: for <quote xml:lang="grc"> κατά</quote> placed after its case, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 969">cp. 969</ref> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφ_Ὀδυσσεῖ_303">: for <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀμφί</quote> with dat. in this sense, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 340">cp. 340</ref>, 684: <ref n="Eur. El. 1180"> <title>El.</title> 1180</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφ’ ἐμοὶ στένεις.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συντιθεὶς_πολύν_303">, ‘combining,’ ‘mingling,’ much laughter with the vaunts: cp. <title>Suppl.</title> 65 <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυντίθησι δὲ παιδὸς μόρον</quote>, <emph>blends</emph> that theme with her lament.—Not, ‘fabricating,’ with reference to the unreality of the triumph.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γέλων_303">, as in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 647"> <title>Ant.</title> 647</ref>: but <quote xml:lang="grc">γέλωτ’</quote> below, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 382"> Ant. 382</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 958."> Ant. 958.</ref> Eur. too uses <quote xml:lang="grc">γέλων</quote> where it is metrically convenient ( <ref n="Eur. Ion 1172">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 1172</ref>). The form implies an Attic declension, like that of <quote xml:lang="grc">νεώς</quote>. In <ref n="Hom. Od. 18.350">Hom. <title>Od.</title> 18. 350</ref> and 20. 346 <quote xml:lang="grc">γέλον</quote> should prob. be read; in the former place the MSS. give also <quote xml:lang="grc">γέλω</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">γέλων</quote>. Stems in </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τ_303"> are post-Homeric, as Monro observes (<title>Hom. Gr.</title> § 107 n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὕβριν_304"> is plainly that which he inflicts, not that which he punishes; though the latter would be suggested by the usual sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτίνεσθαι</quote>, as in <ref n="Eur. Her. 547">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 547</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή ποτε Κρέοντος θάνατον ἐκτεισαίατο</quote> (‘avenge’). Here the verb means, ‘inflict in vengeance.’</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτείσαιτο_304"> (for the spelling, <ref target="cl180">see on 180 f.</ref>), not </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτείσοιτο_304">: the latter would be tenable only if <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοῦ</quote> could replace </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτῶν_304">. When he spoke with Athena, he fancied that he had already slain the Atreidae (100); and Odysseus, though reserved for further chastisement, was already <quote xml:lang="grc">δεσμώτης</quote> (105).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰών_304"> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτε ᾔει</quote>) adds animation; see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 768"> <title>Ant.</title> 768</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δράτω, φρονείτω μεῖζον ἢ κατ’ ἄνδρ’ ἰών</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπᾴξας_305"> is better here than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπᾴξας_305">. The regular sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπᾴσσειν</quote> is ‘to rush <emph>at</emph>,’ or ‘<emph> against</emph>’; here it denotes that he rushes in again as if to renew the attack. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπᾴξας</quote>, on the other hand, would be somewhat awkward, since he was coming <emph>towards</emph> the speaker; and certainly cannot be defended by <ref n="Soph. Trach. 693"> <title>Tr.</title> 693</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴσω δ’ ἀποστείχουσα</quote>, where Deianeira means, ‘as I was going <emph>away from you</emph> into the house.’ It is quite needless to write <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσᾴξας.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὖθις_πάλιν_305">: <ref n="Soph. OC 1418"> <title>O. C.</title> 1418</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μόλις_πως_306">, by some slow and painful process, which she cannot analyse. Plat. <title>Prot.</title>p. 328 D <quote xml:lang="grc">μόγις πως ἐμαυτὸν ὡσπερεὶ ουναγείρας</quote>. So <quote xml:lang="grc">μόλις ποτέ</quote> <title>Helen.</title> 896. For <quote xml:lang="grc">πως</quote> thus used, cp. also <ref n="Hom. Il. 14.104"> <title>Il.</title> 14. 104</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μάλα πώς με καθίκεο θυμὸν ἐνιπῇ</quote>, ‘thou hast strangely moved me.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄτης_307">, the havoc made by him; cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1260"> <title>Ant.</title> 1260</ref>(alluding to the corpse of Haemon), <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἀλλοτρίαν | ἄτην</quote>, ‘the work of no stranger's madness.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θώϋξεν_308">. In <ref n="Soph. OC 1624"> <title>O. C.</title> 1624</ref> this word begins a trimeter, the augment being omitted, as often in <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥήσεις</quote> (see <ref n="Soph. OT 1249"> <title>O. T.</title> 1249</ref> n.): here, however, it is better to suppose aphaeresis. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1337">Cp. 1337</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">)κράτησα.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρειπίοις_308"> is defined by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νεκρῶν_308">, wrecks consisting of corpses; and this phrase, again, by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρνείου_φόνου_308">, corpsewrecks of slain sheep. Thus both the genitives here serve to define; while in <quote xml:lang="grc">λείας..βουκόλων φρουρήματα</quote> (54), the first gen. defines, and the second is possessive. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 465">Cp. 465</ref>, 616 f. The phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">νεκρῶν ἐρείπια</quote> occurs also in Eur. fr. 266. 2; and <quote xml:lang="grc">χλανιδίων ἐρειπίοις</quote> (which seems to verge on bathos) in frag. incert. 7 (ed. Nauck).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρειφθεὶς_308">: the pres. pass. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρείπεται</quote> (‘crashes down’) occurs in <ref n="Soph. OC 1462"> <title>O. C.</title> 1462</ref>; this aor., in Arrian <ref n="Xen. Anab. 1. 21. 4"> <title>Anab.</title> 1. 21. 4</ref>(of a tower) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ..χαλεπῶς ἂν ἠρείφθη</quote>. <title>Ol.</title> 2. 47 has <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐριπέντι</quote>. The old <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρεισθεὶς_308"> would mean, ‘supported on,’ but is wretchedly weak. The very fact that </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρειφθεὶς_308_2"> follows </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρειπίοις_308_2">—that the slayer is prostrate among the slain—gives the word a singular force and pathos. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπρὶξ_συλλαβὼν_310">, tightly clutching: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Theaet. 155e">Plat. <title>Theaet.</title> 155 E</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗ ἂν δύνωνται ἀπρὶξ τοῖν χεροῖν λαβέσθαι</quote> </cit>. Cp. fr. 328. 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ γε κερδαίνειν ὅμως | ἀπρὶξ ἔχονται</quote>. The word is from the rt. of <quote xml:lang="grc">πρίω</quote>, as=‘to grip’ (1030 n.), with euphonic <emph>a</emph>: Aesch. uses <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄπριγδα</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 1057">Aesch. <title> Pers.</title> 1057</ref>). Cp. the Latin phrase <foreign xml:lang="lat">mordicus tenere.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: οὗ ἂν δύνωνται ἀπρὶξ τοῖν χεροῖν λαβέσθαι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄνυξι_χερί_310">, <emph>with</emph> the hand, <emph> by</emph> the nails; both datives are instrumental, but one (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὄνυξι</quote>) more closely defines the other; <ref target="cl230">see on 230</ref> f. (<quote xml:lang="grc"> χερὶ..ξίφεσιν</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_πλεῖστον_311"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The bold order of words is explained by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπειτα</quote> in 312: <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, the thought is; ‘for <emph>one</emph> part of the time—the longest —he sat mute; <emph>then</emph>,’ etc. By separating <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν</quote> from <quote xml:lang="grc">πλεῖστον</quote>, the writer obtains the same effect as if he had said, <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ πρῶτον μὲν καὶ τὸν πλεῖστον χρόνον κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ἔπη_312">, ‘<emph>those</emph> dread threats’ (which still haunt my memory): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 650">cp. 650</ref>, 1226: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 180">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 180</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ δ’, ὃς τὰ δεινὰ τῇδ’ ἐφυβρίζει πόλει | Καπανεύς;</quote> ‘<emph>those</emph> dread vaunts’ (of which we have heard). See <ref n="Soph. Trach. 476">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 476</ref>, and Appendix there, p. 192. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φανοίην_313">. The optat. of the fut. <quote xml:lang="grc">φανέω</quote> is formed with the modal suffix </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ιη_313">, like the pres. optat. of contracted verbs, <quote xml:lang="grc">δρα‐ο‐ιη‐ν, δρῴην</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 3. 1. 14">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 3. 1. 14</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐροίη</quote> (opt. of fut. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐρέω</quote>): Platonic <title>Epist.</title> 7. p. 339 D <quote xml:lang="grc">διαβαλοίην</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_πράγματος_314">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1229"> <title>Ant.</title> 1229</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῷ συμφορᾶς διεφθάρης</quote>; <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 174"> <title>Ph.</title> 174</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ παντί τῳ χρείας</quote> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀγώ_δείσασα_315"> are apologetic; she would gladly have spared him the details which his threats constrained her to relate. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_τε_319">: for the prep., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 581">cp. 581</ref>, 1071. He always set forth, laid down as a rule, <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιούσδε γόους <emph>ἔχειν πρὸς</emph> ἀνδρὸς κακοῦ</quote>, <emph>pertain to</emph> him, are characteristic of him. The words, <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ἀνδρὸς κακοῦ κ.τ.λ.</quote>, are equiv. to an adverb with the intrans. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχειν</quote> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, as we can say, <quote xml:lang="grc">γόοι ἀνάνδρως ἔχουσι</quote>, so <quote xml:lang="grc">γόοι ἔχουσι πρὸς κακοῦ ἀνδρός</quote>. This intrans. use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχειν</quote> with phrases of an adverbial kind is frequent with Herodotus; <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> 2. 91 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγῶνα γυμνικὸν <*>ιὰ πάσης ἀγωνίης ἔχοντα</quote>, ‘<emph>consisting in</emph> every sort of contest’: see other examples on <ref n="Soph. OT 709."> <title>O. T.</title> 709.</ref>—The alternative explanation is, ‘he taught that it (was) the part of a craven <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχειν γόους τοιούσδε</quote>, to indulge in such laments.’ <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχειν</quote> would then be used as in <ref n="Hom. Od. 24.515"> <title>Od.</title> 24. 515</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆριν ἔχουσι</quote>. But this implies an impossible ellipse of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐ=ναι</quote> after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξηγεῖτο</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαρυψύχου_319">, ‘heavy-hearted,’ lacking the buoyant spirit which quickly rallies itself from despondency. Ajax was emphatically a soldier. (The schol.'s paraphrase, <quote xml:lang="grc"> μικροψύχου</quote>, conveys a different idea.) The word occurs nowhere else, <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρυθυμος</quote> being the usual term; but cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρύφρων</quote>, and the post-classical <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρυκάρδιος</quote>. Plutarch illustrates the poet's meaning when he speaks ( <title>Mor.</title>p. 477 E) of men <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ὀδυρμοῖς τὰ πολλὰ καὶ βαρυθυμίαις καὶ μερίμναις..διατρίβοντας</quote>. So Heracles says, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1074"> <title>Tr.</title> 1074</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἀστένακτος αἰὲν εἱπόμην κακοῖς</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξηγεῖτ_319">: the word implies authoritative exposition (as of the sacred law by the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξηγηταί</quote>), and suggests the submissive reverence with which Tecmessa listened to her lord. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀψόφητος_κωκυμάτων_321">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 677"> <title>O. C.</title> 677</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀνήνεμον..χειμώνων</quote> (n.).— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπεστέναζε_321">, groaned <emph>low</emph>; cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 79"> <title>El.</title> 79</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποστενούσης.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀξέων_321">: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 423"> <title>Ant.</title> 423</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πικρᾶς | ὄρνιθος ὀξὺν φθόγγον.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταῦρος_βρυχώμενος_321">: <title>Theog.</title> 832 <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦρος ἐριβρύχης</quote>. The word expresses <emph> deep</emph>, <emph>sullen</emph> tones, such as might come from a bull in pain: it usually implies a sound of anger or anguish, whereas <quote xml:lang="grc">μυκᾶσθαι</quote> can denote the mere <emph>lowing</emph> of oxen; hence Nonnus 29. 311 <quote xml:lang="grc">βρυχηδὸν ἐμυκήσαντο</quote>. The unhappy conjecture </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βριμώμενος_321"> (‘snorting’) was prompted by a supposed inconsistency between <quote xml:lang="grc">βρυχώμενος</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὑπεστέναζε</quote>: but there is no reason why deep tones should not be also muffled. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νῦν_δ_323"> contrasts his present behaviour with that described in 317. The contrast is not with <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπεστέναζε</quote> (322), as though he were now wholly silent. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄσιτος_324">. <ref n="Hom. Od. 4.788"> <title>Od.</title> 4. 788</ref>(Penelope in her anxiety for Telemachus) <quote xml:lang="grc">κεῖτ’ ἄρ’ ἄσιτος ἄπαστος ἐδητύος ἠδὲ ποτῆτος</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σιδηροκμῆσιν_324">: as the dead are <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ καμόντες, οἱ κεκμηκότες</quote>, so <quote xml:lang="grc">σιδηροκμής</quote> is one who has died by the sword: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 365">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 365</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δουρικμῆτι λαῷ</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 889 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδροκμῆτα πέλεκυν</quote> (an axe by which men die). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥς_δρασείων_326">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">δρασείων τι</quote> simply: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 630"> <title>O. C.</title> 630</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς τελῶν ἐφαίνετο</quote> </cit> : <ref n="Xen. Anab. 1. 5. 9">Xen. <title>An.</title> 1. 5. 9</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆλος ἦν Κῦρος ὡς σπεύδων</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 12.90">Lys. or. 12 § 90</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆλοι ἔσεσθε ὡς ὀργιζόμενοι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρασείων_326">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1001"> <title>Ph.</title> 1001</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐργασείεις</quote> (n.). <title>Vesp.</title> 168 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνθρωπος οὗτος μέγα τι δρασείει κακόν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιαῦτα_327"> is qualified by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πως_327">: something in his utterances, which she cannot define, suggests this. Cp. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 3. 3. 7">Xen. <title> Cyr.</title> 3. 3. 7</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλεξεν ὧδέ πως εἰς τὸ μέσον.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_κὠδύρεται_327">. The word </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥσυχος_327"> in 325 does not imply <emph>silence</emph>; it contrasts the quietness of his present demeanour with his former frenzy, and with the first vehemence (317) of his grief. His occasional words, or laments (such as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰώ μοί μοι</quote>, 333), are in a tone which foreshadows the worst.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐστάλην_328">, her (self-imposed) errand; cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 404"> <title>El.</title> 404</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷπερ ἐστάλην ὁδοῦ</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OC 20"> <title>O. C.</title> 20</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προὐστάλης</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰσελθόντες_328">. Dramatic effect required that, instead of the Chorus literally complying with this request, the interior of the tent should be disclosed to them (346). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγοις_330">. The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φίλοι_330"> of the MSS. was doubtless in its origin a mere oversight, but may have been helped to keep its place in the text by the construction in 1353, <quote xml:lang="grc">κρατεῖς τοι τῶν φίλων νικώμενος</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Τελεύταντος_331">: 210 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμῖν_331"> could be joined with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγεις_331">: for we sometimes find a word devoid of emphasis standing first in a trimeter, though a slight pause follows; <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> 847 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴδῃς</quote> : <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1130">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1130</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ κομπάσαιμ’ ἂν θεσφάτων γνώμων ἄκρος | εἶναι, κακῷ δέ τῳ προσεικάζω τάδε</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. PB 673">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 673</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">διάστροφοι | ἦσαν, κεραστὶς δ’ κ.τ.λ.</quote> But on the whole it seems better to have a comma after <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγεις</quote>, and to take <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἡμῖν</quote> as ethic dat. (‘to our sorrow’): though this, too, is slightly harsh; for such an ethic dat. ought not to stand first, but to follow some significant word, as in 216 <quote xml:lang="grc">μανίᾳ γὰρ ἁλοὺς ἡμὶν ὁ κλεινός</quote>: <ref n="Eur. El. 272"> <title>El.</title> 272</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν αὐτοέντην ἡμίν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διαπεφοιβάσθαι_331">: the compound occurs only here. <quote xml:lang="grc">φοιβάζω</quote>, from <quote xml:lang="grc"> Φοῖβος</quote>, meant ‘to inspire,’ as Apollo inspires the divine frenzy of <quote xml:lang="grc">μάντις</quote> or of poet; <title>Anthol.</title> 9. 525. 22 <quote xml:lang="grc">Φοῖβον, φοιβάζοντα, φιλοστέφανον, φιλογηθῆ</quote>: Longinus 8 § 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">πάθος φοιβάζον τοὺς λόγους</quote>. (The word could mean also ‘to utter prophetically,’ as in Lycophron 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">δαφνηφάγων φοίβαζεν ἐκ λαιμῶν ὄπα</quote>.) Tecmessa has just described both the recent frenzy of Ajax—which she had already pictured in vv. 233 ff.—and his present despair. By <quote xml:lang="grc">διαπεφοιβάσθαι</quote> the Chorus mean that a malign power has taken <emph>permanent possession</emph> of his mind. The mental trouble outlasts the frenzy (279 f.). Both <quote xml:lang="grc">διά</quote>, and the perfect tense, serve to mark this. By </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοῖς_331"> they mean his troubles in regard to the arms of Achilles. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰώ_μοι_333">. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 77"> <title>El.</title> 77</ref>, where a similar cry (behind the scenes) is a prelude to the heroine's entrance. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μᾶλλον_334">: we understand <quote xml:lang="grc">νοσήσει</quote>, or the like.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_οὐκ_334">: the same crasis as in <ref n="Soph. OT 555"> <title>O. T.</title> 555</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 993"> O. T. 993</ref> , <ref n="Soph. OT 1140."> O. T. 1140.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Αἴαντος_οἵαν_334"> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 785">cp. 785</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅρα..τόνδ’ ὁποἶ ἔπη θροεῖ</quote>. As in 308 <quote xml:lang="grc">)θώϋξεν</quote> marked the first pangs of his despair, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θωΰσσει_334"> here denotes a fresh access. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_ξυνοῦσι_337"> =<quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς πάλαι ξυνοῦσι ν.</quote>: for the irregular order, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1316"> <title>Ph.</title> 1316</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς..ἐκ θεῶν | τύχας δοθείσας</quote> (n.). The sense is <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς ν. ἃ πάλαι ξυνῆν</quote>. If the order of words were normal, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνοῦσι_337"> would be predicate; ‘vexed by his former maladies, as they haunt him,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτε ξύνεστιν</quote>. But then (1) the alternative to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ νοσεῖν</quote> is less clearly marked, since the old <quote xml:lang="grc">νοσήματα</quote> are, in a sense, still with him; and (2) <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνοῦσι</quote>, as referring merely to a <emph>memory</emph> of them, is somewhat forced.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρών_337">, being, as he is, in the presence of his own handiwork. The implied antithesis is with what he might feel if told of things which he had done elsewhere, but which he could not <emph> see.</emph> <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1131">Cp. 1131</ref>, 1156. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰὼ_παῖ_339">. One of the signs that he is resolved to die is the way in which his thoughts dwell upon his son; he cannot rest till he sees him (530—544). The child is the heir of his fame, and may live to clear it of the stain (556 f.). As Eurysaces is not at once brought to him, he next cries (342), </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Τεῦκρονκαλῶ_339">: Teucer is his <emph>second</emph> thought, for to Teucer he will commit the care of his son (562).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὤμοι_τάλαιν_340">: the nom. as in 800, <ref n="Eur. El. 788"> <title>El.</title> 788</ref>, and oft.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Εὐρύσακες_340">, so named from the shield of Ajax (19): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 574">cp. 574</ref> n. The first syll. of a dactyl in the third foot is usually either the last syllable of a word, or else a monosyllable; but proper names are exempt from the rule.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφὶ_σοὶ_340">: for the prep., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 303">cp. 303</ref>: in 562 the sense is different.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῦ_εἶ_340">; She had sent the child out of the tent, in charge of servants (531—539), and now fears that he has not been removed to a sufficient distance. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Τεῦκρον_342">: the son of Telamon by Hesionè (1302), and half-brother of Ajax, whose mother was Eriboea (569).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_χρόνον_342">: the phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἀεὶ χρόνον</quote> is frequent. The separation of <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν εἰσαεὶ</quote> from <quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνον</quote> deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility that <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἀεὶ</quote> may sometimes have been used (without <quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνον</quote>) as=‘for ever’: a usage which, however, lacks proof: see on <ref n="Eur. El. 1075."> <title>El.</title> 1075.</ref>— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λεηλατήσει_342">: he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720), ‘in pursuit of foes’ (564) to be despoiled. Cp. <ref n="Thuc. 1. 11">Thuc. 1. 11</ref>§ 1 (the Greeks at Troy) <quote xml:lang="grc">φαίνονται...πρὸς γεωργίαν τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ</quote>. The <title> Iliad</title> glances at such predatory expeditions (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> 1. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plot, since Teucer might have averted his brother's suicide. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνοίγετε_344">: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular person, but to the inmates of the house generally; <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 877">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 877</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἀνοίξατε</quote>: <title>Adelph.</title> 4. 4. 26 <quote xml:lang="lat">aperite, aliquis.</quote> Ajax had <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσπολοι</quote>, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰδῶ_λάβοι_344">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1078"> <title>Ph.</title> 1078</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φρόνησιν.. λάβοι</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Trach. 669"> <title>Tr.</title> 669</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">προθυμίαν | ... λαβεῖν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀπ_ἐμοὶ_344">: for this modest <quote xml:lang="grc">καί</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 192"> <title>Ph.</title> 192</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴπερ κἀγώ τι φρονῶ</quote>, and n. on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 719."> <title>Ant.</title> 719.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βλέψας_344"> should naturally go with <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀπ’ ἐμοί</quote>, though <quote xml:lang="grc">βλέπειν ἐπί τινι</quote> seems to occur nowhere else, and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιβλέπειν τινί</quote> only in Lucian <ref n="Lucian Astr. 20"> <title>Astr.</title> 20</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ σφίσι γινομένοισι τῷ μὲν ἡ Ἀφροδίτη τῷ δὲ ὁ Ζεὺς...ἐπέβλεψαν</quote> (‘looked with favour’). The alternative is to take <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπ’ ἐμοί</quote> as= ‘in my case,’ and <quote xml:lang="grc">βλέψας</quote> as epexegetic; but this is certainly harsh. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διοίγω_346">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1287"> <title>O. T.</title> 1287</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">διοίγειν κλῇθρα</quote>, and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1295.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πράγη_346">, deeds: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 21">cp. 21</ref>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰὼ_ναυβάται_348">: his first words mark the affection which was so deep in the rugged nature.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμμένοντες_348">: Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 351"> <title>O. T.</title> 351</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ κηρύγματι</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμμένειν.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρθῷ_νόμῳ_348">, the right, sound rule of loyalty to friendship—which the Greek chiefs have forsaken. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴδεσθέ_μ_351">: for this midd. aor., cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 351"> <title>Ph.</title> 351</ref> n. The constr. is as in <ref n="Aesch. PB 92">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 92</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴδεσθέ μ’ οἷα πρὸς θεῶν πάσχω θεός.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κῦμα_351"> is the bloodshed; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζάλης_351">, the storm of frenzy by which it was caused: cp. <ref n="Pind. O. 12">Pind. <title>O.</title> 12. 11</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δ’ ἀνιαραῖς | ἀντικύρσαντες ζάλαις ἐσλὸν βαθὺ πήματος ἐν μικρῷ πεδάμειψαν χρόνῳ</quote>. The epithet </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοινίας_351">, denoting the <emph>effect</emph> of the <quote xml:lang="grc">ζάλη</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, really belonging, in sense, to <quote xml:lang="grc">κῦμα</quote>), has a more vivid fitness than in <ref n="Soph. OT 24">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 24</ref>, where by <quote xml:lang="grc">βυθῶν..φοινίου σάλου</quote> is meant the pestilence.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφίδρομον_351">, ‘running around’ me.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυκλεῖται_351">: this rare midd. is read in <ref n="Hdt. 8. 16"> Her. 8. 16</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">μηνοειδὲς ποιήσαντες τῶν νεῶν ἐκυκλεῦντο ὡς περιλάβοιεν αὐτούς</quote>. But in fr. 787. 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">κυκλεῖται</quote> is pass.; and so Ellendt would take it here (‘<emph>is rolled</emph> around me’),—needlessly, I think. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυκλοῦται_351"> would be the more usual <emph> midd.</emph> form ( <ref n="Hdt. 3. 157"> Her. 3. 157</ref>, and oft.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴμ_354">: this elision occurs in 587; <ref n="Soph. Ant. 320"> <title>Ant.</title> 320</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1270"> Ant. 1270</ref> ; <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 590.">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 590.</ref>Though it breaks the rule of Tragedy against eliding diphthongs, it was doubtless too familiar to offend the ear. The <quote xml:lang="grc">οἲ ἐμὲ δειλήν</quote> in <title>Anth.</title> 9. 408 does not warrant us in supposing that <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴμ’</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc">οἴ με</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφροντίστως_ἔχει_354">. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 366"> <title>Tr.</title> 366</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πέμπων οὐκ ἀφροντίστως</quote>: <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 1. 6. 42">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 1. 6. 42</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδέποτ’ οὖν ἀφροντίστως ἔχε</quote>, ‘never be heedless.’ For the pass. form of the word, cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσλόγιστον</quote> (40 n.). It is not easy to decide whether the subject to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχει</quote> is Ajax, or <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὔργον</quote>: but the usage of the adverb rather favours the view that it is Ajax. The phrase is designedly euphemistic and reticent. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναΐας_τέχνας_357">, helpful <emph>of</emph> the seaman's art, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, its ministers: the gen., as in <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 486">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 486</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρωγὰ τῆς δίκης ὁρκώματα</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 201">Cp. 201</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅλιον_ἐπέβας_358"> is the best correction of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁλίαν_ἐπέβας_358">. The two short syllables <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς ἐπ‐</quote> then correspond with a long syllable (the first of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμμένοντες</quote>) in v. 350; as the dochmiac metre allows. Hermann's later emendation, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_ἔβας_358">, avoids, indeed, resolving the long syllable, but unwarrantably alters <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέβας</quote>: nor is there much force in his reason for preferring it, viz., that the gloss <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέβας τῶν νεῶν</quote> points to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁλιᾶν.. πλατᾶν</quote>, and this to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁλίαν</quote> (rather than <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἅλιον</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">πλάταν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 82">Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 82</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁλίῳ πλάτᾳ</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_358"> follows </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γένος_358">, as in 760 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις</quote> refers to <quote xml:lang="grc">σώματα</quote> in 758, and in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 707"> <title>Ant.</title> 707</ref> ff. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις</quote> is resumed by <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτοι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπέβας_358">, absol., ‘embarked’ (as in <ref n="Thuc. 7. 62">Thuc. 7. 62</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐπιβήσονται</quote>),—recalling the moment when they set forth from Salamis together; a point which is lost if <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέβας</quote> be taken as =‘thou hast come hither.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλίσσων_358">: cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 171"> Eur. <title>Or.</title> 171</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόδα σὸν εἱλίξεις</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘move swiftly.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πημονὰν_ἐπαρκέσοντ_360">: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.873"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 873</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέ τί οἱ τό γ’ ἐπήρκεσε λυγρὸν ὄλεθρον</quote>: <ref n="Hom. Od. 17.568"> <title>Od.</title> 17. 568</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε τι Τηλέμαχος τό γ’ ἐπήρκεσεν οὔτε τις ἄλλος</quote>. Thus, though <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπαρκεῖν</quote> could not mean literally ‘to ward <emph> off</emph>,’ epic precedent warranted its use in an equivalent sense, which was strictly that of bringing one help <emph>against</emph> a danger. In lyrics, at least, where epic associations have a large scope, it seems needless to write </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπαρκέσοντ_360">.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποιμένων_360"> is explained by the schol. in L, <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐμὲ ποιμαινόντων καὶ θαλπόντων</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the sense was taken to be, ‘I see that thou, alone <emph>of my shepherds</emph> (=of those who care for me), canst help.’ But <quote xml:lang="grc"> ποιμένων</quote>, in such a context, would suggest rather the idea of chieftainship (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ποιμένα λαῶν, ναῶν ποιμένες</quote> in <title>Suppl.</title> 767): and there can be little doubt that </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πημονὰν_360"> is right. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλά_361">, appealing: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 14"> <title>O. T.</title> 14</ref>, etc.: <ref n="Pind. O. 6">Pind. <title> O.</title> 6. 22</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ Φίντις, ἀλλὰ ζεῦξον ἤδη μοι σθένος ἡμιόνων</quote> (‘<emph>come</emph>, yoke’).— For the enclitic </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="με_361"> before its verb, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1359"> <title>El.</title> 1359</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλά με | λόγοις ἀπώλλυς.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συνδάϊξον_361">: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅμα τοῖς βοτοῖς</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔφημα_φώνει_362">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 591">cp. 591</ref>.— </gloss>
