<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὸν_ἄκος_362">: so fr. 74 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνταῦθα μέντοι πάντα τἀνθρῶπων νοσεῖ</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">κακοῖς ὅταν θέλωσιν ἰᾶσθαι κακά</quote>. <ref n="Hdt. 3. 53"> Her. 3. 53</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ τῷ κακῷ τὸ κακὸν ἰῶ</quote>: <ref n="Thuc. 5. 65">Thuc. 5. 65</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">διανοεῖται κακὸν κακῷ ἰᾶσθαι</quote>: Plat. <title> Prot.</title>p. 340 E <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰώμενος μεῖζον τὸ νόσημα ποιῶ</quote>.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ἄτης_362">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 765">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 765</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ πῆμα.. τῆς νόσου</quote>: <ref n="Hom. Od. 3.152"> Hom. <title>Od.</title> 3. 152</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ γὰρ Ζεὺς ἤρτυε πήμα κακοῖο</quote>.—Not, ‘make the present woe worse than the (<emph> original</emph>) plague’: <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἄτης</quote> would then need further definition. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θρασύν_364">, bold, enterprising; </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐκάρδιον_364">, stout-hearted in facing danger; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄτρεστον_364">, intrepid in the critical stress of fight. The good sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">θρασύς</quote> is frequent in poetry from Homer onwards, though in Attic prose the bad sense predominates. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφόβοις_366">, fearing no harm from man;—a pathetic epithet, which is marred by taking it as=‘not <emph>formidable</emph>’ to man. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφόβοις..θηρσὶ</quote> is not an oxymoron (as if it meant, ‘wild creatures which are not wild,’ ‘tame beasts’): <quote xml:lang="grc">θηρσί</quote> is a generic term; he attacked beasts instead of men: cp. fr. 855. 12 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν θηρσίν, ἐν βροτοῖσιν, ἐν θεοῖς ἄνω</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινὸν_χέρας_366">: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.457"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 457</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφαυρότερος χεῖράς τε μένος τε</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴμοι_γέλωτος_367">: for the gen., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 908">cp. 908</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤμοι ἐμᾶς ἄτας</quote> : <ref n="Soph. OC 1399"> <title>O. C.</title> 1399</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴμοι κελεύθου κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέσποτ_368">, as in 485: she is a <quote xml:lang="grc">δούλη</quote> (489). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ἄψορρον_369"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> It seems more probable that in v. 384 the MSS. have lost a syllable (as <quote xml:lang="grc">μήν</quote>) than that here we should omit the second <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 430"> <title>O. T.</title> 430</ref> f.: <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εἰς ὄλεθρον; οὐχὶ θᾶσσον; οὐ πάλιν | ἄψορρος οἴκων τῶνδ’ ἀποστραφεὶς ἄπει</quote>; If here we read, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_πόδα_369">; the verse becomes much tamer; while <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτὸς</quote>, taken with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄψορρον ἐκνεμεῖ</quote>, is positively weak. It may be added that the first syllable of <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἄψορρον</quote> here, and of <quote xml:lang="grc">καίπερ</quote> in 384, must then be treated as having the time-value of <foreign xml:lang="meter">-u</foreign>: whereas all the other trimeters in this kommos are normal.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτὸς_369"> cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 676"> <title>O. T.</title> 676</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔκουν μ’ ἐάσεις κἀκτὸς εἶ;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄψορρον_369"> is probably the adv., as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 902"> <title>Tr.</title> 902</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως ἄψορρον ἀντῴη πατρί</quote>, <ref n="Soph. El. 53"> <title>El.</title> 53</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄψορρον ἥξομεν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκνεμεῖ_369"> here gives the notion, ‘take forth into other pastures.’ This rare compound occurs in Theophr. <title>Hist. Plant.</title> 9. 16 § 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλίγος ὁ τόπος ὁ φέρων, καὶ τοῦτον αἱ αἶγες ἐκνέμονται</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> depascunt</foreign>, ‘the region which bears (the plant <foreign xml:lang="lat">dictamnum</foreign>) is small, and is stripped of it by the browsing goats.’ The analogy of <ref n="Pind. N. 6">Pind. <title> N.</title> 6. 15</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴχνεσιν ἐν Πραξιδάμαντος ἑὸν πόδα νέμων</quote>, would certainly point to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκνεμεῖς_369">, but we must allow for the poetical use of the middle voice, so frequent with Sophocles. Of the midd. fut., <ref n="Thuc. 4. 64">Thuc. 4. 64</ref>§ 5 has <quote xml:lang="grc"> νεμούμεθα</quote>, <ref n="Dem. 21.203">Dem. or. 21 § 203</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεμεῖσθαι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_θεῶν_371"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The MSS. seem right in giving this verse to the Chorus. Just after so violent a rebuke, the timid Tecmessa would scarcely venture on praying her ‘master’ to be ‘sane’; while the intercession of the Chorus is natural enough. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὢ_δύσμορος_372">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1319"> <title>Ant.</title> 1319</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὢ μέλεος</quote>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">ὢ</quote> is exclamatory, and stronger than the mere sign of the vocative (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ</quote>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_372">, with causal force; <ref n="Eur. El. 160"> <title>El.</title> 160</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χερὶ_μεθῆκα_372">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">χερὶ μεθῆκα μὲν</quote>: for the irregular place of <quote xml:lang="grc">μέν</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 279"> <title>Ph.</title> 279</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρῶντα μὲν ναῦς</quote>.. | ..<quote xml:lang="grc">βεβώσας, ἄνδρα δ’ οὐδέν’ ἔντοπον</quote> (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρῶντα ναῦς μὲν</quote>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χερὶ_372"> belongs in sense to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔδευσα</quote> no less than to <quote xml:lang="grc"> μεθῆκα</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_ἀλάστορας_372">: in <ref n="Soph. OC 788"> <title>O. C.</title> 788</ref> and <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1235"> <title>Tr.</title> 1235</ref> the word denotes ‘avenging spirits’; here, ‘accursed wretches,’ as the polluted Orestes calls himself <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλάστορα</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 236">Aesch. <title> Eum.</title> 236</ref>): cp. <ref n="Dem. 18.296">Dem. or. 18 § 296</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνθρωποι μιαροὶ καὶ κόλακες καὶ ἀλάστορες, ἠκρωτηριασμένοι τὰς ἑαυτῶν ἕκαστοι πατρίδας</quote> (‘who have crippled their respective cities’),—a passage which suggests that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλάστωρ</quote>, as said of a man, meant rather one who is a ‘curse’ or ‘plague’ to his neighbours, than one who is driven by an avenging spirit; indeed, such a passive sense is not easily conceived.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλυτοῖς_372">: from the Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">κλυτὰ μῆλα</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 9.308"> <title>Od.</title> 9. 308</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰπολίοις_372">: <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.679"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 679</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰπόλια πλατἔ αἰγῶν</quote>. This is the only express mention of goats among his victims; but there is no reason to think that <quote xml:lang="grc"> αἰπόλιον</quote> could be used as merely =<quote xml:lang="grc"> ποίμνιον.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρεμνὸν_372">: suggested doubtless by <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1390">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1390</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρεμνῇ ψακάδι φοινίας δρόσου.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἷμ_ἔδευσα_372">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 848"> <title>Tr.</title> 848</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέγγει δακρύων ἄχναν</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπ_ἐξειργασμένοις_377">: <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐπὶ</quote> denotes the condition: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1379">Aesch. <title> Ag.</title> 1379</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕστηκα δ’ ἔνθ’ ἔπαισ’ ἐπ’ ἐξειργασμένοις</quote>. (The phrase occurs also in <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 525.">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 525.</ref>) Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 556">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 556</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπ’ ἀρρήτοις..τοῖς ἐμοῖς λόγοις</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἂν_377"> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Two modes of expression are here mixed: (1) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν γένοιτο τοῦτο οὐχ ὧδ’ ἔχειν</quote>, <emph>it could not come to pass that this should not be thus.</emph> (2) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν γένοιτο ὅπως τοῦτο οὐχ ὧδ’ ἕξει</quote>,—with the same meaning: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OT 1058"> <title>O. T.</title> 1058f.</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν γένοιτο τοῦθ’, ὅπως ἐγὼ … | … οὐ φανῶ τοὐμὸν γένος</quote> </cit>. In other words, the constr. would be plain if </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐκ ἂν γένοιτο τοῦθ’, ὅπως ἐγὼ … | … οὐ φανῶ
							τοὐμὸν γένος

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπως_377"> were struck out. The irregular presence of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως</quote> is due to its association with statements of impossibility in the formula <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔστιν ὅπως οὐ</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 97"> <title>O. C.</title> 97</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 1479"> <title>El.</title> 1479</ref>): its <emph>place</emph> is explained by the analogy of such a sentence as <ref n="Soph. OT 1058"> <title>O. T.</title> 1058</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν γένοιτο τοῦθ’, ὅπως κ.τ.λ.</quote>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο</quote> is subject to <quote xml:lang="grc">γένοιτο</quote>. The declension of <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδεὶς‐ὅστισοὐ</quote>, as an integral equivalent for <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶς τις</quote>, similarly illustrates the manner in which the associations of idiom could sometimes generate anomalies in grammar.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάνθ_ὁρῶν_379">: as Philoctetes says to Odysseus, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1013"> <title>Ph.</title> 1013</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἡ κακὴ σὴ διὰ μυχῶν βλέπουσ’ ἀεὶ | ψυχή κ.τ.λ.</quote>, ‘thy base soul, ever peering from some ambush.’ The conjecture <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντα δρῶν</quote> is not only weak, but incorrect, since the sense would require <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶν δρῶν</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁπάντων_τ_379">. It is needless to change </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τ_379"> to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δ_379">: though <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote> often occurs thus in ‘epanaphora,’ as <ref n="Soph. Ant. 806"> <title>Ant.</title> 806</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰν νεάταν ὁδὸν | στείχουσαν, νέατον δὲ φέγγος λεύσσουσαν</quote> (n.). Here the case for </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δ_379_2"> would be stronger if <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅπανθ’</quote> (and not <quote xml:lang="grc">πάνθ’</quote>) had preceded.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακῶν_ὄργανον_379">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 407"> <title>Ph.</title> 407</ref>(of Odysseus) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξοιδα γάρ νιν παντὸς ἂν λόγου κακοῦ | γλώσσῃ θιγόντα καὶ πανουργίας</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλημα_381">, ‘fine meal’ (<quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀλέω</quote>), hence, ‘a subtle knave,’—a word found only here and in 389. <quote xml:lang="grc">παιπάλη</quote> (reduplicated from <quote xml:lang="grc">πάλη</quote>) had the same senses, literal and figurative; and <quote xml:lang="grc">παιπάλημα</quote> was a current term ( <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 430">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 430</ref>, <ref n="Aeschin. 2.40">Aeschin. or. 2 § 40</ref>). In fr. 827 Odysseus is called <quote xml:lang="grc">πάνσοφον κρότημα</quote>, as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 927"> <title>Ph.</title> 927</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πανουργίας | δεινῆς τέχνημ’ ἔχθιστον</quote>.—For the early repetition of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλημα</quote>, in 389, cp. that of <quote xml:lang="grc">κείσομαι</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 76"> <title>Ant.</title> 76</ref>(n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_που_382">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 176">cp. 176</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄγεις_382">. The phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγειν γέλωτα</quote> denotes frequent or continued derision, as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγειν κτύπον</quote>=‘to keep up a noise’: <ref n="Eur. Orest. 182">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 182</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κτύπον ἠγάγετ)· οὐχὶ σῖγα κ.τ.λ.</quote> So <quote xml:lang="grc">νεῖκος ἄγειν</quote>, to sustain a conflict ( <ref n="Pind. P. 9">Pind. <title>P.</title> 9. 33</ref>): <quote xml:lang="grc">σχολὴν ἄγειν</quote>, etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξὺν_θεῷ_383">. Those who write <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύν τοι θεῷ</quote> here do so on the ground that <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν θεῷ</quote>, not <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν τῷ θεῷ</quote>, is the regular phrase when the sense is general, ‘with the divine aid’; whereas in <ref n="Soph. OT 146"> <title>O. T.</title> 146</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν τῷ θεῷ</quote> refers to a particular god (Apollo). But there is an arbitrary rigour in this doctrine. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ θεός</quote> often means ‘the divine power’ generally: <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> frag. adesp. 471 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ γὰρ θεὸς μέγιστος ἀνθρώποις νόμος</quote>: and 496. 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">πόρρω γὰρ ἑστὼς ὁ θεὸς ἐγγύθεν βλέπει</quote>. And this very phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν τῷ θεῷ</quote>, occurs once, at least, in a passage where the context plainly indicates that the sense is general, viz. Eur. fr. 490 <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν τῷ θεῷ χρὴ τοὺς σοφοὺς ἀναστρέφειν | βουλεύματ’ ἀεί</quote>. There, indeed, as here, Nauck changes <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">τοι</quote>, but without any warrant.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵδοιμι_383"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The question whether the MSS. have lost a syllable here depends on the view taken of 369. I have given reasons for thinking that the second <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ</quote> in that verse is genuine; from which it would follow that there is a defect here. Bellermann, indeed, is content to hold that Sophocles neglected an exact correspondence; but this seems very unlikely. L. Dindorf's remedy <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴδοιμι <<emph> μήν</emph>> νιν</quote>, has this advantage over the others (cr. n.), that it gives a light adversative force, and so fitly responds to v. 383, <quote xml:lang="grc">ξὺν τῷ θεῷ κ.τ.λ.</quote> ‘Triumph, like defeat, is the gift of heaven.’—‘<title>Yet</title> would that I could see him,’ etc. The next best conjecture is perhaps that of Apitz, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴδοιμί <emph>νύν</emph> νιν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδὲν_εἴπῃς_386">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 830"> <title>El.</title> 830</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲν μέγ’ ἀΰσῃς</quote> (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προπάτωρ_387">, a word used by Pindar, Eur. , and Herodotus. The reading </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάτερ_387"> (requiring </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χεροῖν_387"> instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">χερὶ μὲν</quote> in 372) had an obvious and prosaic motive; viz., that Aeacus, the grandfather of Ajax, was the son of Zeus ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 21.189"> <title>Il.</title> 21. 189</ref>), so that Zeus could not properly be called an ‘ancestor’ of the hero's ‘ancestors.’ But when the poet wrote <quote xml:lang="grc">προγόνων προπάτωρ</quote>, it was enough for him that it expressed the thought, ‘author of my line’; he did not trouble himself with this subtlety.—It was the nymph Aegina who bore Aeacus to Zeus ( Plat. <title>Gorg.</title>p. 526 E: <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν δικαστὴν τὸν τῆς Αἰγίνης υἱόν</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πῶς_θάνοιμι_387">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 531"> <title>Ph.</title> 531</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς ἂν ὑμὶν ἐμφανὴς | ἔργῳ γενοίμην</quote> (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δισσάρχας_389"> (found only here): <ref target="cl251">see on 251</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δικρατεῖς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀλέσσας_389">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1163"> <title>Ph.</title> 1163</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πέλασσον</quote>. (Below, in 927, some edd. read <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξανύσσειν</quote>: see n. there.) This epic licence in tragic lyrics is illustrated by their toleration of such forms as <quote xml:lang="grc">τόσσον</quote> (185), <quote xml:lang="grc">μέσσος, ζώειν</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. El. 157"> <title>El.</title> 157</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OC 1213"> <title>O. C.</title> 1213</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">πνείειν</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1146"> <title>Ant.</title> 1146</ref>), etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βασιλῆς_389"> is the form which the grammarians Draco and Herodian read here (cr. n.). But, so far as Attic inscrr. are available, they indicate that the acc. plur. from <quote xml:lang="grc"> ευ</quote> stems ended in <quote xml:lang="grc">‐έα—ς</quote>, always uncontracted; while the contraction in <quote xml:lang="grc">‐εῖς</quote> (not <quote xml:lang="grc">‐ῆς</quote>) was the rule from the Macedonian age onwards. (The earliest example of <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς βασιλεῖς</quote> quoted by Meisterhans, <title>Gramm. Att. Inschr.</title> § 39, belongs to 318—311 B.C.) We must regard the acc. <quote xml:lang="grc">βασιλῆς</quote> here, then, not as an old Attic, but as a poetical form. On the other hand, <quote xml:lang="grc">βασιλῆς</quote> was the form of the <emph>nom.</emph> plur. in the older Attic (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 189">cp. 189</ref>). Herodian (<emph>l. c.</emph>, cr. n.) cites <quote xml:lang="grc">νομῆς</quote> from Xenophon, as if it were an <emph>acc.</emph> pl. like <quote xml:lang="grc">βασιλῆς</quote> here: but in the place to which he apparently refers ( I. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 1"> <title>Cyr.</title> 1</ref>§ 2) it is <emph>nom.</emph>, and the best recent edd. give <quote xml:lang="grc">νομεῖς</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θάνοιμι_καὐτός_389">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 438">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 438</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπειτ’ ἐγὼ νοσφίσας ὀλοίμαν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκότος_394">, the darkness of death, as the gates of Hades are <quote xml:lang="grc">σκότου πύλαι</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. Hec. 1">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 1</ref>): </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔρεβος_394">, as in <ref n="Soph. OC 1389">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1389</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ Ταρτάρου | στυγνὸν...ἔρεβος</quote>. So, too, in <ref n="Hom. Il. 8.368"> <title>Il.</title> 8. 368</ref> it is merely a term for ‘the nether gloom’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἐρέβευς ἄξοντα</quote>), not a definitely named region, Erebos.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἐμοί_394">: for this limiting force of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 20"> <title>O. C.</title> 20</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μακρὰν...ὡς γέροντι</quote>: Plat. <title>Soph.</title>p. 226 C <quote xml:lang="grc">ταχεῖαν, ὡς ἐμοί, σκέψιν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕλεσθ_μ_396">: the most probable reading; <ref target="cl414">see on 414</ref>. Here the midd. means, ‘<emph>take to yourselves</emph>’ (and not, as normally, ‘<emph>choose</emph>’): it is thus more expressive than <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕλετε</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 887"> <title>O. T.</title> 887</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακά νιν ἕλοιτο μοῖρα</quote>. Conversely we find <quote xml:lang="grc">εὑρεῖν</quote> where <quote xml:lang="grc">εὑρέσθαι</quote> would be normal ( <ref n="Soph. El. 1061"> <title>El.</title> 1061</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γένος_398">, as well as </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄνασιν_398">, is governed by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_398">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 734"> <title>O. T.</title> 734</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Δελφῶν κἀπὸ Δαυλίας</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1205 <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ἄταις ἀγρίαις, τίς ἐν πόνοις</quote>: <ref n="Soph. El. 780"> <title>El.</title> 780</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε νυκτὸς..οὔτ’ ἐξ ἡμέρας.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄξιος_398">. For the ellipse of <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰμί</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 813">cp. 813</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βλέπειν_398">, to look for help; cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 958"> <title>El.</title> 958</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς τίν’ ἐλπίδων | βλέψασ’ ἔτ’ ὀρθήν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁ_θεὸς_401">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 450">cp. 450</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OC 623"> <title>O. C.</title> 623</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χὡ Διὸς Φοῖβος.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀλέθριον_401"> should answer metrically to <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔφρονες</quote> in 420. If it be sound, the first syllable must represent the anacrusis, which is omitted before <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔφρονες</quote>: and the <quote xml:lang="grc">ε</quote> is long, as it is in 799 (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλεθρίαν</quote>), <ref n="Soph. OT 1341"> <title>O. T.</title> 1341</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλέθριον</quote>), and <ref n="Soph. OC 1683"> <title>O. C.</title> 1683</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλεθρία</quote>): though we find <quote xml:lang="grc">ε^</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 845"> <title>Tr.</title> 845</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλεθρίαισι</quote>), and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 878 (<quote xml:lang="grc"> ὀλεθρία</quote>). The neatest emendation is </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔλιον_401"> (cr. n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φύγῃ_μενῶ_403">. For the delib. subjunct. combined with fut. indic., cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 973"> <title>Tr.</title> 973</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί πάθω; τί δὲ μήσομαι;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_φθίνει_405"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> The conjectures of various critics are recorded and classified in the Appendix. Here I will briefly state what seem the main points of the problem.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖσδ_405"> in 406 answers to the </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τινα_405"> of <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτινα</quote> in 424, where the <quote xml:lang="grc">α</quote>, being the last syllable of a verse, could be either long or short, and is here long. (Some, indeed, read <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτιν’ ἁ</quote>: cr. n.) That is, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖσδ’</quote>, we require <foreign xml:lang="meter"> u-</foreign>. As to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξερέω</quote> in 423, answering to <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ τὰ μὲν</quote> in 405, we should write <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξερῶ</quote>. With regard to the <emph> diction</emph> of 405 ff., the most suspicious point is the redundancy </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμοῦ_πέλας_405">, suggesting that one of the words was a gloss upon the other.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιοῖσδ_405"> for </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖσδ_405_2">: cp. the words of Ajax in 453 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστ’ ἐν τοιοῖσδε χεῖρας αἱμάξαι βοτοῖς</quote>. There he points to the slain cattle around him; and so he probably does here also. We could then understand the sense to be: ‘If those things (<quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ μὲν</quote>, his glories in the past) perish, my friends, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμοῦ τοιοῖσδε</quote> , <emph>along with</emph> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, by the slaughter of) such creatures, <quote xml:lang="grc">πέλας</quote>, near me there.’ But <quote xml:lang="grc">πέλας</quote> may have been a marginal gloss (on <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμοῦ</quote>), which has displaced some other word: <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, the poet may have written </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιοῖσδ_βοτοῖς_405"> (cp. v. 453).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσκείμεθα_407">, ‘addicted’ to them. <ref n="Hdt. 3. 34"> Her. 3. 34</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> φιλοινίῃ...προσκέεσθαι</quote>. The word can also denote, in a good sense, that to which the attention is given, as Thuc. (1. 93 § 7) says of Themistocles, <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῖς γὰρ ναυσὶ μάλιστα προσέκειτο.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μώραις_407">. L has </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μωραῖς_407"> (as it has <quote xml:lang="grc">μωρὰν</quote> in <ref n="Eur. El. 890"> <title>El.</title> 890</ref>), that being the later accent, according to the general rule that adjectives in <quote xml:lang="grc"> ‐ρος</quote> are oxytone. But the grammarians attest that the Attic accent was <quote xml:lang="grc">μῶρος</quote>. See, <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, Eustath. p. 245. 17 <quote xml:lang="grc">μῶρος παρ’ Ἀττικοῖς, ὁ παρὰ τοῖς ὕστερον μωρός</quote>: and Chandler, <title>Greek Accentuation</title>, § 404 (2nd ed.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δίπαλτος_408">, in active sense (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄψαυστος ἔγχους</quote>, <ref n="Soph. OT 969"> <title>O. T.</title> 969</ref> n.), wielding their swords with both hands, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, with their utmost force. <title>I. T.</title> 323 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς δ’ εἴδομεν δίπαλτα πολεμίων ξίφη</quote>. That the word had passed into a figurative sense (in which <quote xml:lang="grc">δι‐</quote> was merely equiv. to ‘fiercely’), is indicated by <quote xml:lang="grc">τριπάλτων πημάτων</quote> in <ref n="Aesch. Seven 985">Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 985</ref>, woes hurled on one with crushing force. <quote xml:lang="grc">δίπαλτος</quote> should not be explained with ref. to the <emph>two spears</emph> of the Homeric warrior ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.495"> <title>Il.</title> 5. 495</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάλλων δ’ ὀξέα δοῦρε</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φωνεῖν_411">, exclamatory: <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 837">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 837</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμὲ παθεῖν τάδε</quote>. It was common in colloquial Attic; see <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> <title>Vesp.</title> 835 <quote xml:lang="grc">βάλλ’ ἐς κόρακας· τοιουτονὶ τρέφειν κύνα</quote>. For this inf. with the article added, see <ref n="Soph. Phil. 234"> <title>Ph.</title> 234</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φεῦ τὸ καὶ λαβεῖν</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτλη_411">, of what one <emph>brings oneself</emph> to do; here, ‘deigned.’ <ref n="Soph. Aj. 528">Cp. 528</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 158."> <title>Tr.</title> 158.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πόροι_ἁλίρροθοι_412">: probably ‘paths or straits of the sounding sea,’ as in <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 367">Aesch. <title> Pers.</title> 367</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔκπλους φυλάσσειν καὶ πόρους ἁλιρρόθους</quote>: meaning here the waters of the Hellespont. His thought passes from those waters to the </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάραλαἄντρα_412"> beside them, and thence to the neighbouring woodlands. For the form of the phrase, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1062">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1062</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιμφαρμάτοις...ἁμίλλαις</quote>.—The other version, ‘paths <emph>by</emph> the sounding sea,’ is possible, but less probable. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέμος_413">, properly pasture simply; but associated with trees in <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.480"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 480</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν νέμεϊ σκιερῷ</quote> (a phrase repeated in <title>Anth.</title> 7. 55). In the Lat. <foreign xml:lang="lat">nemus</foreign> the notion of ‘woodland’ is seen dominant.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολὺν_με_414"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> This order of words has the best authority, and is confirmed by the metre. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 396">Cp. 396</ref>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὴ_414"> merely emphasises </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δαρόν_414">. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμπνοὰς_ἔχοντα_416">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμπνουν ὄντα</quote>. The proper sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναπνοή</quote> is (1) ‘recovery of breath’; or (2) =<quote xml:lang="grc">εἰσπνοή</quote> as opp. to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκπνοή</quote>, the drawing in of breath. Here, however, it means merely <quote xml:lang="grc">πνοή</quote>, as=‘the breath of life.’ Cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 421">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 421</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μητρὸς οἴχονται πνοαί</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Σκαμάνδριοι_ῥοαί_417">: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.467"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 467</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν λειμῶνι Σκαμανδρίῳ ἀνθεμόεντι</quote>. The Scamander, still called the <title> Mendere</title>, is the most important river of the Troad. Rising in Ida, it flows through the central plain which now bears the name of the town Bairamitch, and thence passes northward into the plain of Troy. On the confines between the two plains, where the river winds in large curves through deep gorges in limestone rocks, its scenery is striking. From the south border of the Trojan plain to the Hellespont, the Mendere has a course of between seven and eight miles. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔφρονες_Ἀργείοις_420">: as supplying them with water. So in 863 the <quote xml:lang="grc">ποταμοί</quote> of the plain are called <quote xml:lang="grc">τροφῆς</quote>.— Not: ‘friendly to my Greek <emph>foes</emph>, but hostile to me.’ Nor should the words be taken adverbially with <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκέτ’ ἄνδρα μὴ τόνδ’ ἴδητ’</quote>, as meaning, ‘No longer, allies of the Greeks, will ye see me,’— <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘You will no longer see me victorious beside your favouring stream.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκέτ_ἴδητ_421">: <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ μὴ</quote> with subjunct. gives a strong emphasis; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 83">cp. 83</ref>, 560. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξερῶ_423"> gives an exact correspondence with <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ τὰ μὲν</quote> in 405. The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξερέω_423"> of the MSS. might, indeed, be compared with <ref n="Eur. El. 178"> <title>El.</title> 178</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπεράχθεο</quote> , <ref n="Soph. OC 227"> <title>O. C.</title> 227</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπέσχεο</quote> , <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1244 <quote xml:lang="grc"> κλονέουσιν</quote>. (In <ref n="Soph. Trach. 639"> <title>Tr.</title> 639</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καλέονται</quote> should be <quote xml:lang="grc">κλέονται</quote>.) But <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξερέω</quote> was so familiar as the Homeric form that it could easily have displaced <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξερῶ</quote> here. It is not likely that the poet would have written <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξερέω</quote> if he had meant the word to be scanned <foreign xml:lang="meter">-u-</foreign> by synizesis.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτινα_423"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στρατοῦ_423">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1175">cp. 1175</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεἴ τινα στρατοῦ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χθονὸς_Ἑλλανίδος_423">: for the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπό</quote>, and for the hiatus, cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 510"> <title>Tr.</title> 510</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Βακχίας ἀπὸ | ἦλθε...Θήβας</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόκειμαι_427">: lie prostrate (323 ff.): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1059">cp. 1059</ref>.—The <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόκειται_427"> was caused by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρα_τόνδε_427">: but cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1329"> <title>O. C.</title> 1329</ref>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷδ’ ἀνδρὶ</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμοὶ</quote>) is immediately followed by <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὐμοῦ</quote>, as in <ref n="Soph. OT 534"> <title>O. T.</title> 534</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦδε τἀνδρὸς</quote> by <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἐμῆς</quote>. See also below, <ref n="Soph. OT 865."> O. T. 865.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτοι_οὐδ_428">. There can be little doubt that the <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔθ’</quote> of the MSS. should be <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’</quote> here. In <ref n="Eur. El. 1197"> <title>El.</title> 1197</ref> and 1412 L has <quote xml:lang="grc"> οὔθ’</quote>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’</quote> is right; as in <ref n="Soph. OC 496"> <title>O. C.</title> 496</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήθ’</quote> instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδ’</quote>. As to the conditions under which </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_οὔτε_428"> was admitted in Attic poetry, see on <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1058"> <title>Tr.</title> 1058</ref> f.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπως_ἐῶ_428"> (subjunct.), the indirect form of the ‘deliberative’ <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς ἐῶ;</quote> (‘how am I to allow..?’) Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1367"> <title>O. T.</title> 1367</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅπως σε φῶ βεβουλεῦσθαι καλῶς</quote>: <ref n="Dem. 9.54">Dem. or. 9 § 54</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔχω τί λέγω</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_ᾤεθ_430">, ‘could have thought’; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 119">cp. 119</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ἂν..ηὑρέθη;</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπώνυμον_430"> here goes closely with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνοίσειν_430">, ‘would <emph>agree</emph> so <emph> significantly</emph>’ with my woes. Hence in 914 he is called <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσώνυμος</quote>. For the verb, cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 1232">Ar. <title>Eq.</title> 1232</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μήν σ’ ἐλέγξαι βούλομαι τεκμηρίῳ</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ τι ξυνοίσεις τοῦ θεοῦ τοῖς θεσφάτοις</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘agree’ with the description of the person mentioned in them. For the adj., cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 7.54">Hom. <title> Od.</title> 7. 54</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀρήτη δ’ ὄνομ’ ἐστὶν ἐπώνυμον</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 19. 409 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ δ’ Ὀδυσεὺς ὄνομ’ ἔστω ἐπώνυμον</quote>: where in each case <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπώνυμον</quote> means that the name is <emph> significant</emph> (the queen was the ‘desired one’; the child was to be ‘a man of wrath’). This usage of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπώνυμος</quote>, with ref. to the <emph>aptness</emph> of a name (or surname), is different from that in which a person or thing is said to be <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπώνυμός τινος</quote>, either as (1) being named from it, or (2) giving a name to it. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 574">Cp. 574</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_τρίς_432">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1238"> <title>Ph.</title> 1238</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δὶς ταὐτὰ βούλει καὶ τρὶς ἀναπολεῖν μ’ ἔπη;</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιούτοις_γὰρ_432">: for <quote xml:lang="grc"> γάρ</quote> in two successive sentences, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 186">cp. 186</ref> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατὴρ_434">: Telamon, whom Heracles brought with him to the war at Troy, as Pindar relates ( <ref n="Pind. I. 5"> <title>Isthm.</title> 5. 27</ref> ff.), and rewarded with the hand of Hesionè (1300 ff.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ἀριστεύσας_434">, a free poetical mode of saying, ‘having won by prowess the first meed of honour.’ The word <quote xml:lang="grc">καλλιστεῖα</quote> (properly ‘prize for beauty’) may have been chosen because the prize was Hesionè. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1300">Cp. 1300</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατοῦ τὰ πρῶτ’ ἀριστεύσας</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόπον_Τροίας_437">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">Τροίαν</quote>: a periphrasis like <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν Κιθαιρῶνος τόπον</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OT 1134"> <title>O. T.</title> 1134</ref>). Here <quote xml:lang="grc">Τροία</quote> is used in the Homeric manner, to denote not only the city but the country; <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ Τρῳάς</quote>, as=‘the Troad,’ occurs first in Herodotus (5. 122).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπελθὼν_437">, <emph>after</emph> Telamon; cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιγίγνομαι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρκέσας_439"> has here (though not elsewhere) a sense which <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπαρκεῖν</quote> with acc. often bears, viz., ‘to furnish at need’: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1170">Aesch. <title> Ag.</title> 1170</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκος δ’ οὐδὲν ἐπήρκεσαν</quote>. The strict meaning is then, ‘having rendered no less service by the deeds of my hand.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοσοῦτόν_ἐξεπίστασθαι_444">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1455"> <title>O. T.</title> 1455</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καίτοι τοσοῦτόν γ’ οἶδα</quote> (and <ref n="Soph. El. 332"> <title>El.</title> 332</ref>). <ref n="Hdt. 7. 152"> Her. 7. 152</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπίσταμαι δὲ τοσοῦτο, ὅτι κ.τ.λ.</quote> Here the omission of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι</quote> adds vigour to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_ζῶν_444"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_ἔμελλε_444">, ‘if he <emph>had been going to</emph> award,’ ‘if it had devolved upon him to award.’ The imperfect (here referring to an unreal condition in past, not in present, time) is rightly used, because it expresses the constraint of a supposed situation. But in the apodosis, the aor., </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκἄν_ἔμαρψεν_444">, is used, because the taking of the prize is an act done at a given moment.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπλων_πέρι_444">, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign> in a case where they were the prize. Sophocles has <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅς</quote>, <emph>suus</emph>, (epic <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑός</quote>,) in <ref n="Soph. OT 1248"> <title>O. T.</title> 1248</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">οἷσιν</quote> ), <ref n="Soph. OC 1639"> <title>O. C.</title> 1639</ref> and <ref n="Soph. Trach. 266"> <title>Tr.</title> 266</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν</quote>), <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 525 (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅν</quote>). Here it is emphatic: ‘his own arms,’—of which he could dispose with the best right.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρίνειν_ἀριστείας_444">, to award the first place for prowess; cp. <ref n="Pind. I. 7">Pind. <title>I.</title> 7. 5</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀέθλων..κράτος</quote>, victory in them. For the pres. inf. <quote xml:lang="grc">κρίνειν</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμελλε</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1774">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1774</ref> n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔμαρψεν_444">, <emph>praeripuisset</emph>; the prize due to Ajax was snatched from him.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντ_ἐμοῦ_444">: so <ref n="Aesch. PB 467"> Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 467</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτις ἄλλος ἀντ’ ἐμοῦ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νῦν_δ_445">, with ref. to a past moment (‘but as it was’); so in 450, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 88"> <title>Tr.</title> 88</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 1334."> <title>El.</title> 1334.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παντουργῷ_445"> occurs only here as=<quote xml:lang="grc">πανούργῳ</quote>: cp. <quote xml:lang="grc"> παντότολμος</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">πάντολμος</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Seven 671">Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 671</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φωτὶ παντόλμῳ φρένας</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπραξαν_445">. Though <quote xml:lang="grc"> πράσσειν</quote> oft. denotes intrigue ( <ref n="Soph. OT 125"> <title>O. T.</title> 125</ref>), the phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">πράσσειν τί τινι</quote> (‘to <emph>procure</emph> a thing for one by intrigue’) is peculiar. Cp. <ref n="Plut. Pomp. 51">Plut. <title>Pomp.</title> 51</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πράττειν μὲν ἑαυτοῖς ἐπαρχιῶν καὶ στρατοπέδων ἡγεμονίας.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπώσαντες_445">, ‘having thrust out of account,’=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτιμάσαντες</quote>. The midd. is usual as=‘to reject’ ( <ref n="Soph. Trach. 216"> <title>Tr.</title> 216</ref>); but the act. here is not a mere equivalent for it.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κράτη_445">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 689"> <title>El.</title> 689</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ οἶδα τοιοῦδ’ ἀνδρὸς ἔργα καὶ κράτη</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόδ_ὄμμα_447">: some force and pathos are lost by reading <quote xml:lang="grc">τό τ’ ὄμμα</quote> (with <quote xml:lang="grc">χαἱ</quote>). Cp. Athena's words (51) <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσφόρους ἐπ’ ὄμμασι | γνώμας βαλοῦσα.— <emph> διάστροφοι</emph> </quote>: <ref n="Aesch. PB 673">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 673</ref>(Io speaking of herself) <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐθὺς δὲ μορφὴ καὶ φρένες διάστροφοι | ἦσαν.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_ἐμῆς_447"> is emphatic: my true purpose: so 100 <quote xml:lang="grc">τἄμ’</quote>: 442 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ὧν</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ἐψήφισαν_447">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, they would have died before they could repeat such a villainy. See on v. 100, <quote xml:lang="grc">θανόντες ..ἀφαιρείσθων</quote>. The midd. <quote xml:lang="grc">ψηφίζομαι δίκην</quote> means ‘to decide a cause by one's vote’; Isae. or. 3 § 7 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς περὶ αὐτοῦ τούτου τὴν δίκην μέλλουσι ψηφιεῖσθαι</quote>. And for </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατ_φωτὸς_447"> cp. Plat. <title> Gorg.</title>p. 515 E <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδεμίαν αἰσχρὰν δίκην κατεψηφίσαντο αὐτοῦ</quote>. The act. <quote xml:lang="grc">ψηφίζω</quote> usu.=‘to count’ (as Polyb. 5. 26 <quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ τὴν τοῦ ψηφίζοντος βούλησιν</quote>, ‘at the reckoner's will’). Here, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δίκην_ἐψήφισαν_447"> has the general sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">δίκην ἐψηφίσαντο</quote>: but it is not directly modelled on that prose idiom: rather it is a new poetical phrase, meaning strictly, ‘<emph>get</emph> a cause <emph>decided</emph> by <quote xml:lang="grc">ψῆφοι</quote>.’ It implies that the votes against Ajax were secured by the intrigues of the chiefs: cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 8">Pind. <title>N.</title> 8. 26</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">κρυφίαισι γὰρ ἐν ψάφοις Ὀδυσσῆ Δαναοὶ θεράπευσαν· | χρυσέων δ’ Αἴας</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">στερηθεὶς ὅπλων φόνῳ πάλαισεν</quote>. [<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐψήφισαν</quote> certainly has not the technical sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεψήφισαν</quote>, as if the Atreidae were the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγεμόνες δικαστηρίου</quote>, who put the issue to the vote. Even if the simple <quote xml:lang="grc"> ψηφίζω</quote> could be so used, this would be too technical and prosaic.] </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡ_θεὰ_450">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 401">cp. 401</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γοργῶπις_450">, as in fr. 760. 2 the poet calls her <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν Διὸς γοργῶπιν Ἐργάνην</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.199"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 199</ref>, where Athena appears to Achilles: <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτίκα δ’ ἔγνω | Παλλάδ’ Ἀθηναίην· δεινὼ δέ οἱ ὄσσε φάανθεν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀδάματος_450"> is the form required by metre in <ref n="Soph. OT 205"> <title>O. T.</title> 205</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 1315"> O. T. 1315</ref>, and <ref n="Soph. OC 1572"> <title>O. C.</title> 1572</ref>; though in all three passages L gives the epic form <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀδάμαστος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπεντύνον_451"> ‘making ready’: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐτρεπίζοντα</quote>. <ref n="Hom. Il. 8.374"> <title>Il.</title> 8. 374</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ σὺ μὲν νῦν νῶιν ἐπέντυε μώνυχας ἵππους</quote>. Oppian <ref n="Opp. H. 5. 562"> <title>Hal.</title> 5. 562</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤδη γὰρ δελφῖσιν ἐπεντύνουσιν Ἄρηα</quote>.—The reading </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπευθύνοντ_451"> seems less fitting in reference to the <emph>purpose</emph> which the goddess foiled. It rather pictures him as already in the <emph> act</emph> of stretching forth his hand against his foes. But Athena had not suffered him to arrive in their presence; he had only reached their doors (49). If, however, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπευθύνοντ’</quote> is to mean merely, ‘<emph>preparing</emph> for use against them,’ then it is decidedly less vivid than <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεντύνοντ’</quote>. The chief recommendation of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπευθύνοντ’</quote> is the fact that it was first written by the scribe of L, though corrected either by him or by an early hand. But (since <quote xml:lang="grc"> εὐθύνω</quote> was so familiar) it may easily have been a mere slip for the rarer and more exquisite word <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεντύνοντ’</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λυσσώδη_νόσον_452">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 59">cp. 59</ref>: fr. 855. 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">λύσσα μαινάς</quote>. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 13.53"> <title>Il.</title> 13. 53</ref>Hector is <quote xml:lang="grc">λυσσώδης, φλογὶ εἴκελος</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπεγγελῶσιν_454">. A compound used in Attic prose, but otherwise peculiar to this play; it recurs in vv. 969, 989. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμοῦ_μὲν_455">: the particle merely emphasises the pron.: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 121">cp. 121</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βλάπτοι_455">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 696"> <title>El.</title> 696</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν δέ τις θεῶν | βλάπτῃ, δύναιτ’ ἂν οὐδ’ ἂν ἰσχύων φυγεῖν</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅστις_457">, causal. It is needless to read <quote xml:lang="grc">δρᾶν <emph>μ’</emph> </quote>. See on <ref n="Soph. OC 263"> <title>O. C.</title> 263</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἄμοιγε ποῦ ταῦτ’ ἐστίν; οἵτινες κ.τ.λ.</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεὶ ὑμεῖς</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μισεῖ_μ_457">: the relative clause passes into an independent sentence; see appendix on <ref n="Soph. OC 424."> <title>O. C.</title> 424.</ref>— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεδία_457">: for the tribrach in the 5th foot, consisting of a single word, cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 719"> <title>O. T.</title> 719</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄβατον ὄρος</quote> (n.), <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1496 <quote xml:lang="grc">πατέρα πατήρ</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πότερα_460">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 265">cp. 265</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναυλόχους_ἕδρας_460">. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Hec. 1015">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 1015</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀχαιῶν ναύλοχοι περιπτυχαί</quote> (the Greek camp at the ships, with its <quote xml:lang="grc">τεῖχος</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μόνους_Ἀτρείδας_460"> (<quote xml:lang="grc"> λιπών</quote>), <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, leaving them bereft of my aid. <ref n="Eur. Med. 52">Eur. <title>Med.</title> 52</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς σοῦ μόνη Μήδεια λείπεσθαι θέλει;</quote> Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.437"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 437</ref>, where Phoenix imagines himself remaining with the army at Troy after Achilles has gone home,—<quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς ἂν ἔπειτ’ ἀπὸ σεῖο, φίλον τέκος, αὖθι λιποίμην | οἶος;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_ποῖον_462">..; for <quote xml:lang="grc">καί</quote> in questions, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 263"> <title>O. C.</title> 263</ref>(n.), <ref n="Soph. El. 236."> <title>El.</title> 236.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄμμα_462">: so <ref n="Soph. OT 1371"> <title>O. T.</title> 1371</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ γὰρ οὐκ οἶδ’ ὄμμασιν ποίοις βλέπων | πατέρα ποτ’ ἂν προσεῖδον</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 110"> <title>Ph.</title> 110</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς οὖν βλέπων τις ταῦτα τολμήσει λακεῖν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γυμνὸν_464"> is defined by <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἀριστείων ἄτερ</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 31"> <title>Ph.</title> 31</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κενὴν οἴκησιν ἀνθρώπων δίχα</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 57"> <title>O. T.</title> 57</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρημος ἀνδρῶν μὴ ξυνοικούντων ἔσω</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 445"> <title>Ant.</title> 445</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξω βαρείας αἰτίας ἐλεύθερον</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_στέφανον_464"> (‘a glory-crown of which’..): both genitives define the quality of the <quote xml:lang="grc">στέφανος</quote>, but <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐκλείας</quote> goes more closely with it: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 308">cp. 308</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρειπίοις | νεκρῶν...ἀρνείου φόνου</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλὰ_δῆτ_466">, introducing another alternative, as in <ref n="Eur. El. 537"> <title>El.</title> 537</ref>(n.).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔρυμα_466">, their city-wall; cp. <ref n="Hdt. 7. 223"> Her. 7. 223</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ ἔρυμα τοῦ τείχεος.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μόνος_μόνοις_466">: for the doubled adj., <ref target="cl267">see on 267</ref>. The point of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μόνοις_466"> is that the Trojans will not have their attention distracted by any other Greek foe. The phrase is thus an expression of the warrior's proud self-reliance (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 423">cp. 423</ref> f.): it is marred by reading <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλοῖς μόνος</quote> (cr. n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρῶν_χρηστόν_466">: for the order of words, cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 128">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 128</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἐργάσομαί τι δεινὸν ἔργον καὶ μέγα</quote>. The sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">δρᾶν τι</quote> alone is often similar: <ref n="Eur. El. 30"> <title>El.</title> 30</ref>5n. The pres. part., not <quote xml:lang="grc">δράσας</quote>, because he would die in the act.—There was a legend, which the poet glances at here, that Ajax, in his madness, attacked the Trojans with success; <emph>manu restituit praelium insaniens</emph> ( <ref n="Cic. Tusc. 4. 23">Cic. <title>Tusc.</title> 4. 23</ref>); and that his death was caused by an arrow from the bow of Paris: see n. on the Argument to the play, line 33. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀτρείδας_που_469">. <cit> <bibl n="Verg. A. 2.104">Verg. <title>Aen.</title> 2. 104</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">Hoc Ithacus velit et magno mercentur Atreidae.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: Hoc Ithacus velit et magno mercentur Atreidae.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ταῦτα_470">, as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 449"> <title>Tr.</title> 449</ref>: but <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔστι</quote> simply, <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 709, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 289"> <title>Ant.</title> 289</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 448."> <title>El.</title> 448.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δηλώσω_γεγώς_471">: cp. <ref n="Thuc. 1. 21">Thuc. 1. 21</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">δηλώσει...μείζων γεγενημένος</quote>: Andoc. or. 4 § 14 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐδήλωσε τῶν νόμων καταφρονῶν.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μή_γ_471">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">μή τοι...γε</quote>, see on <ref n="Eur. El. 518."> <title>El.</title> 518.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοι_471"> (‘at any rate,’ Lat. <emph>sane</emph>) limits, while </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_471"> emphasises the word which it follows. Note that </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔ_τοι_471"> could be used here, if the result were viewed simply as a fact; <ref n="Soph. OC 1353"> <title>O. C.</title> 1353</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκούσας</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιαῦθ’ ἃ τὸν τοῦδ’ οὔ ποτ’ εὐφρανεῖ βίον</quote>. But </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μή_τοι_471"> is used, because the result is viewed as an aim; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the relative clause is virtually a final clause: cp. <ref n="Isoc. 11.49">Isocr. or. 11 § 49</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιαῦτα ζητήσεις λέγειν, ἐξ ὧν μήτ’ αὐτὸς χείρων εἶναι δόξεις μήτε τοὺς μιμουμένους λυμανεῖ μήτε τὴν περὶ τοὺς λόγους παίδευσιν διαβαλεῖς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄσπλαγχνος_471">, only here in this sense; but cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">κακόσπλαγχνος</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Seven 237">Aesch. <title>Th.</title> 237</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">θρασύσπλαγχνος</quote>: and <quote xml:lang="grc"> εὐσπλαγχνία</quote> [Eur. ] <title>Rhes.</title> 192. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_βίου_473">, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, the normal span of life; cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 518"> <title>O. T.</title> 518</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτοι βίου μοι τοῦ μακραίωνος πόθος</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοῖσιν_ἐξαλλάσσεται_473">, finds no variation in respect to his woes; for the dat. cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 25"> <title>O. T.</title> 25</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φθίνουσα μὲν κάλυξιν</quote>: <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 4. 1. 8">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 4. 1. 8</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">διεφθάρθαι..ταῖς γνώμαις</quote>. The generic negative </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδὲν_473"> is used, because <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις</quote> refers to a class or type. (Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 178">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 178</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις..μὴ..ἅπτεται</quote>.) For the sentiment, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 463">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 463</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις γὰρ ἐν πολλοῖσιν, ὡς ἐγώ, κακοῖς | ζῇ, πῶς ὅδ’ οὐχὶ κατθανὼν κέρδος φέρει;</quote> fr. 866 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις γὰρ ἐν κακοῖσιν ἱμείρει βίου</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ δειλός ἐστιν ἢ δυσάλγητος φρένας</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρ_ἡμέρα_475">, ‘the <emph>successive</emph>’ (not, ‘<emph>alternate</emph>’) ‘days’: the series formed by placing each new day at the side of its predecessors, as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνὴρ παρ’ ἄνδρα</quote> could be said of forming men in rank. The sense is: ‘When a man's miseries are unbroken, <quote xml:lang="grc">τί τέρπειν ἔχει ἡμέρα παρ’ ἦμαρ</quote>, what power to please him has each successive day, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσθεῖσα_475"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸν</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ κατθανεῖν</quote>, when it has brought him close up to death, <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>κἀναθεῖσα</emph> τοῦ κατθανεῖν</quote>, and then again moved him back from death?’ Death is the boundary-line (<quote xml:lang="grc"> γραμμή</quote>) on the field of life: <ref n="Eur. El. 955">Eur. <title> El.</title> 955</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὶν ἂν πέλας | γραμμῆς ἵκηται καὶ τέλος κάμψῃ βίου</quote> (<emph>mors ultima linea rerum</emph>). The man who is captive to evil fortune is like a <quote xml:lang="grc"> πεσσός</quote> on the draughtboard, at one moment moved close up to the line, and then again withdrawn from it a little; but it is death, after all,—death and nothing else,—that awaits him (<quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ <emph> γε</emph> κατθανεῖν</quote>). This is not the platitude, ‘all men must die’, but a thought sug gested by the case of the man ‘whose woes are unvarying.’ <title>Life</title> has nothing in store for him; the question is merely whether he is to die at once, or to have a short and wretched reprieve. This is brought out by v. 479: <quote xml:lang="grc">καλῶς ζῆν</quote> is denied to him; and that being so, the next best thing is to die honourably <emph>and quickly</emph>—<quote xml:lang="grc">καλῶς τεθνηκέναι</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσθεῖσα_475_2">: cp. <title>I. A.</title> 540 <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὶν Ἅιδῃ παῖδ’ ἐμὴν προσθῶ λαβών</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Hec. 368"> <title>Hec.</title> 368</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἅιδῃ προστιθεῖσ’ ἐμὸν δέμας</quote>. The dat. <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ κατθανεῖν</quote> is easily supplied from the genitive, which is adapted to the nearer participle.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀναθεῖσα_475">. Cp. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀνατίθεσθαι</quote>, to ‘take back’ a move, to ‘retract’ an opinion ( <ref n="Xen. Mem. 1. 2">Xen. <title>Mem.</title> 1. 2</ref>§ 44, etc.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πριαίμην_477">: cp. Eur. fr. 934 <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλον πρίασθαι χρημάτων πολλῶν σαφῆ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγου_477"> here=‘estimate,’ ‘rate of value’: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1225"> <title>O. C.</title> 1225</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ φῦναι τὸν ἅπαντα νικᾷ λόγον</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τεθνηκέναι_479">: for the perf., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 275">cp. 275</ref> n.: for the sentiment, <ref n="Eur. El. 1320"> <title>El.</title> 1320</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ γὰρ ἂν καλῶς | ἔσωσ’ ἐμαυτήν, ἢ καλῶς ἀπωλόμην.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάντ_λόγον_479">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 876"> <title>Tr.</title> 876</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντ’ ἀκήκοας</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Phil. 241"> <title>Ph.</title> 241</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶσθα δὴ τὸ πᾶν</quote> : <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 582">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 582</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντ’ ἔχεις λόγον</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπόβλητον_481">: <ref target="cl188">see on 188</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποβαλλόμενοι</quote>. Eustath. p. 106. 7 <quote xml:lang="grc">Σοφοκλῆς ὑποβολιμαίους εἶπε λόγους τοὺς μὴ γνησίους</quote>. (In <ref n="Soph. OC 794"> <title>O. C.</title> 794</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπόβλητον στόμα</quote>, the sense is, ‘suborned.’) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_μέντοι_483">: <ref n="Soph. OT 442"> <title>O. T.</title> 442</ref> n.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρατῆσαι_483">, aor., as the sense is, ‘to gain a victory.’ <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1353">Cp. 1353</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_τύχης_485">. The phrase means simply, ‘a fortune imposed by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάγκη</quote>,’—by necessity, fate; but it has different shades of meaning according to the context. Here, it is the fortune by which <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάγκη</quote> has doomed her to be a slave; but there is no <emph>direct</emph> reference to slavery in the words. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 803">Cp. 803</ref>. In <ref n="Eur. El. 48"> <title>El.</title> 48</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναγκαίας τύχης</quote> is the ‘fatal chance’ by which Orestes was killed. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 16.836"> <title>Il.</title> 16. 836</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦμαρ ἀναγκαῖον</quote> is ‘the day of doom’ hanging over Troy. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴπερ_σθένοντος_488">,=<quote xml:lang="grc">σθένοντος, εἴ τις ἔσθενε</quote>: cp. <title>O.C.</title> 733 <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς πόλιν δ’ ἐπίσταμαι | σθένουσαν ἥκων, εἴ τιν’ Ἑλλάδος, μέγα</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_πλούτῳ_488">, lit., <emph>amid</emph> wealth; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the phrase = ‘strong <emph>and</emph> rich,’ rather than, ‘strong <emph>in</emph> riches.’ Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 996">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 996</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χαίρετ’ ἐν αἰσιμίαισι πλούτου</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοῖς_489">: for the synizesis, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1129">cp. 1129</ref>: <ref n="Eur. El. 1264"> <title>El.</title> 1264</ref> n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάλιστα_489">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, as the immediate and visible agent of the gods. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιγαροῦν_490">, ‘So then’—marking that she turns away from the mournful past.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ξυνῆλθον_490">: <quote xml:lang="grc">λέχος</quote> is acc., as after a verb of motion: <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 817">Eur. <title>Phoen.</title> 817</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ δὲ ξύναιμον λέχος ἦλθεν</quote>. (In <ref n="Soph. Trach. 28">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 28</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέχος</quote> is rather nom., ‘as bride.’)</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_σά_490">, acc. of respect, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">σοι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐφεστίου_Διὸς_492">, the god of the domestic <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑστία</quote>. In <ref n="Hdt. 1. 44"> Her. 1. 44</ref> the <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἐπίστιος Ζεύς</quote> is the god who punishes a wrong done to the hearth by an abuse of hospitality. Cp. Eustath. p. 1930. 28 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῇ κατ’ οἶκον ἑστίᾳ Δΐ ἐγίνοντο θυσίαι, ὃν οἱ μὲν ἄλλοι ἐφέστιον, Ἡρόδοτος δὲ Ἰωνικῶς λέγει ἐπίστιον</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συνηλλάχθης_493">: cp. <ref n="Eur. Andr. 1245"> Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 1245</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἑλένῳ συναλλαχθεῖσαν εὐναίοις γάμοις</quote>,—where, as here, the bride became such by the fortune of war. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάξιν_ἐχθρῶν_494">: cp. <ref n="Hdt. 9. 78"> Her. 9. 78</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπαινον ἕξεις..ὑπὸ πάντων</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 576">Eur. <title>Phoen.</title> 576</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλέος | τοιόνδε..ὑφ’ Ἑλλήνων λαβεῖν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χειρίαν_494">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποχείριον</quote> : <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 177">Eur. <title>Cycl.</title> 177</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλάβετε Τροίαν τὴν Ἑλένην τε χειρίαν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐφεὶς_494">, having yielded up: <ref n="Thuc. 1. 95">Thuc. 1. 95</ref>§ 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷς οὐκέτι ἐφίεσαν οἱ ξύμμαχοι τὴν ἡγεμονίαν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾗ_σὺ_496"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The reason for preferring Bothe's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾗ_496"> to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_496"> is that it brings out her thought with greater force: the last day of his life will be the first of her misery. There is no objection to <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ</quote> with the subjunctive, even in trimeters; cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1443"> <title>O. C.</title> 1443</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ σου στερηθῶ</quote>, and see <title>O.T.</title> 198 n. Either <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾗ</quote> would have been written EI by Sophocles.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφῇς_496">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">με</quote>: but it is needless to write <quote xml:lang="grc">μ’ ἀφῇς</quote> with Brunck. For the omission of the pron. in acc., cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 801"> <title>Ph.</title> 801</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμπρησον</quote> (‘burn me’): <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 769 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕκηλον εὕδειν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόν</quote>): <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1368 <quote xml:lang="grc">πέμψον</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">με</quote>): <title>O.T.</title> 461 <quote xml:lang="grc">κἂν λάβῃς ἐψευσμένον</quote>.—For the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφῇς</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 887"> <title>Ant.</title> 887</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄφετε μόνην, ἔρημον</quote>: <ref n="Hdt. 8. 70"> Her. 8. 70</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπέντες τὴν ἑωυτῶν ἀφύλακτον</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυναρπασθεῖσαν_498">. Ajax being now viewed as a public enemy (1132), his property, including the <quote xml:lang="grc"> δούλη</quote> and her son, would be seized by the Greek chiefs.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δουλίαν_498">: the comparative rarity of the fem. form led to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δούλιν_498"> displacing it in some MSS. (cr. n.); but cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1084">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1084</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δουλίᾳ..φρενί</quote>: <ref n="Hdt. 3. 14"> Her. 3. 14</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσθῆτι δουλίῃ</quote> (or <quote xml:lang="grc">δουληίῃ</quote>). The Attic prose word would be <quote xml:lang="grc">δουλικήν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τροφή_498">, mode of life; <ref n="Eur. El. 1183"> <title>El.</title> 1183</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσμόρου..τροφῆς</quote> : <title>O.C.</title> 1687 <quote xml:lang="grc">δύσοιστον ἕξομεν τροφάν</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καί_τις_500"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> A reminiscence of <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.459"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 459 ff.</ref> (where Hector forebodes the fate of Andromachè) <quote xml:lang="grc">καί ποτέ τις εἴπῃσιν, ἰδὼν κατὰ δάκρυ χέουσαν· | ‘Ἕκτορος ἥδε γυνή, ὃς ἀριστεύεσκε μάχεσθαι | Τρώων ἱπποδάμων, ὅτε Ἴλιον ἀμφεμάχοντο.’</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πικρὸν_ἐρεῖ_500"> describes what will be said, not to her, but <emph>of</emph> her; cp. <title>Polit.</title> p. 287 E <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγγεῖον ὃ δὴ μιᾷ κλήσει προσφθεγγόμεθα</quote> (call by that name). Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1213"> <title>El.</title> 1213</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔ σοι προσήκει τήνδε προσφωνεῖν φάτιν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόν</quote>), <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, to speak of him as dead. The reference of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πικρὸν_500"> is not only to the scornful word <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμευνέτιν</quote>, but also to <quote xml:lang="grc">οἵας λατρείας κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγοις_ἰάπτων_500">, lit. ‘shooting with words,’—launching taunts like missiles. The instrum. dat. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγοις_500"> marks the figurative sense of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰάπτων_500">, just as <quote xml:lang="grc">τόξοις</quote> defines its literal sense in <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 510">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 510</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">τόξοις ἰάπτων μηκέτ’ εἰς ἡμᾶς βέλη</quote>): the object answering to the literal <quote xml:lang="grc">βέλη</quote> (such as <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀνείδη</quote>) is left to be understood. Cp. Rhianus (3rd cent. B.C.) <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Stobaeus <title>Flor.</title> 4. 34. 9 <quote xml:lang="grc">μακάρεσσιν ἐπὶ ψόγον αἰνὸν ἰάπτει</quote> (by tmesis for <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐπιάπτει</quote>). This seems truer than to suppose that the constr. is <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγοις ἰάπτων</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">με</quote>), ‘assailing me with taunts,’ though the latter view might be supported by the rare use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰάλλω</quote> in <ref n="Hom. Od. 13.142"> <title>Od.</title> 13. 142</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρεσβύτατον καὶ ἄριστον ἀτι‐</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">μίῃσιν ἰάλλειν</quote>. As to the root of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰάπτω</quote>, Curtius holds that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰα‐π</quote> is expanded from <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἰα</quote> (=Skt. <foreign xml:lang="sanskrit">jA</foreign>, ‘go’), in a causative sense, by the determinative <quote xml:lang="grc">π</quote>, just as the Lat. <emph><*>a-c</emph> is by <emph>k.</emph> (<title>Greek Verb</title>, p. 167 Eng. ed.) <ref n="Soph. Aj. 700">Cp. 700</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵσχυσε_502"> would usu. be an ‘ingressive’ aor. (‘became powerful’), like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνόσησε</quote> etc. Here, however, it refers to the past <emph>period</emph> of his pre-eminence; as the reign of a king is summed up in retrospect by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦρξε, ἐβασίλευσε</quote>. Cp. the aor. in <ref n="Eur. El. 1144"> <title>El.</title> 1144</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">τροφῆς</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν ἐγὼ θάμ’ ἀμφὶ σοὶ | πόνῳ γλυκεῖ παρέσχον</quote>: where Electra looks back on a closed chapter of her life.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἵας_ὅσου_502">: for this double relative in contrasts, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 923">cp. 923</ref>, <ref n="Eur. El. 751"> <title>El.</title> 751</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1045"> <title>Tr.</title> 1045</ref>, etc.; <ref n="Thuc. 5. 7">Thuc. 5. 7</ref>§ 2, <ref n="Thuc. 7. 75">Thuc. 7. 75</ref>§ 6.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζήλου_502">, enviable happiness; cp. <ref n="Dem. 23.64">Dem. or. 23 § 64</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃ καὶ ζῆλόν τινα καὶ τιμὴν φέρει τῇ πόλει. </quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρέφει_502">, only a stronger <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχει</quote>,—has around her in her daily life. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 503">Cp. 503</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 817"> <title>Tr.</title> 817</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὄγκον..ὀνόματος..τρέφειν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 795"> <title>Ph.</title> 795</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρέφοιτε..νόσον</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀμὲ_μὲν_504"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The chief emphasis is on the clause </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοὶ_αἰσχρὰ_504"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: she merely glances at the results to herself; ‘while I shall suffer, thou and thine will be disgraced.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλᾷ_504">, <emph>vexabit</emph>, as in 756; cp. also 275.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰσχρὰ_504">: Ajax had said that it was <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχρόν</quote>, in such a case as his, to go on living (473). Tecmessa wishes him to feel that it would be <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχρόν</quote> to die. But Ajax believes that Teucer's care will avert the evils which she fears (562). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἴδεσαι_προλείπων_506">. The participle, when used with <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχύνομαι</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰδοῦμαι</quote>, implies that the person is doing, or has done, the act which causes shame. The infinitive implies that he has not yet done it. Cp. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 5. 1">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 5. 1</ref>§ 21 <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τοῦτο μὲν οὐκ αἰσχύνομαι λέγων· τὸ δ’ ‘ἐὰν μένητε παρ’ ἐμοί, ἀποδώσω,’.. αἰσχυνοίμην ἂν εἰπεῖν</quote>: (‘I am not ashamed <emph>of saying</emph> this; but I should be ashamed <emph>to say</emph> that.’) Here, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προλείπων_506"> is more forcible than an infinitive. Since his words pointed to a fixed resolve (479 f.), she speaks as if he were already engaged in the deed.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κληροῦχον_506"> is not elsewhere thus used, but the fact that a word had a technical (and prosaic) sense was no bar to its figurative use in Attic poetry; cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">πράκτωρ</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔθυνος</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. El. 953"> <title>El.</title> 953</ref> n.). <ref n="Isoc. 5.136">Isocr. or. 5 § 136</ref> has the phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐνοίας..κληρονόμους</quote> (‘heirs’).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρᾶται_506">, in a good sense, as in <ref n="Soph. OC 1445"> <title>O. C.</title> 1445</ref>, where see n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴκτιρε_510">..</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_510"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> A clause with <quote xml:lang="grc"> εἰ</quote> and fut. indic. often denotes an object of pity or indignation ( <ref n="Eur. El. 1210"> <title>El.</title> 1210</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 988"> <title>Ph.</title> 988</ref>). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 13.15">Lys. or. 13 § 15</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐλεοῦντες..τὰ τείχη, εἰ πεσεῖται, οὐδὲ κηδόμενοι τῶν νεῶν, εἰ..παραδοθήσονται.— <emph>νέας τροφῆς</emph> </quote> </cit>, the nurture suitable to the young: <ref n="Soph. OC 345"> <title>O. C.</title> 345</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ὅτου νέας | τροφῆς ἔληξε</quote> (n.).</gloss>

data.quote:
οὐκ ἐλεοῦντες..τὰ τείχη, εἰ πεσεῖται, οὐδὲ
							κηδόμενοι τῶν νεῶν, εἰ..παραδοθήσονται.—

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διοίσεται_510">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">βίον</quote>, ‘pass his life’: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">διάξει, βιώσεται</quote>. The midd. has this absolute sense in Hippocr. <title>De artic.</title> p. 823 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑγιηροὶ τἄλλα..διαφέρονται</quote> (‘they pass through life’): <ref n="Xen. Mem. 2. 1. 24">Xen. <title>Mem.</title> 2. 1. 24</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκοπούμενος διοίσει</quote> (a correction of <quote xml:lang="grc">διέσῃ</quote>). We find also <quote xml:lang="grc">διαφέρειν βίον</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰῶνα</quote> ( <ref n="Hdt. 3. 40"> Her. 3. 40</ref>, <title>Helen.</title> 10), or <quote xml:lang="grc">διαφέρειν</quote> only ([Eur. ] <title>Rhes.</title> 982).—Others explain <quote xml:lang="grc">διοίσεται</quote> as pass., <emph> diripietur</emph>, ‘(if) he shall be plundered.’ In this sense the usual word is <quote xml:lang="grc">διαφορεῖν</quote>, though <ref n="Eur. Ba. 754">Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 754</ref> has <quote xml:lang="grc">διέφερον</quote> in a kindred sense, and <ref n="Aristot. Poet. 1451a">Arist. <title>Poet.</title> 8</ref>§ 4 the pass. <quote xml:lang="grc">διαφέρεσθαι</quote>: but such a meaning, which would fix attention on the boy's property, is utterly out of place here. [Lobeck, and Blaydes after him, cite Dion or. 41 p. 506 C <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπ’ ὀρφανιστῶν διασπασθήσεται</quote>: but the correct reference is or. 43 p. 506 C, and the words, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπὸ τῶν συγγενῶν καὶ ἐπιτρόπων διασπασθῆναι</quote> .]— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_μόνος_510">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1250">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1250</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρῶν γε μοῦνος</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Med. 52">Eur. <title> Med.</title> 52</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοῦ μόνη</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπ_ὀρφανιστῶν_512"> (<quote xml:lang="grc"> διοίσεται</quote>), if he shall have his life <emph>controlled by</emph> them: cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπό</quote> with the midd. <quote xml:lang="grc">πορεύεται</quote> in 1253 f.: <ref n="Soph. OC 681"> <title>O. C.</title> 681</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θἁλλει δ’..ὑπ’ ἄχνας</quote>. The sense is not merely, ‘live <emph>under</emph> them,’ as if <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπό</quote> with the genitive here took the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπό</quote> with the dative (<emph>subditus illorum imperio</emph>, Ellendt).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_φίλων_512"> (the generic <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote>), of no friendly kind; for the order, cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 903">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 903</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁποῖα νίκης μὴ κακῆς ἐπίσκοπα</quote>. [The <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ</quote> could also be explained by <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ</quote> in 510: but this is less simple.]</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βλέπω_514">, pres. subjunct.: this is the indirect form of <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς τί βλέπω;</quote> <ref n="Soph. Aj. 428">Cp. 428</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐῶ</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾔστωσας_514">. There is no other certain instance of <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾀστόω</quote> for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀϊστόω</quote>. (In fr. 493, <quote xml:lang="grc">κόρον ἀϊστώσας πυρί</quote>, Kuster's conjecture <quote xml:lang="grc">κηρὸν</quote>, if right, would point to <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾀστώσας</quote>.) The ordinary form occurs in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 881"> <title>Tr.</title> 881</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὑτὴν διηΐστωσε.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δορί_514">. As to this form <emph>versus</emph> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δόρει_514">, see on <title>O.C.</title> 1304. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλη_μοῖρα_516">. Destiny, working through Ajax, ravaged her country. Destiny in some other form brought her father and mother to the grave.
