The poet did not wish to represent Tecmessa as living with the man who had slain her parents; and so followed, or invented, a legend which ascribed their deaths to a different agency. Throughout this speech, the Homeric scene between Hector and Andromachè is present to the mind of Sophocles. Andromachè's father had been slain by Achilles; her mother, by the visitation of Artemis ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.414"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 414</ref>—428). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καθεῖλεν_οἰκήτορας_517"> (proleptic), brought them low, so that they should be dwellers, etc. After </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἅιδου_θανασίμους_517"> is redundant; but cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1161"> <title>Tr.</title> 1161</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὅστις Ἅιδου φθίμενος οἰκήτωρ πέλοι</quote>: though <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 282 we have simply, <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἅιδου πάντες εἴσ’ οἰκήτορες</quote>. For <quote xml:lang="grc">θανάσιμος</quote> said of the <emph>dead</emph>, cp. <title>O.T.</title> 959, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 819."> <title>Ph.</title> 819.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατρίς_518">: Cp. <ref n="Xen. Anab. 1. 3">Xen. <title> An.</title> 1. 3</ref>§ 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">νομίζω γὰρ ὑμᾶς ἐμοὶ εἶναι καὶ πατρίδα καὶ φίλους καὶ συμμάχους</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_σῴζομαι_518">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 314"> <title>O. T.</title> 314</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν σοὶ γὰρ ἐσμέν</quote> (n.). The prep. expresses that her safety is in his power,—depends on him. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶς_518">, adverbial: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 275">cp. 275</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀμοῦ_520">: as well as of his parents and his son.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσεῖναι_520">, of a quality or attribute; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1079">cp. 1079</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 720."> <title>Ant.</title> 720.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τερπνὸν_πάθοι_520">: cp. Dido's words to Aeneas ( <ref n="Verg. A. 4. 316"> <title>Aen.</title> 4. 316</ref> ff.) <quote xml:lang="lat">Per conubia nostra, per inceptos hymenaeos, | Si bene quid de te merui, fuit aut tibi quicquam | Dulce meum, miserere.</quote> For the optat., marking the generality of the statement, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1344">cp. 1344</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 666"> <title>Ant.</title> 666</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ δ\ν πόλις στήσειε, τοῦδε χρὴ κλύειν</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χάρις_γάρ_522">: <title>Helen.</title> 1234 <quote xml:lang="grc">χάρις γὰρ ἀντὶ χάριτος ἐλθέτω</quote>. For the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">γάρ</quote>, cp. <ref n="Aesch. PB 29">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 29</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεὸς θεῶν γάρ κ.τ.λ.</quote>: for that of the art., <ref n="Soph. OT 139">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 139</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖνον ὁ κτανών.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίκτους_522">: cp. the proverb in Zenobius 3. 328 <quote xml:lang="grc">δίκη δίκην ἔτικτε καὶ βλάβη βλάβην</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπορρεῖ_523">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1267">cp. 1267</ref> : <ref n="Eur. El. 1000"> <title>El.</title> 1000</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γένοιτ_523">, cannot ‘become’ such, in the sense, ‘cannot finally be ranked as such.’ Whatever his other merits may be, their sum will not amount to true nobleness. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχειν_ἄν_525">: the first <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote>, as well as the second, belongs to <quote xml:lang="grc">θέλοιμι</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 537">cp. 537</ref> : <title>O.T.</title> 339 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_κἀγὼ_525">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχω</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.476"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 476</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δότε δὴ καὶ τόνδε γενέσθαι | παῖδ’ ἐμόν, ὡς καὶ ἐγώ περ, ἀριπρεπέα Τρώεσσιν</quote>: this also illustrates the use of <quote xml:lang="grc">καί</quote>, on which see <title>O.C.</title> 53 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσ’ οἶδα κἀγώ</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_κάρτ_527">. Here <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote>=‘and.’ But where <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ κάρτα</quote> replies to a question (<title>O.C.</title> 65 and 301), the verb being understood, <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> merely emphasises (‘Yea, surely’), and <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ κάρτα</quote> is then equiv. to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ κάρτα</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. El. 312"> <title>El.</title> 312</ref>). Similarly in <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μάλα, καὶ</quote> sometimes=‘and,’ but sometimes merely strengthens the adv. (<emph>vel maxime</emph>): <ref n="Eur. El. 1178"> <title>El.</title> 1178</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ταχθὲν_527">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὃ ἂν ταχθῇ</quote>: he has not yet given his command. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1187"> <title>Tr.</title> 1187</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ μὴν ἐμοὶ τὸ λεχθὲν ἔργον ἐκτελεῖν</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃ ἂν λεχθῇ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τολμᾷ_527">, bring herself to do it: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 411">cp. 411</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 481"> <title>Ph.</title> 481</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τόλμησον</quote>, ‘make the effort.’ Instead of agreeing to take her <emph>advice</emph> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπη</quote>), Ajax replies that he will be ready to praise her <emph>obedience.</emph> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_529">, in assent; cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 48"> <title>Ph.</title> 48</ref> n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἴδω_530">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 538">cp. 538</ref>. The words express his impatient yearning. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_γ_531">. The formula <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μήν</quote> (lit. ‘and verily’) introduces a new fact or thought; as in Tragedy it often announces a new comer (1168). When this new fact or thought raises a difficulty in the way of something proposed by the last speaker, then <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μήν</quote> acquires an adversative force. Thus here, its literal sense, ‘and verily,’ ‘indeed,’ is tinged by the context with the sense, ‘oh, but,’ or ‘nay, but.’ The effect of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_531"> is to place a slight stress on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φόβοισι_531">. The combination </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_γε_531"> is very frequent with Sophocles: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 539">cp. 539</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OT 290"> <title>O. T.</title> 290</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 345"> O. T. 345</ref> , <ref n="Soph. OT 836"> O. T. 836</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 987"> O. T. 987</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 1004"> O. T. 1004</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 1066"> O. T. 1066</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OC 396"> <title>O. C.</title> 396</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 221"> <title>Ant.</title> 221</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 660"> <title>Ph.</title> 660</ref>: <ref n="Soph. El. 1045"> <title>El.</title> 1045</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 1188."> El. 1188.</ref>In all these passages the effect of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_531_2"> is the same; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, it does not modify the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μήν</quote>, but emphasises the word or phrase with which it is immediately connected.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φόβοισι_531_2">, causal dat.: the plur. as in <ref n="Soph. OT 585"> <title>O. T.</title> 585</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξὺν φόβοισι</quote>. Her fears were indicated at v. 340.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξελυσάμην_531">, lit. ‘released’: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, allowed him to leave the tent. The midd. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκλύομαι</quote> means to ‘release,’ ‘set free,’ in <title>O.T.</title> 1003, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1112"> <title>Ant.</title> 1112</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 21"> <title>Tr.</title> 21</ref>: <title>H.</title> 7. 1. 25 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξελύσαντο τοὺς Ἀργείους</quote>. The choice of the word seems to be prompted by a wish not to say more than is implied in <quote xml:lang="grc">φόβοισι</quote>, or to imply that she had <emph> rescued</emph> the child from a danger. She speaks merely as if (in her undefined ‘fears’) she had left the care of the child to others. Then the blunt and impatient question of Ajax—<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τοῖσδε τοῖς κακοῖσιν κ.τ.λ.</quote>—startles her into speaking plainly,—<quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ σοί γέ που δύστηνος κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξερρυσάμην_531"> (cr. n.), ‘rescued,’ would efface this trait of reticence. It is inferred from the scholiast's phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν φόβων χάριν ῥύσασθαι θέλουσα ἐξήγαγον</quote>. But <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξήγαγον</quote> is there the important word, while the words <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥύσασθαι θέλουσα</quote> are merely the scholiast's expansion of the motive implied in <quote xml:lang="grc">φόβοισι</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοῖσιν_532">: a half-euphemistic phrase, as in 272, 431, 433. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_γε_533"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> Here <quote xml:lang="grc">γε</quote> replies to his question (‘<title> Yes</title>, lest..’), and qualifies the whole sentence (cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 648"> <title>Ant.</title> 648</ref> n.): but it also adds to the emphasis on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοί_533">. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρέπον_ἦν_534">. For <quote xml:lang="grc">γέ τοι</quote> cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 823"> <title>Ph.</title> 823</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δαίμονος_534">, fortune: <ref n="Eur. El. 1306"> <title>El.</title> 1306</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ παρόντι δαίμονι</quote>. A gen. after <quote xml:lang="grc">πρέπων</quote> is very rare, but analogous to the gen. after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄξιος</quote>: Plat. <title>Menex.</title>p. 239 C <quote xml:lang="grc">πρεπόντως τῶν πραξάντων</quote>. [In Plat. <title>Rep.</title>p. 400 B <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕβρεως ἢ μανίας καὶ ἄλλης κακίας πρέπουσαι βάσεις</quote>, the gen. seems to depend on <quote xml:lang="grc">πρέπουσαι</quote>: but might be possessive.] </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_οὖν_535"> (‘well, at any rate’), followed by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_535"> (emphasising the word before it), occurs also in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 84"> <title>Ant.</title> 84</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1305"> <title>Ph.</title> 1305</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 233"> <title>El.</title> 233</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 1035"> El. 1035</ref>, etc.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φύλαξα_535">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 308">cp. 308</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">)θώϋξεν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρκέσαι_535">, infin. of purpose: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 198"> <title>O. T.</title> 198</ref> n. For the sense, <emph>defendere</emph>, cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.289"> <title>Il.</title> 20. 289</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ κόρυθ’ ἠὲ σάκος, τό οἱ ἤρκεσε λυγρὸν ὄλεθρον</quote>: <ref n="Eur. El. 1300">Eur. <title> El.</title> 1300</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἠρκέσατον κῆρας μελάθροις;</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπῄνες_536">: for the aor., cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 668"> <title>El.</title> 668</ref> n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔθου_536">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 13">cp. 13</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_τῶνδ_537">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, seeing that the child has been sent away, and that Ajax approves of her precaution (536). She wishes to divert him from the desire of seeing his son. But he instantly recurs to it.—For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτῶνδε_537">, ‘under these conditions,’ cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1109"> <title>Tr.</title> 1109</ref>(n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_537"> gives a limiting force (as in <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐμοί</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 395"> Tr. 395</ref>): <ref n="Eur. Andr. 1184"> Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 1184</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτός τ’ ἂν ὡς ἐκ τῶνδ’ ἐτιμᾶτ’ ἄν, γέρον</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">θανών</quote> . <ref n="Thuc. 4. 17">Thuc. 4. 17</ref>§ 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐκ τῶν παρόντων</quote>. There is a verbal likeness to <ref n="Soph. Ant. 552">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 552</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δῆτ’ ἂν ἀλλὰ νῦν σ’ ἔτ’ ὠφελοῖμ’ ἐγώ</quote>; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_539"> here announces a fact which favours the last speaker's wish, and not, as in 531, a fact opposed to it; here, therefore, it becomes an expression of assent.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_539"> emphasises </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέλας_539"> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσπόλοις_539">, dat. of agent; rare, except with the <emph>perf.</emph> pass.; but cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1218"> <title>Ant.</title> 1218</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοῖσι κλέπτομαι</quote>, and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 504 f. (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_οὐ_540">, since </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίμέλλει_540"> is equiv. to <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ μελλέτω</quote>: cp. <ref n="Aesch. PB 627">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 627</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δῆτα μέλλεις μὴ οὐ γεγωνίσκειν τὸ πᾶν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρουσίαν_ἔχειν_540">=<quote xml:lang="grc"> παρεῖναι</quote>: a periphrasis like <quote xml:lang="grc">θήραν ἔχων</quote> (564), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχει στίβον</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 157"> <title>Ph.</title> 157</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐθύνων_542">: cp. <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 728"> Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 728</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐθύνων πόδα</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕρποντι_φωνεῖς_543">...; the partic. expresses the leading idea; cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1038"> <title>O. C.</title> 1038</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χωρῶν ἀπείλει νῦν</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λελειμμένῳλόγων_543">, unable to catch the sound of thy words; schol. in L, <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἀκούοντι</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1085">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1085</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ πολὺ λέλειψαι τῶν ἐμῶν βουλευμάτων</quote> (‘laggest far behind them,’—failest to comprehend them): <title>Helen.</title> 1246 <quote xml:lang="grc">λέλειμμαι τῶν ἐν Ἕλλησιν νόμων</quote> (‘am not versed in them’). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_δὴ_544">, ‘already’: <ref n="Soph. OC 31"> <title>O. C.</title> 31</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἶρε_δεῦρο_545">. The child is led in by an attendant: Ajax means, ‘lift him’ (from the ground) ‘to my arms.’ Some take <quote xml:lang="grc">αἶρε</quote> as=‘bring,’ comparing <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.264"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 264</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή μοι οἶνον ἄειρε</quote>, <ref n="Aristoph. Peace 1">Ar. <title>Pax</title> 1</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἶρ’ αἶρε μᾶζαν ὡς τάχιστα κανθάρῳ</quote>: but this is less simple, and less fitting.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταρβήσει_οὒ_545">: for <quote xml:lang="grc"> οὐ</quote> placed after the verb, see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 96."> <title>Ant.</title> 96.</ref>This passage recalls <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.466"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 466</ref>—470, where Hector is about to take his little son from the nurse's arms, but the child shrinks back, frightened by the helmet,— <quote xml:lang="grc">ταρβήσας χαλκόν τε ἰδὲ λόφον ἱππιοχαίτην</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νεοσφαγῆ_φόνον_546">, the adj. compounded with a word akin in sense to the subst.; cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1283"> <title>Ant.</title> 1283</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεοτόμοισι πλήγμασιν</quote>.—There is no reason to doubt the genuineness of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="που_546">, which gives a touch of grim irony. L's reading, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_546">, certainly points to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτόν_γε_546">: but this is very in ferior to the vulgate. Wecklein, reading </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="του_546">, thinks that Ajax wishes to avoid saying <quote xml:lang="grc">μου</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δικαίως_547">, in a full and true sense: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 852"> <title>O. T.</title> 852</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτοι ποτ’, ὦναξ, τόν γε Λαΐου φόνον | φανεῖ δικαίως ὀρθόν</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘properly fulfilled.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_πατρόθεν_547"> is re dundant, but not pointless; the qualities derived from the father will prevail over any weaker qualities derived <quote xml:lang="grc">μητρόθεν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠμοῖς_νόμοις_548">, the rugged usages of a warrior inured to the sight of bloodshed. For the adj., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 205">cp. 205</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠμοκρατής</quote>, n. In saying <quote xml:lang="grc">νόμοις</quote> rather than <quote xml:lang="grc">τρόποις</quote>, he speaks with a certain heroic grandeur (<quote xml:lang="grc">μεγαλοφρονῶν</quote>, as the schol. remarks). Cp. <title>C.</title> 2. 15. 11 <quote xml:lang="lat">non ita Romuli | Praescriptum et intonsi Catonis | Auspiciis veterumque norma.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πωλοδαμνεῖν_548">, to break him in like a colt. The word was familiar in Attic ( <ref n="Xen. Ec. 3. 10">Xen. <title> Oec.</title> 3. 10</ref>, etc.). Cp. <ref n="Plut. De Lib. 13e">Plut. <title> Mor.</title> 13</ref>E <quote xml:lang="grc">οὕτω σκιρτῶσα νεότης πωλοδαμνεῖται</quote>. Lucian <title>Amor.</title> 45 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν νεότητα πωλοδαμνήσας</quote>. For the metaphor implicit in the compound verb, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 994"> <title>Ant.</title> 994</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐναυκλήρεις πόλιν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀξομοιοῦσθαι_548"> is passive, and <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόν</quote> (the object of <quote xml:lang="grc"> πωλοδαμνεῖν</quote>) is its subject, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φύσιν_548"> being acc. of respect. For the infinitives, linked by <quote xml:lang="grc">καί</quote>, yet having different subjects, cp. Plat. <title> Rep.</title>p. 359 E (<quote xml:lang="grc">λέγουσιν</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸν ἀφανῆ γενέσθαι τοῖς παρακαθημένοις, καὶ διαλέγεσθαι</quote> [<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοὺς</quote>] <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς περὶ οἰχομένου</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_παῖ_550"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> Paraphrased by Attius, <title>Armorum Iudicium</title> fr. 10, <title>Virtuti sis par</title>, <emph>dispar fortunis patris</emph>: and imitated by <ref n="Verg. A. 12. 435">Verg. <title>Aen.</title> 12. 435</ref>(Aeneas to Ascanius), <title>Disce</title>, <emph>puer</emph>, <emph>virtutem ex me verumque laborem</emph>, | <title>Fortunam ex aliis.</title> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ὅμοιος_550">: so Hector prays for Astyanax that he may be like his father, —<quote xml:lang="grc">ὧδε βίην τ’ ἀγαθὸν καὶ Ἰλίου ἶφι ἀνάσσειν</quote>: but adds the nobler prayer that men may say, <quote xml:lang="grc">πατρός γ’ ὅδε πολλὸν ἀμείνων</quote>. ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.476"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 476</ref> ff.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καίτοι_νῦν_552">: nay, <emph>even now</emph>—while that prayer still awaits fulfilment—the child is happier than his father, in unconsciousness of evil.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σε_552"> is better here than </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὲ_552"> (which L has), though the emphasis could be defended (‘I, the man, might envy <emph>thee</emph>, the child’).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτό_γε_552">: this acc. of respect (instead of the ordinary genitive) with <quote xml:lang="grc">ζηλοῦν</quote> is unusual; but the same constr. sometimes occurs with words of a like sense, <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> <title>Vesp.</title> 588 <quote xml:lang="grc">τουτὶ γάρ τοί σε μόνον..μακαρίζω</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲν_552"> is best taken as acc. governed by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπαισθάνει_552">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 996">cp. 996</ref> : <ref n="Soph. OT 424"> <title>O. T.</title> 424</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλων δὲ πλῆθος οὐκ ἐπαισθάνει κακῶν</quote>. It might, however, be adv. (cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1183"> <title>Ant.</title> 1183</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν λόγων ἐπῃσθόμην</quote>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_μηδὲν_554">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, before there is any intelligent consciousness of joy or sorrow (555).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_γὰρ_554"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>] Such an unconsciousness is an ‘evil,’ as excluding <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ χαίρειν</quote>, but ‘painless,’ as exempt from <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ λυπεῖσθαι</quote>. This verse was probably written in the margin, as a parallel passage to v. 554, and then crept into the text. It may come (as Valckenär thought) from some other play of Sophocles; its tone seems less suggestive of Euripides. That it was a familiar quotation, may be seen from the way in which it is brought in by the novelist Eustathius (or Eumathius), in <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ καθ’ Ὑσμίνην καὶ Ὑσμινίαν σρᾶμα</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 1100 A.D. ?), ch. 2 § 7 (<title>Erot. Scriptores</title> vol. II. p. 174 ed. Hercher), <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ ἔπους ἐμνήσθην ὡς τὸ μὴ φρονεῖν κάρτ’ ἀνώδυνον κακόν</quote>. It is translated, along with v. 553, in the sentences of Publilius Syrus (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 45 B.C.), 876 f., <quote xml:lang="lat">Suavissima haec est vita, si sapias nihil: | Nam sapere nil doloris expers est malum.</quote> But those two verses are doubtless later interpolations in the text of Publilius: they are wanting in the best MS. (Monac. lat. 6292). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕως_555">, without <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote>: so <ref n="Soph. Phil. 764"> <title>Ph.</title> 764</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 148."> <title>Tr.</title> 148.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵκῃ_τοῦτο_556">, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τὸ μαθεῖν</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1365">Cp. 1365</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεῖ_δείξεις_556">: see on <ref n="Soph. Phil. 54"> <title>Ph.</title> 54</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν Φιλοκτήτου σε δεῖ | ψυχὴν ὅπως λόγοισιν ἐκκλέψεις λέγων.— <emph>)τράφης</emph> </quote> suggests the inbred qualities of the race; cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 3"> <title>Ph.</title> 3</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρατίστου πατρὸς Ἑλλήνων τραφείς</quote>. For the prodelision of the augment in the 6th foot of the v., cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 457"> <title>Ant.</title> 457</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">)φάνη</quote>: <title> Helen.</title> 263 (<quote xml:lang="grc">εἴθε</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴσχιον εἶδος ἀντὶ τοῦ καλοῦ )λαβον</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέως_558">, ‘meanwhile,’ referring to the limit of time marked by v. 556. So in <ref n="Hom. Od. 15.127"> <title>Od.</title> 15. 127</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆος δὲ φίλῃ παρὰ μητρὶ | κείσθω</quote>, the ref. is to the limit marked by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς γάμου ὥρην</quote> just before. And <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 230 <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἐνιαυτὸν | εἶχε βίῃ· ὁ δὲ τῆος...δέδετο</quote>. Other usages of <quote xml:lang="grc">τέως</quote> are: (1) when it answers to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως</quote>: <ref n="Aristoph. Peace 32">Ar. <title> Pax</title> 32</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέως ἕως λάθοις σαυτὸν διαρραγείς</quote>: and (2) when it means, ‘for a time’ (or, ‘hitherto’), and is followed by a clause with <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλά</quote>: <ref n="Hdt. 1. 82"> Her. 1. 82</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέως μὲν δὴ..τέλος δέ κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κούφοις_πνεύμασιν_558">, light airs, gentle breezes, such as nourish young plants. Lobeck quotes Dion Chrysostomus or. 12 p. 202 B <quote xml:lang="grc">τρεφόμενοι τῇ διηνεκεῖ τοῦ</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">πνεύματος ἐπιρροῇ ἀέρα ὑγρὸν ἕλκοντες ὥσπερ νήπιοι παῖδες</quote>. Pliny <title>H. N.</title> 18. 34 <title>Zephyrum dicit in plantas nutricium exercere.</title> Lucian <title>Bix accus.</title> § 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς ἀνέμους φυτουργοῦντας</quote>. We might add Catull. 62. 39 <emph>ut flos</emph>.. | <title>Quem mulcent aurae</title> , <emph>firmat sol</emph>, <emph>educat imber.</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέαν_ἀτάλλων_558">. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 144"> <title>Tr.</title> 144</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ γὰρ νεάζον ἐν τοιοῖσδε βόσκεται | χώροισιν αὑτοῦ</quote> etc. (n.). The word <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτάλλω</quote> (which in <ref n="Hom. Il. 13.27"> <title>Il.</title> 13. 27</ref> means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in <title>Hom. epigr.</title> 4. 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">νήπιον αἰδοίης ἐπὶ γούνασι μητρὸς ἀτάλλων</quote>, and Pind. fr. 214 <quote xml:lang="grc">γλυκεῖά οἱ καρδίαν ἀτάλλοισα</quote>... | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπίς</quote>. The Homeric form in this sense is <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτιτάλλω</quote>, <ref n="Hom. Od. 18.323">Hom. <title> Od.</title> 18. 323</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παῖδα δὲ ὣς ἀτίταλλε</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χαρμονήν_558"> might be acc. in appos. with <quote xml:lang="grc">ψυχὴν</quote> only; but is better taken as acc. in appos. with the whole sentence (see on <ref n="Eur. El. 130"> <title>El.</title> 130</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥκετ’ ἐμῶν καμάτων παραμύθιον</quote>).—The conjecture </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χαρμονή_558"> is no gain.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶδα_558">, which is not rare; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 938">cp. 938</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OC 1615"> <title>O. C.</title> 1615</ref>, <title>El.</title>|354.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτοι_μή_558">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 83">cp. 83</ref>, 421. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖον_562">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 164">cp. 164</ref>, 218, 251.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πυλωρὸν_562">, warder, guardian; <ref n="Eur. Tro. 956">Eur. <title>Tro.</title> 956</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">πύργων</quote>), <title>I. T.</title> 1227 (<quote xml:lang="grc">ναῶν</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τροφῆς_ἄοκνον_563">: any adj. compounded with <emph>a privativum</emph> can take a genitive; and here the gen. is the more natural since <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅοκνος</quote> suggests the notion of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφειδής.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔμπα_563">: this form occurs in <ref n="Pind. N. 4">Pind. <title>N.</title> 4. 36</ref>, and <ref n="Call. Epigr. 13">Callim. <title>Epigr.</title> 13</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">καί σφιν ἀνιηρὸν μὲν ἐρεῖς ἔπος, ἔμπα δὲ λέξον</quote>). A Doric form <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμπα—ν</quote> is used by <ref n="Pind. P. 5">Pind. <title>P.</title> 5. 51.</ref>In 122 and 1338, as in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 845">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 845</ref>, we have <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμπας</quote>. (The form <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμπακ’</quote>, once read here, was a mere blunder: see cr. n.)— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεἰ_563"> stands here (as in 692 and 962) where <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ καί</quote> would be normal, since the reference is to an actual fact: cp. Soph. <title>O. T.</title>appendix on v. 305, p. 224. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τηλωπὸς_564">, properly ‘of distant aspect’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὤψ</quote>), here merely ‘distant,’ as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 216"> <title>Ph.</title> 216</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βοᾷ τηλωπὸν ἰωάν.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἰχνεῖ_564">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 165"> <title>El.</title> 165</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θήραν_ἔχων_564">: for the periphrasis, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 540">cp. 540</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 839"> <title>Ph.</title> 839</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θήραν | τήνδ’ ἁλίως ἔχομεν</quote>. He had gone on a foray (343) in the highlands of Mysia (720). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀσπιστῆρες_565">. The Salaminian followers of Ajax are at once seamen and warriors; as Thuc. (1. 10 § 4) says of the Greeks who went against Troy, <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτερέται.. ἦσαν καὶ μάχιμοι πάντες.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χάριν_565">, this act of kindness; viz., care for the child. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπως_δείξει_567"> is the object clause to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγγείλατ’ ἐντολήν</quote>. A final clause, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως..δείξῃ</quote>, would be less fitting here.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἐριβοίᾳ_λέγω_567">. The dat. is more forcible than the acc. would be, as it keeps the command, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως δείξει μητρί</quote>, before the mind; cp. Aesch. fr. 175 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς Ἀντικλείας ἆσσον ἦλθε Σίσυφος</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς σῆς λέγω τσι μητρός</quote>. <ref n="Dem. 19.152">Dem. or. 19 § 152</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">περὶ ..μειζόνων, λέγω δὲ Φωκέων καὶ Πυλῶν</quote>. Ajax adds these words to show that he does not mean Teucer's mother, Hesionè (1300). Eriboea was the daughter of Alcathoüs, king of Megara: Pindar mentions her as the mother of Ajax (<title>I.</title> 5. 45). She is called Periboea by Apollodorus (3. 12 § 7) and Pausanias (1. 42. 1). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέχρις_οὗ_571">. This verse is doubtless due to an interpolator who wished to limit <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰσαεί</quote>. It has three marks of spuriousness. (1) <quote xml:lang="grc">μέχρι</quote>, not <quote xml:lang="grc">μέχρις</quote>, is the Attic form. (2) The anapaest in the first foot is a needless harshness, when either <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔστ’ ἂν</quote> was available. (3) The division of an anapaest (in the first foot) between two words has no Sophoclean parallel except in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 795"> <title>Phil.</title> 795</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἴσον χρόνον τρέφοιτε τήνδε τὴν νόσον</quote> </cit>: and the <title>Philoctetes</title> was one of the latest plays (<date when="-0409">409 B.C.</date>).—It might be added that <quote xml:lang="grc">μυχοὺς κίχωσι</quote> is a somewhat strange phrase; though we may compare <ref n="Hom. Il. 21.128"> <title>Il.</title> 21. 128</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄστυ κιχείομεν</quote>. The use of <quote xml:lang="grc">κίχω</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Aj. 657">657</ref> is slightly different. </gloss>

data.quote: τὸν ἴσον χρόνον τρέφοιτε τήνδε τὴν νόσον

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήτ_θήσους_572">: depending on <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως</quote> in 567. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 11.546"> <title>Od.</title> 11. 546</ref>(referring to the contest from the arms), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔθηκε δὲ πότνια μήτηρ</quote> (Thetis), ‘offered them as a prize.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγωνάρχαι_572"> (a word found only here)=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγωνοθέται</quote>, the presidents of the games, such as the Amphictyons were at the Pythian festival. The presidents appointed the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιμεληταί</quote> who actually supervised the contests, such as the <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἑλλανοδίκαι</quote> at Olympia. (Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 690"> <title>El.</title> 690</ref> n.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήθ_ἐμός_572">. Only two parallels for the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμός</quote> are brought from classical Greek literature. (1) <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 683">Eur. <title> Hipp.</title> 683</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεύς σ’ ὁ γεννήτωρ ἐμός</quote>: where G. Wolff would omit <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ</quote>. (2) <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 27">Theocr. 27. 58</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὠμπέχονον ποίησας ἐμὸν ῥάκος</quote> </cit>: where Schaefer's remedy, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμοὶ</quote>, is quite admissible; Hermann wrote <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμπεχόναν..ἐμάν</quote>. The nearest analogy to such a license as <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ λυμεὼν ἐμός</quote> is afforded by such instances as <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἐμὸν πατέρ’ ἄθλιον</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. El. 133">Eur. <title>El.</title> 133</ref> n.), where <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄθλιον</quote> is a mere epithet, but ought, by position, to be a predicate. Remembering the originally pronominal sense of the art., we may hesitate to affirm that an Attic poet could not have ventured to write <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ λυμεὼν ἐμός</quote>, meaning, ‘that destroyer of mine.’</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήτελυμεὼν_ἐμός_572">: but the article, if not indispensable, is at least very desirable here. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτό_574">, <emph>that</emph>,—with an emphasis due to the place of the word.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπώνυμον_574">, ‘that <emph>gives</emph> thee thy name’; as at Athens the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπώνυμοι</quote> were the heroes who gave names to the Attic tribes. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 430">Cp. 430</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολυρράφου_πόρπακος_575">. This must be interpreted by the usage of the poet's day, not by Homeric practice. The <quote xml:lang="grc">πόρπαξ</quote> may be seen on shields depicted in Greek vase-paintings; an example is reproduced in Smith's <title>Dict. of Antiquities</title> (3rd ed., vol. I. p. 459, art. <emph>clipeus</emph>). It was a leathern thong, running round the inner edge of the shield, and fixed at intervals of six inches or so by pins or nails, so as to form a succession of loops. The name, <quote xml:lang="grc">πόρπαξ</quote>, was derived from these pins (<quote xml:lang="grc">πόρπαι</quote>), which could be taken out, when it was wished to remove the <quote xml:lang="grc">πόρπαξ</quote> and so to unfit the shield for immediate use. (It is made a charge against Cleon in <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 849">Ar. <title>Eq.</title> 849</ref> that he had dedicated the shields taken at Pylos <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοῖσι τοῖς πόρπαξιν</quote>.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολυρράφου_575"> (‘much, or well, stitched’) is a general epithet for elaborate leatherwork, and is again illustrated by the vase-painting cited above, where ornamental tassels hang from the pins which divide the loops of the <quote xml:lang="grc">πόρπαξ</quote>. In <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 25">Theocr. 25. 265,</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολύρραπτόν τε φαρέτρην</quote> </cit>, the epithet probably refers to braiding; quivers were often made of hide or leather.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑπτάβοιον_575">=epic <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἑπταβόειον</quote>: see n. on 19. The second part of the compound is not <quote xml:lang="grc">βοῦς</quote>, but <quote xml:lang="grc">βοεία</quote>, ox-hide ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 12.296"> <title>Il.</title> 12. 296</ref>). The shield was the work of <quote xml:lang="grc">Τυχίος, σκυτοτόμων ὄχ’ ἄριστος</quote>,—so essentially was the currier's art that which it chiefly demanded ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.220"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 220</ref>). Tychios dwelt at <quote xml:lang="grc">Ὕλη</quote>,—probably the Boeotian ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.500"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 500</ref>). The number of <emph>seven</emph> layers of hide was probably exceptional; in <ref n="Hom. Il. 15.479"> <title>Il.</title> 15. 479</ref>Teucer has a <quote xml:lang="grc">σάκος τετραθέλυμνον</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, with four such layers. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τεθάψεται_577">. Here, as at 1141, the fut. perf. gives a peremptory tone. Athena uses it in <title>I. T.</title> 1464: <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗ καὶ τεθάψει</quote>. (Cp. <title>Nub.</title> 1436 <quote xml:lang="grc">τεθνήξεις</quote>.) The ordinary fut. pass. was <quote xml:lang="grc">ταφήσομαι</quote>. The practice of burying a warrior's arms with him was a primitive Aryan custom; witness the swords found in the graves at Mycenae. Sophocles in this play follows the legend that the body of Ajax was <emph>interred</emph>, and not, as was the ordinary practice in the heroic age, burned (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1166">cp. 1166</ref> n.). The reference to the burial of the arms is thus perfectly fitting. There was less meaning in the practice, noticed by Homer, of <emph>burning</emph> a warrior's armour with him; <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.418"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 418</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἄρα μιν κατέκηε σὺν ἔντεσι δαιδαλέοισιν</quote>: <ref n="Hom. Od. 11.74"> <title>Od.</title> 11. 74</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλά με κακκῆαι σὺν τεύχεσιν</quote>. It may have come down from the earlier days when interment was the rule. No arms are burned on the pyre of Patroclus ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 23.165"> <title>Il.</title> 23. 165</ref> ff.), Hector (24. 785 ff.), or Achilles ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 24.65"> <title>Od.</title> 24. 65</ref> ff.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάκτου_579">. <quote xml:lang="grc">πακτόω</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">πακτός</quote>= <quote xml:lang="grc">πηκτός</quote>) is used by <ref n="Hdt. 2. 96"> Her. 2. 96</ref>(in the compound <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμ‐</quote>), and by <title>Vesp.</title> 128, of ‘stopping up’ holes, ‘caulking,’ and this may have been its special sense. But the general sense, ‘to make fast,’ occurs in <ref n="Aristoph. Lys. 264">Ar. <title>Lys.</title> 264</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μοχλοῖς τε καὶ κλήθροισι τὰ προπύλαια πακτοῦν</quote>. Eustathius, who explains it by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλίζεσθαι</quote> (p. 742. 43), seems to regard the use of the word with ref. to closing doors as peculiarly Attic (p. 1937. 62 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ συγκλεῖσαι, πακτῶσαι παρ’ Ἀττικοῖς</quote>). According to Pollux 10. 27, however, Archilochus had used <quote xml:lang="grc">πακτῶσαι</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">κλεῖσαι</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπισκήνους_579">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ τῇ σκηνῇ</quote>, <emph>at</emph> the tent, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, in front of it. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1247"> <title>Ant.</title> 1247</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς πόλιν γόους | οὐκ ἀξιώσειν, ἀλλ’ ὑπὸ στέγης ἔσω, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φιλοίκτιστον_579">: schol. on <ref n="Hom. Il. 22.88"> <title>Il.</title> 22. 88</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλοικτον χρῆμα ἡ γυνή</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Her. 536">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 536</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ θῆλυ γάρ πως μᾶλλον οἰκτρὸν ἀρσένων</quote>. For the neut., cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1035">Eur. <title>El.</title> 1035</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μῶρον μὲν οὖν γυναῖκες</quote>: O. <title>C.</title> 592 n. The adj. is formed from the midd. <quote xml:lang="grc"> οἰκτίζομαι</quote> as= ‘to lament’ ( <title>I. T.</title> 486, etc.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πύκαζε_581">: the vague word (‘to close,’ ‘cover up’) is explained by the preceding <quote xml:lang="grc">δῶμα πάκτου</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hes. WD 622">Hes. <title>Op.</title> 622</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῆα δ’ ἐπ’ ἠπείρου ἐρύσαι, πυκάσαι τε λίθοισι | πάντοθεν</quote> (‘protect’ it): perh. the nearest approach to the use of the word here, in ref. to shutting the door of a dwelling.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἰατροῦ_581">: for the prep., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 319">cp. 319</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θρηνεῖν_ἐπῳδὰς_581">: as to the medical use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπῳδαί</quote>, see on <ref n="Soph. OC 1194"> <title>O. C.</title> 1194</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλων ἐπῳδαῖς ἐξεπᾴδονται φύσιν</quote>. The transition from gentle incantations to drastic surgery is similarly implied in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1000"> <title>Tr.</title> 1000</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς γὰρ ἀοιδός, τίς ὁ χειροτέχνης | ἰατορίας, ὃς τήνδ’ ἄτην | χωρὶς Ζηνὸς κατακηλήσει;</quote> (n.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τομῶντι_581"> means here, not <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιθυμοῦντι τέμνειν</quote>, but <quote xml:lang="grc">δεομένῳ τομῆς</quote>: cp. Lucian <title>Lexiphanes</title> 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ ὄμματά μοι φαρμακᾷ</quote>,= <quote xml:lang="grc">δεῖται φαρμάκων</quote>. <cit> <bibl n="Ov. Met. 1.190">Ov. <title>Met.</title> 1. 190</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">Cuncta prius tentata; sed immedicabile vulnus | Ense recidendum est, ne pars sincera trahatur.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
Cuncta prius tentata; sed immedicabile vulnus
							| Ense recidendum est, ne pars sincera trahatur.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προθυμίαν_583">, the eagerness expressed by <quote xml:lang="grc">πύκαζε θᾶσσον.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρέσκει_583"> with acc., as often in Attic: <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 185">Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 185</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέ σ’ ἀρέσκει τὸ παρόν</quote> (and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 106 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδείς μ’ ἀρέσκει</quote>): <title>Vesp.</title> 776 <quote xml:lang="grc">τουτί μ’ ἀρέσκει</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Seven 406"> <title>Th.</title> 406</ref>, <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 103"> <title>Ran.</title> 103</ref>, <ref n="Aristoph. Pl. 353."> <title>Pl.</title> 353.</ref>Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 147"> <title>El.</title> 147</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμέ γ’...ἄραρεν</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τεθηγμένη_583">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. PB 311"> Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 311</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τραχεῖς καὶ τεθηγμένους λόγους</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρασείεις_585">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 326">cp. 326</ref> .</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρενί_585"> is not weak, because his wish for seclusion was not in itself disquieting. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρῖνε_586">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάκρινε</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Ant. 399"> <title>Ant.</title> 399</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ κρῖνε κἀξέλεγχε</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴμ_ὡς_587">: 354.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_γένῃ_587">: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 773"> <title>Ph.</title> 773</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">κτείνας γένῃ</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄγαν_λυπεῖς_589">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 951">cp. 951</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 573"> <title>Ant.</title> 573</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγαν γε λυπεῖς καὶ σὺ καὶ τὸ σὸν λέχος.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρκεῖν_589">, to render service (439 n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀφειλέτης_589">: the gods hate him (457); he has no hope from them,—they are doing their worst (399—403): he owes them no duty. When Hermes reproaches Prometheus with not wishing to conciliate Zeus, the sufferer ironically answers, <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μὴν ὀφείλων γ’ ἂν τίνοιμ’ αὐτῷ χάριν</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. PB 985"> Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 985</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔφημα_φώνει_591">, as in 362.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_λέγε_591">: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 15">Theocr. 15. 90</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πεισομένοις ἐπίτασσε</quote> </cit>. Euripides has what seems an echo of this verse in the <title>Hercules Furens</title> (a play referable to 421— 416 B.C., and so later than the <title> Ajax</title>), 1184 <quote xml:lang="grc">ΘΗ. εὔφημα φώνει. ΑΜΦ. βουλομένοισιν ἐπαγγέλλει</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνέρξεθ_593">,=<quote xml:lang="grc"> συγκλείσετε</quote>, fut. of <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνείργω</quote>: but in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1407"> <title>Ph.</title> 1407</ref> we find <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴρξω</quote>, a form which the poet may have preferred there, because in the verse before he had used <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρξεις</quote> as fut. of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρδω</quote>. (In <ref n="Soph. Trach. 83"> <title>Tr.</title> 83</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνέρξων</quote> is fut. of <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνέρδω</quote>.) The command is given to the <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσπολοι</quote> (544). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρτι_595">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> this new hope (if such she has) is one of which long experience might have taught her the vanity.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναίεις_597">: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.626"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 626</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νήσων, αἳ ναίουσι πέρην ἁλός.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁλίπλακτος_597"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">πλήσσω</quote>), not <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁλίπλαγκτος</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc"> πλάζω</quote>), is right here; the latter has the better MS. authority, but could mean only, ‘wandering on the sea,’ as in 695 <quote xml:lang="grc">Πὰν ἁλίπλαγκτε</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Pind. P. 4"> Pind. <title>P.</title> 4. 14</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τᾶσδ’ ἐξ ἁλιπλάκτου..γᾶς</quote> (the island of Thera). <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 307">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 307</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θαλασσόπληκτον νῆσον Αἴαντος</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶσιν_ἀεί_597"> does not allude to the victory at Salamis, but, for Athenian ears, would necessarily be tinged with the thought of it. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παλαιὸς_χρόνος_600">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 493"> <title>Ph.</title> 493</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃν δὴ παλαιὸν ἐξ ὅτου δέδοικ’ ἐγὼ | μή μοι βεβήκῃ</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἰδαῖα_603"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> If this passage cannot be restored with certainty, at least the doubt lies within narrow limits. Three points should be noted.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐνῶμαι_603">, as a correction of <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐνόμᾳ</quote>, may be regarded as certain. Sophocles would have written <quote xml:lang="grc">ΕΓΝΟΜΑΙ</quote>. It is confirmed by the fact that our best MS., L, has </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μίμνων_603">, not <quote xml:lang="grc">μίμνω</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηνῶν_603">, as a correction of <quote xml:lang="grc">μήλων</quote>, is (to my mind) not less certain. For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηνῶν_ἀνήριθμος_603">, cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 247"> <title>Tr.</title> 247</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνον</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμερῶν ἀνήριθμον</quote>. In no other way can <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνήριθμος</quote> be justified.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήλων_603"> is at once explained; for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπαυλα</quote> meant properly a fold for cattle, as in <ref n="Soph. OT 1138"> <title>O. T.</title> 1138</ref>, where it is synonymous with <quote xml:lang="grc">σταθμά</quote>. Here, however, it would have the general sense which it bears in <ref n="Soph. OC 669"> <title>O. C.</title> 669</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵκου τὰ κράτιστα γᾶς ἔπαυλα</quote>, ‘dwellings,’—a sense in which <quote xml:lang="grc">σταθμά</quote> too was poetically used. No other conjecture accounts for the origin of <quote xml:lang="grc">μήλων</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρόνῳ_605">, notwithstanding <quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνος</quote> in 600. Tennyson's poem, <title>The LotosEaters</title>, begins thus:—‘“Courage!” he said, and pointed toward the land, | “This mounting wave will roll us shoreward soon.” | In the afternoon they came unto a land | In which it seemed always afternoon.’ The repetition of the word ‘land’ there was deliberate, being designed to suggest languor. Sophocles doubtless had no such conscious aim here; he was simply indifferent, as so often, to the recurrence ( <ref n="Soph. OC 554"> <title>O. C.</title> 554</ref> n.); but something of a like effect is actually produced. The conjecture <quote xml:lang="grc">πόνῳ</quote> for <quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνῳ</quote> is not probable. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλπίδ_606">, the neutral ‘expectation,’ is here colured by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακάν_606">: below, in 1382, it stands alone as=a foreboding of evil: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 799">cp. 799</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπίζει</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτι_607">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, before the campaign is over.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="με_607">, though the pron. refers to the subject of the inf.: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 706"> <title>Tr.</title> 706</ref> n.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνύσειν_Ἅιδαν_607">, as <title>Suppl.</title> 1142 <quote xml:lang="grc">ποτανοὶ δ’ ἤνυσαν τὸν Ἅιδαν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1562"> <title>O. C.</title> 1562</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξανύσαι τὰν παγκευθῆ κάτω | νεκρῶν πλάκα</quote>. But in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 657"> <title>Tr.</title> 657</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς πόλιν ἀνύσειε</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἀπότροπον_607">, the god from whom mortals shrink in horror, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃν ἀποτρέπονται</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1313"> <title>O. T.</title> 1313</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ σκότου | νέφος ἐμὸν ἀπότροπον</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀΐδηλον_Ἅιδαν_607">: the etymology of Hades was so far forgotten in the per sonification that the tautology of this phrase would not be felt. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.758"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 758</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Πρόθοος θοὸς ἡγεμόνευεν</quote>. The Homeric sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀΐδηλος</quote> is active, ‘destroying’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφανίζων</quote>): but <ref n="Hes. WD 754">Hes. <title>Op.</title> 754</ref> has <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀΐδηλα</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφανῆ</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔφεδρος_610"> was said of an athlete who ‘sat by’ at a match between two other men, prepared to engage the winner (cp. <quote xml:lang="lat">suppositicius</quote> in <ref n="Mart. 5.24.8">Mart. 5. 24. 8</ref>). Thus in <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 792">Aristoph. <title> Ran.</title> 792</ref>Sophocles proposes <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφεδρος καθεδεῖσθαι</quote>, while the two other poets contend, and to encounter Euripides if the latter should vanquish Aeschylus. To the Chorus (<quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνῳ τρυχόμενος</quote>), Ajax is an <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφεδρος</quote>, as being a fresh trouble in reserve. Schol.: <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τοῖς πρώτοις κακοῖς ὥσπερ δεύτερόν ἐστί μοι κακὸν τὸ τοῦ Αἴαντος ξυνεστηκός</quote>: where the last word is happily chosen to mark that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφεδρος</quote> implies a trouble with which they have <emph>to grapple</emph>: see on <ref n="Soph. OC 514">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 514</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλγηδόνος, ᾇ ξυνέστας</quote>. For the fig. sense, cp. Philo vol. 2 p. 527 <quote xml:lang="grc">μετὰ πάσας τὰς αἰκίας..αὐτοῖς ἡ τελευταία καὶ ἔφεδρος τιμωρία σταυρὸς ἦν</quote>, ‘after all their torments, the final doom <emph>reserved</emph> for them was the cross.’ The technical sense of the word was so familiar (cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 4">Pind. <title>N.</title> 4. 96</ref>, <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 866">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 866</ref>) that it would be understood here without direct help from the context.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θείᾳ_611">, as in 186 <quote xml:lang="grc">θεία νόσος.— <emph>ξύναυλος</emph> </quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">αὐλή</quote>), dwelling with: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1205"> <title>O. T.</title> 1205</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄταις</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύνοικος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξεπέμψω_θουρίῳ_612">: a reminiscence of <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 137">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 137</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἑκάστα</quote>, each Persian wife) <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν αἰχμάεντα θοῦρον εὐνατῆρα προπεμψαμένα</quote>: where, as here, the midd.=‘from herself.’</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὶν_ποτε_612">, ‘in some bygone day.’</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἄρει_612"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="α_612">, as in 254 (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρενὸς_οἰοβώτας_614">, ‘a lonely pasturer of his thoughts,’—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, one who nurses lonely thoughts. They allude to the gloomy and ominous despair which has replaced his frenzy. The ending <quote xml:lang="grc">‐βώτης</quote> could mean either <quote xml:lang="grc">βοσκόμενος</quote>, as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1148"> <title>Ph.</title> 1148</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐρεσιβώτας</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">θῆρας</quote>), or <quote xml:lang="grc">βόσκων</quote>. The latter seems best here; his <quote xml:lang="grc">φρήν</quote> represents the flock; he is the shepherd. Cp. <title>Suppl.</title> 304 <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖον</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">πανόπτην οἰοβουκόλον λέγεις;</quote> (Argus,— Io being his sole charge.) Simonides fr. 133 <quote xml:lang="grc">Ὄσσα, Κιθαιρῶνός τ’ οἰονόμοι σκοπιαί</quote>. Other compounds in which <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶος</quote> has a like force are <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰόφρων</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">πέτρα</quote>, <title>Suppl.</title> 795), <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰόζωνος</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OT 846"> <title>O. T.</title> 846</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὕρηται_615">. <quote xml:lang="grc">ηὕρημαι</quote> is usually pass.; but sometimes midd., as in <ref n="Dem. 19.17">Dem. or. 19 § 17</ref>, or. 55 § 31, <ref n="Aeschin. 3.162">Aeschin. or. 3 § 162</ref>. Here the pass. sense is more forcible: Ajax is himself the <quote xml:lang="grc">πένθος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔργα_ἀρετᾶς_616">, handdeeds of valour: both genitives define <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔργα</quote>, but <quote xml:lang="grc">χεροῖν</quote> belongs to it more closely: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 308">cp. 308</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρειπίοις | νεκρῶν..φόνου</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄφιλα_ἀφίλοις_620">: for the doubled adj., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 267">cp. 267</ref> n. <quote xml:lang="grc">παρά</quote> with dat. =‘in their estimation’: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 589"> <title>Tr.</title> 589</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκεῖς παρ’ ἡμῖν οὐ βεβουλεῦσθαι κακῶς</quote>: <ref n="Dem. 2.3">Dem. or. 2 § 3</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θαυμαστότερος παρὰ πᾶσι νομίζεται.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄφιλα_ἔπεσε_620">, have fallen, have turned out, so as to win no kindness. The adj. is proleptic: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπεσε</quote> is a metaphor from dice: cp. <ref n="Pind. O. 12">Pind. <title>O.</title> 12. 10</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλὰ δ’ ἀνθρώποις παρὰ γνώμαν ἔπεσεν. </quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπεσ_ἔπεσε_620">: for the iteration, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1205">cp. 1205</ref>: fr. 686 <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρὺς βαρὺς ξύνοικος, ὦ ξένοι, βαρύς</quote>. Elsewhere Sophocles usu. iterates a word only after a slight break, as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1462"> <title>Ph.</title> 1462</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λείπομεν ὑμᾶς, λείπομεν ἤδη</quote> (cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 211"> <title>El.</title> 211</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύντροφος_622"> is strongly recommended by metrical reasons, for the short <quote xml:lang="grc">μέν</quote> (=the 1st syll. of <quote xml:lang="grc">κεύθων</quote> in 635) is very difficult to defend. Sophocles has, indeed, used the other compound in <ref n="Soph. OC 1362"> <title>O. C.</title> 1362</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> μόχθῳ..ἔντροφον</quote>. Here, however, the <quote xml:lang="grc">εν</quote> of <quote xml:lang="grc">μὲν</quote> might have led to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔντροφος_622">. Similarly in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 837"> <title>Ant.</title> 837</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔγκληρα</quote> is probably a corruption of <quote xml:lang="grc">σύγκληρα</quote>. For <quote xml:lang="grc">σύντροφος</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 611">cp. 611</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύναυλος</quote>, n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παλαιᾷ_ἁμέρᾳ_622">, the day of old age; cp. <ref n="Eur. Ion 720">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 720</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νέαν δ’ ἁμέραν ἀπολιπὼν θάνοι</quote>. <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 347">Ar. <title>Ran.</title> 347</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χρονίους τ’ ἐτῶν παλαιῶν ἐνιαυτούς</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λευκῷ_622">, the general epithet of <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆρας</quote>, seems slightly more poetical here than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λευκὰ_622">, though the latter may be supported by <ref n="Eur. Her. 909">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 909</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ λευκὰ γήρᾳ σώματ’</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Ba. 258">Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 258</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆρας πολιόν</quote>. The use of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὲν_622"> and </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὲ_622"> here is the same as in ‘epanaphora,’ where the ideas represented by the formally opposed clauses are often closely akin; <foreign xml:lang="lat"> e.g.</foreign> <title>Theog.</title> 656 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴδμεν ὅ τοι πέρι μὲν πραπίδες πέρι δ’ ἐστὶ νόημα</quote>, <ref n="Hdt. 7. 9"> Her. 7. 9</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐπιστάμεθα μὲν τὴν μάχην ἐπιστάμεθα δὲ τὴν δύναμιν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νοσοῦντα_φρενομόρως_625">, suffering from a calamity (<quote xml:lang="grc">μόρος</quote>) to the mind. The adv. (a somewhat strange compound) may have been suggested by the Aeschylean <quote xml:lang="grc">φρενώλης</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Seven 757"> <title>Theb.</title> 757</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">φρενομανής</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1140"> <title>Ag.</title> 1140</ref>). It recalls also the paraphrase of <quote xml:lang="grc">μανία</quote> in <ref n="Eur. Her. 1024">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 1024</ref> by <quote xml:lang="grc">λυσσάδι..μοίρᾳ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἴλινον_627">, a <emph>loud</emph>, <emph>wild</emph> cry of grief, which for the Greeks had barbaric associations; cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1395">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1395</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴλινον αἴλινον ἀρχὰν θανάτου | βάρβαροι λέγουσιν, αἰαῖ</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀσιάδι φωνᾷ κ.τ.λ.</quote> The mother's passionate grief will break forth in a cry of shrill anguish,—not in more subdued and plaintive accents, like those of the nightingale's lament. The contrast meant here is plain enough; though in some other places, where the bitter <emph>grief</emph> of the nightingale is the fore<*>st thought, the bird's note is sometimes described as ‘piercing’; <emph>e.g. </emph> <ref n="Soph. Trach. 963">Soph. Tr. 963</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προὔκλαιον, ὀξύφωνος ὡς ἀηδών</quote> (cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 103">Soph. <title>El.</title> 107</ref> ff.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀηδοῦς_627"> in apposition with <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄρνιθος</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Her. 465">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 465</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">στολήν τε θηρὸς ἀμφέβαλλε σῷ κάρᾳ | λέοντος</quote>. For the form, cp. voc. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀηδοῖ</quote> ( <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 679">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 679</ref> ), <quote xml:lang="grc">χελιδοῖ</quote> ( <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 1411">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 1411</ref> etc.), <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰκώ</quote> acc. ( <ref n="Eur. Med. 1162">Eur. <title> Med.</title> 1162</ref> etc.), <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰκούς</quote> acc. pl. ( <ref n="Eur. Tro. 1178">Eur. <title>Tro.</title> 1178</ref>). No nom. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀηδώ, χελιδώ</quote>, or <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰκώ</quote> occurs. Conversely <quote xml:lang="grc"> γοργώ</quote> is the regular nom., but the genit. either <quote xml:lang="grc">γοργοῦς</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 8.349"> <title>Il.</title> 8. 349</ref>) or <quote xml:lang="grc">γοργόνος</quote>, and the pl. always <quote xml:lang="grc">γοργόνες</quote>. Schol. in L: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ἀηδὼ δὲ κατὰ Μιτυληναίους</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀξυτόνους_630">: <ref n="Eur. El. 243"> <title>El.</title> 243</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀξυτόνων γόων</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1316"> <title>Ant.</title> 1316</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀξυκώκυτον πάθος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χερόπλακτοι_δοῦποι_631">, the sound of beating hands: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 55">cp. 55</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολύκερων φόνον</quote> (n.): <ref n="Soph. OC 1464"> <title>O. C.</title> 1464</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κτύπος.. διόβολος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄμυγμα_634">, here ‘rending,’ would ordinarily mean ‘a scratch’; cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 24">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 24</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρέπει παρηῒς φοινίοις ἀμυγμοῖς</quote>. The more natural word here would have been <quote xml:lang="grc"> σπάραγμα</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Andr. 826">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 826</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σπάραγμα κόμας ὀνύχων τε δάϊ) ἀμύγματα θήσομαι</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1209 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ σπαράξομαι κόμαν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρείσσων_κεύθων_635">, the personal constr., instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">κρεῖσσόν ἐστι κεύθειν αὐτόν</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1368"> <title>O. T.</title> 1368</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρείσσων γὰρ ἦσθα μηκέτ’ ὢν ἢ ζῶν τυφλός</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 26.4">Lys. or. 26 § 4</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρείττων ἦν ὁ πατὴρ αὐτοῦ μὴ λειτουργήσας</quote> </cit> : <ref n="Dem. 3.34">Dem. or. 3 § 34</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴκοι μένων βελτίων</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 6. 9">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 6. 9</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρείττων γὰρ ἂν... γένοιτο ὁ τοιοῦτος πολίτης ἀποθανών</quote>.</gloss>

data.quote: κρείττων ἦν ὁ πατὴρ αὐτοῦ μὴ λειτουργήσας

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεύθων_635">, as in <ref n="Soph. OT 968"> <title>O. T.</title> 968</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεύθει κάτω δὴ γῆς</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 911"> <title>Ant.</title> 911</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν Ἅιδου..κεκευθότοιν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_μάταν_635">: here the adv. = ‘foolishly,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, insanely. Cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Peace 95">Ar. <title>Pax</title> 95</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί πέτει; τί μάτην οὐχ ὑγιαίνεις;</quote> <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 288">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 288</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ λύσσα καὶ μάταιος ἐκ νυκτῶν φόβος</quote>. For the order of words, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ μάταν νοσῶν</quote>, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 792"> <title>El.</title> 792</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ θανόντος ἀρτίως</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_Ἀχαιῶν_636">, lit., ‘noblest of the Achaeans by his descent (<quote xml:lang="grc"> ἥκων</quote>) from the line of his fathers’: <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, having a prouder lineage than any other Achaean can claim. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥκων_636"> here, going with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄριστος_636">, has nearly the same force as (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>) in <ref n="Soph. OT 1519"> <title>O. T.</title> 1519</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοῖς ἔχθιστος ἥκω</quote>, ‘I have become most hateful to them’: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, it denotes the <emph>outcome</emph> of an illustrious ancestry. Though </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄριστος_636_2"> (see cr. n.) cannot be regarded as certain, and may be a mere conjecture, it is at least far better than anything else that has been suggested.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολυπόνων_636"> refers to warlike toils: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 320">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 320</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολύπονον δόρυ</quote>. <ref n="Hdt. 9. 27"> Her. 9. 27</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τοῖσι Τρωικοῖσι πόνοισι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συντρόφοις_ὀργαῖς_639">, the dispositions that have grown with his growth, his natural <quote xml:lang="grc">τρόποι</quote>: for the subst., cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 355"> <title>Ant.</title> 355</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀστυνόμους ὀργάς</quote> (n.): for the adj., <ref n="Soph. Phil. 203"> <title>Ph.</title> 203</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">κτύπος</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">φωτὸς σύντροφος ὡς τειρομένου του</quote>. With </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔμπεδος_639"> supply <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐστί</quote>: he is not stable, constant, in respect to them (=<quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐμμένει αὐταῖς</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτὸς_ὁμιλεῖ_639">, is conversant (with thoughts) <emph>outside of</emph> the <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύντροφοι ὀργαί</quote>. The only peculiarity is that from <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυντρόφοις ὀργαῖς</quote> we are left to supply <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλαις ὀργαῖς</quote> (suggested by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτὸς_639">) with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμιλεῖ_639">. (We cannot, surely, understand <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτὸς ὁμιλεῖ ξυντρόφοις ὀργαῖς</quote>, as if it were an oxymoron, =<quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ὁμιλεῖ</quote>.) The expression is of the same stamp as that in <ref n="Eur. Ba. 331">Eur. <title> Bacch.</title> 331</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴκει μεθ’ ἡμῶν, μὴ θύραζε τῶν νόμων</quote>, (‘dwell with us, forsaking not the pale of our customs,’ etc.): <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 853 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξω δ’ ἐλαύνων τοῦ φρονεῖν</quote>. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμιλεῖ_639_2">, cp. <title>Nub.</title> 1399 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἡδὺ καινοῖς πράγμασιν καὶ δεξιοῖς ὁμιλεῖν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τλᾶμον_641">. Sophocles has this voc. in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1112"> <title>Tr.</title> 1112</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ τλῆμον Ἑλλάς</quote>), and in <ref n="Soph. OC 978."> <title>O. C.</title> 978.</ref>In the latter place, as here, L has the nom., which may perh. be due to the fact that the nom. <quote xml:lang="grc">τλήμων</quote> so often occurs in exclamations; <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> 893: <title>O.C.</title> 185 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ τλάμων</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 229"> <title>Ant.</title> 229</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1102"> <title>Ph.</title> 1102</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 986."> <title>Tr.</title> 986.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύσφορον_643">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 51">cp. 51</ref> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔθρεψεν_644">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 503">cp. 503</ref>, n. on <quote xml:lang="grc">τρέφει.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰὼν_644"> (if sound) means ‘life,’ not merely as=‘living man,’ but in the sense of ‘life-destiny’: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 34"> <title>Tr.</title> 34</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιοῦτος αἰὼν εἰς δόμους τε κἀκ δόμων | ἀεὶ τὸν ἄνδρ’ ἔπεμπε</quote>. The strict meaning would be then, ‘no life-destiny which the line of Aeacus has known.’ There is a certain pathos in this which may plead for it as against Reiske's very plausible emendation </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δίων_644"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">Δ</quote> for A), which may be right, though, as compared with <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰών</quote>, it is perhaps a little weak. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.451"> <title>Il.</title> 5. 451</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δῖοι Ἀχαιοί</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_χρόνος_646">: see <ref n="Hdt. 5. 9"> Her. 5. 9</ref>, quoted in n. on 86.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φύει_τ_646"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: the emphasis is on the power of time to enfeeble and destroy, rather than to produce; but the first clause serves to bring the second into relief, and is co-ordinated with it, as in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1112"> <title>Ant.</title> 1112</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτός τ’ ἔδησα καὶ παρὼν ἐκλύσομαι</quote>.—The rash change of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φύει_646"> to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φαίνει_646"> overlooks the poet's tendency to vary his phrase in such cases; <emph>e.g. </emph> <ref n="Soph. OC 1501"> O. C. 1501</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σαφὴς μὲν ἀστῶν ἐμφανὴς δὲ τοῦ ξένου</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 54"> <title>O. T.</title> 54</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄρξεις..κρατεῖς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρύπτεται_646">, properly, ‘hides in its own bosom’ (midd.): cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 127">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 127</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γαῖαν..ἣ τὰ πάντα τίκτεται</quote>, ‘produces from herself.’ The midd. of the simple <quote xml:lang="grc"> κρύπτω</quote> is rare: but <ref n="Soph. Aj. 246">cp. 246</ref>, and <ref n="Soph. Trach. 474"> <title>Tr.</title> 474</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρύψομαι</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄελπτον_648">: Archil. fr. 76 <quote xml:lang="grc">χρημάτων ἄελπτον οὐδέν ἐστιν οὐδ’ ἀπώμοτον</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 388.">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 388.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁλίσκεται_648">, absol., ‘is captured,’ ‘is proved weak’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1267">cp. 1267</ref>.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινὸς_648">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 476"> <title>Tr.</title> 476</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δεινὸς ἵμερος</quote> : <ref n="Soph. El. 770"> <title>El.</title> 770</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινὸν τὸ τίκτειν ἐστίν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περισκελεῖς_648">: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 475"> <title>Ant.</title> 475</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σίδηρον ὀπτὸν ἐκ πυρὸς περισκελῆ</quote> (n.). Thus the associations of the word lead naturally to his next thought. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_δείν_650">, adv., ‘so wondrously’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 312">cp. 312</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τότε_650"> , <emph>olim</emph>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1240">cp. 1240</ref>: 1377: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 391"> <title>Ant.</title> 391</ref>: <ref n="Soph. El. 278."> <title>El.</title> 278.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαφῇ_ὥς_650">, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">καρτερὸς γίγνεται</quote>, supplied from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκαρτέρουν</quote>. The <quote xml:lang="grc"> βαφή</quote> is the cold bath (<emph>lacus</emph>) into which the hot iron is plunged, and from which it receives the temper of steel. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 9.391"> <title>Od.</title> 9. 391</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc"> <lg type="hexameter"> <l>ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ἀνὴρ χαλκεύς πέλεκυν μέγαν ἠὲ σκέπαρνον</l> <l>εἰν ὕδατι ψυχρῷ βάπτῃ μεγάλα ἰάχοντα</l> <l>φαρμάσσων· τὸ γὰρ αὖτε σιδήρου γε κράτος ἐστίν</l> </lg> </quote> </cit>: where Eustathius says, <quote xml:lang="grc">στομοῦται σίδηρος τοιαύτῃ βαφῇ καὶ κράτος ἔχει, ὅ ἐστι κρατερὸς γίνεται πυκνούμενος εἰς πλέον</quote>. So Galen compares the tonic effect of a cold bath on the human body with the effect of the <quote xml:lang="grc">βαφή</quote> upon iron (<title>Meth. Med.</title> x. 10, vol. x. 717 Kuhn), <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ γὰρ ψυχόμεθα καὶ τονούμεθα, καθάπερ ἐκεῖνος</quote> (iron) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπειδὰν διάπυρος γενόμενος ἐμβάπτηται τῷ ψυχρῷ</quote> . <ref n="Lucr. 6.968">Lucr. 6. 968</ref> <emph>umor aquae ferrum porro condurat ab igni</emph> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘after fire’). Hence <quote xml:lang="grc">βαφή</quote>=the ‘temper’ of steel, and is often used figuratively. <ref n="Aristot. Pol. 7.1334a"> Arist. <title>Pol.</title> 4.</ref>(7.) 14 § 22 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν γὰρ βαφὴν ἀφιᾶσιν, ὥσπερ ὁ σίδηρος, εἰρήνην ἄγοντες</quote>: Plut. <title> Mor.</title>p. 988 D <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς μὲν ἀνδρείας οἶον βαφή τις ὁ θυμός ἐστι καὶ στόμωμα</quote> (‘wrath gives, as it were, a temper and an edge to courage’).— This passage has been discussed by R. Paehler, in an essay on ancient steel (1885), and by Prof. H. Blümner in his work on Greek and Roman technology (1887): see Appendix.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐθηλύνθην_στόμα_650">. The aor. is like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπῄνεσα</quote> in 536 (n.): <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, it refers, like <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκτίρω</quote>, to the present, not to the time at which Tecmessa spoke. (Verses 594 f. suffice to prove this.) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στόμα_650">, standing so close to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαφῇ_ὥς_650_2">, necessarily suggests the sense of a sharp, hard edge. At the same time, it refers, in its literal sense, to the <quote xml:lang="grc">γλῶσσα τεθηγμένη</quote> (584) by which his purpose was announced. Just so the father in Aristophanes (<title>Nub.</title> 1107), who wishes his son to be made both acute and fluent, says, <quote xml:lang="grc">μέμνησ’ ὅπως | εὖ μοι στομώσεις αὐτόν</quote>. Hence <quote xml:lang="grc">στόμα</quote> cannot be completely translated; and it is the literal sense which should here be sacrificed to the other. For the verb, cp. <title>Anth.</title> 5. 251. 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔπω ἐθηλύνθης</quote> (‘softened’), <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ μαραινομένη</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἰκτίρω_λιπεῖν_652"> naturally suggests the meaning, ‘pity forbids me to leave her’; cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 20.202"> <title>Od.</title> 20. 202</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐλεαίρεις ἄνδρας</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">μισγέμεναι κακότητι</quote>. But the words could also mean, ‘I feel pity at the thought of leaving her,’ implying that he does intend to leave her, though with pain; which would usually be <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκτίρω εἰ λείψω</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρός_λουτρὰ_654">=<quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς λουτρά τε</quote>: 53 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λύμαθ_ἁγνίσας_654"> refers ostensibly to his washing off (with sea water) the stains of the slaughter. Such an act might be symbolical of purging oneself from a sin; as it is in <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.313"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 313</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λαοὺς δ’ Ἀτρείδης ἀπολυμαίνεσθαι ἄνωγεν· | οἱ δ’ ἀπελυμαίνοντο καὶ εἰς ἅλα λύματ’ ἔβαλλον</quote>: where the meaning is that, by washing in the sea, they cast off their stains upon it ( <title>I. T.</title> 1193 <quote xml:lang="grc">θάλασσα κλύζει πάντα τἀνθρώπων κακά</quote>). So here the thought in the mind of Ajax is that he will purge himself of his stains by death.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξαλύξωμαι_654">: on the question between this form and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξαλεύσωμαι_654">, see note in Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μολών_ἔνθ_657"> = <quote xml:lang="grc">μολὼν ἐκεῖσε ἔνθα</quote>, as often: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 796"> <title>O. T.</title> 796</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1466"> <title>Ph.</title> 1466</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 1495."> <title>El.</title> 1495.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κίχω_657">, ‘find,’ as in <ref n="Soph. OT 1257"> <title>O. T.</title> 1257</ref>: not merely ‘reach,’ as in the spurious v., <ref n="Soph. OT 571."> O. T. 571.</ref>The pres. <quote xml:lang="grc">κιγχάνει</quote> occurs in <ref n="Soph. OC 1450."> <title>O. C.</title> 1450.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρύψω_657">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 899">cp. 899</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεῖται κρυφαίῳ φασγάνῳ περιπτυχής.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γαίας_657">, partitive gen. with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕνθα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔνθα_ὄψεται_657">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1412"> <title>O.
