T.</title> 1412</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκρίψατ’, ἔνθα μήποτ’ εἰσόψεσθ’ ἔτι</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 800"> <title>Tr.</title> 800</ref>: <ref n="Soph. El. 380"> <title>El.</title> 380</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 436."> El. 436.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_αὐτὸ_660"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> So Clytaemnestra's gifts to Agamemnon's tomb are to be laid up for her with the gods below: <quote xml:lang="grc">κειμήλἰ αὐτῇ ταῦτα σῳζέσθω κάτω</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. El. 438"> <title>El.</title> 438</ref>). An ingenious critic, GeelJ. , writing on vv. 646—692 in <title>Mnemosyne</title> (II. pp. 200—208, 1853), wishes to omit this verse, because it implies the only direct falsehood in the speech; Ajax was not going to bury his sword <emph>under ground.</emph> But why should not Ajax think of the sword as destined to be buried in his grave? The shield alone was excepted from the direction which he gave in 577: <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ δ’ ἄλλα τεύχη κοίν’ ἐμοὶ τεθάψεται</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χειρὶ_661"> adds a certain emphasis, as if he said, ‘from the day that this sword came into my hand.’ Cp. <ref n="Eur. Hec. 527">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 527</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλῆρες δ’ ἐν χεροῖν λαβὼν δέπας | πάγχρυσον αἴρει χειρὶ παῖς Ἀχιλλέως | χοὰς θανόντι πατρί</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔσχον_661"> in its normal sense, ‘obtained.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡ_παροιμία_664">: for the absence of a second art., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 118">cp. 118</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐχθρῶν_δῶρα_664">: cp. <ref n="Men. Sent. 166">Menander <title>Sent.</title> 166</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐχθροῦ παρ’ ἀνδρὸς οὐδέν ἐστι χρήσιμον</quote>. <ref n="Verg. A. 2. 49">Verg. <title>Aen.</title> 2. 49</ref> <emph>timeo Danaos et dona ferentes.</emph> The <quote xml:lang="grc">γνώμη</quote> with which Medea rejects Jason's offers is different: <quote xml:lang="grc">κακοῦ γὰρ ἀνδρὸς δῶρ’ ὄνησιν οὐκ ἔχει</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. Med. 618"> <title>Med.</title> 618</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιγὰρ_666"> prefaces the announcement of a purpose, as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1249"> <title>Tr.</title> 1249</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιγὰρ ποήσω</quote> : <ref n="Soph. El. 29"> <title>El.</title> 29</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιγὰρ τὰ μὲν δόξαντα δηλώσω.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_λοιπὸν_666">, ‘henceforth.’ The hearers would infer that he had renounced his purpose of suicide. But in his own thought the phrase refers merely to the brief space before his death.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰσόμεσθα_666">, by the experience itself; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθησόμεσθα_666">, by the self-discipline which such an experience recommends. But the principal antithesis is between <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοῖς</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀτρείδας</quote>, rather than between the verbs. We sometimes find, in good writers of this age, even synonymous verbs placed in apparent contrast, though the real antithesis lies elsewhere: <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 25.22">Lys. or. 25 § 22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγούμενοι διὰ τὴν τῶν τρ<*>άκοντα πονηρίαν πολὺ μᾶλλον σωθήσεσθαι ἢ διὰ τὴν τῶν φευγόντων δύναμιν κατιέναι</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote:
ἡγούμενοι διὰ τὴν τῶν τρ<*>άκοντα
							πονηρίαν πολὺ μᾶλλον σωθήσεσθαι ἢ διὰ τὴν τῶν φευγόντων δύναμιν κατιέναι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_μήν_668">; <gloss xml:lang="lat">quid vero?</gloss> ‘what then?’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘of course we must yield.’ Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 672">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 672</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγουσιν ἡμᾶς ὡς ὀλωλότας· τί μήν;</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, it is only natural that they should do so.) So in <title>Suppl.</title> 999, <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 203."> <title>Eum.</title> 203.</ref>With Plato <quote xml:lang="grc">τί μήν</quote> is frequent in assenting replies, as <title>Phaedr.</title> p. 229 A, <quote xml:lang="grc">ΦΑΙ. ὁρᾷς οὖν ἐκείνην τὴν..πλάτανον; ΣΩ. τί μήν;</quote> Cp. <title>Phileb.</title>p. 17 B and 44 B, <title> Polit.</title> 258 B, etc. The reason for preferring </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_μήν_668_2"> to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_μή_668"> here is that the former is well attested, whereas there seems to be no certain example of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_μή_668_2"> in the Attic of this period. With <quote xml:lang="grc">τί μή</quote> (<emph>quidni?</emph>) we should supply <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπείκωμεν;</quote> cp. Plat. <title> Theaet.</title>p. 161 E <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς μὴ φῶμεν;</quote> <ref n="Dem. 21.35">Dem. or. 21 § 35</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ τοιοῦτος πότερα μὴ δῷ διὰ τοῦτο δίκην;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_δεινὰ_669">, the dread elemental forces of nature. The word <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινός</quote> might be called the key-note of the earlier part of this speech (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 648">cp. 648</ref> f., 674): it comes readily to the mind of the strong man, full of the thought how strength can become weakness.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τιμαῖς_669">, ‘dignities,’ ‘prerogatives,’ here, the provinces assigned to these elemental forces in the order of nature. Plat. <title>Apol.</title>p. 35 B <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔν τε ταῖς ἀρχαῖς καὶ ταῖς ἄλλαις τιμαῖς</quote>. Cp. <title>Troilus and Cressida</title> 1. 3. 83 (Ulysses tracing the ill-success of the siege to the bad discipline of the Greeks):—<quote xml:lang="eng">Degree being vizarded, | The unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask. | The heavens themselves, the planets and this centre | Observe degree, priority and place, | Insisture, course, proportion, season, form, | Office and custom, in all line of order.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτο_μὲν_669">, followed by <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote> (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο δέ</quote>), as in <ref n="Soph. OC 440"> <title>O. C.</title> 440</ref> f. (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νιφοστιβεῖς_χειμῶνες_669">, probably ‘winters with snowy paths,’ ‘snow-strewn.’ <quote xml:lang="grc">στίβος</quote>, ‘path,’ is the notion present in other like compounds; <ref n="Soph. OT 301"> <title>O. T.</title> 301</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐράνιά τε καὶ χθονοστιβῆ</quote> (‘walking the earth’): <title>Suppl.</title> 1000 <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ κνώδαλα πτεροῦντα καὶ πεδοστιβῆ</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. PB 791"> <title>P. V.</title> 791</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ἀντολὰς φλογῶπας ἡλιοστιβεῖς</quote>, ‘where are the paths of the Sun.’—Some understand, ‘storms that <emph>range over</emph> snow’: but such a personification of the <quote xml:lang="grc">χειμῶνες</quote> seems harsh. A third version is, ‘storms dense (or piled) with snow,’ from <quote xml:lang="grc">στείβω</quote> in the sense of ‘pressing down,’ ‘packing.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξίσταται_672"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 543">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 543</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νυκτός τ’ ἀφεγγὲς βλέφαρον ἡλίου τε φῶς | ἴσον βαδίζει τὸν ἐνιαύσιον κύκλον</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐδέτερον αὐτῶν φθόνον ἔχει νικώμενον</quote>. Plut. <title>Mor.</title>p. 604 A <quote xml:lang="grc">καίτοι τῶν πλανήτων ἕκαστος ἐν μιᾷ σφαίρᾳ, καθάπερ ἐν νήσῳ, περιπολῶν διαφυλάττει τὴν τάξιν· Ἥλιος γὰρ οὐχ ὑπερβήσεται μέτρα, φησὶν ὁ Ἡράκλειτος· εἰ δὲ μή, Ἐρινύες μιν δίκης ἐπίκουροι ἐξευρήσουσι</quote>. (Frag. XXIX of Heracleitus, ed. Bywater.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰανὴς_672"> has L's support here, as in <ref n="Eur. El. 506"> <title>El.</title> 506</ref>, where see n. The prevalence of <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰανῆς</quote> in the texts of this passage may be partly explained by a desire of symmetry, since in v. 673 an epithet is given to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμέρᾳ</quote>. Both <quote xml:lang="grc"> αἰανής</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰανός</quote> were probably classical. Reading </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰανὴς_672_2"> here, we may best take </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κύκλος_672"> with ref. to the course or ‘round’ of night; cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1365"> <title>El.</title> 1365</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλαὶ κυκλοῦνται νύκτες</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῇ_λευκοπώλῳ_672">: <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 386"> Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 386</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λευκόπωλος ἡμέρα | πᾶσαν κατέσχε γαῖαν εὐφεγγὴς ἰδεῖν</quote>, where the last two words suggested </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέγγος_φλέγειν_672"> here,—epexegetic of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξίσταται</quote> (‘makes room for her, so that she may kindle,’ etc.). As to the ascription of white horses to deities or heroes, see on <ref n="Eur. El. 706."> <title>El.</title> 706.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκοίμισε_674">, gnomic aor., followed by the pres. <quote xml:lang="grc">λύει</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 26"> <title>El.</title> 26</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θυμὸν οὐκ ἀπώλεσεν</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὀρθὸν οὖς ἵστησιν</quote>. The <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄημα πνευμάτων</quote> is personified as an elemental power (like <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ δεινὰ</quote> etc. in 669). That power can either vex the sea, or give it rest; as Aeolus, the <quote xml:lang="grc">ταμίης ἀνέμων</quote>, has the prerogative, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠμὲν παυέμεναι ἠδ’ ὀρνύμεν, ὅν κ’ ἐθέλῃσι</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 10.22"> <title>Od.</title> 10. 22</ref>). So in 706 <quote xml:lang="grc"> Ἄρης</quote> is a giver of <emph>peace.</emph> Cp. <title>C.</title> 1. 3. 15 (Notus), <quote xml:lang="lat">quo non arbiter Hadriae | Maior, tollere seu ponere vult freta.</quote> Vergil may have had Sophocles in mind when he wrote <quote xml:lang="lat">placataque venti | Dant maria</quote> ( <ref n="Verg. A. 3. 69"> <title>Aen.</title> 3. 69</ref>): but when he says, <quote xml:lang="lat">placidi straverunt aequora venti</quote> ( <ref n="Verg. A. 5. 763"> <title>Aen.</title> 5. 763</ref>), the epithet makes all the difference (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνεμοι λήξαντες</quote>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινῶν_674"> to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λείων_674">, thinks that the vulgate can be defended only by supposing that the foregoing verbs, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπείκει, ἐκχωροῦσιν, ἐξίσταται</quote>, tinge </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκοίμισε_674_2"> with the sense, ‘<emph>cease from troubling</emph> the sea’: otherwise some addition to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄημα</quote>, such as <quote xml:lang="grc">λῆξαν</quote>, would be needed; cp. <ref n="Pind. I. 7">Pind. <title>I.</title> 7. 12</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεῖμα..παροιχόμενον | καρτερὰν ἔπαυσε μέριμναν</quote>. But this difficulty vanishes if <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄημα</quote> is a personified agency.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_δ_674">, ‘and among them’; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, like the other powers of nature (669). <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν δέ</quote> is similarly used in <ref n="Soph. OT 27"> <title>O. T.</title> 27</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 181"> O. T. 181</ref> , <ref n="Soph. Trach. 206."> <title>Tr.</title> 206.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνωσόμεσθα_677">, ‘come to know,’ ‘learn,’ with inf., as in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1089"> <title>Ant.</title> 1089</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ γνῷ τρέφειν τὴν γλῶσσαν ἡσυχωτέραν</quote>. In <ref n="Soph. Ant. 779"> <title>Ant.</title> 779</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γνώσεται</quote>=‘she will learn’ (by bitter experience). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔγωγ_678"> <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">γνώσομαι</quote>: ‘I, at least, will so learn.’ For this elliptical <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔγωγ’</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1347">cp. 1347</ref>, 1365, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1248."> <title>Tr.</title> 1248.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅ_ἡμῖν_679"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> The maxim is two-edged. <quote xml:lang="grc">φιλεῖν ὡς μισήσοντα</quote> is the side of it which is really in the mind of Ajax:—he dies hating the Greeks whom he had served so nobly (839—844). But the other side—<quote xml:lang="grc">μισεῖν ὡς φιλήσοντα</quote>—is that which he wishes his hearers to conceive as foremost in his thoughts.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔς_φίλον_680">: these words do not go closely with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπουργῶν_680">, but rather indicate generally the line of conduct in this case:—‘while, <emph>in relation to</emph> a friend,’ etc. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 411"> <title>Tr.</title> 411</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς τήνδε μὴ δίκαιος ὤν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. El. 24"> <title>El.</title> 24</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσθλὸς εἰς ἡμᾶς γεγώς</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βουλήσομαι_680">, as in <ref n="Soph. OT 1077"> <title>O. T.</title> 1077</ref>(n.), <ref n="Soph. OC 1289"> <title>O. C.</title> 1289</ref>: cp. below, <ref n="Soph. OC 825"> O. C. 825</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰτήσομαι</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 1446"> <title>O. T.</title> 1446</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προστρέψομαι</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_γὰρ_682"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> This is a ground for <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ φιλεῖν ὡς μισήσοντα</quote>, but not (directly, at least) for the converse; and bewrays what is really uppermost in his mind. Bias , acc. to Diogenes Laertius (1. 5 § 87), gave a similar reason,—<quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς γὰρ πλείστους εἶναι κακούς. </quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑταιρείας_682"> has better authority here than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑταιρίας_682">. Some have supposed that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑταιρεία</quote> was the form used in the sense of <emph> factio</emph>, or party ‘association,’ and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑταιρία</quote> in that of <emph>amicitia</emph>; but there is really no good evidence for this. In <ref n="Thuc. 3. 82">Thuc. 3. 82</ref>§ 5, where the word has its political sense, the best MSS. give <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑταιρίας διαλυτής</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφὶ_τούτοισιν_684">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 302">cp. 302</ref>.— <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>διὰ τέλους</emph>..τελεῖσθαι</quote>, fulfilled in all fulness. For the ordinary meaning of <quote xml:lang="grc">διὰ τέλους</quote> in Attic prose, see <ref n="Antiph. 5.42">Antiphon or. 5 § 42</ref>, where it occurs twice: <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὼν διὰ τέλους</quote> (‘present <emph>all through</emph>,’ from first to last): <quote xml:lang="grc">διὰ τέλους γάρ με ἀπέλυε</quote> (‘he acquitted me <emph> throughout</emph>,’—in all his statements). So <ref n="Aesch. PB 273"> Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 273</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκούσαθ’ ὡς μάθητε διὰ τέλους τὸ πᾶν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> from beginning to end), etc. Here the stress on the notion of <emph>end</emph>, given by <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>διὰ τέλους</emph> τελεῖσθαι</quote>, suits the inmost thought of Ajax. The <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διὰτάχους_684"> is much feebler. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταὐτὰ_τῇδε_687">=<quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ αὐτὰ ἃ ἥδε τιμᾷ</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 839"> <title>O. T.</title> 839</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγων | σοὶ ταὔτ’.— <emph>μοι</emph> </quote> ethic dat. ( <ref n="Soph. OC 1475"> <title>O. C.</title> 1475</ref> n.), ‘I pray you.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάδε_τιμᾶτε_687">, respect these wishes. The use of <quote xml:lang="grc">τιμᾶν</quote> is not exactly like that in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 514"> <title>Ant.</title> 514</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς δῆτ’ ἐκείνῳ δυσσεβῆ τιμᾷς χάριν</quote> (where see n.), but more like that in <ref n="Eur. Tro. 1210">Eur. <title>Tro.</title> 1210</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νόμους | τιμῶσιν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέλειν_689">, probably personal (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιμελεῖσθαι</quote>), as in <ref n="Eur. El. 342"> <title>El.</title> 342</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κείνου λελῆσθαι τῆς δὲ τικτούσης μέλειν</quote> (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκεῖς_690">. At first sight we might desire </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεῖς_690"> (810), as giving a better rhythm; but the slower movement of the verse may here be designed.—Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1458"> <title>O. T.</title> 1458</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν ἡμῶν μοῖῤ, ὅποιπερ εἶς’, <ref n="Soph. OT i"> ο. τ. ι</ref>)/τω</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάχ_ἴσως_691">: a formula used by Thucydides to express a <emph>strong</emph> probability (6. 10 § 4, 34 § 2, 78 § 3).— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σεσωσμένον_691">: contrasted in <ref n="Eur. El. 1229"> <title>El.</title> 1229</ref> with <quote xml:lang="grc">θανόντα</quote>: cp. <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 59 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν λόγῳ θανὼν | ἔργοισι σωθῶ</quote>. The word was thus wellchosen for his aim here. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔφριξ_693">: for the aor., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 536">cp. 536</ref>: <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 696">Ar. <title> Eq.</title> 696</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥσθην ἀπειλαῖς, ἐγέλασα ψολοκομπίαις</quote>. Aesch. fr. 387 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφριξ’ ἔρως δὲ</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρωτι</quote> Brunck) <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦδε μυστικοῦ τέλους</quote>. Here </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔρωτι_693"> seems to mean <emph>a transport of joy</emph>; it cannot be explained of their yearning for the bright future of which they are dreaming. I do not know any exactly similar use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρως</quote>. Cp. Statius <ref n="Stat. Theb. 1.493"> <title>Theb.</title> 1. 493</ref> <quote xml:lang="lat">laetusque per artus | Horror iit.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνεπτάμαν_693">: for the form, <ref target="cl282">see on 282</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προσέπτατο</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1307"> <title>Ant.</title> 1307</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνέπταν φόβῳ</quote> : <title>Helen.</title> 632 <quote xml:lang="grc">γέγηθα, κρατὶ δ’ ὀρθίους ἐθείρας | ἀνεπτέρωκα</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁλίπλαγκτε_693">, though separated from <quote xml:lang="grc">φάνηθ’</quote>, is perhaps best taken with it, since, as merely a general epithet of the god, it would here be less fitting; but then there must be no comma after it. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 760"> <title>Ph.</title> 760</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύστηνε..φανείς</quote> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 828 <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐαὲς ἡμῖν ἔλθοις</quote> (n.): <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 17">Theocr. 17. 66</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄλβιε κῶρε γένοιο</quote> </cit>. Nonnus 43. 214 describes Pan as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀβάτοισιν ἐν ὕδασι κοῦφος ὁδίτης</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Κυλλανίας_δειράδος_693">. Mount Cyllenè, in the N. E. of Arcadia, a great isolated peak, was sacred (as his birth-place) to Hermes, the father of Pan,—whose own birth was associated by legend with Cyllenè. But, of the Arcadian hills, the well-wooded Maenalus, in the interior, was more especially beloved of Pan ( <title>Geo.</title> 1. 17 <emph>tua si tibi Maenala curae</emph>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χιονοκτύπου_693"> (only here): cp. <title>Nub.</title> 270 <quote xml:lang="grc">Ὀλύμπου κορυφαῖς..χιονοβλήτοισι</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 206">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 206</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπὸ δειράσι νιφοβόλοις | Παρνασοῦ</quote>. Cyllenè attains a height of about 8000 feet. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεῶν_ἄναξ_699">: the gen. <quote xml:lang="grc">θεῶν</quote> seems to be possessive rather than partitive; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> the precise sense seems to be, ‘divine dance-maker <emph>of</emph> the gods,’ rather than, ‘among the gods, that god who makes dances.’ For such a partitive gen., we may, indeed, compare <ref n="Soph. OC 868"> <title>O. C.</title> 868</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεῶν | ὁ πάντα λεύσσων Ἥλιος</quote> (unless <quote xml:lang="grc">θεὸς</quote> should be read there). But here the meaning seems to be that Pan represents the gods in this function. Pan was to rustic <quote xml:lang="grc">χοροί</quote>, those of nymphs and satyrs, what Apollo <quote xml:lang="grc">Μουσαγέτης</quote> was to the Olympians; and the province denoted by <quote xml:lang="grc"> χοροποιός</quote> here is thus limited by the context. So Pindar fr. 75 calls Pan <quote xml:lang="grc">χορευτὰν τελεώτατον θεῶν</quote>: and an Attic <quote xml:lang="grc">σκολιόν</quote> greets him as <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀρχηστά, βρομίαις ὀπαδὲ νύμφαις</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Νύσια_699">: such dances as the worshippers of Dionysus—with whom Pan is closely associated through the satyrs—hold in his honour at Nysa. As to the various places so called, see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1131."> <title>Ant.</title> 1131.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Κνώσια_699">: such dances as the Cretan Corybantes hold at Cnosus in honour of Zeus and Apollo. Both the epithets <quote xml:lang="grc">Νύσια</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc"> Κνώσια</quote> denote a character of wild enthusiasm.—Cnosus, the chief city of Crete, was situated in the north of the island, in one of the plains at the foot of Ida. The form <quote xml:lang="grc">Κνωσός</quote> has older and better authority than <quote xml:lang="grc">Κνωσσός</quote>. It was there that Daedalus was said to have made the <quote xml:lang="grc">χορός</quote> (dancing-place) for Ariadnè ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.590"> <title>Il.</title> 18. 590</ref> ff.). Crete was the part of Hellas in which an art of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀρχηστική</quote> was first elaborately cultivated. The hyporcheme itself was originally Cretan (schol. on <ref n="Pind. P. 2">Pind. <title>P.</title> 2. 127</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοδαῆ_699"> is best explained, with the schol. in L, <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτομαθῆ, ἃ σὺ σαυτὸν ἐδίδαξας</quote>. Pan is the inspired and inspiring <quote xml:lang="grc">χοροποιός</quote>. The dances will be joyous as those of Nysa or Cnosus, but due to his prompting alone. So the minstrel Phemius says, <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοδίδακτος δ’ εἰμί, θεὸς δέ μοι ἐν φρεσὶν οἴμας | παντοίας ἐνέφυσεν</quote>, <ref n="Hom. Od. 22.347."> <title>Od.</title> 22. 347.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰάψῃς_699"> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 501">cp. 501</ref>) here denotes properly the act of <emph>putting forth</emph> the feet or the arms in lively movement; so that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰάπτειν ὀρχήματα</quote> means strictly, ‘to dance with lively gestures.’ The musician Aristoxenus (<foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 300 B.C.) mentioned the <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρητικαὶ ὀρχήσεις</quote> among those which he admired <quote xml:lang="grc">διὰ τὴν τῶν χειρῶν κίνησιν</quote> (Athen. I. p. 22 B). How <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰάπτω</quote> could be associated with swift <emph>motion</emph>, appears from the intrans. use in <title>Suppl.</title> 547 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰάπτει δ’ Ἀσίδος δἰ αἴας</quote> (‘rushes’).—Pan might possibly be said <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰάπτειν ὀρχήματα</quote> as ‘<emph>impelling</emph>’ the dance, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘setting it in movement’; but this seems less probable. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χορεῦσαι_701">, aor., because a particular occasion (or act) of dancing is in view: but in <ref n="Soph. OT 896"> <title>O. T.</title> 896</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δεῖ με χορεύειν;</quote> because the sense is, ‘why should sacred dances continue?’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἰκαρίων_πελαγέων_702">: the island of Icaria, W. of Samos and E. of Myconos, gave its name to the ‘Icarian sea’: <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.145"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 145</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόντου Ἰκαρίοιο</quote>. <title>C.</title> 3. 7. 21 <emph>scopulis surdior Icari.</emph> <ref n="Ov. Met. 8. 229">Ov. <title>Met.</title> 8. 229</ref>(describing how Icarus, son of Daedalus, was drowned) <title>Oraque caerulea</title> , <emph>patrium clamantia nomen</emph>, | <title>Excipiuntur aqua</title> , <emph>quae nomen traxit ab illo.</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πελαγέων_702">: the plur. as in <ref n="Hom. Od. 5.335"> <title>Od.</title> 5. 335</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁλὸς ἐν πελάγεσσιν</quote>. For the synizesis, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 718">cp. 718</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεικέων</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 697"> <title>Ph.</title> 697</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑλκέων</quote> .—For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπὲρ_702"> with gen., cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 105"> <title>Ant.</title> 105</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Διρκαίων ὑπὲρ ῥεέθρων μολοῦσα</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀπόλλων_702"> was, like Pan, a lord of the dance; cp. Pind. fr. 148 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀρχήστ’ ἀγλαΐας ἀνάσσων, εὐρυφάρετρ’ Ἀπόλλων</quote>: fr. 116 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ Μοισαγέτας με καλεῖ χορεῦσαι</quote>. Here, however, the words <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν γὰρ ἐμοὶ μέλει χορεῦσαι</quote> seem to close the reference to dancing. Apollo, who in 187 was invoked as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποτρόπαιος</quote>, is here invited more especially as the healer,—to crown, by his bright presence, their joy at the recovery of Ajax.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Δάλιος_702">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 154"> <title>O. T.</title> 154</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Δάλιε Παιάν</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔγνωστος_702">, ‘easily recognised,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, in a visible shape, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐναργής</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 11"> <title>Tr.</title> 11</ref> n.: <ref n="Hom. Od. 3.420"> <title>Od.</title> 3. 420</ref>(Athena) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥ μοι ἐναργὴς ἦλθε</quote>. On <quote xml:lang="grc">γνωτός</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">γνωστός</quote>, see <title>O. T.</title>, appendix on 361, p. 225. Some editors read </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὔγνωτος_702">, though the form with <quote xml:lang="grc">ς</quote> is here the better attested.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διὰ_παντὸς_702">, with ref. to time (the regular sense of the phrase in Thuc. ; see Classen on 1. 38 § 1). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔλυσεν_Ἄρης_706">. Ares, the god of bloodshed and violent death (253 n.), is said to have ‘cleared away’ the cloud of dread trouble which darkened their eyes, because Ajax has renounced his purpose of suicide. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 654"> <title>Tr.</title> 654</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄρης</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξέλυσ’ ἐπίπονον ἁμέραν</quote>, ‘has cleared away the day of trouble’ (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰνὸν_ἄχος_706">: <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.83"> <title>Il.</title> 17. 83</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἕκτορα δ’ αἰνὸν ἄχος πύκασε φρένας.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπ_ὀμμάτων_706">: <ref n="Aesch. Seven 228"> Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 228</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">θεὸς</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀκ χαλεπᾶς δύας ὕπερθ’ ὀμμάτων | κρημναμενᾶν νεφελᾶν ὀρθοῖ</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάρα_709">=<quote xml:lang="grc">πάρεστι</quote> :</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λευκὸν_φάος_709">, acc., subject to <quote xml:lang="grc">πελάσαι</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 301"> Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 301</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ λευκὸν ἦμαρ νυκτὸς ἐκ μελαγχίμου</quote>. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐάμερονφάος_709"> <ref n="Soph. Aj. 138">cp. 138</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγος κακόθρους</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πελάσαι_709"> with gen., as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1327"> <title>Ph.</title> 1327</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πελασθεὶς φύλακος</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 17"> <title>Tr.</title> 17</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοίτης ἐμπελασθῆναι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θοᾶν_709"> describes the ship as a thing of life (<emph>velox navis</emph>), <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠκυάλων</quote> rather as a swift vehicle over the sea (<emph>celeris</emph>): cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 7.34"> <title>Od.</title> 7. 34</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νηυσὶ θοῇσι πεποιθότες ὠκείῃσι</quote>. For the double epithet, cp. also <ref n="Soph. Phil. 516"> <title>Ph.</title> 516</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐστόλου ταχείας νεώς</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαθίπονος_711"> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐστί</quote>),=<quote xml:lang="grc">λανθάνεται πόνων</quote>: the word occurs only here and in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1021"> <title>Tr.</title> 1021</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">λαθίπονον δ’ ὀδυνᾶν</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάνθυτα_ἐξήνυς_712">. As Ajax had announced his purpose of ‘purging his stains’ (655) and ‘submitting to the gods’ (666 f.), the Chorus assume that he has now duly performed all the rites of <quote xml:lang="grc">καθαρμός</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱλασμός</quote>. By <quote xml:lang="grc">θεῶν πάνθυτα θέσμια</quote> is meant, ‘the ordinances of the gods, with all the <quote xml:lang="grc">θυσίαι</quote> which they enjoin’; since the ablutions of Ajax would be followed (as the Chorus conceive) by sacrifices to the deities whom he had offended, esp. to Athena and Artemis. There is thus a tragic irony in </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάνθυτα_712">, since a <quote xml:lang="grc">θυσία</quote> is indeed about to be offered.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐνομίᾳ_712">, ‘loyalty’ to these <quote xml:lang="grc">θέσμια</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαραίνει_714">. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 2. 3">Soph. <title> Ant.</title> 2. 3</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ πάντα μαραίνων τὰ καλὰ χρόνος</quote>. The reading of the MSS., <quote xml:lang="grc">μαραίνει <emph>τε καὶ φλέγει</emph> </quote>, clearly bewrays an interpolation. The schol. in L has, <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ ὑπὸ Αἴαντος διὰ πολλῶν εἰρημένα διὰ βραχέων διεξῆλθεν</quote>: vague words which obviously do <emph>not</emph> require us to suppose that the <quote xml:lang="grc">φανέντα κρύπτεται</quote> of v. 647, as well as the <quote xml:lang="grc">φύει τ’ ἄδηλα</quote>, found an echo here. But it is possible that this very scholium may have led a prosaic reader to surmise a loss, and to supply it. (Another possibility is that <quote xml:lang="grc">μαραίνει</quote> was corrupted to <quote xml:lang="grc">μαραίνεται</quote>, and this to <quote xml:lang="grc">μαραίνει τε</quote>, when a defect would be inferred.) Compare the undoubted interpolations in <ref n="Soph. OT 896">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 896</ref> and <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1407.">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 1407.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀναύδατον_715"> is not here ‘unutterably dreadful’ (as in <ref n="Eur. Ion 782">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 782</ref>), but ‘not to be spoken of,’ in the sense, ‘not to be affirmed as possible’: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 388">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 388</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βροτοῖσιν οὐδέν ἐστ’ ἀπώμοτον</quote>. Thus <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνέλπιστον</quote> (schol.) gives the meaning correctly. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_ἀέλπτων_716">: <title>Suppl.</title> 357 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἀέλπτων κἀπρομηθήτων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μετανεγνώσθη_717"> is prob. passive; ‘has been converted from his anger.’ I cannot find an example of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγνώσθην</quote> (simple or compound) in any but a pass. sense. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνεγνώσθην</quote> is regularly pass. in Herod. ; <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> 4. 154 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναγνωσθεὶς ὑπὸ τῆς γυναικός</quote> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 6">cp. 6</ref>. 50; 7. 7, etc.). The schol. in L took the word to be pass.; he explains it by <quote xml:lang="grc">μετεπείσθη</quote> (as Hesychius does), and <quote xml:lang="grc">μετεβλήθη</quote>. The other view —that <quote xml:lang="grc">μετανεγνώσθη</quote> is midd. in sense— appears in the glosses <quote xml:lang="grc">μετέγνω</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">μεταβεβούλευται</quote>: but no proof is brought. If it be passive, however, it does not mean that the Chorus suppose Ajax to have been converted by themselves or Tecmessa: the cause is left indefinite.—The form </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μετανεγνώθη_717"> is preferred by Wecklein: Hesychius is, however, our only witness for it. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θυμοῦ_θυμῶν_718"> (cr. n.) is indeed nearer to the <quote xml:lang="grc">θυμὸν</quote> of the MSS., since Sophocles would write it <quote xml:lang="grc">ΘΥΜΟΝ</quote>: but, though the plur. <quote xml:lang="grc">θυμοί</quote> is common enough in prose (as=‘fits of passion’), it never occurs in Tragedy. The gen. depends on <quote xml:lang="grc">μετανεγνώσθη</quote> as a verb of ‘desisting’ or ‘withdrawing’ from (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">μεταστῆναί τινος</quote>). The dat. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀτρείδαις_718"> depends on <quote xml:lang="grc">μετανεγνώσθη θυμοῦ</quote> as implying <quote xml:lang="grc">κατηλλάχθη</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνέγνω</quote> . <ref n="Soph. Aj. 774">Cp. 774</ref>: I. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.283"> <title>Il.</title> 283</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀχιλλῆι μεθέμεν χόλον</quote>: <ref n="Hom. Od. 21.377"> <title>Od.</title> 21. 377</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέθιεν χαλεποῖο χόλοιο | Τηλεμάχῳ.— <emph>νεικέων</emph> </quote>: for the synizesis, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 702">cp. 702</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πελαγέων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_πρῶτον_719">, adv., in the first place. The omission of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι</quote> after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγγεῖλαι</quote> marks the speaker's eager haste: cp. <title> O.T.</title> 1234 f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ μὲν τάχιστος τῶν λόγων εἰπεῖν τε καὶ | μαθεῖν, τέθνηκε θεῖον Ἰοκάστης κάρα</quote>. For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_πρῶτον_719_2">, compare also <ref n="Soph. Ant. 238"> <title>Ant.</title> 238</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 232"> <title>Tr.</title> 232</ref>: <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 642">Ar. <title> Eq.</title> 642</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγους ἀγαθοὺς φέρων | εὐαγγελίσασθαι πρῶτον ὑμῖν βούλομαι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Μυσίων_κρημνῶν_720">. The eastern boundary of the ancient Mysia, dividing it from Bithynia and Phrygia, is formed by the range of Olympus, which attains a height of about 8500 ft. The <quote xml:lang="grc">κρημνοί</quote> meant here are the lower spurs of Olympus, in the region of Ida. Teucer had gone on a foray (343 n.) to some of the upland towns or villages of the enemy.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στρατήγιον_720">, the <quote xml:lang="grc"> κλισία</quote> of Agamemnon. So in <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.382"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 382</ref> an agora is held <quote xml:lang="grc">νηὶ πάρα πρυμνῇ Ἀγαμέμνονος</quote>. He was stationed near Odysseus, whose post, at the middle point of the naval camp ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.6"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 6</ref>), is mentioned as being near the place of assembly, judgment, and sacrifice; <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵνα σφ’ ἀγορή τε θέμις τε | ἤην, τῇ δὴ καί σφι θεῶν ἐτετεύχατο βωμοί</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.807"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 807</ref> f.). Hence </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέσον_720"> here. The chiefs of the army had now met in front of these headquarters to hold a <quote xml:lang="grc">βουλή</quote> on the deed of Ajax; while the <quote xml:lang="grc">λαοί</quote> were gathered in <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγορά</quote> around them. In Attic prose <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατήγιον</quote> means the council-chamber of the ten <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατηγοί</quote> (<ref n="Aeschin. 2.85">Aeschin. or. 2 § 85</ref>: <ref n="Aeschin. 3.146">or. 3. § 146</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυδάζεται_722">. The word from which this verb comes is written <quote xml:lang="grc">κῦδος</quote> by the schol. in L here (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρσενικῶς δὲ ὁ κῦδος</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ τῆς ὕβρεως</quote>), and by the schol. on Apoll. Rhod. 1. 1337 <quote xml:lang="grc">κῦδος ἀρσενικῶς ἡ λοιδορία παρὰ Συρακουσίοις</quote>. The schol. in L illustrates the verb by two quotations: (1) from the <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄμυκος</quote> of Epicharmus: <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄμυκε μὴ κύδαζέ μοι τὸν πρεσβύτερον ἀδελφόν</quote>: (2) from the <title>Iphigeneia</title> of Aeschylus: <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔ τοι γυναιξὶ κυδάζεσθαι· τί γάρ;</quote>—where Elmsley inserts <quote xml:lang="grc">δεῖ</quote>, and Blomfield <quote xml:lang="grc">χρή</quote>, after <quote xml:lang="grc">γυναιξί</quote>. The verb having <quote xml:lang="grc">υ^</quote>, the noun must have been <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ κύδος</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">υ^</quote>).—For the dat. of the agency, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀργείοις_722">, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 539">cp. 539</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στείχοντα_723"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> They saw him coming while he was still far off; when he drew nearer, they gathered round him in a threatening crowd; and now, having arrived at the <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατήγιον</quote>, he is being reviled by them. Notwithstanding the position of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_κύκλῳ_723">, the poet may have meant </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόσωθεν_723"> to go with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθόντες_723">, which certainly suits the sense better than to take it with <quote xml:lang="grc">στείχοντα</quote>. The order of words, though somewhat awkward, is not bolder than that in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 944"> <title>Ant.</title> 944</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔτλα καὶ Δανάας οὐράνιον φῶς | ἀλλάξαι δέμας ἐν χαλκοδέτοις αὐλαῖς</quote>. Cp. also <ref n="Soph. El. 1349"> <title>El.</title> 1349</ref> f., <ref n="Soph. Phil. 598"> <title>Ph.</title> 598</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1163."> Ph. 1163.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤρασσον_725">, as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 374"> <title>Ph.</title> 374</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χολωθεὶς εὐθὺς ἤρασσον κακοῖς | τοῖς πᾶσιν</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1244">Cp. 1244</ref> : <ref n="Aesch. Seven 382">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 382</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θείνει δ’ ὀνείδει μάντιν</quote>. <title>Nub.</title> 1373 <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐθὺς ἐξαράττω | πολλοῖς κακοῖς κᾀσχροῖσι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔνθεν_κἄνθεν_725">: cp. <ref n="Verg. A. 4. 447">Verg. <title>Aen.</title> 4. 447</ref> <quote xml:lang="lat">adsiduis hinc atque hinc vocibus heros | Tunditur.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτις_οὔ_725">: cp. <title>O.T.</title> 372 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃ σοὶ | οὐδεὶς ὃς οὐχὶ τῶνδ’ ὀνειδιεῖ τάχα</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_μανέντος_726"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote>: the art. <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν</quote> marks a quotation of the phrase which they used: ‘calling him “that kinsman of the maniac,”’ etc. Cp. <ref n="Xen. Anab. 6. 6. 7">Xen. <title>Anab.</title> 6. 6. 7</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιχειροῦσι βάλλειν τὸν Δέξιππον, ἀνακαλοῦντες τὸν προδότην. </quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀπιβουλευτοῦ_στρατοῦ_726">. The MSS. agree in </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στρατοῦ_726">, which is correct; as one could say <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνταγωνιστής τινος</quote>. The dat. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στρατῷ_726"> would also be tenable (cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 668"> <title>Tr.</title> 668</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν σῶν Ἡρακλεῖ δωρημάτων</quote> n.), and is strongly recommended by euphony. But euphony is not a sure guide in such cases (cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1354"> <title>Ph.</title> 1354</ref> n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποκαλοῦντες_726">, in a bad sense, as usu.: <ref n="Dem. 19.305">Dem. or. 19 § 305</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλάστορα τὸν Φίλιππον ἀποκαλῶν</quote>. The good sense is rare in Attic of this age; <title>De re equestri</title> 10. 17 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἵππον τοιοῦτον ἀποκαλοῦσιν ἐλευθέριον</quote>: but may have been less rare later (cp. <title>Eth. N.</title> 2. 9: <ref n="Plut. Maxime 776e"> Plut. <title>Mor.</title> 776</ref>E).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_θανεῖν_726">: that he should not avail to save himself from dying: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς οὐκ ἀρκέσοι ἑαυτῷ τὸ μὴ λιθόλευστος γενέσθαι</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. PB 918">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 918</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν γὰρ αὐτῷ ταῦτ’ ἐπαρκέσει τὸ μὴ οὐ | πεσεῖν ἀτίμως</quote>. For the fut. optat., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 313">cp. 313</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καταξανθεὶς_726">, carded (like wool), torn to shreds; Eur. imitates this (<title>Suppl.</title> 503) <quote xml:lang="grc">πέτροις καταξανθέντες ὀστέων ῥαφάς</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 319">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 319</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί φειδόμεσθα τῶν λίθων, ὦ δημόται</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐ καταξαίνειν τὸν ἄνδρα τοῦτον εἰς φοινικίδα;</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥστ_729"> (‘and so’) has been suspected on account of the second </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥστε_729">: but the latter, going with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοσοῦτον_729">, does not offend the ear, since its sense is different and subordinate; cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 735"> <title>Ant.</title> 735</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾷς τόδ’ ὡς εἴρηκας ὡς ἄγαν νέος</quote> <emph>; </emph> <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1241"> Tr. 1241</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τάχ’, ὡς ἔοικας, ὡς νοσεῖς φράσεις</quote>. So in <ref n="Xen. Anab. 2. 2. 17">Xen. <title>Anab.</title> 2. 2. 17</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κραυγὴν.. ἐποίουν,..ὥστε καὶ τοὺς πολεμίους ἀκούειν· ὥστε οἱ μὲν ἐγγυτάτω..ἔφυγον</quote>: where the first <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστε</quote>=‘so that,’ while the second =‘and so.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κολεῶν_ξίφη_729">. The swords <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>διεπεραιώθη</emph> κολεῶν</quote>, were drawn through (and out of) the scabbards, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρυστά_729">, by a sharp, quick pull,—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> with angry haste.—Not, ‘swords plucked from the sheaths were <emph>crossed</emph>’: as if Teucer actually crossed swords with one or more of his assailants. The whole scene has been suggested by that in the first book of the <title> Iliad</title>, as the schol. in L saw:—<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ τῆς Ἀχιλλέως δὲ πρὸς Ἀγαμέμνονα ἀρχῆς</quote> (read <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὀργῆς</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">παραγέγραπται</quote>. There, Achilles was drawing his sword—<quote xml:lang="grc">ἕλκετο δ’ ἐκ κολεοῖο μέγα ξίφος</quote>—when Athena came to him ( I. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.194"> <title>Il.</title> 194</ref>): <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄψ δ’ ἐς κουλεὸν ὦσε μέγα ξίφος</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 220).—Some of the later MSS. here have </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κουλεῶν_729">, which was a current form in late Greek (Eustathius p. 1604. 58 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ κολεὸν κοινότερον κουλεὸν λέγεται</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δραμοῦσα_προσωτάτω_731">: for the partitive gen., cp. <ref n="Xen. Anab. 1. 3. 1">Xen. <title>Anab.</title> 1. 3. 1</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔφασαν ἰέναι τοῦ πρόσω</quote>: <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 174">Ar. <title>Ran.</title> 174</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπάγεθ’ ὑμεῖς τῆς ὁδοῦ.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_γερόντων_731">, by means of the conciliatory words of elders: for the double gen., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 308">cp. 308</ref> f.: for </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_731">, denoting the instrument, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 60"> <title>Ph.</title> 60</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν λιταῖς στείλαντες</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1393 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν λόγοις | πείσειν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμὶν_733">, ethic dat.: <ref n="Soph. OC 81"> <title>O. C.</title> 81</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ βέβηκεν ἡμὶν ὁ ξένος;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_κυρίοις_733">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, Ajax himself, who is the <quote xml:lang="grc">κύριος</quote> or ‘principal person’ in this matter, as being most nearly concerned in it. For the poet. plur., cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 688">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 688</ref>(Orestes to Clytaemnestra) <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δὲ τυγχάνω | τοῖς κυρίοισι καὶ προσήκουσιν λέγων | οὐκ οἶδα</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέας_βουλὰς_735">, his new ‘counsels,’ in respect of his supposed resolve to propitiate gods and men; </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέοισιν_τρόποις_735">, the new ‘dispositions,’ the character of greater gentleness and docility, which the resolve implies. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγκαταζεύξας_735">: he has ‘harnessed’ the new resolve, as it were, to the new character,—brought it under the yoke of his chastened will. The word conveys more than the idea of ‘adapting’ (Pindar's <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕργμασιν νικαφόροις ἐγκώμιον ζεῦξαι μέλος</quote>, <title>N.</title> 1. 7). It further implies self-conquest. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰοὺ_ἰού_737">, a cry of despair. In <ref n="Soph. OT 1071"> <title>O. T.</title> 1071</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 1182"> O. T. 1182</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1143"> <title>Tr.</title> 1143</ref>, and <ref n="Soph. Phil. 38"> <title>Ph.</title> 38</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰοὺ ἰού</quote> stands within the trimeter.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βραδεῖαν_737">, predicate. ‘Either Teucer was too late in sending me, or I have been too long upon the road,’—though he had come, of course, with all speed. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμᾶς_ὁδόν_737">: for the cogn. acc., cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1163"> <title>El.</title> 1163</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πεμφθεὶς κελεύθους</quote>. With <quote xml:lang="grc">πέμπω</quote>, the second acc. usu. denotes the place <emph>to which</emph> ( <ref n="Soph. OT 761"> <title>O. T.</title> 761</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγρούς σφε πέμψαι</quote>).— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φάνην_737">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 308">cp. 308</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">)θώϋξεν</quote>: 557 <quote xml:lang="grc">)τράφης</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρείας_τῆσδ_740">, ‘this urgent matter’ (as they infer it to be from the speaker's distress). So <quote xml:lang="grc">χρεία</quote> sometimes=‘a request’: <ref n="Soph. OT 1435"> <title>O. T.</title> 1435</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τοῦ με χρείας ὦδε λιπαρεῖς τυχεῖν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπεσπανισμένον_740">, ‘scanted,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘imperfectly done.’ With Aesch. this partic. means ‘scanted of’ a thing, ‘insufficiently provided’ with it: <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">βορᾶς</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 490">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 490</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">φόνου</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 577">Aesch. <title> Ch.</title> 577</ref>). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Shak. OTH 1.3.267">Shakesp. <title>Othello</title> 1. 3. 267</bibl> <quote xml:lang="eng">You think | I will your serious and great business scant</quote> </cit> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘neglect’). </gloss>

data.quote:
You think | I will your serious and great
							business scant

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπηύδα_741">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 236"> <title>O. T.</title> 236</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπαυδῶ</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">μήτ’ εἰσδέχεσθαι κ.τ.λ.</quote>: <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 1. 4. 14">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 1. 4. 14</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπηγόρευε μηδένα βάλλειν.— <emph>παρήκειν</emph> </quote>. When verbs of motion compounded with <quote xml:lang="grc">παρά</quote> mean to ‘go <emph>forward</emph>,’ that sense comes through the notion of going into the presence of others (<quote xml:lang="grc">παρά τινα</quote>): so <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ παριόντες</quote> are those who come forward to address the ecclesia. Teucer was anxious that Ajax should not go forth into public (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξω παρήκειν</quote>). In <ref n="Soph. OT 1241">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 1241</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 900">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 900</ref>, and <ref n="Soph. El. 1337">Soph. <title>El.</title> 1337</ref>, as often elsewhere, <quote xml:lang="grc">παρελθεῖν</quote> is said of <emph> entering</emph> a house.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τύχῃ_741"> represents the ‘vivid construction,’ by which the subjunct. of the ‘direct discourse’ can be retained, though the principal verb is in a secondary tense: <ref n="Thuc. 1. 45">Thuc. 1. 45</ref>§ 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">προεῖπον..μὴ ναυμαχεῖν..ἢν μὴ..πλέωσι</quote> (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ πλέοιεν</quote>). For <quote xml:lang="grc">πρίν</quote> and subjunct., without <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 965">cp. 965</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τύχοι_741"> would mark more clearly that he is merely repeating what Teucer said: but the weight of MS. authority is on the side of <quote xml:lang="grc">τύχῃ</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴχεται_743">, an unconsciously ominous word.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_κέρδιστον_743">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> the most advantageous course which he could possibly take. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1113"> <title>Ant.</title> 1113</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέδοικα γὰρ μὴ τοὺς καθεστῶτας νόμους | ἄριστον ᾖ σῴζοντα τὸν βίον τελεῖν</quote>. There is no more reason for desiring </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_κέρδιον_743"> here than <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄμεινον</quote> there. For <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ κέρδιστον.. <emph>γνώμης</emph> </quote>, cp. <ref n="Thuc. 1. 90">Thuc. 1. 90</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ..βουλόμενον καὶ ὕποπτον τῆς γνώμης</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοῖσιν_χόλου_743">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 717">cp. 717</ref> f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὖ_φρονῶν_746">, ‘with intelligence’ (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1252">cp. 1252</ref>): not ‘with good will,’ as in <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.73"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 73</ref>(Calchas) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐῢ φρονέων ἀγορήσατο</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάρει_747">, as a correction of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέρι_747">, is irresistibly commended by the answer, <quote xml:lang="grc">τοσοῦτον οἶδα</quote>. Moreover, the question, ‘what does Calchas know of this matter?’ is strange in reference to the inspired seer, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς ᾔδη τά τ’ ἐόντα τά τ’ ἐσσόμενα πρό τ’ ἐόντα</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.70"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 70</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοσοῦτον_748">. Schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντὶ μέχρι τούτου</quote>: meaning that the word goes not only with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶδα_748">, but also adverbially with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρὼν_748">: ‘thus much I know, and thus far was I an eye-witness.’ Rather the clause </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_παρὼνἐτύγχανον_748"> is independent of <quote xml:lang="grc">τοσοῦτον οἶδα</quote>, as an independent sentence is often subjoined to a relative clause: see on <ref n="Soph. OC 424"> <title>O. C.</title> 424</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἧς νῦν ἔχονται κἀπαναίρονται δόρυ</quote>. It is equiv. to a participial phrase giving the ground for <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶδα</quote>, such as <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς ἰδών</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1192"> <title>Ant.</title> 1192</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὼν ἐρῶ</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συνέδρου_κύκλου_749">,= <quote xml:lang="grc">κύκλου τῶν συνεδρευόντων βασιλέων</quote>: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.503"> <title>Il.</title> 18. 503</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δὲ γέροντες | εἵατ’ ἐπὶ ξεστοῖσι λίθοις ἱερῷ ἐνὶ κύκλῳ</quote> (of judges). The Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">βουλή</quote> consists, not of all the chiefs, but of a select number, specially summoned: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 10.195"> <title>Il.</title> 10. 195</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀργείων βασιλῆες, ὅσοι κεκλήατο βουλήν</quote>. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 10.108"> <title>Il.</title> 10. 108</ref> ff. the number indicated is about nine.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶος_δίχα_749">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 464">cp. 464</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φιλοφρόνως_751">: for the <quote xml:lang="grc"> ο—</quote> before <quote xml:lang="grc">φρ</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1104"> <title>Ant.</title> 1104</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς κακόφρονας</quote> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 336 <quote xml:lang="grc"> περιβρυχίοισιν</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παντοίᾳ_τέχνῃ_752">: <ref n="Hdt. 1. 112"> Her. 1. 112</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐχρήιζε μηδεμιῇ τέχνῃ ἐκθεῖναί μιν</quote> . <ref n="Xen. Anab. 4. 5. 16">Xen. <title>Anab.</title> 4. 5. 16</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐδεῖτο αὐτῶν πάσῃ τέχνῃ καὶ μηχανῇ μὴ ἀπολείπεσθαι</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶρξαι_753">. The primitive sense of the root (<quote xml:lang="grc">vεργ</quote>) was to ‘press’: whence come both the meanings of this verb, ‘to shut out,’ and ‘to shut in.’ Acc. to Eustathius (p. 1387. 3) the Attic form was <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴργω</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">κωλύω</quote> (‘shut out’ or ‘hinder’), but <quote xml:lang="grc">εἵργω</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγκλείω</quote>. Curtius (<title>Etym.</title> § 142) thinks that this distinction was of comparatively late origin. Our MSS. consistently give <quote xml:lang="grc">εἱρκτή, εἱργμός</quote>, ‘a prison.’ Andoc. or. 4 § 27 has <quote xml:lang="grc">εἱργνύων</quote> (‘imprisoning’): Plat. <title> Tim.</title>p. 45 E <quote xml:lang="grc">καθείργνυσι</quote> (indeed, the forms from <quote xml:lang="grc">ειργνυ</quote> are always aspirated). But in regard to the other forms the evidence of MSS. is often conflicting, and the practice of editors has varied. In Thuc. , Bekker always writers <quote xml:lang="grc">εἵργω</quote>: Classen and Stahl, always <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴργω</quote>, even (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>) in 8. 74 § 3 <quote xml:lang="grc"> εἴρξειν</quote> and 4. 47 § 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">κατεῖρξαν</quote>, where the ref. is to imprisonment; though in the latter place the MSS. seem to agree on <quote xml:lang="grc">καθεῖρξαν</quote>. On the other hand in <ref n="Eur. Ba. 443">Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 443</ref> the best editions give <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶρξαι</quote>. Eur. Itmay be noted that Lobeck could find no instance of <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀφείργειν</quote> earlier than Aelian (<title>Hist. An.</title> 12. 21 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφειργμένη</quote>): as to <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἄφερκτος</quote> in <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 446">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 446</ref>, he justifies it as meaning, ‘shut in (apart),’ not ‘shut off.’ Recent editors are generally agreed in writing <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶρξαι</quote> here, and <quote xml:lang="grc"> εἴργειν</quote> in 795. This is justifiable in any case, the sense being ‘to <emph>restrain</emph>,’ rather than definitely ‘to <emph>shut in.</emph> ’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦμαρ_τόδε_753">: the cumulative phrase marks the seer's anxiety to impress the fact upon his hearer; it is like the precise fulness of 741 f., <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνδοθεν στέγης | μὴ )ξω παρήκειν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπὸ_σκηναῖσι_754">=<quote xml:lang="grc">σκηνῆς ὕπαυλον</quote> (796).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδ_ἐᾶν_754">: not to release him (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφέντα</quote>), and leave him to himself. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκεῖνον_755">, where we might have looked for the less emphatic <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόν</quote>, since </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Αἴαντα_755"> has so lately preceded; an Attic idiom: cp. Andoc. or. 1 § 60 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλέγξαι Διοκλείδην ψευσάμενον, καὶ τιμωρήσασθαι ἐκεῖνον.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποτέ_755"> has been suspected, but needlessly; it refers to <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδ’ ἀφέντ’ ἐᾶν</quote>: if Ajax were let out, Teucer would <emph>nevermore</emph> see him alive. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλᾷ_756">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 504">cp. 504</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῇδε_θἡμέρᾳ_756">. The fact that Aristophanes uses this crasis ( <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 1071"> <title>Av.</title> 1071</ref>, <title>Thesm.</title> 76) proves that it was familiar to Athenian ears. There is no good reason for excluding it from Tragedy, when <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴμ’</quote> is allowed in tragic verse on the ground that Comedy proves it to have been common. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_λέγων_757">, lit., as he said in the course of his statement, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘as he went on to say.’ So <ref n="Hdt. 3. 156"> Her. 3. 156</ref>(Zopyrus) ‘<quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν τε,’ ἔφη λέγων, ‘ἐγὼ ὑμῖν..ἥκω μέγιστον ἀγαθόν</quote>’ (‘he went on to say’— in continuation of his story. So too in <ref n="Hdt. 5. 36."> Her. 5. 36.</ref>Cp. <ref n="Dem. 18.51">Dem. or. 18 § 51</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ νῦν εἶπέ που λέγων, ‘ὁ τὴν Ἀλεξάνδρου ξενίαν ὀνειδίζων ἐμοἴ</quote>’ (‘he has said in some discourse or other’). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_περισσὰ_758"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> To judge the text aright here, we must remember that these are the words of the <quote xml:lang="grc">μάντις</quote>, who speaks as the prophet of the gods. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περισσὰ_ςματα_758"> are mortals whose over-great strength and success have made them wax too proud, so that they no longer serve the gods with due piety. Such mortals are <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνόνητοι</quote>,—their lives can yield no worthy fruit. Compare the words of warning addressed to Xerxes ( <ref n="Hdt. 7. 10"> Her. 7. 10</ref>): <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾷς τὰ ὑπερέχοντα ζῷα ὡς κεραυνοῖ ὁ θεὸς οὐδὲ ἐᾷ φαντάζεσθαι..φιλέει γὰρ ὁ θεὸς τὰ ὑπερέχοντα πάντα κολούειν</quote>. See also v. 1077, <quote xml:lang="grc">κἄν τις σῶμα γεννήσῃ μέγα κ.τ.λ.</quote>: and Athena's phrase in 129, <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδ’ ὄγκον ἄρῃ μηδέν)</quote> .</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀνόνητα_758"> is supported by the general consensus of ancient testimony. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀνόητα_758"> is adopted by several recent editors, because the <emph>folly</emph> of Ajax is elsewhere recognised (763 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνους</quote>, 766 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφρόνως</quote>), whereas he could not, they think, be called <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνόνητος</quote>. But that depends on the point of view. In the sight of the gods, the greatest warrior would be <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνόνητος</quote>, if he ceased <quote xml:lang="grc">κατ’ ἄνθρωπον φρονεῖν</quote>. Observe, too, that the word </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σώματα_758"> confirms <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀνόνητα</quote>: the idea is that of greatness which, swollen beyond the human limit, has ceased to fulfil the proper function of mankind. Such <quote xml:lang="grc">σώματα</quote> are <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνόνητα</quote> <emph> because</emph> <quote xml:lang="grc">περισσά</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅστις_760">, referring to <quote xml:lang="grc"> σώματα</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1505"> <title>El.</title> 1505</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς πᾶσιν δίκην</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις κ.τ.λ.</quote> (n.).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φύσιν_βλαστὼν_760">: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1062"> <title>Tr.</title> 1062</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θῆλυς κοὐκ ἀνδρὸς φύσιν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονῇ_760"> has the authority of the first hand in L, though here there is little to choose between indic. and subjunct.: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1231"> <title>O. T.</title> 1231</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἳ φανῶσ’</quote> : <ref n="Soph. OC 395"> <title>O. C.</title> 395</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς νέος πέσῃ</quote> : <ref n="Eur. Ion 855">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 855</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦλος ὅστις ἐσθλὸς ᾖ</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεῖνος_δ_762">. All this, down to v. 779, is still what Calchas said, as v. 780 shows.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλῶς_λέγοντος_762">: gen. absol. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸν_ἐννέπει_764">: <ref n="Hom. Il. 12.210"> <title>Il.</title> 12. 210</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δὴ τότε Πουλυδάμας θρασὺν Ἕκτορα εἶπε παραστάς</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OC 991"> <title>O. C.</title> 991</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἓν γάρ μ’ ἄμειψαι μοῦνον</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1065"> <title>Ph.</title> 1065</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή μ’ ἀντιφώνει μηδέν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_θεῷ_765">, with the help of the gods (generally): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 383">cp. 383</ref> (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_ὢν_767">: he who is as nought,—a mere nonentity. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1231">Cp. 1231</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_κείνων_768">. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.629"> <title>Il.</title> 17. 629</ref> ff. Ajax says that Zeus is manifestly on the side of the Trojans; and adds, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἄγετ’, αὐτοί περ φραζώμεθα μῆτιν ἀρίστην</quote>,—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, without his aid. But in these words there is no impiety—a trait foreign to the Ajax of the <title>Iliad</title>: see Introduction § 1. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπισπάσειν_κλέος_769">. Hesych. 2, p. 168 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπισπάσει· ἐπιτεύξεται. Σοφοκλῆς Ἀτρεῖ ἢ Μυκήναις</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">Μυκηναίας</quote>: fr. 137). ‘Draw to,’ or ‘on,’ oneself: so here, ‘achieve.’ Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 477">Aesch. <title> Pers.</title> 477</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοσόνδε πλῆθος πημάτων ἐπέσπασεν</quote>, which recalls <ref n="Hom. Od. 18.73">Hom. <title> Od.</title> 18. 73</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπίσπαστον κακὸν ἕξει</quote>. Neophron fr. 3. 2 (Nauck, <title>Trag. Gr. Fragm.</title> p. 731) <quote xml:lang="grc">βροχωτὸν ἀγχόνην ἐπισπάσας δέρῃ</quote> (where <quote xml:lang="grc">δέρῃ</quote> should prob. begin the verse). The middle voice would seem fitter in all these places: cp. <ref n="Apollod. 2.1">Apollod. 2. 1</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπισπᾶσθαι τὴν ἀπὸ τῶν θεῶν ὀργήν</quote>. This seems an instance in which metrical necessity accounts for the use of the active voice; as, conversely, a metrical motive so often induced the use of middle forms. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δίας_Ἀθάνας_771">. The genitive, if sound, is best taken as depending on <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντιφωνεῖ</quote> in the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντίον λέγει</quote>, ‘says to her face.’ In <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1065"> <title>Ph.</title> 1065</ref>, however, this verb takes an acc. of the person, <quote xml:lang="grc">μή μ’ ἀντιφώνει μηδέν</quote>: and no verb of ‘accosting’ affords a parallel to such a constr. as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντιφωνεῖν τινος</quote>. Such phrases as those in <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 694">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 694</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντία λέξαι | σέθεν</quote> (‘in thy presence’), <ref n="Hom. Od. 15.377">Hom. <title>Od.</title> 15. 377</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντία δεσποίνης φάσθαι</quote>, are not relevant. (In <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.230">Hom. <title>Il.</title> 1. 230</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις σέθεν ἀντίον εἴπῃ</quote>, the sense is, ‘<emph> against</emph> thee.’)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δίανἈθάναν_771">, so that the verb shall have the same constr. as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1065."> <title>Ph.</title> 1065.</ref>But, if this be right, how did the genitive arise? Possibly some annotator, who thought that after <quote xml:lang="grc">ηὐδᾶτ’</quote> in 772 the subject of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντιφωνεῖ</quote> might be obscure, wrote <quote xml:lang="grc">ΑΙΑΣ</quote> in the margin, and this, mistaken for <quote xml:lang="grc">ΔΙΑΣ</quote>, led to <quote xml:lang="grc">ΔΙΑΣ ΑΘΑΝΑΣ</quote> supplanting <quote xml:lang="grc">ΔΙΑΝ ΑΘΑΝΑΝ</quote> in the text. The occurrence of the same words in 757 may have helped. [The Homeric fem. is <quote xml:lang="grc">δῖα, δῖαν</quote>. But <quote xml:lang="grc">δία—</quote> occurs in <title>Rhes.</title> 226 <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄπολλον, ὦ δία κεφαλά</quote>.]</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δίας_Ἀθάνας_771_2"> be genuine, then corruption may lurk in </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεύτερον_771"> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> the poet may have written <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶτα δ’ ἀντίον</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_Ἀργείων_774">: a somewhat unusual phrase, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς ἄλλοις Ἀργείοις</quote>, or <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς ἄλλοις τῶν Ἀργείων</quote>. The dat. with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέλας_774"> is rare, but cp. <ref n="Pind. O. 7"> Pind. <title>O.</title> 7. 18</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀσίας..νᾶσον πέλας | ἐμβόλῳ ναίοντας</quote>: <title>Suppl.</title> 208 <quote xml:lang="grc">θέλοιμ’ ἂν ἤδη σοὶ πέλας θρόνους ἔχειν</quote>. Aesch. fr. 102 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφωτίδες τοι τοῖς ἐνωτίοις πέλας</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καθ_ἡμᾶς_774">, ‘over against’ the place in the line of battle where Ajax is stationed. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 7. 1">Xen. <title> Cyr.</title> 7. 1</ref>§ 16 (with ref. to an army arrayed for battle) <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ μὲν καθ’ ἡμᾶς ἔμοιγε δοκεῖ..καλῶς ἔχειν· ἀλλὰ τὰ πλάγια</quote> (the flanks) <quote xml:lang="grc">λυπεῖ με</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔποτ_μάχη_774">. The only natural sense of these words is, ‘battle will never <emph>break forth.</emph>’ This may mean, ‘the enemy will never be able to break forth (like a torrent bursting through a barrier), and carry confusion into our ranks.’ Ajax will suffice to stem the <*>de.—The words could not mean, ‘the battle (on our side) will never break up.’ For the verb, cp. <title> Meteor.</title> 2. 8 (p. 366 <emph>b</emph> 32) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκρήξας εἰς τὸν ὑπὲρ γῆς τόπον φανερῶς ὥσπερ ἐκνεφίας ἐξῆλθεν ὁ κινήσας ἄνεμος</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιοῖσδέ_τοι_776">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 984"> <title>El.</title> 984</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιαῦτά τοι νὼ πᾶς τις ἐξερεῖ βροτῶν</quote>: fr. 25 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιαῦτά τοί σοι..λέγω</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 903">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 903</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιοῖσδέ τοί νιν ἀξιῶ προσφθέγμασιν</quote>. With the </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_776"> of the MSS., <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιοῖσδε</quote> would be predicative (‘such were the words by which..’). But </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοι_776"> suits the final comment.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀστεργῆ_776">, pass., ‘not to be desired,’ as in <ref n="Soph. OT 228"> <title>O. T.</title> 228</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πείσεται γὰρ ἄλλο μὲν | ἀστεργὲς οὐδέν</quote> (the only other place where it occurs). The mildness of the word gives it a peculiar force: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 745"> <title>Tr.</title> 745</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄζηλον..ἔργον.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτήσατ_ὀργήν_776">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1003"> <title>El.</title> 1003</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακὰ | κτησώμεθ’</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Trach. 793"> <title>Tr.</title> 793</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κατακτήσαιτο λυμαντὴν βίου</quote>: fr. 101. 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔκλειαν ἂν κτήσαιτο μᾶλλον ἢ ψόγον.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_φρονῶν_776">: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 768"> <title>Ant.</title> 768</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φρονείτω μεῖζον ἢ κατ’ ἄνδρ’ ἰών</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔστι_778">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ζῇ</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 783">cp. 783</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 422."> <title>Ph.</title> 422.</ref>— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοῦ_σωτήριοι_778">: the <emph>dat.</emph> of the person is usual with <quote xml:lang="grc">σωτήριος</quote>: but cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1156"> Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1156</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γάμοι..ὀλέθριοι φίλων</quote>: <ref n="Hdt. 2. 74"> Her. 2. 74</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνθρώπων..δηλήμονες.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_θεῷ_778">, qualifying the augury: cp. <ref n="Eur. Med. 915">Eur. <title>Med.</title> 915</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλὴν ἔθηκε σὺν θεοῖς προμηθίαν</quote>: <ref n="Aristoph. Pl. 114">Ar. <title>Pl.</title> 114</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξὺν θεῷ δ’ εἰρήσεται</quote>. <ref n="Soph. OT 145"> Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 145</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐτυχεῖς | σὺν τῷ θεῷ φανούμεθ’</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν Ἀπόλλωνι</quote> ). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_Τεῦκρος_780">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 371"> <title>Ph.</title> 371</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δ’ εἶπ’ Ὀδυσσεύς</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐθὺς_ἕδρας_780">, immediately on rising from his seat beside Calchas (750 n.). No sooner had Calchas finished, than Teucer rose, and sent the messenger, who was close by,—sitting among the <quote xml:lang="grc">λαοί</quote>. (Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.96"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 96</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λαῶν ἱζόντων</quote>,—in the agora.) Some take <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐθὺς ἐξ ἕδρας</quote> as= ‘immediately, <emph>from</emph> his seat,’—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, without rising (so that he would beckon or call the man to him): cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 19.77"> <title>Il.</title> 19. 77</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόθεν ἐξ ἕδρης, οὐδ’ ἐν μέσσοισιν ἀναστάς</quote>: <ref n="Hom. Od. 13.56"> <title>Od.</title> 13. 56</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔσπεισαν</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόθεν ἐξ ἑδρέων</quote>, ‘even there as they sat.’ But in those phrases <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόθεν</quote> helps to fix the sense: whereas <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</quote> following </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐθὺς_780"> regularly denotes the point from which the further action sets out (<quote xml:lang="grc">εὐθὺς ἐξ ἀρχῆς, εὐθὺς ἐκ νέου</quote>, etc.). Hence <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐθὺς ἐξ ἕδρας</quote> <emph> ought</emph> to mean, ‘immediately <emph>after</emph> sitting.’— Other explanations of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἕδρας</quote> are: (1) ‘from where I (the messenger) sat.’ (2) ‘After the sitting of the council.’ But Teucer would not wait for that. (3) ‘Leaving the council’ (or strictly, its neighbourhood, since Calchas had come apart from it, Od. 750). This would imply that Teucer had been included in the <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύνεδρος κύκλος</quote>: but the tone used towards him by Menelaüs (1120 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ τοξότης</quote>) and Agamemnon (1235 <quote xml:lang="grc">δούλων</quote>) makes this very unlikely.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπιστολὰς_781">: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 493"> <title>Tr.</title> 493</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φυλάσσειν_781">, (these mandates) for you to observe; cp. <title>Suppl.</title> 179 <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰνῶ φυλάξαι τἄμ’ ἔπη δελτουμένας</quote>: and for the epexegetic inf., <ref n="Soph. OC 231"> <title>O. C.</title> 231</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόνον.. ἀντιδίδωσιν ἔχειν.—φυλάσσειν</quote> should not be taken as governing <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴαντα</quote> understood.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπεστερήμεθα_781">: ‘deprived’ (of the power to obey the command); hence, ‘frustrated.’ Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 769"> <title>O. T.</title> 769</ref> ff., where Iocasta says, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀξία δέ που μαθεῖν | κἀγὼ κ.τ.λ.</quote>, and Oed. replies, <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐ μὴ στερηθῇς</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ μαθεῖν</quote> ). <ref n="Eur. Andr. 913">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 913</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἄκτεινας, ἤ τις συμφορά σ’ ἀφείλετο;</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ κτεῖναι</quote>,— ‘prevented’ or ‘baffled’ thee).—Wakefield's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφυστερήμεθα_781"> is a perf. pass. which nowhere occurs: a better conjecture is Badham's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_ὑστερήσαμεν_781">: but the text appears sound. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δαΐα_784">, pass., ‘afflicted’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">δαίω</quote>, to burn), as in <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 280">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 280</ref>, etc. For the act. sense, ‘hostile,’ which is more frequent, see above, <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 365.">Aesch. Pers. 365.</ref>The epic form <quote xml:lang="grc">δήϊος</quote> (which never means ‘wretched’) is foreign to Tragedy, which, however, admits <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀδῃος</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 1533">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1533</ref>) and <quote xml:lang="grc">δῃοῦν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1319).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γένος_784">, ‘being,’ ‘creature,’ an epic use: <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.538"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 538</ref>(Artemis) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ δὲ χολωσα‐</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">μένη δῖον γένος ἰοχέαιρα</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 6. 180 (the Chimaera) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ δ’ ἄρ’ ἔην θεῖον γένος οὐδ’ ἀνθρώπων.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θροεῖ_784">: 67 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυρεῖ_χρῷ_786">. The metaphor from close shaving ( <ref n="Hdt. 4. 175"> Her. 4. 175</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κείροντες ἐν χροΐ</quote>) means that the moment is critical: <quote xml:lang="grc">παροιμία ἐπὶ τῶν ἐπικινδύνων πραγμάτων</quote>. The razor grazes the surface of the flesh. Itwould convey a different notion if we said, ‘the knife cuts to the quick.’ (The Lat. <emph>tondere ad vivam cutem</emph> is used of ‘fleecing’ a person in Plaut. <ref n="Pl. Bac. 2.3"> <title>Bacch.</title> 2. 3. 8.</ref>) Thus the different image in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 996"> <title>Ant.</title> 996</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ ξυροῦ τύχης</quote>, is yet kindred in purport. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνχρῷ_786">, cp. Lucian <title>Adv. Indoct.</title> 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἐν χρῷ πρὸς τὰ βιβλία συνουσίας</quote>.—The dat. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρῷ_786"> occurs only in this phrase. Sophocles has <quote xml:lang="grc">χρωτί</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 246"> <title>Ant.</title> 246</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 767"> <title>Tr.</title> 767</ref>, and the Ion. <quote xml:lang="grc"> χροΐ</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 605."> <title>Tr.</title> 605.</ref>Cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">γέλῳ</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 18.100"> <title>Od.</title> 18. 100</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρῳ</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 212), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱδρῷ</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.385"> <title>Il.</title> 17. 385</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">φῷ</quote> (‘light,’ Eur. fr. 534).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_τινά_786">: inf. of result, without <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστε</quote>: 822: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 63"> <title>Ant.</title> 63</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρχόμεσθ’ ἐκ κρεισσόνων</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ταῦτ’ ἀκούειν κ.τ.λ.</quote> (n.).</gloss>
