<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτρύτων_786">: <ref n="Pind. P. 4">Pind. <title> P.</title> 4. 178</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄτρυτον πόνον</quote>: Moschus 4. 69 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτρύτ <*>τιν | ἄλγεσι μοχθίζουσαν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρᾶξιν_790">, ‘fortune,’ ‘plight,’ the usual sense of the sing. in Sophocles ( <ref n="Soph. OC 560"> <title>O. C.</title> 560</ref> n.). The word is somewhat strange, since the message announces nothing new which has befallen Ajax, but merely points to an imminent crisis in his fate. This is the true recommendation of the conjecture </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάξιν_790">,—not the fact that <quote xml:lang="grc">πρᾶξιν</quote> recurs in 792. But </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρων_πρᾶξιν_790"> may be a reminiscence of <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 248"> <title>Pers.</title> 248</ref>(a play of which there are several echoes in the <title>Ajax</title>): <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ φέρει</quote> (‘announces’) <quote xml:lang="grc">σαφές τι πρᾶγος ἐσθλὸν ἢ κακὸν κλύειν.— <emph>ἤλγησ’</emph> </quote>: for the aor. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 693">cp. 693</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνθρωπε_791">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1154">cp. 1154</ref>. These seem to be the only examples of this voc. in Tragedy, as Elmsley observed. If we add <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ, <emph>ὤνθρωπε</emph> </quote> is the correct form (by the rule that, in crasis, the accent of the second word is kept: cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠγαθέ</quote>). But the absence of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ</quote> makes the voc. a little less familiar and colloquial. In 1154, on the other hand, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤνθρωπε</quote> is suitable.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀλώλαμεν_791">: like Deianeira's <quote xml:lang="grc">σεσώσμεθα</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Trach. 83"> <title>Tr.</title> 83</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Αἴαντος_792"> is governed by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέρι_792">; but, coming immediately after <quote xml:lang="grc">πρᾶξιν</quote>, it would necessarily strike the ear as if opposed to <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν σήν</quote>: ‘I do not know thy plight, but (I do know) that of Ajax,— viz., that, if he is abroad, I fear for him.’ It would not be well, however, to omit the comma after <quote xml:lang="grc">πρᾶξιν</quote>, and so bind it strictly to <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴαντος</quote>. That slight pause helps to prepare the ear for the coming construction with <quote xml:lang="grc">πέρι</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_794"> in assent: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 556"> <title>El.</title> 556</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μὴν ἐφίημ’</quote>. The conjectural insertion of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γ_794"> after </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θυραῖος_794"> is plausible (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 531">cp. 531</ref> n.), but needless.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠδίνειν_φής_794">: <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 644">Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 644</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάλαι γὰρ ὠδίνουσα τῶν ἀφιγμένων | ψυχὴν ἐτήκου νόστος εἰ γενήσεται</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴργειν_795">: 753 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξεφίεται_795">: the only instance of this compound, except <title>I. T.</title> 1468, where <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐξεφίεμαι</quote> has a like sense. But <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξαφιέναι</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Trach. 72"> <title>Tr.</title> 72</ref>) was current in prose. Cp. the unique <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξαπείδομεν</quote> in <ref n="Soph. OC 1648."> <title>O. C.</title> 1648.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκηνῆς_ὕπαυλον_795">: <ref n="Eur. El. 1386"> <title>El.</title> 1386</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δωμάτων ὑπόστεγοι</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀπὶ_τῷ_797">: ‘by reason of what?’ Here <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπί</quote> with dat. denotes cause or occasion (rather than aim, ‘with a view to what?’). Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 333"> <title>El.</title> 333</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλγῶ )πὶ τοῖς παροῦσιν</quote> (and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1230): <ref n="Soph. Phil. 174"> <title>Ph.</title> 174</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"><*>λύει δ’ ἐπὶ παντί τῳ | χρείας ἱσταμένῳ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τήνδε_φέρειν_798">. There is strong reason to think that <quote xml:lang="grc">φέρειν</quote> is genuine, and has the sense of ‘<emph>tending</emph> towards.’ For (1) Sophocles has thus used <quote xml:lang="grc">φέρω</quote> in <ref n="Soph. OT 517"> <title>O. T.</title> 517</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς βλάβην φέρον</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 519 f. <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ εἰς ἁπλοῦν | ἡ ζημία μοι τοῦ λόγου τούτου φέρει</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 991 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς φόβον φέρον</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hdt. 1. 10"> Her. 1. 10</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς αἰσχύνην φέρει</quote>. (2) This sense precisely suits the context here, where the apprehension is <emph> vague</emph>; Calchas had not said <emph>how</emph> the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξοδος</quote> was to be fatal, but merely that it was to be prevented, on pain of never again seeing Ajax alive. But <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλεθρίαν..φέρειν</quote> could not mean, ‘is of fatal tendency.’ Such a fusion of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλεθρίαν εἶναι</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">φέρειν εἰς ὄλεθρον</quote> is impossible.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλπίζειν_φέρει_798"> (‘Teucer announces that he forebodes,’ etc.) strains both verbs. Enger's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλπίζει_κυρεῖν_798"> is somewhat tame, and does not seem very probable.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀλεθρίαν_Αἴαντος_798"> have come from </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Αἴαντος_ὄλεθρον_798">? Easily, doubtless, if <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς</quote> had been lost after <quote xml:lang="grc"> ‐ος</quote>. I incline to this solution. <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴαντος εἰς ὄλεθρον</quote> is not only intrinsically better, but also slightly more probable, than <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄλεθρον εἰς Αἴαντος</quote> (the reading of Blaydes in his text), since then <quote xml:lang="grc"> εἰς</quote> follows <quote xml:lang="grc">‐ον</quote>, and its unusual position would also tend to prevent its being overlooked. But the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς</quote> after its case is no objection, since <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴαντος</quote> is an attributive gen. : see <ref n="Soph. OT 178"> <title>O. T.</title> 178</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_μάντεως_801">: <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.69"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 69</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Κάλχας Θεστορίδης, οἰωνοπόλων ὄχ’</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄριστος</quote>. Cp. above, <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.134"> Il. 134</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">Τελαμώνιε παῖ</quote>: and n. on <ref n="Soph. OT 267."> <title>O. T.</title> 267.</ref>According to one legend, Thestor was the son of Idmon (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἴδμων</quote>), the seer who accompanied the Argonauts, and whose father was Apollo (schol. Apoll. Rhod. 1. 139). The name <quote xml:lang="grc">Θές‐τωρ</quote> is from the root <quote xml:lang="grc">θες</quote>, ‘desire,’ ‘pray,’ whence <quote xml:lang="grc">θεσσάμενος</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc"> αἰτησάμενος</quote>, Archil. fr. 11, etc.), <quote xml:lang="grc"> πολύθεστος</quote> ‘much besought’ (Curt. <title>Etym.</title> vol. II. p. 137): meaning, ‘one who prays to the gods.’ <quote xml:lang="grc"> Κάλχας</quote> is prob. from <quote xml:lang="grc">καλχαίνω</quote>, one who ‘darkly broods’ on futurity ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 20"> <title>Ant.</title> 20</ref> n.).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτ_φέρει_801">. The traditional </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτ_801"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτε</quote>) seems right. Tecmessa has already heard that the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξοδος</quote> is perilous. The new fact which she is now to learn is that ‘<emph>this day</emph>’ must decide the fate of Ajax. If, however, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτ_801_2"> be changed to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_801">, then this new fact will not be told, unless the words <quote xml:lang="grc">καθ’ ἡμέραν τὴν νῦν</quote> be taken with what follows (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς..φέρει</quote>). But they go more naturally with what precedes them (<quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ..μάντεως</quote> , <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">μαθών</quote> ).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρει_801"> be sound, the subject to it is <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ἔξοδος</quote> (798). There is nothing harsh in this, since the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξοδος</quote> is the matter uppermost in the minds of the speakers. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρει_βίον_801"> then means, ‘is <emph>fraught with</emph> death or life’: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 109"> <title>Ph.</title> 109</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ τὸ σωθῆναί γε τὸ ψεῦδος φέρει</quote>: <ref n="Soph. El. 84"> <title>El.</title> 84</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα γὰρ φέρει | νίκην</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1042 <quote xml:lang="grc">χἡ δίκη βλάβην φέρει</quote>. The subject to <quote xml:lang="grc">φέρει</quote> is certainly not <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμέρα ἡ νῦν</quote>. If Calchas were subject to <quote xml:lang="grc">φέρει</quote>, the verb would mean <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγγέλλει</quote>: but, for this sense, the subject must be the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγγελος</quote> himself, not the sender. There is no parallel for <quote xml:lang="grc"> φέρει</quote> as=merely ‘<emph>portends.</emph>’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θροεῖ_801">, compare <ref n="Soph. OC 1425"> <title>O. C.</title> 1425</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ τοῦδε</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">μαντεύμαθ’, ὃς σφῷν θάνατον ἐξ ἀμφοῖν θροεῖ</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἲ_γώ_803">: rare in Tragedy: in <ref n="Eur. El. 674"> <title>El.</title> 674</ref>, <ref n="Eur. El. 1115"> El. 1115</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τάλαινα</quote> is added: but cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1274">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 1274</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἲ )γώ, τί λέξεις;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόστητ_803">, place yourselves (as it were) <emph>in front of</emph> it, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘interpose between it and me,’ ‘defend me from it.’ Cp. <ref n="Hdt. 9. 107"> Her. 9. 107</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δορυφόροι οἱ Μασιστέω προέστησαν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοῦ</quote>). For the usage of <quote xml:lang="grc">προστῆναι</quote>, see on <ref n="Eur. El. 980."> <title>El.</title> 980.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀναγκαίας_τύχης_803">, the fortune impending over Tecmessa from that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάγκη</quote>, or destiny, which Calchas has expounded. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 485">Cp. 485</ref>.—Not, ‘avert the fatal chance’ which threatens Ajax (as if they were to place themselves between <emph>him</emph> and the <quote xml:lang="grc">τύχη</quote> ). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_μὲν_804">, the messenger, and the <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσπολοι</quote> of Ajax, who are to hasten to the camp: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_δέ_804">, the two divisions of the Chorus, who are to search the coast.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Τεῦκρον_μολεῖν_804">, depending on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σπεύσατε_804">: cp. <ref n="Hdt. 1. 74"> Her. 1. 74</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔσπευσαν... εἰρήνην ἑωυτοῖσι γενέσθαι</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑσπέρους_ἀντηλίους_804">. So in <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1258">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1258</ref> ff. the Chorus is divided into two <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμιχόρια</quote>, which, by Electra's direction, guard respectively the east and the west side of the palace at Mycenae:—<quote xml:lang="grc">ΗΜ. χωρεῖτ’, ἐπειγώμεσθ)· ἐγὼ μὲν οὖν τρίβον | τόνδ’ ἐκφυλάξω, τὸν πρὸς ἡλίου βολάς</quote>. | <quote xml:lang="grc">ΗΜ. καὶ μὲν ἐγὼ τόνδ’, ὃς πρὸς ἑσπέραν φέρει</quote>. There, the ‘eastward path’ is the <quote xml:lang="grc">πάροδος</quote> on the spectator's left; the ‘westward,’ that on his right. In the <title> Orestes</title>, however, the hemichoria do not leave the orchestra. The Ionic form <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντήλιος</quote> was used in Tragedy: so <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπηλιώτης</quote>, even in Attic prose. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνθήλιος</quote> occurs first in the comic poet Theopompus (<foreign xml:lang="lat">circ.</foreign> 390 B.C.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγκῶνας_804">, the bends or bays of the coast, as in <ref n="Hdt. 2. 99"> Her. 2. 99</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγκών</quote> is a bend of the Nile. The acc. depends on <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰόντες</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OT 637"> <title>O. T.</title> 637</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εἶ σύ τ’ οἴκους</quote>).— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζητεῖτ_804">, a new finite verb, instead of an inf. <quote xml:lang="grc">ζητεῖν</quote>, parallel with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μολεῖν_804">. This is a tendency of Greek idiom: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 216"> <title>Ph.</title> 216</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">βοᾷ</quote>), <ref n="Soph. OC 351"> <title>O. C.</title> 351</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγεῖται</quote> ), <ref n="Soph. Trach. 267"> <title>Tr.</title> 267</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">φωνεῖ</quote>), <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 677 (<quote xml:lang="grc">φθίνει</quote> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φωτὸς_ἠπατημένη_807">, deceived by him: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">καταφρονήσας ἠπάτησέ με</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 497">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 497</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πληγεὶς θυγατρός</quote>. Others understand, ‘deceived <emph>concerning</emph> (or <emph>in</emph>) him’: but the genitive will hardly yield that sense.—She refers esp. to his words in 684—692.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χάριτος_807">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 201">cp. 212</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">στέρξας ἀνέχει</quote>), and her words in 520 ff.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκβεβλημένη_807">: for the assonance (after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠπατημένη</quote>) with the end of the last v., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1085">cp. 1085</ref> f.: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 121"> <title>Ph.</title> 121</ref> f.: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1265"> <title>Tr.</title> 1265</ref> f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_τέκνον_809">; She shrinks from leaving the child, but decides that she must, and leaves him at the tent (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 985">cp. 985</ref>), where she rejoins him after v. 973.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅποιπερ_σθένω_809">. These words, implying that she has no strenght to go far, are significant, because she is to find the body of Ajax near the tent (891), while the Chorus have been vainly seeking him further off. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγκονῶμεν_811">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 988">cp. 988</ref> : <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1255"> <title>Tr.</title> 1255</ref>(n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐχ_ἀκμὴ_811">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 22"> <title>El.</title> 22</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔργων ἀκμή</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Phil. 12"> <title>Ph.</title> 12</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκμὴ γὰρ οὐ μακρῶν ἡμῖν λόγων</quote>. Verse 812 seems genuine. The fear which had haunted Tecmessa from the moment when Ajax regained his sanity (326), and which his words had lulled, has been revived by the message of Calchas. The definite expression of that fear, by <quote xml:lang="grc">σπεύδῃ θανεῖν</quote>, is a fitting close to this scene, and prepares for the next.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_811"> after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρα_811"> emphasises, not that word, but the whole clause, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρα ὃς σπεύδῃ θανεῖν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 213"> <title>Ant.</title> 213</ref> f., <ref n="Soph. Ant. 648"> Ant. 648</ref> f.: <ref n="Soph. El. 1506"> <title>El.</title> 1506</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OC 1278."> <title>O. C.</title> 1278.</ref>It contrasts <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἕδρας</quote> with <emph>his</emph> <quote xml:lang="grc">σπουδή</quote>. (2) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σπεύδῃ_811"> is the original reading to which L's points (cr. n.). It generalises the statement. (3) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θέλοντας_811">, which was written by the first hand in L, is in its turn supported by <quote xml:lang="grc">σπεύδῃ</quote> as against </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θέλοντες_811">: for, if the sentiment is general, it will depend on <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ἕδρας ἀκμή</quote> more fitly than on <quote xml:lang="grc">χωρῶμεν</quote>. In this case, the acc. <quote xml:lang="grc">θέλοντας</quote> depends on <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ἕδρας ἀκμή</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ἱδρυτέον</quote>, a constr. quite possible for poetry: cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 479"> <title>El.</title> 479</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕπεστί μοι θράσος..κλύουσαν</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕτοιμος_813">, without the verb <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰμί</quote>, as in <ref n="Soph. OT 92"> <title>O. T.</title> 92</ref>: <ref n="Eur. El. 796">Eur. <title> El.</title> 796</ref>: <ref n="Dem. 9.4">Dem. or. 9 § 4</ref>: <title> Polit.</title> 277 E, and often.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔργου_813">, the usual antithesis to <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγῳ</quote>, is defined by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποδῶν_813">.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_σφαγεὺς_813"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> is delayed: it is given by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_τῶνδε_813"> in 823. Meanwhile, the reasons why the weapon should prove deadly have been developed in three clauses (<quote xml:lang="grc">δῶρον μὲν— πέπηγε δ)—ἔπηξα δ’</quote>). Hence <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ μὲν σφαγεὺς κ.τ.λ.</quote> is resumed in 823 by <quote xml:lang="grc">οὕτω μὲν εὐσκευοῦμεν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σφαγεὺς_813"> here is simply ‘the slayer.’ In <ref n="Eur. Andr. 1134">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 1134</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σφαγῆς</quote> are sacrificial knives.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τομώτατος_813">: Plat. <title>Tim.</title>p. 61 E <quote xml:lang="grc">σφοδρὸν ὂν καὶ τομόν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴ_σχολή_816">: lit., ‘if one has leisure <emph>e)en</emph> to reason about it,’—when it is <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔργου ἀκμή</quote>. He is not, indeed, hurried now: he has secured solitude. But in a man like Ajax, who has a deed to do, any words that delay it move a kind of scorn, which gleams through his phrase here: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 852">cp. 852</ref> f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δῶρον_μὲν_817"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The sword should do its work well, because (1) it is the gift of a foe, (2) it is fixed in hostile soil, and (3) Ajax has planted it with care.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνδρὸς_817">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 45"> <title>El.</title> 45</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρὸς Φανοτέως</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξένων_817">, because the sword itself had been a <quote xml:lang="grc">ξένιον</quote> (661 n.). He means: ‘No one ever had such cause to rue the relationship of <quote xml:lang="grc">ξενία</quote> as I in the case of Hector—a foe whom I had hated; for his gift has been my bane.’ See his words in 661—663. The point is missed if <quote xml:lang="grc">ξένων</quote> is taken as merely=<quote xml:lang="grc">βαρβάρων</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολεμίᾳ_819">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 459">cp. 459</ref>: the soil itself is his enemy.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σιδηροβρῶτι_819">: the word occurs only here.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θηγάνῃ_819">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκόνῃ</quote>, Aeschylean ( <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1536"> <title>Ag.</title> 1536</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νεηκονής_819">, not <quote xml:lang="grc"> νεακονής</quote>, is now read here by all edd.: cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">νεηκής</quote> (Hom. ), <quote xml:lang="grc"> νεηλιφής</quote> (Arist. ). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περιστείλας_821"> denotes merely the careful handling which he gave to it when fixing it in the ground.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανεῖν_821">, ‘so that I should die’: its <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔνοια</quote> will appear in his <emph>speedy</emph> death. For the inf. of result, without <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστε</quote> , <ref n="Soph. Aj. 786">cp. 786</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εύσχευοῦμεν_823">: ‘I am well equipped’: the preparations are complete. The verb occurs nowhere else; nor is <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔσκευος</quote> found.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_τῶνδε_823">, in the next place: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 537">cp. 537</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ζεῦ_823">. He invokes (1) <title>Zeus</title>, to apprise Teucer: (2) <title>Hermes</title>, to be his guide to the shades: (3) the <title>Erinyes</title>, to avenge him: (4) <title>Helios</title>, to give tidings at Salamis: (5) <title>Thanatos</title>, to bring the end.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_εἰκός_823">: since Zeus is the ancestor of the Aeacidae (387).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰτήσομαι_823">: for the fut., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 681">cp. 681</ref> n. The verb takes a double acc., and </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαχεῖν_823"> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτό</quote>) is epexegetic inf.: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1255"> <title>O. T.</title> 1255</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοιτᾷ γὰρ ἡμᾶς ἔγχος ἐξαιτῶν πορεῖν</quote> (‘that we should give it’): <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1098"> <title>Ant.</title> 1098</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐβουλίας δεῖ..λαβεῖν. </quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μακρὸν_823">=<quote xml:lang="grc">μέγα</quote> (130 n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμῖν_826">, ethic dat. (‘I pray thee’), with imperat. ( <ref n="Soph. OC 1475"> <title>O. C.</title> 1475</ref>).— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄγγελον_826">: the fulfilment of this prayer is related in vv. 998 f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαστάσῃ_827">, take in the hands, ‘lift’ (920). Cp. <ref n="Eur. Alc. 724">Eur. <title>Alc.</title> 724</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βαστάζων νεκρόν</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκφέρων</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 43">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 43</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεκρὸν..κουφιεῖς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεπτῶτα_ξίφει_827">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 899">cp. 899</ref>, 907: II. <ref n="Hom. Od. 2.424"> <title>Od.</title> 424</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποθνῄσκων περὶ φασγάνῳ</quote>: <ref n="Hom. Il. 13.570"> <title>Il.</title> 13. 570</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">περὶ δουρὶ | ἤσπαιῤ</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 8. 86 <quote xml:lang="grc">κυλινδόμενος περὶ χαλκῷ</quote> (said of a wounded horse, ‘writhing about’ the barb of an arrow): <foreign xml:lang="lat"> ib.</foreign> 23. 30 (<quote xml:lang="grc">βόες</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφὶ σιδήρῳ | σφαζόμενοι</quote>. <ref target="cl899">See on 899</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόβλητος_830"> goes closely with the datives: <ref n="Hdt. 9. 112"> Her. 9. 112</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς μαζοὺς κυσὶ προέβαλε</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hor. Epod. 6. 10">Hor. <title>Epod.</title> 6. 10</ref> <emph>proiectum odoraris cibum.</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕλωρ_830">, an epic word, once used (in the plur.) by Aesch. , <title>Suppl.</title> 800 <quote xml:lang="grc">κυσὶν δ’ ἔπειθ’ ἕλωρα κἀπιχωρίοις | ὄρνισι δεῖπνον οὐκ ἀναίνομαὶ πέλειν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.4"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 4</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοὺς δὲ ἑλώρια τεῦχε κύνεσσιν | οἰωνοῖσί τε πᾶσι</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοσαῦτά_προστρέπω_831">: the constr. is the same in <ref n="Soph. OC 50"> <title>O. C.</title> 50</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">μή μ’ ἀτιμάσῃς</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν σε προστρέπω φράσαι</quote>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc">τούτων ἅ</quote>, and the inf. is epexegetic. The midd. <quote xml:lang="grc">προστρέπομαι</quote> is ordinarily used for this sense, as in fr. 760. 3: but the act. occurs also in <title>Suppl.</title> 1195, <quote xml:lang="grc">κακῶς ὀλέσθαι πρόστρεπ’ Ἀργείων χθόνα</quote> (‘pray that..’).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλῶ_δ_831"> seems better than </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλῶ_θ_831">, in turning to a new invocation.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πομπαῖον_831"> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ψυχοπομπόν</quote>) is defined by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χθόνιον_831">, just as in <ref n="Soph. OC 1548"> <title>O. C.</title> 1548</ref> the context defines a like epithet,—<quote xml:lang="grc">Ἑρμῆς ὁ πομπὸς ἥ τε νερτέρα θεός</quote>. See n. there, and on <ref n="Soph. Phil. 133"> <title>Ph.</title> 133</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">Ἑρμῆς ὁ πέμπων</quote> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀσφαδάστῳ_833">, ‘without convulsion.’ <quote xml:lang="grc">σφαδάζω</quote> is from rt. <quote xml:lang="grc"> σφαδ</quote>, denoting sudden, violent movement: whence <quote xml:lang="grc">σφεδανός, σφοδρός, σφενδόνη</quote> (a sling): Curt. <title> Etym.</title> § 296. The verb was often used with ref. to a convulsive <emph> death-</emph> struggle; Eur. fr. 1020 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δ’ ἐσφάδαζεν, οὐκ ἔχων ἀπαλλαγάς</quote>: <title>Anton.</title> 76 <quote xml:lang="grc">σφαδάζοντος</quote> (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc"> δυσθανατῶν</quote> <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign>). <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1292">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1292</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεύχομαι δὲ καιρίας πληγῆς τυχεῖν</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἀσφάδαστος, αἱμάτων εὐθνησίμων | ἀπορρυέντων, ὄμμα συμβάλω τόδε</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πηδήματι_833">, the act of throwing himself upon the sword; <title>Helen.</title> 96 (of Ajax) <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκεῖον αὐτὸν ὤλεσ’ ἅλμ’ επὶξίφος</quote>. This swift act, followed by no <quote xml:lang="grc">σφαδασμός</quote>, is to be the means (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξὺν_833">) by which Hermes is to lay him to rest. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλευρὰν_διαρρήξαντα_834">. Acc. to the legend followed by Aeschylus in his <quote xml:lang="grc">Θρῇσσαι</quote> (fr. 83), Ajax was invulnerable, except in one spot; when he sought to fall on his sword, it bent ‘like a bow,’— until a <quote xml:lang="grc"> δαίμων</quote> showed him the fatal place. See Introduction, § 4. The schol. here fancies that Sophocles used <quote xml:lang="grc">πλευρὰν</quote> with a purposed vagueness,—wishing neither to imitate nor to contradict his predecessor. Rather Sophocles, like the <title>Iliad</title>, ignores altogether the legend which Aeschylus used. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰς_παρθένους_835">: ‘the maidens who live for ever, and who ever behold,’ etc.: <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς ἀεὶ</quote> =<quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς ἀεὶ οὔσας</quote>. For <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ ἀεὶ</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc"><*> ἀεὶ ὤν</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1700"> <title>O. C.</title> 1700</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἀεὶ‐ κατὰ | γᾶς σκότον εἱμένος</quote>. For <quote xml:lang="grc">παρθένους</quote> , <ref n="Soph. OC 127"> <title>O. Pers. 1041">Aesch. <title> Pers.</title> 1041</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δόσιν κακὰν κακῶν κακοῖς</quote>. The dialogue in 866—878 is conducted by the two leaders of hemichoria. When Sophocles raised the number of the tragic Chorus from twelve to fifteen, his object was to provide a coryphaeus (distinct from the ordinary choreutae), and two subordinate leaders. The technical name for these leaders of hemichoria was <quote xml:lang="grc">παραστάται</quote>, because they stood one on each side of the coryphaeus when the Chorus was drawn up in ranks (<quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ ζυγά</quote>). </gloss>

The conjecture <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐστίβευται</quote> rests on the fact that <quote xml:lang="grc">στιβεύω</quote> occurs in later, though not in classical, Greek. But as Lycophron (121) used <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀστίβητος</quote>, he either knew <quote xml:lang="grc">στιβέω</quote>, or thought it a possible form. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχεις_οὖν_875">; Euripides has a similar phrase in <title>Suppl.</title> 818 (Adrastus) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχεις ἔχεις</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ τέκνα</quote>)—<quote xml:lang="grc">ΧΟ. πημάτων γ’ ἅλις βάρος</quote>. Cp. also <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 683"> <title>Cycl.</title> 683</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΧΟ... ἔχεις;</quote> (‘hast thou caught them?’) <quote xml:lang="grc">ΚΥ. κακόν γε πρὸς κακῷ</quote>. For a like coincidence, see 591 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοὐδὲν_πλέον_876">, lit., ‘and nothing more in respect to seeing,’ —<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, to descrying the object of our search. For this sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 706"> <title>O. T.</title> 706</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_δὴ_877">, in rejecting an alternative: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1128"> <title>Tr.</title> 1128</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 913."> <title>El.</title> 913.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὴν_βολῶν_877">: so <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1258">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1258</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ μὲν οὖν τρίβον | τόνδ’ ἐκφυλάξω, τὸν πρὸς ἡλίου βολάς. βολαί</quote>, like <emph>ictus</emph> ( <title>C.</title> 2. 15. 10),=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκτῖνες</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Ba. 14"> Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 14</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡλιοβλήτους πλάκας.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δηλοῖ_877">=<quote xml:lang="grc">δῆλός ἐστι</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Aj. 471">cp. 471</ref> n. ‘He is not found to have appeared anywhere <emph>along the path</emph> from the east.’ The acc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κέλευθον_877"> denotes the ground which the searchers have traversed: the phrase is a terse equivalent for <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδαμοῦ δηλοῖ φανεὶς τοῖς τὴν..κέλευθον ἐλθοῦσιν</quote>. There is no real resemblance to <ref n="Eur. El. 1273"> <title>El.</title> 1273</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φιλτάταν | ὁδὸν ἐπαξιώσας ὧδέ μοι φανῆναι</quote>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁδὸν</quote> is cognate acc. to <quote xml:lang="grc">φανῆναι</quote> as implying <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλθεῖν</quote> (cp. <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1318 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξήκεις ὁδόν</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_ἂν_879"> with the optat. (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπύοι</quote>, 887) expresses a wish, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1103"> <title>El.</title> 1103</ref> n.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁλιαδᾶν_879">, sons of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅλιοι</quote> (sea-faring men, fishermen); poetical for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁλιέων</quote>, like <quote xml:lang="grc">παῖδες Ἑλλήνων</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 402"> Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 402</ref>). The use of the patronymic in Greek poetry was a free one; thus Pindar can say <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφθίτου Ἐννοσίδα</quote> (Poseidon, <title>P.</title> 4. 33), forming the word from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνοσις</quote>. We might compare <quote xml:lang="grc">τεκτονίδης</quote>, which occurs as a proper name in <ref n="Hom. Od. 8.114."> <title>Od.</title> 8. 114.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχων_ἄγρας_879">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 564">cp. 564</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θήραν ἔχων</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀΰπνους_879">: the <quote xml:lang="grc">υ</quote> is long here, as in <ref n="Soph. OC 685"> <title>O. C.</title> 685</ref>(where <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄϋπνοι</quote> =<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀηδών</quote> in 672), though short in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 848"> <title>Ph.</title> 848</ref>: as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 827"> <title>Ph.</title> 827</ref> the first <quote xml:lang="grc">Υπνε</quote> has <quote xml:lang="grc">υ—</quote>, and the second <quote xml:lang="grc">υ^</quote>. Hermann unnecessarily inserted </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφ_879"> before <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀΰπνους</quote> (taking the <quote xml:lang="grc">υ</quote> as short). The metre is dochmiac: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 926">cp. 926</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_θεᾶν_883"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> ‘Can any Oread of the Mysian Olympus, or any Naiad of the streams that flow into the Hellespont, tell us where he is?’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεᾶν_883"> is understood again with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποταμῶν_883"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">Ὀλυμπιάδες θεαί, ἢ θεαὶ ποταμῶν</quote>): for the adj. co-ordinated with a gen., cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 8">Pind. <title>N.</title> 8. 2</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρθενηΐοις παίδων τ’ ἐφίζοισα γλεφάροις</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Med. 404">Eur. <title>Med.</title> 404</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς Σισυφείοις τοῖς τ’ Ἰάσονος γάμοις</quote>. As to the Mysian Olympus, <ref target="cl720">see on 720</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥυτῶν_883">, a general epithet of sea or river: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1408">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1408</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥυτᾶς ἐξ ἁλός</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 123">Eur. <title> Hipp.</title> 123</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥυτὰν παγάν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Βοσπορίων_883">, of the Hellespont; cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 723">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 723</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τόδ’ ἐξέπραξεν, ὥστε Βόσπορον κλῇσαι μέγαν</quote>; with ref. to the bridges of boats made by order of Xerxes, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ξεῦξις τοῦ Ἑλλησπόντου</quote> ( <ref n="Hdt. 7. 35"> Her. 7. 35</ref>).—The word </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴδρις_883">, added in L and most MSS. after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποταμῶν_883_2">, was an early interpolation, caused by the elliptical construction. The schol. (on 879) read it, and explains <quote xml:lang="grc">ποταμῶν ἴδρις</quote> by <quote xml:lang="grc">Ναΐς</quote>. But the antistr., <ref n="Hdt. 5.930"> Her. v. 930</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">πάννυχα καὶ φαέθοντ’ ἀνεστέναζες</quote>, is clearly sound; though Elmsley suggested that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄναξ</quote> may have dropped out before <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνεστέναζες</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴ_λεύσσων_885">=<quote xml:lang="grc">λεύσσων, εἴ ποθι</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">που</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">λεύσσει</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1204"> <title>Ph.</title> 1204</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξίφος, εἴ ποθεν</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ γένυν, ἢ βελέων τι, προπέμψατε</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ ποθεν προπέμψαι ἔχετε</quote> (n.).—<quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>ἀπύοι</emph>, <foreign xml:lang="meter">‐υ‐</foreign> </quote> : <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 1023">Ar. <title>Eq.</title> 1023</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ μέν εἰμ’ ὁ κύων· πρὸ σοῦ γὰρ ἀπύω</quote>. (Moschus 2. 124 has <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠπύοντες</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">υ—</quote>: elsewhere the pres. has <quote xml:lang="grc">υ^</quote>: the fut. and aor. have <quote xml:lang="grc">υ—</quote>.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σχέτλια_885">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc"> σχέτλιον</quote>: so 1126 <quote xml:lang="grc">δίκαια</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 524"> <title>Ph.</title> 524</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχρά</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Orest. 413">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 413</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινά</quote>: <ref n="Thuc. 5. 14">Thuc. 5. 14</ref>§ 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀδύνατα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_πόνων_885">. The similar phrase in <ref n="Aesch. PB 900">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 900</ref> , <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλατείαις πόνων</quote>, implies the constr. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλᾶσθαι πόνους</quote> (as cogn. acc.); and Sophocles may have had that in mind. But the gen. could also be explained as equiv. to an adj. <quote xml:lang="grc">πολύπονον</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 114">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 114</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λευκῆς χιόνος πτέρυγι</quote> (n.).— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐρίῳ_δρόμῳ_885">, ‘cannot come near him (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ Αἴαντι</quote>), with prospered course.’ Others take <quote xml:lang="grc">δρόμῳ</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">πελάσαι</quote>, ‘<emph>attain to</emph>, obtain, a prosperous course.’ (Cp. <ref n="Pind. O. 1">Pind. <title>O.</title> 1. 78</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κράτει..πέλασον</quote>, ‘bring me to victory.’) Those who read <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐρίων..δρόμων</quote> (cr. n.) explain it in the same way. But this is surely forced. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμενηνὸν_890">, enfeebled in mind by the <quote xml:lang="grc">νόσος</quote>, distempered. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.887"> <title>Il.</title> 5. 887</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤ κε ζὼς ἀμενηνὸς ἔα χαλκοῖο τυπῇσιν</quote> (‘feeble’),—the only instance of the word in the <title>Iliad.</title> In the phrases <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμενηνὰ κάρηνα</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 10.521"> <title>Od.</title> 10. 521</ref>, etc.), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμενηνῶν.. ὀνείρων</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 19. 562), the notion is ‘unsubstantial.’ <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμενηνός</quote> is probably formed from <quote xml:lang="grc">μένος</quote>. (Wecklein suggests that Sophocles here meant by it ‘unstable,’ ‘restless,’ as if it came from <quote xml:lang="grc">μένω</quote>.)— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπου_890">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐστί</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 33">cp. 33</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰώ_μοι_891">. Tecmessa,—who is not seen till v. 894,—is approaching the entrance on the spectator's left, when she descries the body of Ajax lying at the other side of the scene. The underwood amidst which he has fallen screens the sight from the Chorus, until they draw nearer. (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 815">Cp. 815</ref> n.) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίνος_βοὴ_892"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote>: ‘whose cry came from the wood, in the covert near us?’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάραυλος_892">, having an <quote xml:lang="grc"> αὐλή</quote> near at hand; screened from view in the neighbouring covert: <quote xml:lang="grc">τίνος πάραυλος βοή</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc">τίνος παραύλου βοή</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 785"> <title>O. C.</title> 785</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὡς πάραυλον οἰκίσῃς</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">με</quote>), n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰὼ_τλήμων_893">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγώ</quote>, not <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴας</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1102"> <title>Ph.</title> 1102</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ τλάμων τλάμων ἄρ’ ἐγώ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δουρίληπτον_894">: for the Ionic form, cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">δούρειος</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. Tro. 14">Eur. <title> Tro.</title> 14</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">γούνατα</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 1607">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1607</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">μοῦνος, ξεῖνος</quote>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴκτῳ_συγκεκραμένην_894">, steeped in the anguish which the lament expresses; <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1311"> <title>Ant.</title> 1311</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δειλαίᾳ δὲ συγκέκραμαι δύᾳ</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾤχωκα_896"> is now read in <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 13">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 13</ref>, Soph. fr. 220: and in <ref n="Hom. Il. 10.252"> <title>Il.</title> 10. 252</ref>Leaf gives <quote xml:lang="grc"> παρῴχωκεν</quote> (the reading of Aristarchus, acc. to Didymus), instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">παρῴχηκεν</quote>, as there is no good authority for <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾤχηκα</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴχηκα</quote> before Polybius. <quote xml:lang="grc"> οἴχωκα</quote>, the traditional form here, is Ionic ( <ref n="Hdt. 1. 189"> Her. 1. 189</ref>, etc.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διαπεπόρθημαι_896">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1198">cp. 1198</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπερσεν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1104"> <title>Tr.</title> 1104</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκπεπόρθημαι</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_ἔστιν_897">; <ref n="Soph. OT 319"> <title>O. T.</title> 319</ref> n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμῖν_898">, ethic: 216.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρτίως_νεοσφαγὴς_898">: the same phrase occurs in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1130."> <title>Tr.</title> 1130.</ref>Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1283"> <title>Ant.</title> 1283</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">τέθνηκε</quote> ..) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄρτι νεοτόμοισι πλήγμασιν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρυφαίῳ_899">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 658">cp. 658</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρύψω.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φας_899"> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γάνῳ_περιπτυχής_899">, wrapped, as it were, round the sword; cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 8">Pind. <title> N.</title> 8. 23</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">φθόνος</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">Τελαμῶνος δάψεν υἱόν, φασγάνῳ ἀμφικυλίσας</quote>. <ref n="Verg. A. 10. 681">Verg. <title>Aen.</title> 10. 681</ref> <quote xml:lang="lat">An sese mucrone ob tantum dedecus amens | Induat.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὤμοι_900"> with gen.: 908, 980: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 971."> <title>Tr.</title> 971.</ref>If the first thought of the Salaminians is, in Homeric phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤλετο μέν μοι νόστος</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.413"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 413</ref>), this is an indirect tribute to the chief on whom their welfare depended. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὤμοι_τάλας_901">. The text is not certain here; but it seems most probable that v. 901 is sound, and that in the antistr., 947 f., <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄναυδ’ | ἔργ’</quote> should replace <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄναυδον | ἔργον</quote>. The <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ</quote> which the MSS. place before </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάλας_901"> in 902 may well have been an error.—Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 871"> <title>Ant.</title> 871</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανὼν ἔτ’ οὖσαν κατήναρές με</quote>: and <ref n="Soph. El. 808."> <title>El.</title> 808.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_γύναι_903">. We should expect either <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ ταλαῖφρον γύναι</quote>, or <quote xml:lang="grc">ὢ ταλαίφρων γυνή</quote>, exclamatory, like <ref n="Eur. El. 150"> <title>El.</title> 150</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ παντλάμων Νιόβα</quote>. But the reading given above has the best MS. authority, and is tacitly accepted in several recent editions. I retain it, because the words, though addressed to Tecmessa, are in fact rather a comment upon her fate. Hence it is conceivable that the nom. of the adjective, usual in exclamations, should here be combined with a vocative of the person. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἔχοντος_904">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 281">cp. 281</ref> n.: 981: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1179"> <title>Ant.</title> 1179</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ὧδ’ ἐχόντων τἄλλα βουλεύειν πάρα.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰάζειν_904">, with allusion to his name (430 f.): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 914">cp. 914</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> δυσώνυμος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίνος_ἔπραξε_905"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> The antistrophic verse is 951, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγαν ὑπερβριθὲς ἄχθος ἤνυσαν</quote>. I believe that the text is sound here, and that <quote xml:lang="grc">γὰρ</quote> has dropped out before <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄχθος</quote> in 951. The case is parallel with that of vv. 369 and 384, in the latter of which a syllable was lost. The only tolerable emendation of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπραξε_905"> is </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔρξε_905">: and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπραξε</quote> is the fitter word, since, with its possible sense of ‘contrived,’ it suits the hypothesis that he may have procured death from another's hand; while <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρξε</quote> would, in that case, be somewhat forced. It may be added that the aorist of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρδω</quote> is never used by Sophocles in the indicative (though he has <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρξειεν</quote> <ref n="Soph. Trach. 935"> <title>Tr.</title> 935</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρξον</quote> <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1201, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρξας</quote> <ref n="Soph. Phil. 117"> <title>Ph.</title> 117</ref> etc.); and by Aeschylus only once, <ref n="Aesch. Seven 924"> <title>Th.</title> 924</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρξάτην</quote> (lyr.): for in <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1529"> <title>Ag.</title> 1529</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦρξεν</quote> is right, and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρξεν</quote> only a conjecture. As to v. 951, the insertion of <quote xml:lang="grc">γὰρ</quote> is not only admissible, but desirable. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸς_αὑτοῦ_906">. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1176"> <title>Ant.</title> 1176</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΧΟ. πότερα πατρῴας ἢ πρὸς οἰκείας χερός; ΑΓ. αὐτὸς πρὸς αὑτοῦ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_χθονί_906">: the order of words is Ionic in style; cp. <ref n="Hdt. 6. 69"> Her. 6. 69</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν γάρ σε τῇ νυκτὶ ταύτῃ ἀναιρέομαι</quote>: id. 1. 108 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ γάρ οἱ τῆς ὄψιος..ἐσήμαινον</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 468"> <title>Ph.</title> 468</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρός νύν σε πατρός</quote>. Join </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_πηκτὸν_906"> (dat. of agent: 539).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατηγορεῖ_906">: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 271">Aesch. <title> Ag.</title> 271</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖ γὰρ φρονοῦντος ὄμμα σοῦ κατηγορεῖ</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περιπετὲς_906">, in passive sense, ‘on which he has fallen’: a bold use, as Eustathius felt (p. 644. 47): <quote xml:lang="grc">Σοφοκλῆς ἔγχος περιπετὲς εἰπεῖν ἐτόλμησεν, ᾧ περιπέπτωκεν Αἴας</quote>. Lobeck quotes some phrases which, though not precisely similar, are analogous; as Aelian <title>Hist. An.</title> 15. 10 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ ἄγκιστρα..περιπαγέντα τοῖς ἰχθύσι</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘on which the fish are caught,’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">περιπαρέντα</quote> Schneider): Chrysost. <title>Opp.</title> vol. III. p. 85 A <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑαυτῷ τὸ ξίφος περιέπειρε</quote>, made the sword a spit for his body, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> transfixed himself with his sword. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶος_909">, the reading of the MSS., is far better here than <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷος.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄφρακτος_909">. Dindorf writes <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄφαρκτος</quote>, as the older Attic form. Attic inscriptions attest <quote xml:lang="grc">φάρξαι</quote> (420 B.C.) and <quote xml:lang="grc">διαφάρξαντι</quote> (409 B.C.): though <quote xml:lang="grc">διαφράξαι</quote> occurs as early as 347 B.C.; Meisterhans, <title>Gramm. Att. Inschr.</title> § 43. No instance of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄφαρκτος</quote> is quoted from an Attic inscr., but <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄφρακτος</quote> occurs <foreign xml:lang="lat">c.</foreign> 290 B.C., and often later. For the gen. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φίλων_909"> , <ref n="Soph. Aj. 321">cp. 321</ref>: <ref n="Eur. El. 36"> <title>El.</title> 36</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄσκευον..στρατοῦ</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κωφός_911">, in the general sense of ‘dull-witted’: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναίσθητος. <emph>πάντα</emph> </quote>, adv., as <ref n="Soph. OC 1458"> <title>O. C.</title> 1458</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν πάντ’ ἄριστον</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυστράπελος_913">, ‘intractable,’ not amenable to a guiding hand; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 609">cp. 609</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσθεράπευτος</quote>: and see n. on 595. In <title>Eth. Eud.</title> 3. 7. 6 (p. 1234 <emph>a</emph> 5) the <quote xml:lang="grc">δυστράπελος</quote> is the ‘morose’ man, the opposite extreme to <quote xml:lang="grc">βωμολόχος</quote>, while the <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐτράπελος</quote> is the happy mean.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσώνυμος_913">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 430">cp. 430</ref> f. The epithets show a natural sequence of thought; ‘intractable, and doomed to such a fate as his name foreshadowed.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περιπτυχεῖ_φάρει_915">, a cloak or mantle wrapped round him: for the adj., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 899">cp. 899</ref>. The <quote xml:lang="grc">φάρος</quote>, we may suppose, has been brought by a <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσπολος</quote> from the tent hard by. The shrouded corpse, which remains partly visible (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1172">cp. 1172</ref>), is an effigy, like that of Haemon in the <title>Antigone</title> (1258, cp. p. xvii. n.), and of Clytaemnestra in the <title>Electra</title> (1466). The actor who played Ajax has now to play Teucer.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παμπήδην_915"> is a poet. equiv. (used by Theognis and Aeschylus) for <quote xml:lang="grc">πάμπαν</quote>, formed from it with the adverbial suffix <quote xml:lang="grc">‐δην</quote>: <quote xml:lang="grc">παμπή‐δην</quote>, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc"> παμπάν‐δην</quote>, by compensatory lengthening of <quote xml:lang="grc"> α</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅστις_φίλος_917">, one at least who is a friend. <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> emphasises <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλος</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Her. 58">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 58</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ δυσπραξία</quote>), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἧς μήποθ’, ὅστις καὶ μέσως εὔνους ἐμοί</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">τύχοι</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Ion 232">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 232</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντα θεᾶσθ’, ὅ τι καὶ θέμις, ὄμμασι</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φυσῶντ_ῥῖνας_918">: a reminiscence perh. of <ref n="Hom. Od. 22.18"> <title>Od.</title> 22. 18</ref>(Antinoüs dying of a wound in the throat), <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτίκα δ’ αὐλὸς ἀνὰ ῥῖνας παχὺς ἦλθεν | αἵματος ἀνδρομέοιο</quote>: a thick jet of blood <emph>came up</emph> through his nostrils. The blood is forced up <emph>to</emph> the nostrils, and then issues from them. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1411">Cp. 1411</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μελανθὲν_918">, ‘darkened,’ can hardly be a simple equiv. for <quote xml:lang="grc">μέλαν</quote>: Sophocles may possibly have thought—wrongly—that blood takes a darker colour from the action of air.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἰκείας_σφαγῆς_918">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 260">cp. 260</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκεῖα πάθη</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1176"> <title>Ant.</title> 1176</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">αἱμάσσεται</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς οἰκείας χερός</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαστάσει_920">: <ref target="cl827">see on 827</ref>. The deliber. subjunct. <quote xml:lang="grc">βαστάσῃ</quote>, which the schol. prefers, would be unsuitable here. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκμαἶ_μόλοι_921"> seems the best correction of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκμαῖος_μόλοι_921">. The phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκμαῖα μολεῖν</quote> is quite permissible in poetry: see the examples quoted on 196 f., and add <ref n="Soph. Phil. 310"> Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 310</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μόλις φανεὶς | ἄελπτα κἀδόκητα ματρὸς ὠλέναις.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκμαῖος_μόλοι_921_2"> is impossible: <quote xml:lang="grc">μόλοι</quote> could not stand here for <quote xml:lang="grc">μόλοι ἄν</quote>: see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 605"> <title>Ant.</title> 605</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">κατάσχοι</quote> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συγκαθαρμόσαι_922">: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">περιστεῖλαι</quote>. The double compound occurs only here, but Eur. has <quote xml:lang="grc">καθαρμόζειν</quote> in a similar context, <ref n="Eur. El. 1227">Eur. <title>El.</title> 1227</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κάλυπτε μέλεα ματέρος | πέπλοις, καθάρμοσον σφαγάς</quote> (‘compose,’ ‘close,’ the wounds). Here the sense is, ‘compose,’ with ref. to the laying out of the dead; cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 900">Soph. <title> Ant.</title> 900</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανόντας αὐτόχειρ ὑμᾶς ἐγὼ | ἔλουσα κἀκόσμησα</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OC 1602">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1602</ref> f. (n.): <ref n="Ov. Met. 9. 502"> Ovid <title>Met.</title> 9. 502</ref> <quote xml:lang="lat">peream precor ante toroque | Mortua componar.</quote> The inf. <quote xml:lang="grc">συγκαθαρμόσαι</quote> stands after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκμαἶ ἂν μόλοι</quote> as an inf. follows words of ‘fitness’ ( <ref n="Plat. Sym. 173B">Plat. <title> Symp.</title> 173B</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁδὸς ἐπιτηδεία καὶ λέγειν καὶ ἀκοῦσαι</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἵως_ἔχεις_923">. The adv. <quote xml:lang="grc"> οἵως</quote> has been suspected, but there is no good reason for doubting that it was in use, though less frequent than <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷον</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷα</quote>: it appears sound in <ref n="Aristoph. Wasps 1363">Ar. <title>Vesp.</title> 1363</ref>, and in <ref n="Apollon. 4.786">Apoll. Rh. 4. 786</ref>; though in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1007"> <title>Ph.</title> 1007</ref> we should read <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷ’ αὖ μ’ ὑπῆλθες</quote>.—For <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷος..οἵως</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 557">cp. 557</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἄξιος_924"> is best taken as a heightening of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἵως_ἔχεις_924">: ‘how worthy art thou,’ etc. This is easier than to supply <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤν</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄξιος</quote> (‘as being worthy’). The sense cannot be, ‘<emph>so as</emph> to be worthy,’ etc.; such an ellipse of <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶναι</quote> is impossible.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρ_ἐχθροῖς_924">, in their judgment; 620 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυχεῖν_924">: <ref n="Eur. El. 1469"> <title>El.</title> 1469</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀπ’ ἐμοῦ θρήνων τύχῃ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔμελλες_925">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1027">cp. 1027</ref> : <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1083"> <title>Ph.</title> 1083</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥς σ’ οὐκ ἔμελλον ἄῤ, ὦ τάλας</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">λείψειν.— <emph> χρόνῳ</emph> </quote>: because, for several days, he had been brooding over his wrongs (930 f.): <ref n="Soph. Aj. 193">cp. 193</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μακραίωνι | ...σχολᾷ</quote>. The words of Odysseus in 1336 f. also imply such an interval between the award of the arms and the death of Ajax. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στερεόφρων_926">: as in <title>Polit.</title> p. 309 B <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ στερεὸν ἦθος</quote> is said of <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς ἐπὶ τὴν ἀνδρίαν μᾶλλον ξυντεινούσας</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">φύσεις</quote>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄῤ_926">: 233 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧδ_926"> before </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξανύσειν_926"> has been widely accepted: then <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ‐</quote> (corresponding with the <quote xml:lang="grc">α^</quote> of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀΰπνους</quote> in 881) takes the place of a short syllable; a license possible in dochmiacs. But L's reading, <quote xml:lang="grc">στερεόφρων ἄρ’ <emph> ἐξανύσσειν</emph> κακάν</quote>, gives an exact metrical correspondence, without any conjectural addition. No one could hesitate to prefer it, but for a doubt as to whether Tragic lyrics could admit the form <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξανύσσειν</quote>. The doubled <quote xml:lang="grc"> ς</quote> occurs in <ref n="Hom. Od. 16.373"> <title>Od.</title> 16. 373</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνύσσεσθαι</quote> (fut. midd.): <title>Theog.</title> 954 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνύσσας</quote> : <ref n="Pind. P. 12">Pind. <title>P.</title> 12. 11</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνυσσεν</quote>. Sophocles has <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὀλέσσας</quote> (390), and <quote xml:lang="grc">πέλασσον</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1163">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 1163</ref>). Hartung, G. Wolff, and Wecklein read <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξανύσσειν</quote>: rightly, I believe. Observe that the close kinship of lyric with epic diction here is significantly marked by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐλίῳ_926"> in 933,—an epic and Pindaric word which is free from just suspicion, yet occurs nowhere else in Tragedy. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖα_929">: 164 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάννυχα_φαέθοντ_929">: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ νύκτα καὶ ἡμέραν</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 217">Cp. 217</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νύκτερος</quote> (n.). The bold use of <quote xml:lang="grc">φαέθοντα</quote> for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμερινά</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">πανημέρια</quote> is interpreted and softened by the preceding <quote xml:lang="grc"> πάννυχα</quote>. Doubt would be warrantable if <quote xml:lang="grc">φαέθοντ’ ἀνεστέναζες</quote> stood alone. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠμόφρων_931">, fierce: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 885">cp. 885</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ὠμόθυμον.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐχθοδόπ_931">, poet. for <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐχθρά</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1137"> <title>Ph.</title> 1137</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φῶτ’ ἐχθοδοπόν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐλίῳ_πάθει_931">, with deadly resentment. <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐλίῳ</quote> refers primarily to his deadly hatred of the Atreidae, but suggests also the fatal result of his mood. For <quote xml:lang="grc">πάθος</quote> with ref. to an affection of the mind, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 899"> <title>Ph.</title> 899</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἐνθάδ’ ἤδη τοῦδε τοῦ πάθους κυρῶ</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἀπορίας</quote>). With the exception of these two passages, there is perhaps no clear example of <quote xml:lang="grc"> πάθος</quote> so used before Plato. ( <ref n="Thuc. 3. 84">Thuc. 3. 84</ref>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">διὰ πάθους ἐπιθυμοῦντες</quote> occurs in § 1, is an interpolated chapter.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐλίῳ_πάθει_931_2">, as Prof. Campbell does, ‘under thy calamitous <emph>wrong</emph>’ (the disappointment as to the arms). But <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐλίῳ</quote> is clearly suggestive of a direct reference to <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠμόφρων ἐχθοδόπ’ Ἀτρείδαις</quote>. Further, the prep. <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν</quote> more naturally denotes an accompaniment of the bitter utterance than the cause which had provoked it. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέγας_934">..</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦν_ἄρχων_934">, lit., was potent in beginning,=<quote xml:lang="grc">σφοδρῶς ἦρχε</quote>: the use of <quote xml:lang="grc">μέγας</quote> being analogous to that of <quote xml:lang="grc">πολύς</quote> in such phrases as <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλὸς ἦν λισσόμενος</quote> ( <ref n="Hdt. 9. 91"> Her. 9. 91</ref>). For <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄρχων</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 871"> <title>Tr.</title> 871</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἄρ’ ἡμὶν οὐ σμικρῶν κακῶν | ἦρξεν τὸ δῶρον</quote>: <ref n="Thuc. 2. 12">Thuc. 2. 12</ref>§ 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥδε ἡ ἡμέρα τοῖς Ἕλλησι μεγάλων κακῶν ἄρξει</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦμος_935">, used even in trimeters, <ref n="Soph. OT 1134"> <title>O. T.</title> 1134</ref>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀριστόχειρ_ἀγὼν_935">, like <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠκύπους ἀγών</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. El. 699"> <title>El.</title> 699</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιμφάρματοι ἅμιλλαι</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 1062"> <title>O. C.</title> 1062</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπλων_935">. The defect of <foreign xml:lang="meter">-uu-</foreign> before this word is proved by the metre of the strophe, 890, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἀμενηνὸν ἄνδρα μὴ λεύσσειν ὅπου</quote>. Musgrave proposed </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρυσοδέτων_935">: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.268"> <title>Il.</title> 20. 268</ref>, referring to the arms of Achilles, <quote xml:lang="grc">χρυσὸς γὰρ ἐρύκακε, δῶρα θεοῖο</quote>. The last syll. of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀριστόχειρ</quote> might facilitate the loss of a word beginning with <quote xml:lang="grc">χρ</quote>. For other suggestions, see cr. n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἧπαρ_938">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 135">Aesch. <title> Eum.</title> 135</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλγησον ἧπαρ ἐνδίκοις ὀνείδεσιν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γενναία_938">, true-hearted, loyal, like <quote xml:lang="grc">γενναῖον ἔπος</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1402"> <title>Ph.</title> 1402</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">γενναῖοι πόνοι</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. Her. 357">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 357</ref>). The schol., wrongly, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ἰσχυρά</quote>: a version at which he arrived perh. rather through the use of <quote xml:lang="grc">γενναῖος</quote> as=‘fine,’ ‘good of its kind,’ than through the idea of ‘genuine,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">γνησία</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_δὶς_940">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 432">cp. 432</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ δὶς αἰάζειν</quote>. The aor. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἰμῶξαι_940"> (referring to each act of utterance), as in <ref n="Eur. El. 788"> <title>El.</title> 788</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴμοι τάλαινα· νῦν γὰρ οἰμῶξαι πάρα</quote>: and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 285 <quote xml:lang="grc">κλαῦσαι</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 982">Cp. 982</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">στενάζειν</quote>, of continued lament. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποβλαφθεῖσαν_φίλου_941">: bereft of him: properly, arrested by a hand which separates her from him ( <ref n="Eur. El. 696"> <title>El.</title> 696</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν δέ τις θεῶν | βλάπτῃ, δύναιτ’ ἂν οὐδ’ ἂν ἰσχύων φυγεῖν</quote>). For the gen. (not found elsewhere with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποβλάπτω</quote>), cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 120">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 120</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βλαβέντα λοισθίων δρόμων</quote>: Tyrtaeus fr. 12. 39 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέ τις αὐτὸν | βλάπτειν οὔτ’ αἰδοῦς οὔτε δίκης ἐθέλει</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρτίως_941">. The schol. read </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρτίου_941">, which he explains by <quote xml:lang="grc">γνησίου</quote>: and this reading was approved by Bergk in <title>Rhein. Mus.</title> (1847) p. 150, though in his text (1858) he kept <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρτίως</quote>. Hartung gives <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρτίου</quote>, explaining it of close, congenial friendship ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 570"> <title>Ant.</title> 570</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ὥς γ’ ἐκείνῳ τῇδέ τ’ ἦν ἡρμοσμένα</quote>). But <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρτίως</quote>, though somewhat tame, is clearly genuine. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκεῖν_942">, to conjecture; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονεῖν_942">, to understand, to feel, by one's own experience: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1741"> <title>O. C.</title> 1741</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φρονῶ</quote>, ‘I know it well.’ As the Chorus had recognised Tecmessa's unique place in the affections of Ajax (211 f.), so by <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκεῖν</quote> she implies that they can at least form some estimate of her loss. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δουλείας_ζυγά_944">: her old fear; 499.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἷοι_944"> might be a second exclamation; but seems better taken as causal (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεὶ τοιοῦτοι</quote>). Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 701"> <title>O. T.</title> 701</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρέοντος, οἷά μοι βεβουλευκὼς ἔχει.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκοποί_944">, the <quote xml:lang="grc">δεσπόται</quote> (500) who will be the overseers of her servile tasks (503, <quote xml:lang="grc">λατρείας</quote>). Cp. <title>Suppl.</title> 381 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ὑψόθεν σκοπὸν ἐπισκόπει</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">φύλακα πολυπόνων | βροτῶν</quote>: the watchful god, who punishes guilt. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὤμοι_ἀναλγήτων_946"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote>: ‘in this sorrow (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷδ_ἄχει_946">, lit., ‘by’ it, by the mention of it), thou hast named deeds of the Atreidae that are unutterable,—that make them ruthless’: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, if they should indeed enslave thee, their act would be infamous. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀναλγήτων_946">, as its emphatic place shows, has a predicative force. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄναυδ_ἔργ_946">, as a correction of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄναυδον | ἔργον</quote>, <ref target="cl901">see on 901</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄχει_946"> does not literally mean ‘lament,’ though it might be so rendered here, as in <ref n="Soph. OC 1722"> <title>O. C.</title> 1722</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λήγετε τοῦδ’ ἄχους</quote> (where the literal sense is, ‘cease from this sorrowing’). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ἔστη_950"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> The last words of the Chorus, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλἀπείργοι_θεός_950">, imply that the Atreidae may, after all, be capable of such cruelty, if the gods do not hinder them. Tecmessa replies that things could not have come to the present pass without the help of the gods; so that it is vain to rest hopes on them.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάδ_τῇδε_950">: <ref n="Aesch. PB 511"> Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 511</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ ταῦτα ταύτῃ Μοῖρά πω τελεσφόρος | κρᾶναι πέπρωται.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔστη_950">, have been brought to this state: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1156"> <title>Ant.</title> 1156</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔσθ’ ὁποῖον στάντ’ ἂν ἀνθρώπου βίον | οὔτ’ αἰνέσαιμ’ ἂν οὔτε μεμψαίμην ποτέ</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_μέτα_950">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">στάντα</quote>,=<quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ μετὰ θεῶν τῇδε ἔστη</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1456"> <title>O. T.</title> 1456</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ ἄν ποτε | θνῄσκων ἐσώθην, μὴ )πί τῳ δεινῷ κακῷ</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">σωθείς</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄγαν_ὑπερβριθὲς_951"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> The defect of a syllable in the MSS. here (see 905 n.) is best supplied by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γὰρ_951">, which expresses assent: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 755"> <title>Ph.</title> 755</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΝΕ. δεινόν γε τοὐπίσαγμα τοῦ νοσήματος</quote>. | <quote xml:lang="grc">ΦΙ. δεινὸν γὰρ οὐδὲ ῥητόν</quote>. The addition of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γ_951"> after </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄγαν_951"> in some MSS. seems to have been prompted by a sense that some such link with the preceding verse was required.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄχθος_951">, of sorrow, as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1168"> <title>Ph.</title> 1168</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μυρίον ἄχθος ὃ ξυνοικεῖ. — <emph>ἤνυσαν</emph> </quote>, effected, brought about, as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1145"> <title>Ph.</title> 1145</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοινὰν ἤνυσεν ἐς φίλους ἀρωγάν</quote>. Not, ‘have made too heavy,’ like <ref n="Soph. OT 166"> <title>O. T.</title> 166</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠνύσατ’ ἐκτοπίαν φλόγα πήματος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέντοι_952">, ‘yet,’—crushing though the sorrow is: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 780"> <title>O. C.</title> 780</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρ’ ἂν</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">ματαίου τῆσδ’ ἂν ἡδονῆς τύχοις; | τοιαῦτα μέντοι καὶ σὺ προσφέρεις ἐμοί</quote>. (It is not a mere expression of assent, ‘yes,’ as Paley takes it.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ζηνὸς_θεὸς_952">: for the simple gen. of parentage, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 172">cp. 172</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> Διὸς</quote>, 1302 <quote xml:lang="grc">Λαομέδοντος</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 824"> <title>Ant.</title> 824</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰν Φρυγίαν ξέναν | Ταντάλου</quote>. In 401 and 450 the art. (<quote xml:lang="grc"> ἡ</quote>) is prefixed to <quote xml:lang="grc">Διός.— <emph>φυτεύει</emph> </quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 347"> <title>O. T.</title> 347</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυμφυτεῦσαι τοὔργον</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_ῥα_954">: 172 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐφυβρίζει_954"> here denotes, not deeds or words of insult, but secret exultation; hence it is joined with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κελαινώπαν_θυμὸν_954"> as an acc. ‘of the inner object,’ like that which is often added to verbs of feeling (<quote xml:lang="grc">γέγηθέ τε φρένα</quote>, <ref n="Hom. Il. 8.559"> <title>Il.</title> 8. 559</ref>: <quote xml:lang="grc">ταράσσομαι φρένας</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1095"> <title>Ant.</title> 1095</ref>). <quote xml:lang="grc">κελαινώπαν</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">κελαινός, ὤψ</quote>) is not simply an equiv. for <quote xml:lang="grc">κελαινόν</quote>: the second part of the compound suggests the dark soul which watches from its place of concealment with malevolent joy; as Philoctetes says to Odysseus, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἡ κακὴ σὴ διὰ μυχῶν βλέπουσ’ ἀεὶ | ψυχή</quote> etc.—The epithet ‘dark,’ ‘black,’ is often given to a mind strongly moved by passion (esp. anger): <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.103"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 103</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μένεος δὲ μέγα φρένες ἀμφὶ μέλαιναι | πίμπλαντ’</quote>: Theogn. 1199 <quote xml:lang="grc">καί μοι κραδίην ἐπάταξε μέλαιναν</quote> (dark with resentment): <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 414">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 414</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σπλάγχνα δέ μου κελαινοῦται</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 114">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 114</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτά μοι μελαγχίτων | φρὴν ἀμύσσεται φόβῳ</quote>. Here, however, dark <emph>malignity</emph> is implied, as by <quote xml:lang="grc">κελαινόφρων</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 459"> Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 459</ref>, of Clytaemnestra).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κελαινῶπἀν_θυμὸν_954">: an ingenious conjecture. But the Sophoclean apocopè of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνά</quote> is elsewhere confined to compounds (see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1275">Soph. <title>Ant.</title> 1275</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντρέπων</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κελαινῶπ_ἔνθυμον_954">: ‘mocks at the brooding, passionate man’ (Ajax),—referring to <ref n="Aristot. Pol. 7.1334b">Arist. <title>Pol.</title> 4.</ref>(7.) 7. 3 (where, however, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνθυμος</quote> = ‘spirited,’ opp. to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄθυμος</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολύτλας_956">, much-enduring, ‘patient,’—the Homeric epithet, applied with bitter irony: he has known how to work and wait.—Not ‘unflinching,’ in the sense of ‘sticking at nothing’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">παντουργός</quote>, v. 445). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γελᾷ_δὲ_957">, the traditional reading, is slightly better here than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γελᾷ_τε_957">: <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote>, implying that the speaker turns to a new point, here serves to mark a climax: Odysseus exults in thought,—yes, and laughs aloud. For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γελᾷ_957">, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 382">cp. 382</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1125"> <title>Ph.</title> 1125</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">καί που</quote> ..) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγγελᾷ, χερὶ πάλλων | τὰν ἐμὰν μελέου τροφάν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖσδε_ἄχεσιν_957">, dat. of object with <quote xml:lang="grc">γελᾷ</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1042">cp. 1042</ref> : <title>Nub.</title> 560 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις οὖν τούτοισι γελᾷ, τοῖς ἐμοῖς μὴ χαιρέτω.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαινομένοις_957">: as <quote xml:lang="grc"> μαίνομαι</quote> is said of fire, strife, etc., so here it denotes ‘frantic’ griefs, but with a further refer ence to their source in the <quote xml:lang="grc">μανία</quote> of Ajax. Cp. <title>I. A.</title> 548 <quote xml:lang="grc">μαινομένων οἴστρων</quote> (so Reiske, for <quote xml:lang="grc">μαινόμεν’</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξύν_τε_959">: for the adv. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ξύν</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1288">cp. 1288</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 85."> <title>Ant.</title> 85.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_οὖν_961">: 114 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεἰ_μὴ_961">, where <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ καὶ μή</quote> would be normal (563 n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πόθουν_961">, ‘missed him,’ during the interval between the award of the arms and his death, when he remained in seclusion (193 f., n.). <ref n="Hom. Il. 6.361"> <title>Il.</title> 6. 361</ref>(Hector) <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄφρ’ ἐπαμύνω | Τρώεσς’, οἳ μέγ’ ἐμεῖο ποθὴν ἀπεόντος ἔχουσιν</quote>. 1. 240 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ ποτ’ Ἀχιλλῆος ποθὴ ἵξεται υἶας Ἀχαιῶν</quote>. For the prodelision of the augment in the last foot of the v., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 557">cp. 557</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">)τράφης</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_δορός_961">, ‘in the need of the spear’=‘in the straits of war’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1275">cp. 1275</ref> : <ref n="Soph. Ant. 670"> <title>Ant.</title> 670</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δορὸς..ἐν χειμῶνι</quote>.—Not, ‘when they need <emph>his</emph> spear.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοὶ_γνώμαισι_964">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1374">cp. 1374</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γνώμῃ σοφόν.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἀγαθὸν_χεροῖν_964"> is better attested than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἀγάθ_χεροῖν_964">: and in this context the singular <quote xml:lang="grc">τἀγαθὸν</quote> is preferable. For the dat., cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 431"> <title>El.</title> 431</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν ἔχεις χεροῖν</quote> , <ref n="Soph. Trach. 265"> <title>Tr.</title> 265</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χεροῖν..ἔχων βέλη</quote> .</gloss>
