<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρίν_ἐκβάλῃ_964">=<quote xml:lang="grc">πρὶν ἐκβάλωσι</quote>: the collective <quote xml:lang="grc">τις</quote>, as in <ref n="Thuc. 4. 85">Thuc. 4. 85</ref>§ 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷς ἂν ἐπίω, ἧσσόν τις ἐμοὶ πρόσεισι, δυσχερὲς ποιούμενοι κ.τ.λ.</quote> From the primary sense of ‘casting out,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκβάλλειν</quote> derives that of ‘throwing away,’ ‘losing by one's own folly’: cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 746">Ar. <title>Eccl.</title> 750</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ τὸν ἐμὸν ἱδρῶτα καὶ φειδωλίαν | οὐδὲν πρὸς ἔπος οὕτως ἀνοήτως ἐκβαλῶ</quote>. So a schol. here explains, <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὶν ἄν τις αὐτοῦ στερηθῇ</quote>. Sophocles has this use, with various shades of meaning, in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 648">Soph. <title> Ant.</title> 648</ref>(where see n.), <ref n="Soph. OT 611">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 611</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OC 631.">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 631.</ref>[We could also render, ‘until one <emph>strike it out</emph> of their hands’; cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 2.396">Hom. <title>Od.</title> 2. 396</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλάζε δὲ πίνοντας, χειρῶν δ’ ἔκβαλλε κύπελλα</quote>. But a reason for preferring the other view is that it represents the loss as due solely to the folly of the possessors themselves; and thus suits the context better.]</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμοὶ_πικρὸς_966"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> Schol. in L: <quote xml:lang="grc">μᾶλλον ἐμοὶ πικρὸς τέθνηκεν ἤπερ ἐκείνοις γλυκύς</quote>. This is the only tenable explanation of the words. For the omission of <quote xml:lang="grc">μᾶλλον</quote>, cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.117"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 117</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βούλομ’ ἐγὼ λαὸν σόον ἔμμεναι ἢ ἀπολέσθαι</quote>: <ref n="Hdt. 3. 40"> Her. 3. 40</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βούλομαι...οὕτω διαφέρε<*>ν τὸν αἰῶνα ἐναλλὰξ πρήσσων ἢ εὐτυχέειν τὰ πάντα</quote>. No proposed substitute for </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_966"> (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾗ_καὶ_966">) really fits the sense. Her point throughout is that the death of Ajax is no triumph for the Greeks—only a loss. The sole positive result is her own wretchedness. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γλυκύς_966"> means, a cause of rejoicing for them—if they knew their own interest. Instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ κείνοις γλυκύς, ἀλλ’ ἐμοὶ πικρός</quote>, we have <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμοὶ πικρὸς</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">μᾶλλον</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ κείνοις γλυκύς</quote>: cp. <ref n="Thuc. 1. 34">Thuc. 1. 34</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">πολέμῳ μᾶλλον ἢ τῷ ἴσῳ ἐβουλήθησαν τὰ ἐγκλήματα μετελθεῖν</quote> (= <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ τῷ ἴσῳ, ἀλλὰ πολέμῳ</quote>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θάνατον_966"> is in appos. with the <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα</quote> implied (as antecedent) by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_966">: as we could say,—‘<emph>all</emph> that he desired he has found,—the death of his choice.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπεγγελῷεν_969">, as in 454, 989.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάτα_969">, placed after its case, as in 302, and also separated from it, like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν</quote> in 906. We find <quote xml:lang="grc">κατά</quote> joined with a similar compound verb in <ref n="Eur. El. 834"> <title>El.</title> 834</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">κατ’ ἐμοῦ</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">μᾶλλον ἐπεμβάσει</quote>.—Conjectures which aim at </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγγελῷεν_969"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">τοιοῦδ’, τοῦδ’ ἄν, τοῦδέ γ’</quote>) are needless: the stress on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦδ_969"> mitigates the harshness of the verse. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοῖς_970"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote>: the dat. is one of relation: his death is a matter between the gods and himself,—one in which the Greek chiefs have no part. (‘His death concerns the gods,—not them, not them’: Whitelaw.) See on <ref n="Eur. El. 1152"> <title>El.</title> 1152</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέθνηκ’ ἐγὼ σοί</quote>. The implied meaning is that his death has been brought about by the gods; but <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοῖς</quote> should not be taken as a dat. of the agent (539), ‘<emph>by</emph> the gods’; indeed, that sense would be forced. Tecmessa's phrase is more expressive and more pathetic. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_ταῦτ_971">, with a command, as often; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1066">cp. 1066</ref>, 1115: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 658"> <title>Ant.</title> 658</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ταῦτ’ ἐφυμνείτω Δία | ξύναιμον</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 426"> <title>O. T.</title> 426</ref>: <ref n="Soph. El. 820"> <title>El.</title> 820</ref>, etc.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_κενοῖς_971">, in a case where his triumphs are <quote xml:lang="grc">κενά</quote>, empty, unreal: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1118"> <title>Tr.</title> 1118</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ ἂν γνοίης ἐν οἷς | χαίρειν προθυμεῖ</quote> (n.). <ref n="Soph. El. 331"> <title>El.</title> 331</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θυμῷ..χαρίζεσθαι κενά</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοῖς_971"> as opposed to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμοί</quote>. The emphasis is on <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκέτ’ ἐστίν</quote>, which is repeated in a negative form by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ..διοίχεται</quote> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 167">cp. 167</ref> n.). ‘It is all <emph>loss</emph> for them; nothing remains but the anguish which becomes my portion.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄτης_ἐπίσκοπον_976"> (from <quote xml:lang="grc">σκοπός</quote> as=‘mark’), aimed at it, having regard to it: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ἡμαρτηκὸς τῆς συμφορᾶς, ἀλλ’ ἐστοχασμένον</quote>. Another gloss, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφορον</quote>, represents the view that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπίσκοπον</quote> is from <quote xml:lang="grc">σκοπός</quote> as=‘overseer’, and means ‘looking upon’ the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄτη</quote>: which yields virtually the same sense. But, in actual usage, this <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπίσκοπος</quote>, when figurative, means ‘watching or presiding over.’ In <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 125">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 125</ref> f., <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς γῆς ἔνερθε δαίμονας κλύειν ἐμὰς | εὐχάς, πατρῴων δωμάτων ἐπισκόπους</quote>, the adj. is best taken with <quote xml:lang="grc">δαίμονας</quote>, ‘looking upon.’ Hence it is better to suppose the notion of aiming at a mark both here and in <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 903">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 903</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁποῖα νίκης μὴ κακῆς ἐπίσκοπα</quote>. Herodotus has the literal sense, <ref n="Hdt. 3.35">Aesch. Eum. 3. 35</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">τίνα εἶδες..οὕτω ἐπίσκοπα τοξεύοντα;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέλος_976">, said here of a loud lament, denotes the bellowing of oxen in fr. 637 <quote xml:lang="grc">μέλη βοῶν ἄναυλα καὶ ῥακτήρια</quote> (‘discordant’). Euripides applies the word to Nestor's winning eloquence, <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ Νεστόρειον εὔγλωττον μέλος</quote> (fr. 899). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξύναιμον_ὄμμ_977">, the ‘face’ or ‘form’ of a kinsman: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1004">cp. 1004</ref>: <ref n="Eur. El. 903"> <title>El.</title> 903</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σύνηθες ὄμμα</quote> (n.): <ref n="Soph. Phil. 171"> <title>Ph.</title> 171</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύντροφον ὄμμ’</quote> : <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 238">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 238</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ τερπνὸν ὄμμα</quote> (where Herm. reads <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄνομα</quote>). For <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύναιμον</quote>, cp. <*> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοπη. <title>αντ.</title> αὐτάδελφον..κάρα</quote>, <ref n="Soph. OC 1387">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1387</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">συγγενεῖ χερί</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἠμπόληκας_978">=<quote xml:lang="grc">πέπραγας</quote>, ‘fared’: Hippocr. <title>De morb.</title> II. p. 353 (Kühn) <quote xml:lang="grc">κάλλιον ἐμπολήσει ὁ ἄνθρωπος</quote>, ‘the patient's state will be better.’ In <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 631">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 631</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠμποληκότα | τὰ πλεῖστ’ ἄμεινον</quote> (so Herm. , for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμείνον’</quote>), the sense is similar.—Hermann, reading </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἠμπόληκά_ς_978">, explained, ‘Num te morando prodidi?’ This seems clearly less fitting. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὤμοι_980"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1179"> <title>El.</title> 1179</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴμοι ταλαίνης ἆρα τῆσδε συμφορᾶς</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἐχόντων_981">: the same phrase in <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1393">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1393</ref>: so above, <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 904">Aesch. Ag. 904</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ὧδε τοῦδ’ ἔχοντος αἰάζειν πάρα</quote>, and 281 n. For the neut. plur. part., without subject, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1344"> <title>El.</title> 1344</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τελουμένων εἴποιμ’ ἄν</quote> (n.).—The division of the verse between two speakers (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντιλαβή</quote>) is again used, as in 591 ff., to mark strong emotion. The interruption after <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐχόντων</quote> has the effect of adding emphasis to the announcement: see on <ref n="Soph. OC 645."> <title>O. C.</title> 645.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περισπερχὲς_982">, done in passionate haste,—fierce and sudden. <quote xml:lang="grc">σπέρχομαι</quote> often refers to anger, as in <ref n="Hdt. 5. 33"> Her. 5. 33</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσπέρχετο τῷ Ἀρισταγόρῃ</quote>: cp. id. 7. 207 <quote xml:lang="grc">περισπερχεόντων τῇ γνώμῃ ταύτῃ</quote>, ‘being incensed’ at it: Oppian <ref n="Arr. Cyn. 4.218"> <title>Cyn.</title> 4. 218</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">περισπερχὴς ὀδύνῃσιν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_γὰρ_983">,..</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῦ_κυρεῖ_983">..; For the double question, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 101">cp. 101</ref> f.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοι_983">, ethic dat.: 733. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μόνος_985">: referring to <quote xml:lang="grc"> τέκνον</quote>: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 22.84"> <title>Il.</title> 22. 84</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλε τέκνον</quote> : <ref n="Eur. Andr. 570">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 570</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέκνου τε τοῦδ’, ὃν κ.τ.λ. <emph>παρὰ σκηναῖσιν</emph> </quote>, where Tecmessa had left him at 809.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δῆτ_ἄξεις_985">. There is no other example of <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆτα</quote> as first word of a verse. It is usually read as first word of a clause in <title>Nub.</title> 399 (<quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ πῶς</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴπερ βάλλει τοὺς ἐπιόρκους, δῆτ’ οὐχὶ Σίμων’ ἐνέπρησεν</quote>..; where, however, Dindorf gives <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς οὐχι</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς δῆτ’</quote> being a variant for <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆτ’</quote>). There is, however, no reason to doubt it here. With Sophocles the words sometimes run on from the end of one trimeter to the beginning of the next, as if there were no break between the verses. See <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> 1089 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως | μή</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 409"> <title>Ant.</title> 409</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶσαν κόνιν σήραντες ἣ κατεῖχε τὸν | νέκυν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 263"> <title>Ph.</title> 263</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃν οἱ | δισσοὶ στρατηγοί</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 332"> <title>O. T.</title> 332</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί ταῦτ’ | ἄλλως ἐλέγχεις;</quote> (Such elision at the end of the verse was remarked by the ancients as peculiar to Sophocles: see on <ref n="Soph. OT 29."> <title>O. T.</title> 29.</ref>) The place of <quote xml:lang="grc"> δῆτα</quote> here is only another example of the same tendency, and is illustrated by that of <quote xml:lang="grc">ποτέ</quote> in <ref n="Soph. OT 1084"> <title>O. T.</title> 1084</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν ἐξέλθοιμ’ ἔτι | ποτ’ ἄλλος</quote>. This virtual synaphea of trimeters naturally occurs most often in passages where, as here, the speech is excited or rapid.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κενῆς_985">, ‘robbed’ of her young: <ref n="Bion 1.59">Bion <title>Idyll.</title> I. 59</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χήρα δ’ ἁ Κυθέρεια, κενοὶ δ’ ἀνὰ δώματ’ Ἔρωτες</quote>. The adj. is ‘proleptic’: if the child is not quickly brought, the mother will seek him only to find that she is bereaved. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 791"> <title>Ant.</title> 791</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δικαίων ἀδίκους φρένας παρασπᾷς</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 298">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 298</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνανδρον τάξιν ἠρήμου θανών</quote>. Schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ γὰρ κυνηγοὶ τηροῦσι τὸν καιρὸν ὁπότε ἔρημοι τῶν μητέρων γίγνονται οἱ σκύμνοι</quote>. —Others take </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κενῆς_985_2"> as merely ‘separated’ (at this time) from her child: but this would be a strange sense for it. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγκόνει_988"> (811) and </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύγκαμνε_988"> are said, like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄξεις</quote>, to Tecmessa, who now hurries away. At v. 1168 she returns with her child, but only as a <quote xml:lang="grc">κωφὸν πρόσωπον</quote>, whose part is taken by a supernumerary. The actor who has thus far played Tecmessa has to re-appear as Odysseus (or possibly as Agamemnon): see p. 7.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κειμένοις_988"> is bitterly added after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανοῦσι_988">, to mark the baseness of the action: ‘the dead—when they have fallen.’ Cp. <title>Nub.</title> 550 <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐκ ἐτόλμησ’ αὖθις ἐπεμπηδῆσ’ αὐτῷ κειμένῳ</quote>. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 884">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 884</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστε σύγγονον | βροτοῖσι τὸν πεσόντα λακτίσαι πλέον</quote>. There is no reason for changing </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανοῦσι_988_2"> (cr. n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_990">: 794.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦδε_990">, Eurysaces, the subject of vv. 983 ff. The absence of the child does not require us to make <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦδε</quote> neuter (‘this matter’). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέλειν_990"> might be personal (689), but, in view of <quote xml:lang="grc">μέλει</quote>, is prob. here the impersonal verb.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥσπερ_οὖν_990">: <title>Phaedr.</title> p. 242 E <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἔστιν, ὥσπερ οὖν ἔστι, θεὸς ἤ τι θεῖον ὁ Ἔρως</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁπάντων_δὴ_992">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 858">cp. 858</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πανύστατον δή.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεαμάτων_ὀφθαλμοῖς_992">: the redundant phrase denotes the vehemence of his feeling; cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 763"> <title>Ant.</title> 763</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σύ τ’ οὐδαμὰ | τοὐμὸν προσόψει κρᾶτ’ ἐν ὀφθαλμοῖς ὁρῶν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁδός_πασῶν_994">. The fact that <quote xml:lang="grc">πασῶν</quote> has been corrected in L from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁπασῶν</quote>, the reading of some other MSS., has been regarded as confirming Brunck's conjecture, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁδῶνθ_δή_994">. That reading is specious. In support of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πασῶν_994">, however, these points should be considered. (1) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁπασῶν</quote> could easily arise through the scribe's eye wandering to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁπάντων</quote> in 992: and no MS. which has <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁπασῶν</quote> alters the order of the words <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁδός θ’ ὁδῶν</quote>. (2) After <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἁπάντων..θεαμάτων ἄλγιστον</quote>, there is a rhetorical advantage in having <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁδός θ’ ὁδῶν πασῶν</quote> rather than <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁδῶν θ’ ἁπασῶν ὁδός</quote>. It is a ‘chiasmus.’ (3) The absence of caesura in <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁδός θ’ ὁδῶν πασῶν</quote> may have been intentional: <ref target="cl855">see on 855</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνιάσασα_δή_994">. Here <quote xml:lang="grc">δή</quote> emphasises the whole phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">πασῶν ἀνιάσασα μάλιστα</quote> (rather than <quote xml:lang="grc">πασῶν</quote> only). Cp. Creon's words in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1212"> <title>Ant.</title> 1212</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρα δυστυχεστάτην | κέλευθον ἕρπω τῶν παρελθουσῶν ὁδῶν;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἐπῃσθόμην_996">. On learning that Ajax had left the tent, the Messenger and others had hastened to the camp, to inform Teucer (804). They knew nothing as to the hero's fate. Teucer, who had stayed near the council of chiefs in the hope of mediating (780), then set out to seek Ajax,—going, not, of course, to the tent itself, but to the coast near it. While engaged in the search, he heard the rumour that Ajax was dead.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διώκων_996"> expresses eager, rapid search; as the midd. <quote xml:lang="grc">διώκομαι</quote> denotes speed ( <ref n="Eur. El. 871"> <title>El.</title> 871</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀξιχνοσκοπούμενος_996">. The act. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξιχνοσκοπεῖν</quote> occurs in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 271"> <title>Tr.</title> 271</ref>: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰχνοσκοπεῖν</quote> in <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 228.">Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 228.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάξις_998">, as Ajax had prayed Zeus to apprise Teucer (826).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σου_998"> is genitive of the object (221 n.): </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοῦ_998">, of the subject (as in <ref n="Soph. OC 447"> <title>O. C.</title> 447</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γένους ἐπάρκεσιν</quote>,=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἣν τὸ γένος παρέχει</quote>). For the combination, cp. <ref n="Thuc. 7. 34">Thuc. 7. 34</ref>§ 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">διὰ τὴν τοῦ ἀνέμου ἄπωσιν αὐτῶν</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι ὁ ἄνεμος ἀπωθεῖ αὐτά</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ ναυάγια</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διῆλθ_Ἀχαιοὺς_998">: <ref n="Hdt. 9. 100"> Her. 9. 100</ref>(before the battle of Mycale) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰοῦσι δέ σφι φήμη.. ἐσέπτατο ἐς τὸ στρατόπεδον πᾶν...ἡ δὲ φήμη διῆλθέ σφι</quote> (ethic dat.) <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧδε, ὡς οἱ Ἕλληνες τὴν Μαρδονίου στρατιὴν νικῷεν ἐν</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">Βοιωτοῖσι μαχόμενοι</quote>. As to <quote xml:lang="grc">φήμη</quote> generally, see on <ref n="Eur. El. 1066."> <title>El.</title> 1066.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύστηνος_1000">, L's reading, is better attested than </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δείλαιος_1000">: otherwise there is little to choose between them.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκποδὼν_ὢν_1000">, merely, ‘while yet absent’ from this spot. It is grammatically possible to take it as=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι ἐκποδὼν ἦν</quote>, ‘I lamented that I had been absent’ (cp. fr. 667 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρὸς κακῶς πράσσοντος ἐκποδὼν φίλοι</quote>). But this would be strained; and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νῦν_ὁρῶν_1000"> is decisive in favour of the simpler view.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπεστέναζον_1000">: restraining the vehemence of his grief: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 322">cp. 322</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴθ_ἐκκάλυψον_1003">. This is said to an attendant. Tecmessa left the scene at v. 989. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄμμα_1004">, face, or form; 977 n.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόλμης_πικρᾶς_1004">, a gen. of quality (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 616">cp. 616</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔργα..ἀρετᾶς</quote>). The corpse of the self-slain man shows the ‘cruel courage’ that animated him. For the combination of adj. (<quote xml:lang="grc">δυσθέατον</quote>) with gen., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 481">cp. 481</ref> f.: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 72"> <title>Ph.</title> 72</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’ ἔνορκος..οὔτε τοῦ πρώτου στόλου</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_1004"> (‘O ghastly form! And alas for the cruel daring!’). But </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_1004"> precludes this.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοι_1004"> followed by the acc. (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρήξαντα</quote>) and inf., cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 838"> <title>Ant.</title> 838</ref> n.: <ref n="Eur. Med. 814">Eur. <title> Med.</title> 814</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοὶ δὲ συγγνώμη λέγειν | τάδ’ ἐστί, μὴ πάσχουσαν, ὡς ἐγώ, κακῶς</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_που_1004"> (‘methinks’) is reinforced by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴσως_1004">, which goes more closely with the adjectives (‘radiant and benign, doubtless’). Hermann's change of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴσως_1004_2"> to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰδὼν_1004"> weakens the passage.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμός_ἅμα_1004"> is clearly right: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμός τ’ ἴσως</quote> was a mere error caused by the copyist's eye wandering to the next verse. The use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴσως</quote> in the sense of ‘equally’ ( <title>Legg.</title> p. 805 A) is rare.—Teucer's thought is, ‘Telamon is, indeed, my father no less than thine; but he will not welcome me as a son.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πῶς_οὔχ_1010">; <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέξεται.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτῳ_πάρα_1010"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">πάρεστι</quote> )..</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γελᾶν_1010">, ‘the man whose wont it is to wear no brighter smile (than usual), even when he is fortunate.’ <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote> is used, not <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ</quote>, because <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτῳ</quote> here denotes a class or type. For this ‘generic’ <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote>, see <ref n="Soph. OT 397"> <title>O. T.</title> 397</ref> n.—<quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>πάρα</emph>. πάρεστι</quote>, when thus used, is susceptible of two different shades of meaning. (1) More often it denotes one's situation at some given moment; as in 432, <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν γὰρ πάρεστι καὶ δὶς αἰάζειν ἐμοί</quote>. (2) Sometimes, as here, it denotes a trait of character or disposition; cp. <ref n="Eur. Med. 658">Eur. <title> Med.</title> 658</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀχάριστος ὄλοιθ’ ὅτῳ πάρεστι | μὴ φίλους τιμᾶν</quote> (‘one who is capable of not respecting friendship’). In this sense <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσεστι</quote> is more frequent.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵλεων_1010"> for </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥδιον_1010"> is very inferior, and undoubtedly corrupt. It evidently arose from <quote xml:lang="grc">λεως</quote> in 1009. The force of the comparative here is manifest: ‘If good fortune cannot <emph>lessen</emph> his gloom, what will his aspect be <emph>now?</emph> ’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_κρύψει_1012">; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘what thought, however injurious to me, will he leave unspoken?’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῖον_κακὸν_1012"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> There should be no comma after <quote xml:lang="grc">κακόν</quote>: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρεῖ</quote> here takes a double acc. At the same time the words <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἐκ δορὸς κ.τ.λ.</quote> express the substance of the taunts.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_πολεμίου_1012">, ‘begotten of the war-spear,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ δορικτήτου γυναικός</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1228">cp. 1228</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἐκ τῆς αἰχμαλωτίδος</quote>. Remark that <quote xml:lang="grc">δόρυ πολέμιον</quote>, which here means <emph>hasta bellica</emph>, would usu. mean <emph>hasta hostilis</emph> (as, <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, in <ref n="Aesch. Seven 216">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 216</ref>, <ref n="Aesch. Seven 416">Aesch. Theb. 416</ref>): but it would be forced here to understand, ‘begotten from the ranks of the foe.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακανδρίᾳ_1014">: a word not found elsewhere, except in <title>Rhes.</title> 814.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σέ_φίλτατΑἴας_1014">: the place of the pronoun is emphatic: ‘thee’—for whom I would gladly have died.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_θανόντος_1014">: cp. <ref n="Eur. Hec. 430">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 430</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανούσης ὄμμα</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">συγκλείσει τὸ σόν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κράτη_1014">, royal prerogatives, as in <ref n="Soph. OT 237"> <title>O. T.</title> 237</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 173."> <title>Ant.</title> 173.</ref>— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δόμους_1014">: cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 651"> <title>El.</title> 651</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δόμους Ἀτρειδῶν σκῆπτρά τ’ ἀμφέπειν τάδε</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύσοργος_1017">, naturally prone to anger: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_βαρύς_1017">, choleric, irritable, in his old age. For this sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρύς</quote>, see on <ref n="Soph. OT 673."> <title>O. T.</title> 673.</ref>—Ajax himself felt that, if he went home disgraced, he could not confront his father (462).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_οὐδὲν_1017">, ‘at nothing,’—without cause: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 40">cp. 40</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τί;</quote> 971 <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ταῦτα.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_θυμούμενος_1017">, lit. ‘growing wroth unto quarrelling,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, so as to provoke a quarrel.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπωστὸς_1017"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γῆς_1017">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 641"> <title>O. T.</title> 641</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆς ἀπῶσαι πατρίδος</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 670 <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆς..ἀπωσθῆναι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπορριφθήσομαι_1017">, ‘cast off’ by his father: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1383"> <title>O. C.</title> 1383</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δ’ ἔρρ’ ἀπόπτυστός τε κἀπάτωρ ἐμοῦ</quote>. The fulness of phrase is like that in 830 <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιφθῶ ..πρόβλητος</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοῦλος_φανείς_1020">, ‘made out, represented, in his taunts, to be a slave.’ For <quote xml:lang="grc"> φανείς</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1241">cp. 1241</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ πανταχοῦ φανούμεθ’ ἐκ Τεύκρου κακοί</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 593">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 593</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγοις τοιούτοις πλαγκτὸς οὖσ’ ἐφαινόμην</quote>. The vague </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγοισιν_1020"> could mean either (1) Telamon's words,—schol., <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῖς τοῦ πατρὸς λοιδορίαις</quote>,—which is perhaps the best explanation: or (2) the common talk of men. <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγοισιν</quote> further implies that he is <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔργῳ ἐλεύθερος</quote>, and this is emphasised by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντ_ἐλευθέρου_1020">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 454">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 454</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τυφλὸς..ἐκ δεδορκότος | καὶ πτωχὸς ἀντὶ πλουσίου</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παῦρα_1022"> need not be taken as= <quote xml:lang="grc">παῦροι</quote> (like <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ χρηστὰ</quote> for <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς χρηστὰς</quote> in <ref n="Eur. El. 972"> <title>El.</title> 972</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ..πανοῦργα</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 448"> <title>Ph.</title> 448</ref>, etc.). The sense is simply, ‘few helpful things,’— few resources. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὑρόμην_1023">, with irony, ‘gained’: <ref n="Aesch. PB 267">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 267</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θνητοῖς ἀρήγων αὐτὸς ηὑρόμην πόνους</quote>. In <title> Helen.</title> 94 Teucer says, <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴας μ’ ἀδελφὸς ὤλεσ’ ἐν Τροίᾳ θανών</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦδ_κνώδοντος_1025">, lit., ‘this gleaming spike,’—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the end or point of the sword-blade, projecting through the body of Ajax. <quote xml:lang="grc">κνώδων</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">κνάω, ὀδούς</quote>) meant any tooth-like prong or spike: see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1233"> <title>Ant.</title> 1233</ref>, where the <quote xml:lang="grc">ξίφους διπλοῖ κνώδοντες</quote> are the cross-pieces of the sword-hilt. Some suppose that here, too, <quote xml:lang="grc">κνώδοντος</quote> denotes the handle of the sword, against which the corpse is resting. But there are at least two decisive objections to that view,—(1) the singular number, (2) the epithet <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰόλου</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρα_1025"> after </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φονέως_1025">, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 233">cp. 233</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶδες_1025">, ‘seest thou?’ (a rhetorical apostrophe to the corpse). The aor. is used as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1221"> <title>Tr.</title> 1221</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔγνως</quote> (‘thou art right’). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_ἀποφθίσειν_1027">. As Heracles says of Nessus, <quote xml:lang="grc">ζῶντά μ’ ἔκτεινεν θανών</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1163"> <title>Tr.</title> 1163</ref>(n.). In Homer the fut. <quote xml:lang="grc">φθίσω</quote> and the aor. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἔφθισα</quote> always have <quote xml:lang="grc">ι—</quote>. The Attic poets use <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφθισα</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">ι^</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 173">Aesch. <title> Eum.</title> 173</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 202">Soph. <title>O. T.</title> 202</ref>, etc.); this is the only Attic example of the fut. <quote xml:lang="grc">φθίσω</quote>. (The form <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀποφθιεῖν</quote>, which Dindorf once read here, has no authority, and is contrary to analogy.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκέψασθε_τάδε_1039">. The grounds on which Morstadt and Nauck reject these twelve verses are considered in the Appendix. It is clear, I think, that the verses are genuine. If they were absent, Teucer's speech would end abruptly with v. 1027, and the Chorus could not well say, <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ τεῖνε μακράν</quote> (1040). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾧ_πάρα_1029">, ‘the same with which he had been presented by Ajax.’ <quote xml:lang="grc">δωροῦμαί τινά τινι</quote>, and <quote xml:lang="grc">δωροῦμαί τινί τι</quote>, are equally good constructions (the former being preferred when the notion of <emph>honour</emph> is prominent); but, when <quote xml:lang="grc">δωροῦμαι</quote> is passive, the subject is usually the gift, not the person (see, <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, <title> Polit.</title> 274 C, <ref n="Lucian Tim. 47"> <title>Tim.</title> 47</ref>C). Here, however, the stress marked by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾧ_δὴ_1029"> is on the identity of the girdle, not of the man; and the subject of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐδωρήθη</quote> is Hector.— As to the exchange of gifts between Ajax and Hector ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.303"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 303</ref> ff.), see n. on 661. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρισθεὶς_ἀντύγων_1030">, firmly bound — <emph> gripped</emph> from the chariot-rail. The schol. explains <quote xml:lang="grc">πρισθείς</quote> by <quote xml:lang="grc">δεθείς</quote>: Suidas, by <quote xml:lang="grc">δεθείς, ἐξαφθείς, δεσμευθείς</quote>. The senses of <quote xml:lang="grc">πρίω</quote> are:—1. To <emph>saw.</emph> 2. In <quote xml:lang="grc">πρίειν τοὺς ὀδόντας</quote>, to <emph>grind</emph> or <emph>clench</emph> the teeth. Suidas quotes <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμπρίσαντες τοὺς ὀδόντας</quote> (said of men under torture). 3. To <emph>bite:</emph> Soph. fr. 811 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀδόντι πρῖε τὸ στόμα</quote>. 4. To <emph>clutch tightly</emph> (as with the teeth). Oppian <ref n="Opp. H. 2. 138">Opp. <title> Hal.</title> 2. 138</ref> describes a serpent winding its coils round an <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐχῖνος</quote> (hedgehog): <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴσχει τ’ ἐμπρίει τε</quote>, ‘he holds <emph>and compresses</emph> him’ (schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">πιέζει</quote>). So Hesychius: <quote xml:lang="grc">πρισμοῖς· ταῖς βιαίοις κατοχαῖς</quote> (‘grips’). Hence <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπρίξ, ἄπριγδα</quote>, <emph> mordicus</emph>, ‘tightly’ (as between the teeth): see above, <ref n="Opp. H. 5.310.">Opp. Hal. v. 310.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντύγων_1030">, the rail which protected the front and both sides of the chariot (hence the plur.): see on <ref n="Eur. El. 746."> <title>El.</title> 746.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱππικῶν_1030">, as in Homer <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵπποι</quote> often=‘chariot’: so <ref n="Eur. El. 730"> <title>El.</title> 730</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ναυαγίων..ἱππικῶν</quote>, ‘wreck of chariots.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκνάπτετ_1031">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 576"> Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 576</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κναπτόμενοι..δίνᾳ</quote> (bodies <emph>mangled</emph> by the waves dashing them against rocks). <quote xml:lang="grc">κνάπτω, κναφεύς, κναφεῖον</quote> were the older Attic forms: <quote xml:lang="grc"> γνάπτω</quote>, etc., with softening of <quote xml:lang="grc">κ</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">γ</quote>, came later. <quote xml:lang="grc"> κναφεύς</quote> appears in an Attic inscr. of the 6th cent. B.C. (<title>C. I. A.</title> IV. 373 f.): the first trace of the <quote xml:lang="grc"> γ</quote> form seems to be <quote xml:lang="grc">γναφεῖον</quote>, in an Attic inscr. of 358 B.C. (<title>C. I. A.</title> II. 817 A, 28): Meisterhans, <title>Gramm. d. Att. Inschr.</title> § 23.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔστ_βίον_1031">. The Homeric Achilles slays Hector in fight, and then drags the corpse ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 22.395"> <title>Il.</title> 22. 395</ref> ff.). Hermann sought to reconcile this verse with Homer by writing, <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>αἰῶν’ εὖτ’</emph> ἀπέψυξεν βίου</quote>: quoting, for <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰῶνα βίου</quote>, the author of a <quote xml:lang="grc">Μελαμποδία</quote> <foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Tzetzes on Lycophron 682, <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεῦ πάτερ, εἴθ’ ἥσσω μὲν ἐμοὶ αἰῶνα βίοιο | ὤφελλες δοῦναι</quote>. There, however, <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰῶνα βίου</quote> means ‘<emph>term</emph> of life.’ Euripides could say, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπέπνευσεν αἰῶνα</quote> (fr. 801); but <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπέψυξεν αἰῶνα βίου</quote> is surely impossible. It would have been better, for Hermann's purpose, to keep <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰέν</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">βίον</quote>, merely changing <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔστ’</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖτ’</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δωρεὰν_ἔχων_1032">. The form <quote xml:lang="grc">δωρειά</quote> is quoted by Meisterhans from three Attic inscriptions belonging to the second half of the 5th century B.C.: <quote xml:lang="grc">δωρεά</quote> appears first in 403 B.C., and does not become the predominant form till the early part of the 3rd century B.C. (<title>Gramm.</title> § 10. 4). The Hesychian by-form <quote xml:lang="grc">δωριά</quote> is also significant. Curtius, who remarks that <quote xml:lang="grc">δωρ‐εά</quote> is properly a collective (like <quote xml:lang="grc">μυρμηκ‐ιά</quote> etc.), meaning ‘a number of gifts,’ adds: ‘the original form was <quote xml:lang="grc"> δωρειά</quote>, in which the <quote xml:lang="grc">ε</quote> is of the same kind as that of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵππε‐ιο‐ς, ταύρε‐ιο‐ς’</quote> (<title>Etym.</title> vol. II. p. 244, Eng. ed.). Wecklein may be right in giving <quote xml:lang="grc">δωρειὰν</quote> here. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_τοῦδ_1033">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_κνώδοντος_1033">. This would be clearer if <quote xml:lang="grc">τόδε..ἔχων</quote> had preceded, but the pronoun (<quote xml:lang="grc">τήνδε</quote>) has been assimilated to <quote xml:lang="grc">δωρεὰν</quote> by the ordinary Greek idiom (see on <ref n="Soph. OC 88"> <title>O. C.</title> 88</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ταύτην ἔλεξε παῦλαν</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἐρινὺς_ἐχάλκευσε_1034">: so <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 646">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 646</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Δίκας δ’ ἐρείδεται πυθμήν</quote> (anvil), | <quote xml:lang="grc">προχαλκεύει δ’ Αἶσα φασγανουργός</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1535">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1535</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δίκην δ’ ἐπ’ ἄλλο πρᾶγμα θηγάνει βλάβης | πρὸς ἄλλαις θηγάναισι Μοῖρα</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δημιουργὸς_1034">, a general term for any artificer ( <ref n="Plat. Rep. 373B">Plat. <title>Rep.</title> 373B</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκευῶν..παντοδαπῶν δημιουργοί</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγὼ_οὖν_1036">, which has better authority than <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ μὲν ἄν</quote>, is also intrinsically better, since <quote xml:lang="grc">οὖν</quote> serves to link this concluding sentiment with what precedes.—The active </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηχανᾶν_1036"> occurs nowhere else in classical Greek, except in <ref n="Hom. Od. 18.143"> <title>Od.</title> 18. 143</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηχανόωντας</quote> (Apoll. Rhod. 3. 583 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπέρβια μηχανόωντες</quote>). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1129">Cp. 1129</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτίμα</quote>, a solitary instance in Attic of the Homeric verb <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀτιμᾶν</quote>. In the <title>Thyestes</title> (fr. 247) Sophocles used <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐντέλλω</quote> as= <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐντέλλομαι</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_φίλα_1038">, acceptable ‘<emph>in</emph> his judgment,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, when he ponders them. Distinguish the phrase in <ref n="Hdt. 6. 37"> Her. 6. 37</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦν δὲ ὁ Μιλτιάδης Κροίσῳ..ἐν γνώμῃ γεγονώς</quote>, ‘had won his esteem.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεῖνός_ἐκεῖνα_1038"> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</foreign>, an expression of settled conviction, serving to close the speech, as in <ref n="Soph. OC 1665"> <title>O. C.</title> 1665</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δὲ μὴ δοκῶ φρονῶν λέγειν</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν παρείμην οἶσι μὴ δοκῶ φρονεῖν</quote>. Milton imitates this trait of Greek tragic style in Dalila's last words to Samson:—‘<title>At this whoever envies or repines</title>, | <title>I leave him to his lot</title>, <emph>and like my own</emph>’ (<title>Sams.</title> 995). For the sentiment cp. <title> Suppl.</title> 466 <quote xml:lang="grc">σοὶ μὲν δοκείτω ταῦτ’, ἐμοὶ δὲ τἀντία</quote>. Evenus fr. 1. 4 (Bergk) <quote xml:lang="grc">σοὶ μὲν ταῦτα δοκοῦντ’ ἔστω, ἐμοὶ δὲ τάδε</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_μακράν_1040">: so <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1296">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1296</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μακρὰν ἔτεινας</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 916 <quote xml:lang="grc">μακρὰν γὰρ ἐξέτεινας</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Hec. 1177">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 1177</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς δὲ μὴ μακροὺς τείνω λόγους</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοῖς_γελῶν_1042">: the simple dat., as in 957 <quote xml:lang="grc">γελᾷ..ἄχεσιν</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἃ_δὴ_1042">, in the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷα δή</quote>, is very rare; Simonides Amorg. fr. 1. 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφήμεροι | ἃ δὴ βότ’ αἰεὶ ζῶμεν</quote>. So <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃ</quote> without <quote xml:lang="grc">δὴ</quote> in <ref n="Nic. Alex. 215">Nicander <title>Alex.</title> 215</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">βοάᾳ, ἅ τις ἐμπελάδην φώς κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_ἄνδρα_1044">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς δ’ ἐστὶν ἀνὴρ ὅντιν’</quote>, the antecedent being attracted into the relative clause: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1040"> <title>El.</title> 1040</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴρηκας ὀρθῶς ᾧ σὺ πρόσκεισαι κακῷ</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1060"> <title>Tr.</title> 1060</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔθ’ Ἑλλὰς οὔτ’ ἄγλωσσος οὔθ’ ὅσην ἐγὼ | γαῖαν καθαίρων ἱκόμην</quote>. So in Latin, <title>De Legg.</title> 3. 5. 12 <emph>haec est enim</emph>, <emph>quam Scipio laudat in libris et quam maxime probat</emph> temperationem <emph> reipublicae.</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾧ_δὴ_1045">, dat. of interest (where we might rather have expected the stronger <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗ χάριν</quote>), as in <ref n="Soph. OC 1673"> <title>O. C.</title> 1673</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾧτινι τὸν πολὺν | ... πόνον...εἴχομεν</quote>, and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 508 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς τεκοῦσι γὰρ | οὐδ’ εἰ πονεῖ τις κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλοῦν_ἐστείλαμεν_1045">, as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 911"> <title>Ph.</title> 911</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν πλοῦν στελεῖν</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθεῖν_δυσπετής_1046">. Menelaüs, king of Lacedaemon ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 11.460"> <title>Od.</title> 11. 460</ref>), is for Attic Tragedy a type of Spartan harshness and arrogance. In <ref n="Eur. Andr. 458">Eur. <title> Andr.</title> 458</ref> he is called <quote xml:lang="grc">γοργὸς ὁπλίτης</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗτος_φωνῶ_1047">. In the older printed editions, from the Aldine onwards, a point of some kind is placed after <quote xml:lang="grc">φωνῶ</quote>, to show that <quote xml:lang="grc">σὲ φωνῶ</quote> is parenthetic (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 73">cp. 73</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴαντα φωνῶ</quote>),—<quote xml:lang="grc"> συγκομίζειν</quote> being taken as an infinitive serving for an imperative. Lobeck, who adheres to this view, remarks that there is no other instance of <quote xml:lang="grc">φωνῶ τινα</quote> (=<emph>iubeo</emph>) with infin. This is true; nevertheless it seems probable that <quote xml:lang="grc">φωνῶ</quote> here is used as a verb of ‘commanding’ with the inf., like <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγω</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 101"> <title>Ph.</title> 101</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶπον</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐννέπω</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 932"> <title>O. C.</title> 932</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐδῶ</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 1630), and <quote xml:lang="grc"> φημί</quote> (below, <ref n="Soph. OC 1108"> O. C. 1108</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νεκρὸν_συγκομίζειν_1047">, to aid in paying funeral rites to the corpse. For <quote xml:lang="grc">κομίζειν</quote>, said with ref. to the dead, see <ref n="Eur. El. 1114."> <title>El.</title> 1114.</ref>In <ref n="Plut. Sull. 38">Plut. <title> Sull.</title> 38</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔφθη τὸ σῶμα συγκομισθέν</quote>, the sense is, ‘the obsequies were already completed’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">συγ‐</quote>), <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> the body had been consumed on the pyre. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνήλωσας_1049">. Attic inscriptions, from the 5th cent. B.C. onwards, show that the aor. and perf. of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναλόω</quote> regularly took the temporal augment. No unaugmented form (such as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάλωσα</quote>) occurs in them. See Meisterhans, § 40. 6, who quotes Moeris, p. 23: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνηλωμένον Ἀττικῶς, ἀναλωμένον Ἑλληνικῶς</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> in the <quote xml:lang="grc">κοινὴ διάλεκτος</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκοῦντ_ἐμοί_1050">: this is the acc. neut. plur. (not acc. sing. agreeing with <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγον</quote>), and answers the question <quote xml:lang="grc">τίνος χάριν</quote>,...the partic. having a causal force: ‘I speak because these things seem good to me,’ etc. (Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Seven 1005">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 1005</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκοῦντα καὶ δόξαντ’ ἀπαγγέλλειν με χρὴ | δῆμου προβούλοις κ.τ.λ.</quote>)</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκοῦντα_δ_1050"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκείνῳ</quote> ) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_στρατοῦ_1050">: for the omission of the antecedent in dative, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1123"> <title>El.</title> 1123</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δόθ’, ἥτις ἐστί, προσφέροντες</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 35"> <title>Ant.</title> 35</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς ἃν τούτων τι δρᾷ</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">φόνον προκεῖσθαι</quote>.—The full expression would be, <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκοῦντα μὲν ἐμοί, δοκοῦντα δ’ ἐκείνῳ</quote>: but in such ‘anaphora’ the <quote xml:lang="grc">μέν</quote> is often omitted: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1342"> <title>O. C.</title> 1342</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">στήσω σ’ ἄγων</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">στήσω δ’ ἐμαυτόν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 906"> <title>Ant.</title> 906</ref> f. (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προθείς_1051">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">κελεύεις</quote>, supplied from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνήλωσας λόγον</quote> (1049). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 800">Cp. 800</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ ποτ’ ἀνθρώπων μαθών;</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπίζει</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλπίσαντες_ἄγειν_1052">, not <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄξειν</quote>, because the sense is, ‘having formed the expectation that we <emph>were</emph> bringing him (to be) an ally,’ etc.; not, ‘that we <emph>should bring</emph> him.’ So 799 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπίζει φέρειν</quote>, ‘forebodes that it <emph> tends.</emph>’ Ajax, as Teucer points out at v. 1097, was not ‘brought’ at all, but came of his free will. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζητοῦντες_1054"> seems to be rightly explained in the Triclinian scholium by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξετάζοντες</quote>, ‘on trial’: but the use of the word is peculiar: its ordinary sense, when joined with <quote xml:lang="grc">εὑρίσκω</quote>, may be seen in <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 96">Ar. <title>Ran.</title> 96</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γόνιμον δὲ ποιητὴν ἂν οὐχ εὕροις ἔτι | ζητῶν ἄν</quote> (if you searched for one). Here, it could doubtless mean, ‘on inquiry’ (into the slaughter of the cattle); but this sense is too narrow for the context.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φρυγῶν_1054">=</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Τρώων_1054">. In the <title>Iliad</title>, the Trojans and Phrygians are distinct, though allied, peoples: thus Priam helps the Phrygians against the Amazons ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 3.184"> <title>Il.</title> 3. 184</ref>—189). Post-homeric Greek poets came to use <quote xml:lang="grc">Φρύγες</quote> as a synonym for <quote xml:lang="grc">Τρῶες</quote>, because, when Aeolian colonies were first founded in western Mysia, the country was subject to the Phrygians (cp. Kiepert, <title>Anc. Geo.</title> 66). <ref n="Eur. Hec. 4">Eur. <title> Hec.</title> 4</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Φρυγῶν πόλιν</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc">Τροίαν</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1480">Eur. <title> Or.</title> 1480</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἕκτωρ ὁ Φρύγιος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στρατῷ_ξύμπαντι_1055">, as in 726 he is called <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιβουλευτὴς στρατοῦ</quote>. His design had been against the chiefs (57 f.), the authors of his wrong; but that wrong had also embittered him against the whole Greek army (844). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δορί_1056">. Several editors write <quote xml:lang="grc">δόρει</quote> here, on account of the <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐλοιδόρει</quote>: which may, however, have been originally <quote xml:lang="grc">γρ. ὡς ἕλοι δόρει</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, merely a marginal note of <quote xml:lang="grc">δόρει</quote> as an alternative form. Metre requires <quote xml:lang="grc">δόρει</quote> in <ref n="Soph. OC 620"> <title>O. C.</title> 620</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OC 1314"> O. C. 1314</ref> , <ref n="Soph. OC 1386"> O. C. 1386</ref>: but there is no reason to doubt that Sophocles could also use the ordinary form <quote xml:lang="grc">δορί</quote>, as Aesch. ( IIIAesch. <title>Ag.</title>) and Eur. ( <ref n="Eur. Hec. 5">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 5</ref>) certainly did. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεῶν_τις_1057">: only Odysseus knows who it was.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔσβεσεν_1057">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1149">cp. 1149</ref> : <ref n="Soph. OC 422"> <title>O. C.</title> 422</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔριν κατασβέσειαν</quote>: Critias fr. 1. 40 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν ἀνομίαν τε τοῖς φόβοις κατέσβεσεν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τήνδ_τύχην_1058">, best taken as a ‘cognate’ acc. with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανόντες_1058">, like <ref n="Hom. Il. 3.417"> <title>Il.</title> 3. 417</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακὸν οἶτον ὄληαι</quote>, <ref n="Hom. Od. 1.166"> <title>Od.</title> 1. 166</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπὁλωλε κακὸν μόρον</quote>. If the words </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἣν_τύχην_1058"> stood without </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τήνδ_1058">, they could be taken as acc. in apposition with <quote xml:lang="grc">θανόντες ἂν προὐκ</quote>.: but, with <quote xml:lang="grc">τήνδ’</quote>, such a constr. would be awkward. The easy remedy, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαχόντες_1058"> for <quote xml:lang="grc">θανόντες</quote>, should not be admitted; this is a case in which the harder reading is, as such, the more probable.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προὐκείμεθ_1058">, prostrate in death, as <ref n="Aesch. Seven 965">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 965</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόκεισαι</quote>. Cp. above, <ref n="Aesch. Seven 427.">Aesch. Theb. 427.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰσχίστῳ_1058">, most ignominious; as they would have been assassinated, not slain in fight. The epithet reflects, in fact, on <title>Ajax</title>; commentators who did not see this suggested the feebler </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐχθίστῳ_1058"> or </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀθλίῳ_1058">. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνήλλαξεν_1060">, changed its direction, schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντέστρεψε.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μῆλα_ποίμνας_1060">, ‘sheep and cattle’: <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖμναι</quote> being used here (as in 42 and 300) in the wider sense, so as to include herds of oxen: see 53 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸν_1060"> is resumed and more closely defined by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σῶμα_1060">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1149">cp. 1149</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">βοήν</quote> after <quote xml:lang="grc">σέ</quote>, etc.): <ref n="Soph. OT 819"> <title>O. T.</title> 819</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τάδ’ οὔτις ἄλλος ἦν | ἢ )γὼ )π’ ἐμαυτῷ τάσδ’ ἀρὰς ὁ προστιθείς</quote>. Similarly <ref n="Soph. Trach. 287"> <title>Tr.</title> 287</ref> ff. <quote xml:lang="grc">νιν</quote> after <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυμβεῦσαι_τάφῳ_1060">: Lycophron 154 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐτύμβευσεν τάφῳ</quote>. <title>Thesm.</title> 885 <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ δ’ ἐτυμβεύθη τάφῳ;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφὶ_ψάμαθον_1064">, ‘somewhere on the sand.’ The phrase implies scornful indifference as to the precise place, just as in <ref n="Eur. Andr. 215">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 215</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἀμφὶ Θρῄκην</quote>.. | <quote xml:lang="grc">τύραννον ἔσχες ἄνδρα</quote>, ‘somewhere in Thrace.’ Cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.706"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 706</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφί τε ἄστυ | ἔρδομεν ἱρὰ θεοῖς</quote>, ‘about’ the city, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign> here and there in it.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χλωρὰν_1064">, ‘yellow.’ The epithet serves to call up more vividly a picture of the desolate sea-shore, where the corpse is to lie unburied. Cp. <ref n="Verg. A. 5. 374">Verg. <title> Aen.</title> 5. 374</ref> <emph>fulva moribundum extendit arena.</emph> <quote xml:lang="grc">χλωρός</quote>, primarily an epithet of young verdure (<quote xml:lang="grc">χλόη</quote>), sometimes means ‘yellow’ or ‘yellowish’; a sense found in the kindred Sanskrit <foreign xml:lang="sanskrit">hAris</foreign> and Lat. <foreign xml:lang="lat"> helvus</foreign> (Curt. <title>Etym.</title> § 197). <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.631"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 631</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέλι χλωρόν</quote>. In <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1132"> <title>Ant.</title> 1132</ref> the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc"> χλωρὰ..ἀκτὰ</quote> (‘green’) is defined by the further epithet <quote xml:lang="grc">πολυστάφυλος</quote>.—The sense ‘moist’ is preferred here by Prof. Campbell (‘that part of the sands which the sea has moistened’).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λευρὰν_1064">, the conjecture of Burges ( <ref n="Eur. Hec. 699">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 699</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ψαμάθῳ λευρᾷ</quote>), did not deserve to be received by Wecklein. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄρνισι_1065">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 830">cp. 830</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥιφθῶ κυσὶν πρόβλητος οἰωνοῖς θ’ ἕλωρ</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_ταῦτα_1066">: 971 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξάρῃς_1066"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">α—</quote>): cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 914"> <title>O. T.</title> 914</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑψοῦ γὰρ αἴρει θυμόν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_δυνήθημεν_1067">, ‘granting that we were unable.’ Cp. <ref n="Thuc. 3. 40">Thuc. 3. 40</ref>§ 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ γὰρ οὗτοι ὀρθῶς ἀπέστησαν, ὑμεῖς ἂν οὐ χρεὼν ἄρχοιτε</quote>, ‘assuming that they were right to revolt, your rule would be unwarrantable.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χερσὶν_παρευθύνοντες_1069">, ‘guiding him with our hands’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 542">cp. 542</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χερσὶν εὐθύνων</quote>, said of guiding a child's steps. ‘He will be docile enough now, and will go whither our hands guide him’ (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the body shall be laid where we please). Then </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χερσὶν_1069"> suggests the bitter comment, (‘our <emph>hands</emph>, I say,) for our <emph>words</emph> were at all times lost upon him.’ For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπου_1069">, cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 448"> <title>O. T.</title> 448</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ ἔσθ’ ὅπου μ’ ὀλεῖς</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοῦ_ἀνδρὸς_1071">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">πρός</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 319">cp. 319</ref>. These remarks on authority and obedience are suggested by the alleged insubordination of Ajax, who (in disregard of Homeric conditions) is styled <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνὴρ δημότης</quote>, in contrast to <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ ἐφεστῶτες</quote>, —<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> the Atreidae. (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 945">Cp. 945</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφεστᾶσι</quote>.) The tone of Menelaüs here recalls that of Creon in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 663"> <title>Ant.</title> 663</ref>—676.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρα_1071">, coming after <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀνδρός</quote>, is thought too inelegant by some critics, who replace it by Reiske's conjecture, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄντα_1071">. But it may be doubted whether a Greek ear would have been offended; the words <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρα δημότην</quote> closely cohere, and the emphasis falls, first on <quote xml:lang="grc">κακοῦ</quote>, and then on <quote xml:lang="grc">δημότην</quote>. The phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνὴρ δημότης</quote> occurs in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 690"> <title>Ant.</title> 690</ref> and <title>Nub.</title> 1219. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1093">Cp. 1093</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρες, ἄνδρα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλῶς_ἄν_1073">, ‘have a prosperous course.’ <ref n="Thuc. 5. 16">Thuc. 5. 16</ref>§ I <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖ φερόμενος ἐν στρατηγίαις</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Ec. 5.17">Xen. <title>Oecon.</title> 5. 17</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖ..φερομένης τῆς γεωργίας</quote> </cit> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔνθα_μὴ_1073"> with subjunct. (without <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote>), as in <ref n="Soph. OT 316"> <title>O. T.</title> 316</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα μὴ τέλη | λύῃ. <emph>καθεστήκῃ</emph> </quote>, which L supports, seems slightly better here than <quote xml:lang="grc"> καθεστήκοι</quote>, which would make the statement more abstract or hypothetical. Similarly in 1081 we have <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπου..παρῇ</quote>. (On the other hand, in such a passage as <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1235"> <title>Tr.</title> 1235</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ταῦτ’ ἄν, ὅστις μὴ )ξ ἀλαστόρων νοσοῖ</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕλοιτο;</quote> the optative is clearly better than <quote xml:lang="grc">νοσῇ</quote>.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φόβου_πρόβλημα_1076">, a screen ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1008"> <title>Ph.</title> 1008</ref> n.), a defence, afforded by fear,— the gen. defining that in which the defence consists; cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 682"> <title>El.</title> 682</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσχημ’ ἀγῶνος</quote> , <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 857 <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐλπίδων..ἀρωγαί.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰδοῦς_1076">. The schol. on 1074 quotes from Epicharmus, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα δέος, ἐνταῦθα καὶ αἰδώς</quote>: cp. <title>Euthyphr.</title> p. 12 B, where Socrates quotes from Stasînus, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵνα γὰρ δέος, ἔνθα καὶ αἰδώς</quote>,—remarking that we ought rather to say, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵνα μὲν αἰδώς, ἔνθα καὶ δέος· οὐ μέντοι, ἵνα γε δέος, πανταχοῦ αἰδώς</quote>. The sentiment of Menelaüs is genuinely Spartan. <ref n="Plut. Cleom. 9">Plut. <title> Cleom.</title> 9</ref> dwells on the place of <quote xml:lang="grc"> φόβος</quote> in Spartan government: <quote xml:lang="grc">τιμῶσι δὲ τὸν φόβον...τὴν πολιτείαν μάλιστα συνέχεσθαι φόβῳ νομίζοντες</quote>. The Aeschylean Athena, too, counsels <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ τὸ δεινὸν πᾶν πόλεως ἔξω βαλεῖν</quote> ( <ref n="Plut. Eum. 698">Plut. <title>Eum.</title> 698</ref>), but there the basis of the <emph>fear</emph> is to be <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰδώς</quote>,—the <quote xml:lang="grc">σέβας</quote> (690) for the Areiopagus. As at Sparta there was a shrine of <quote xml:lang="grc">Φόβος</quote> ( <foreign xml:lang="lat">Plut. l.c.</foreign>), so at Athens there was an altar of <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἰδώς</quote> ( <ref n="Paus. 1. 17. 1">Paus. 1. 17. 1</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἂν_μέγα_1077">: cp. the phrases <quote xml:lang="grc">φῦσαι φρένας</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 804"> <title>O. C.</title> 804</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">πτερά</quote> ( <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 785">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 785</ref>), etc.: <ref n="Hdt. 5. 91"> Her. 5. 91</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν βασιλέα ἡμέων..ἐξέβαλε, δόξαν δὲ φύσας αὐξάνεται</quote>. The words allude to the stature of the <quote xml:lang="grc">πελώριος Αἴας</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 3.229"> <title>Il.</title> 3. 229</ref>), but are meant also to be figurative; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Shak. JC 1.2.135">Shakesp. <title>Julius Caesar</title> 1. 2. 135</bibl> <quote xml:lang="eng">Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world | Like a colossus, and we petty men | Walk under his huge legs.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world |
							Like a colossus, and we petty men | Walk under his huge legs.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἂν_κακοῦ_1077">,=<quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἐὰν</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">πέσῃ</quote>): cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1482"> <title>El.</title> 1482</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλά μοι πάρες | κἂν σμικρὸν εἰπεῖν</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἐὰν σμικρὸν παρῇς</quote>: <ref n="Dem. 2.14">Dem. or. 2 § 14</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ὅποι τις ἄν, οἶμαι, προσθῇ κἂν μικρὰν δύναμιν, πάντ’ ὠφελεῖ</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> , <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἐάν τις προσθῇ</quote>. We cannot here well take </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἂν_1077"> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἅν</quote> (the conditional particle), and suppose that it belongs to <quote xml:lang="grc">πεσεῖν</quote> understood. (See appendix on <ref n="Eur. El. 1482."> <title>El.</title> 1482.</ref>)—For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπὸ_1077"> denoting result, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 695"> <title>Ant.</title> 695</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπ’ ἔργων εὐκλεεστάτων φθίνει</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόσεστιν_1079">, said of an attribute or quality: 521 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰσχύνη_1079">, <emph>verecundia</emph>, here virtually an equivalent of <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰδώς</quote>, as in <ref n="Thuc. 1. 84">Thuc. 1. 84</ref>§ 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰδὼς σωφροσύνης πλεῖστον μετέχει, αἰσχύνης δὲ εὐψυχία</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπου_παρῇ_1081">, without <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἄν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1074">cp. 1074</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βούλεται_1081">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τις</quote>: cp. <ref n="Plat. Apol. 29B">Plat. <title> Apol.</title> 29B</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἀμαθία ἐστὶν αὕτη ἡ ἐπονείδιστος, ἡ τοῦ οἴεσθαι εἰδέναι ἃ οὐκ οἶδεν</quote> <emph>; </emph> <ref n="Crito 49">Crito 49</ref>C <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε ἄρα ἀνταδικεῖν δεῖ...οὐδένα ἀνθρώπων, οὐδ’ ἂν ὁτιοῦν πάσχῃ ὑπ’ αὐτῶν</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νόμιζε_1082">..</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρόνῳ_πεσεῖν_1082">. It seems best to take <quote xml:lang="grc">πεσεῖν</quote> as representing a gnomic aor., <quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνῳ ποτὲ ἔπεσε</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Plat. Rep. 490C">Plat. <title>Rep.</title> 490C</ref> (quoted by Goodwin, <title>Moods and Tenses</title>, § 159), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγουμένης δὴ ἀληθείας οὐκ ἄν ποτε..φαῖμεν αὐτῇ χορὸν κακῶν ἀκολουθῆσαι</quote>, ‘when truth leads, we never could say that a chorus of evils accompanies her’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἠκολούθησεν</quote>). It may be observed that this view is slightly confirmed by the words </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_δραμοῦσαν_1082">, which clearly mean, ‘<emph> after</emph> running before favouring winds’ (the sense cannot be that the ship is to be <emph>sunk</emph> by a fatal <quote xml:lang="grc"> οὖρος</quote>): for, if <quote xml:lang="grc">πεσεῖν</quote> is an appeal to experience, then the mention of such a city's transient <emph> prosperity</emph> is fitting; but if <quote xml:lang="grc">πεσεῖν</quote> were a simple prediction, such a clause would be less natural. [I formerly took <quote xml:lang="grc">πεσεῖν</quote> as referring to the future; but now doubt whether <quote xml:lang="grc">νόμιζε</quote>, without more help from the context, could suffice to suggest such a sense. See Appendix on <ref n="Eur. El. 442"> <title>El.</title> 442</ref> f., where I read <quote xml:lang="grc"> δέξεσθαι</quote> for <quote xml:lang="grc">δέξασθαι</quote>. Here we might, of course, write </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποτ_ἂν_1082">, but the change seems needless.]</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_οὐρίων_1082">: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</quote> denotes the condition; cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 486"> <title>O. C.</title> 486</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ εὐμενῶν | στέρνων δέχεσθαι</quote>. For the neut. plur. <quote xml:lang="grc"> οὐρίων</quote>, cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Lys. 550">Ar. <title>Lys.</title> 550</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔρια θεῖτε</quote> (adv.). Lobeck quotes <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ οὐρίων πλεῖν</quote> from Libanius 2. 421. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ οὐρίας πλεῖν</quote> occurs in Polyb. 1. 47. 2, etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑστάτω_1084">, be firmly set, as a principle, in the State; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1074">cp. 1074</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> καθεστήκῃ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοι_1084">, ethic dat. (‘let me see it established.’) Cp. <ref n="Plut. Cleom. 9">Plut. <title>Cleom.</title> 9</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">διὸ καὶ παρὰ τὸ τῶν ἐφόρων συσσίτιον τὸν Φόβον ἵδρυνται Λακεδαιμόνιοι.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_δέος_1084">, ‘fear also’ —to temper natural <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕβρις</quote> (1081). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καίριον_1084">, in due season and measure; as the Eumenides say, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔσθ’ ὅπου τὸ δεινὸν εὖ | καὶ φρενῶν ἐπίσκοπον | δεῖ μένειν καθήμενον</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 517"> <title>Eum.</title> 517</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἃν_ἡδώμεθα_1085">: the cogn. acc. with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥδομαι, λυπεῖσθαι</quote>, etc., is frequent (cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 2">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 2</ref> f.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ἀντιτείσειν_1085">: for the spelling <quote xml:lang="grc">τείσω</quote>, etc., see on <ref n="Soph. OT 810."> <title>O. T.</title> 810.</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ</quote> with inf. is normal after a verb of saying or thinking (n. on <ref n="Soph. OT 1455"> <title>O. T.</title> 1455</ref>).— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἃνλυπώμεθα_1085">: for the assonance (parechesis) at the end of two successive verses, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 807">cp. 807</ref> f., <ref n="Soph. Phil. 121"> <title>Ph.</title> 121</ref> f. (<quote xml:lang="grc">παρῄνεσα, συνῄνεσα</quote>), <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1265"> <title>Tr.</title> 1265</ref> f. (<quote xml:lang="grc">συγγνωμοσύνην, ἀγνωμοσύνην</quote>). It is needless to read <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃν λυποίμεθα</quote>, though the optat. might be illustrated by Alcaeus fr. 82 (Bergk) <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴ κ’ εἴπῃς τὰ θέλεις, ἦ κεν ἀκούσαις τά κεν οὐ θέλοις</quote>. Schneidewin quotes also <ref n="Hes. WD 721"> Hes. <title>Op.</title> 721</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δὲ κακὸν εἴπῃς, τάχα κ’ αὐτὸς μεῖζον ἀκούσαις</quote>: Libanius 2. 84 <quote xml:lang="grc">δρῶντες ἅττα ἐθέλουσι πάσχειν δύναιντ’ ἂν ἅττα ἂν οὐκ ἐθέλοιεν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παραλλὰξ_1087">, alternately; so in <ref n="Hdt. 3. 40"> Her. 3. 40</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐναλλὰξ πρήσσων</quote>=‘with alternations of fortune’ (good and evil).— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἴθων_1087">: see on <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴθονος</quote> in 222. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπως_μὴ_1089">: with regard to the division of these words between two vv., see n. on the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆτα</quote> in 986. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_πέσῃς_1090">, come to need funeral rites: <quote xml:lang="grc">πέσῃς</quote> is used, with grim irony, as in such phrases as <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἀνάγκας πίπτειν</quote> ( <ref n="Thuc. 3. 82">Thuc. 3. 82</ref>§ 2). <quote xml:lang="grc">ταφὰς</quote> has its ordinary sense, ‘rites of sepulture,’ as it has also in v. 1109; it does not stand for <quote xml:lang="grc">τάφους</quote>. Herodotus, indeed, uses <quote xml:lang="grc">ταφαί</quote> as=<quote xml:lang="grc">τάφοι</quote>, and employs the plural in that sense even with ref. to a single tomb ( <ref n="Hdt. 5. 63"> Her. 5. 63</ref> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑποστήσας_1091">, after planting them like pillars (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποστῆσαι κίονας, ἐρείσματα</quote>, etc.); or, as we should say, after ‘laying them down’: the word is much more forcible than <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποβαλών</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποθείς.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_θανοῦσιν_1091">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν</quote> , <ref n="Soph. Aj. 43">cp. 43</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρες_1093">. The burning anger of Teucer is marked in his first words by the fact that he addresses them to the <title> Chorus:</title> as Oedipus does after the speech of Polyneices ( <ref n="Soph. OC 1348"> <title>O. C.</title> 1348</ref>), and Clytaemnestra after that of Electra ( <ref n="Soph. El. 612"> <title>El.</title> 612</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδὲν_γοναῖσιν_1094">: the phrase is exactly parallel with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγέννητος</quote> used in the sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσγενής</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Trach. 61"> <title>Tr.</title> 61</ref>). In 1231 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν ὢν</quote> has a like sense. Here <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲν</quote> is ‘generic,’ denoting the class of person. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιαῦθ_ἔπη_1096">, make such erroneous statements; for the cogn. acc., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1107">cp. 1107</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ σέμν’ ἔπη | κόλαζ’ ἐκείνους. <emph>ἐν λόγοις</emph> </quote>, in their discourse. <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγοι</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπη</quote> are similarly combined in <ref n="Thuc. 3. 67">Thuc. 3. 67</ref>§ 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγοι ἔπεσι κοσμηθέντες</quote>, ‘speeches adorned with fine sentiments.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄγειν_1097">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι ἦγες</quote>, as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγειν</quote> in 1053=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι ἤγομεν</quote>: ‘that thou wast bringing him [when he came hither] as an ally found by thee (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαβών_1097">).’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸς_1099">, <emph>sponte sua:</emph> cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.252"> <title>Il.</title> 17. 252</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀργαλέον δέ μοί ἐστι διασκοπιᾶσθαι ἕκαστον | ...ἀλλά τις αὐτὸς ἴτω</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῦ_1100">, on what ground, in what respect? <ref n="Soph. OT 390"> <title>O. T.</title> 390</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ σὺ μάντις εἶ σαφής;</quote> ‘where hast thou proved thyself a seer?’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λεῶν_1100">: the plur. of the Attic form is somewhat rare (except in the formula <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκούετε λεῴ</quote>); Ar. fr. 346 has <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντες λεῴ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤγαγ_1101">, the reading of one MS. (the Palatinus at Heidelberg, written in the 14th century), was doubtless no more than a conjectural emendation; but it appears probable. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡγεῖτ_1101">, the reading of the other MSS., has been defended by Erfurdt and others on the ground that the elision has the effect of running the two words <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγεῖτ’ οἴκοθεν</quote> together, so that they become virtually one. This is just possible; but in tragic iambics we find no certain examples of a precisely similar kind. (As to <quote xml:lang="grc">σήμαιν’ εἴτ’ ἔχει</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 22"> <title>Phil.</title> 22</ref>, see n. there.) If <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤγαγ’</quote> was the original word, the change to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγεῖτ’</quote> may have been caused by failure to perceive that the genitive </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_1101"> (for <quote xml:lang="grc">οὓς</quote>) was due to attraction. Porson (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ap.</foreign> Kidd, <title>Tracts</title>, p. 194) wished to read </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦγεν_1101">, comparing <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.557"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 557</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴας δ’ ἐκ Σαλαμῖνος ἄγεν δυοκαίδεκα νῆας</quote>. The imperfect tense is, of course, free from objection (cp. also <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 341">Aesch. <title> Pers.</title> 341</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ξέρξῃ..χιλιὰς μὲν ἦν | ὧν ἦγε πλῆθος</quote>): but <quote xml:lang="grc">ΗΓΕΝ</quote> was less likely than <quote xml:lang="grc">ΗΓΑΓ</quote> to tempt the correction <quote xml:lang="grc">ΗΓΕΙΤ</quote>. Elmsley's </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤγετ_1101"> (n. on <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 371">Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 371</ref>) is still nearer to the letters of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγεῖτ’</quote>: but the middle voice would be at least very unusual, where the sense is simply that of ‘leading’; in <ref n="Soph. OC 1460">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1460</ref>, indeed, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄξεται</quote> is hardly more than <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄξει</quote>: but in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 613">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 613</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγοιντο</quote> suggests the notion, ‘bring with them, for their own ends.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδ_ὅπου_1103">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1069">cp. 1069</ref>.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόνδε_κοσμῆσαι_1103">, to exercise authority over him. <quote xml:lang="grc">κοσμεῖν</quote> is properly said of a commander disposing his forces; <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.554"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 554</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοσμῆσαι ἵππους τε καὶ ἀνέρας ἀσπιδιώτας</quote>: [Eur. ] <title>Rhes.</title> 662 <quote xml:lang="grc">κοσμήσων στρατόν</quote>. The Atreidae are <quote xml:lang="grc">κοσμήτορε λαῶν</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.16"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 16</ref>). For <quote xml:lang="grc">κοσμεῖν</quote> with ref. to civil government, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 677."> <title>Ant.</title> 677.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρχῆς_θεσμὸς_1103">, an ordinance, an established right, of command. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔκειτο_1103">, had been laid down (<quote xml:lang="grc">κεῖμαι</quote> serving as perf. pass. of <quote xml:lang="grc">τίθημι</quote>): cp. <ref n="Thuc. 5. 105">Thuc. 5. 105</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε θέντες τὸν νόμον, οὔτε κειμένῳ πρῶτοι χρησάμενοι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_σέ_1103">, ‘than for him, <emph>on his part</emph>, to rule thee’: for this <quote xml:lang="grc">καί</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 53"> <title>O. C.</title> 53</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσ’ οἶδα κἀγώ</quote> (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅλων_1105"> here can be only masc. This use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅλοι</quote> as=</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύμπαντες_1105"> elsewhere occurs only in later Greek; Lobeck cites Nonnus (5th cent. A.D. ) <title>Dionysiaca</title> 47. 482 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅλας οἴστρησε γυναῖκας</quote>, and <title>Anthol. Pal.</title> 7. 679. 5 <quote xml:lang="grc">κτήμασι μὲν πολύολβος ὅλων πλέον ὧν τρέφε Κύπρος</quote> (by Sophronius of Damascus, <foreign xml:lang="lat">circ.</foreign> 630 A.D. ). We are scarcely warranted, however, in assuming that a poet of the classical age could not have ventured on such a use.
