The view that <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅλων</quote> is <emph>neuter</emph> (<emph>summae rerum</emph>) is decisively condemned (1) by the direct antithesis with the masc. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλων</quote>, and (2) by the absence of the article, <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ ὅλα</quote> being the invariable phrase in this sense: see, <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, <ref n="Dem. 19.151">Dem. or. 19 § 151</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπὲρ τῶν ὅλων πεισθεὶς εἰρήνην ἄγειν</quote> (‘for the general interests’): or. 22 § 16 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν τῶν ὅλων σωτηρίαν</quote>: <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 8. 7. 22">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 8. 7. 22</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τήνδε τὴν τῶν ὅλων τάξιν</quote> (the universe): Lucian <title>De Luctu</title> c. 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν τῶν ὅλων δεσποτείαν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧνπερ_αρχε_1107">, as Agamemnon says to Achilles, <quote xml:lang="grc">Μυρμιδόνεσσιν ἄνασσε</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.180"> <title>Il.</title> 1. 180</ref>), and Achilles to him, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλοισιν δὴ ταῦτ’ ἐπιτέλλεο, μὴ γὰρ ἐμοί γε</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 574">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 574</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄναξ Ἄπολλον, ὧν ἔχεις αὐτὸς κράτει.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ἐκείνους_1107">: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπη</quote> is a bold cognate acc.; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1096">cp. 1096</ref>: <ref n="Soph. OT 339"> <title>O. T.</title> 339</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπη | κλύων, ἃ νῦν</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ τήνδ’ ἀτιμάζεις πόλιν</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 230">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 230</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δίκας | μέτειμι τόνδε φῶτα</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτε_στρ_1107">.= <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴτε σὺ μὴ φής, εἴτ’ Ἀγαμέμνων μή φησιν</quote>, whether the veto is thine or his. For <quote xml:lang="grc">φημί</quote> as=‘<emph>to command</emph>’ (a rare use), see <ref n="Pind. N. 3"> Pind. <title>N.</title> 3. 28</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἰακῷ σε φαμὶ γένει τε Μοῖσαν φέρειν</quote>. Here the <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote>, despite its place, belongs in sense to the inf. (<quote xml:lang="grc">θεῖναι εἰς ταφὰς</quote>) understood. (<quote xml:lang="grc">οὔ φημι θεῖναι</quote> could mean only, <emph>nego te sepulturum:</emph> this might be referred to the <emph>assertion</emph> of Menelaüs in 1062 f.; but it would be forced.)</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_θήσω_1107">, I will give him due funeral rites: <ref target="cl1090">see on 1090</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στόμα_1107">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1147">cp. 1147</ref> : <ref n="Soph. Ant. 997"> <title>Ant.</title> 997</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐγὼ τὸ σὸν φρίσσω στόμα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_πλέῳ_1112">, the toiling <quote xml:lang="grc">λαοί</quote>, the born subjects of Menelaüs, who are bound to endure the labours of war in any field to which their lord calls them. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Andr. 695">Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 695</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ τῶν πονούντων τοὔργον ἡγοῦνται τόδε</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὁ στρατηγὸς τὴν δόκησιν ἄρνυται</quote>,—where <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ πονοῦντες</quote> are the rank and file. The strangeness which has been felt in the phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ πόνου πολλοῦ πλέῳ</quote>, will perhaps be lessened if we remember how habitually the Attic poets transfer the associations of their own time to the heroic age. In picturing the followers of the Spartan king, Sophocles may have had in mind the Perioeci who served as hoplites and the Helots who served as light-armed in the armies of their Spartan masters.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅρκων_1113">: the oaths sworn to Tyndareus by the suitors of his daughter Helen, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτου γυνὴ γένοιτο Τυνδαρὶς κόρη</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">τούτῳ συναμυνεῖν, εἴ τις ἐκ δόμων λαβὼν | οἴχοιτο</quote> ( <title>I. A.</title> 61). <ref n="Thuc. 1. 9">Thuc. 1. 9</ref>§ 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀγαμέμνων τέ μοι δοκεῖ τῶν τότε δυνάμει προὔχων καὶ οὐ τοσοῦτον τοῖς Τυνδάρεω ὅρκοις κατειλημμένους τοὺς Ἑλένης μνηστῆρας ἄγων τὸν στόλον ἀγεῖραι</quote>. In <ref n="Soph. Phil. 72">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 72</ref>Odysseus says that (unlike the other chiefs) Neoptolemus came to Troy, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνορκος οὐδενί</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_οὐδὲν_1114">: this third clause repeats the thought of the first, <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάρ τι τῆς σῆς κ.τ.λ.</quote>: on this trait of Sophoclean style see <ref n="Soph. Ant. 465"> <title>Ant.</title> 465</ref> ff. (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_μηδένας_1114">, those who are as nought (<quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote> having its generic force),—mere ciphers. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1322"> <title>Ant.</title> 1322</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν οὐκ ὄντα μᾶλλον ἢ μηδένα</quote>. So <title>I. A.</title> 371 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς οὐδένας</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Andr. 700"> <title>Andr.</title> 700</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄντες οὐδένες</quote> , <ref n="Hdt. 9. 58"> Her. 9. 58</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδένες ἄρα ἐόντες</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κήρυκας_1115">. Menelaüs is attended by two heralds, their presence marking the solemn character of his mission. So in the <title>Iliad</title> the chiefs deputed to intercede with Achilles are accompanied by two heralds (9. 170), whom Eustathius (780. 46) compares to the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀργὰ πρόσωπα</quote> of the theatre. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ψόφου_στραφείην_1116">: the gen. is properly causal, ‘turn <emph>for</emph> it,’ and is joined (here only) with the simple verb, as it is regularly joined with <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐντρέπομαι</quote> (90), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιστρέφομαι</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 599"> <title>Ph.</title> 599</ref>), and in <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 1224"> Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 1224</ref> ff. with the act. <quote xml:lang="grc">μεταστρέφειν</quote>: (<quote xml:lang="grc">πῶλοι</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε ναυκλήρου χερὸς | οὔθ’ ἱπποδέσμων οὔτε κολλητῶν ὄχων | μεταστρέφουσαι</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕως_1116">: cp. <title>Phaedr.</title> 243 E <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕωσπερ ἂν ᾖς ὃς εἶ</quote>. This is a certain correction of the traditional reading </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1116">, as it is also in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1330"> <title>Ph.</title> 1330</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως ἂν αὑτὸς ἥλιος | ταύτῃ μὲν αἴρῃ</quote> etc., and in <ref n="Soph. OC 1361"> <title>O. C.</title> 1361</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔωσπερ ἂν ζῶ</quote>. [Hermann explained </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ᾖς_1116"> as <emph>utcunque sis qualis es</emph>, ‘however much you may be what you are,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, <emph>quantumlibet ferocias.</emph> Prof. Campbell understands, ‘However you may be—just what you are,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷοσπερ εἶ</quote> being said, <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὰ προσδοκίαν</quote>, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">βασιλεύς</quote> or the like.] </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδ_αὖ_1118">, ‘neither, again,’—referring to their reproof of Menelaüs in 1092. <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ αὖ</quote> is similarly used in <ref n="Eur. El. 1034."> <title>El.</title> 1034.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_κακοῖς_1118">, because the friends of Ajax have the felling of the Greek chiefs and army against them. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 335"> <title>El.</title> 335</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’ ἐν κακοῖς μοι πλεῖν ὑφειμένῃ δοκεῖ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_τοξότης_1120">. The name of ‘bowman’ was a reproach only when it implied that the archer was not, like the hoplite, ready to meet his foe in close fight. It is in this sense that Diomedes upbraids Paris ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.385"> <title>Il.</title> 11. 385</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">τοξότα, λωβητήρ, κέρᾳ ἀγλαέ</quote>. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 13.313"> <title>Il.</title> 13. 313</ref>Teucer is said to be <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄριστος Ἀχαιῶν | τοξοσύνῃ·</quote> but the poet adds <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγαθὸς δὲ καὶ ἐν σταδίῃ ὑσμίνῃ</quote>. At Athens, where the <quote xml:lang="grc">τοξόται</quote> or city police were slaves (<quote xml:lang="grc">Σκύθαι</quote>, etc.), the word had acquired ignoble associations. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάναυσον_1121">, sordid, unworthy of a freeborn man: Plato joins <quote xml:lang="grc">βάναυσος</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνελεύθερος</quote> (<title>Legg.</title> 644 A). Cp. <ref n="Aristot. Pol. 8.1337b">Arist. <title>Pol.</title> 8. 2</ref>§ 5 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς..τοιαύτας τέχνας, ὅσαι τὸ σῶμα παρασκευάζουσι χεῖρον διακεῖσθαι, βαναύσους καλοῦμεν</quote>. Thus the notion at the root of the word was that of some mechanical (or sedentary) calling which interfered with efficiency in athletics or war. (Compare the taunts of Euryalus to the disguised Odysseus, <ref n="Hom. Od. 8.159."> Hom. <title>Od.</title> 8. 159.</ref>) Teucer might well say that his art was not <quote xml:lang="grc">βάναυσος</quote>: Heracles and Philoctetes were among its masters. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀσπίδ_1122">: the shield of a hoplite, who wore a helmet and breast-plate, and was armed with a pike (<quote xml:lang="grc">δόρυ</quote>); while the bowman, ranking with the light-armed troops, had no defensive armour. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ψιλὸς_ὡπλισμένῳ_1123">. The contrast is illustrated by the case of the Locrians in the <title>Iliad</title>, who came to Troy armed only with bows, and are described as shrinking from the <quote xml:lang="grc">σταδίη ὑσμίνη</quote>, because they were not armed as hoplites:— <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ ἔχον κόρυθας χαλκήρεας ἱπποδασείας</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἔχον ἀσπίδας εὐκύκλους καὶ μείλινα δοῦρα</quote>. ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 13.714"> <title>Il.</title> 13. 714</ref> f.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρέφει_1124">, has in it; <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, his valour <emph>resides</emph> only in his words. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 817"> <title>Tr.</title> 817</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄγκον..τρέφειν</quote> : <ref n="Soph. OT 356"> <title>O. T.</title> 356</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τἀληθὲς γὰρ ἰσχῦον τρέφω</quote>. Dryden: <title>Tongue-valiant hero</title>, <emph>vaunter of thy might</emph> (l. 336 of his Trans. of the Iliad, bk. 1). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξὺν_δικαίῳ_1125">, with right on my side: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1251"> <title>Ph.</title> 1251</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξὺν τῷ δικαίῳ τὸν σὸν οὐ ταρβῶ φόβον</quote>. <cit> <bibl n="Shak. 2H6 3.2">Shakesp. <title>Henry VI.</title> pt. II. 3. 2. 233</bibl> <quote xml:lang="eng">Thrice is he armed that hath his quarrel just.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: Thrice is he armed that hath his quarrel just.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δίκαια_1126">: for the plur., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 887">cp. 887</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σχέτλια</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κτείναντα_1126">: as Creüsa says to her living son ( <ref n="Eur. Ion 1500">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 1500</ref>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔκτεινά σ’ ἄκους’</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, ‘<emph>doomed</emph> thee to perish.’ So <ref n="Soph. OC 1008">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1008</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλέψας τὸν ἱκέτην</quote>, meaning that Creon had <emph> purposed</emph> to seize him. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινόν_εἶπας_1127">: for <quote xml:lang="grc"> γε</quote> in comment, cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 341"> <title>El.</title> 341</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινόν γέ σ’ οὖσαν πατρὸς οὗ σὺ παῖς ἔφυς | κείνου λελῆσθαι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_ζῇς_1127">: here <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> goes closely with <quote xml:lang="grc">ζῇς</quote>, ‘if thou <emph> indeed</emph> livest’: so <ref n="Soph. OT 305"> <title>O. T.</title> 305</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ καὶ μὴ κλύεις</quote> (if <emph>indeed</emph>..): <ref n="Soph. Trach. 71"> <title>Tr.</title> 71</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ καὶ τοῦτ’ ἔτλη</quote>. Distinguish such instances from the ordinary uses of <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ καί</quote> (‘granting that..’), as in <ref n="Soph. OT 408"> <title>O. T.</title> 408</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ καὶ τυραννεῖς</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷδε_οἴχομαι_1128">. The dat. of relation here means, ‘so far as concerns him,’—so far as his intention went; as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1030"> <title>Ph.</title> 1030</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέθνηχ’ ὑμῖν πάλαι</quote>. In 970 above the similar dat. (<quote xml:lang="grc"> θεοῖς</quote>) has a different shade of meaning. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτίμα_1129">. The verb <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀτιμᾶν</quote> is otherwise confined, in classical Greek, to the Homeric poems and hymns. The fut. and aor. occur both in <title>Il.</title>and <title> Od.</title>; the pres. once, in <ref n="Hom. Od. 16.307"> <title>Od.</title> 16. 307</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτιμᾷ</quote>); the imperf. twice ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 21.99"> <title>Od.</title> 21. 99</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτίμα</quote>: 23. 28 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτίμων</quote>, plur.). Nauck would here read <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτίζει</quote>, with Elmsley (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτίζειν</quote> occurs in <ref n="Soph. OC 1153"> <title>O. C.</title> 1153</ref>); but he would also banish <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτιμᾶν</quote> altogether from the epic texts; see Appendix.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοὺς_1129">, a monosyllable by synizesis, as <quote xml:lang="grc">θεός</quote> normally is with Sophocles, when it belongs to the third foot of the trimeter; see 489, <ref n="Soph. OC 964"> <title>O. C.</title> 964</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1020"> <title>Ph.</title> 1020</ref>, fr. 685. In <ref n="Soph. El. 1264"> <title>El.</title> 1264</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">τότ’ εἶδες ὅτε θεοί μ’ ἐπώτρυναν μολεῖν</quote>, we ought probably to read <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖτε. </quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοῖς_σεσωσμένος_1129">: for the dat. of the agent, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 539">cp. 539</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγὼ_ψέξαιμι_1130">..; for <quote xml:lang="grc">γὰρ</quote> in an indignant question, cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1124"> <title>Tr.</title> 1124</ref>: <title>Vesp.</title> 1159 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ γὰρ ἂν τλαίην</quote>..;— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δαιμόνωννόμους_1130">; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1343">Cp. 1343</ref> (Odysseus to Agam.) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάρ τι τοῦτον, ἀλλὰ τοὺς θεῶν νόμους | φθείροις ἄν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_ἐᾷς_1130">. As <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐῶ</quote>=<emph>veto</emph>, <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ</quote> can follow <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 935"> <title>O. C.</title> 935</ref>(n.) <quote xml:lang="grc">βίᾳ τε κοὐχ ἑκὼν</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκων</quote>), after <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρών_1130"> here has an indignant tone,— ‘You <emph> come</emph> and forbid’; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 338">cp. 338</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τούς_αὑτοῦ_1132">: the inserted <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς</quote> emphasises the reflexive pron.; <ref n="Soph. OC 929"> <title>O. C.</title> 929</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχύνεις πόλιν | τὴν αὐτὸς αὑτοῦ</quote> (n.).—For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοῦ_1132">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμαυτοῦ</quote>, see <ref n="Soph. OT 138"> <title>O. T.</title> 138</ref>(n.), <ref n="Soph. OC 966"> <title>O. C.</title> 966</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 285."> <title>El.</title> 285.</ref>— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_καλόν_1132"> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐᾶν θάπτειν αὐτούς</quote>. Ajax was <quote xml:lang="grc">πολέμιος</quote>, a public enemy, ‘worse than any Trojan’ (1054), in view of his intended onslaught. Menelaüs, like Creon ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 284"> <title>Ant.</title> 284</ref> ff.), conceives that refusal of burial to a <quote xml:lang="grc">πολέμιος</quote> is warranted on religious grounds. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοὶ_προὔστη_1133">, ‘stood forth to confront thee.’ For <quote xml:lang="grc">προστῆναι</quote>, see on <ref n="Eur. El. 980."> <title>El.</title> 980.</ref>(In <ref n="Hdt. 1. 129"> Her. 1. 129</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προσστὰς</quote>, not <quote xml:lang="grc">προστὰς</quote>, should probably be read.)— Teucer parries the argument by asking how Ajax could have been the enemy of Menelaüs, a chief on his own side. He thus makes it a personal question between Ajax and Menelaüs whereas the latter had referred to the design of Ajax against the common weal. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μισοῦντ_ἐμίσει_1134">. Cp. <title>Legg.</title> 697 D <quote xml:lang="grc">μισοῦντες μισοῦνται</quote>. Menelaüs ought to have replied, ‘He was the <emph>public</emph> foe’; but, with the maladroitness which characterises him throughout this scene, he plays into Teucer's hands by saying, ‘If he was not <quote xml:lang="grc"> πολέμιος</quote> to me, at least he was <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐχθρός</quote> .’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ψηφοποιὸς_1135">, ‘<emph>making</emph> votes,’ in the sense of procuring them by a secret canvas among the chiefs. The word <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπραξαν</quote> used by Ajax in 446 implies some such intrigue. Cp. Pindar's phrase, <quote xml:lang="grc"> κρυφίαισι...ψάφοις</quote>, in <title>N.</title> 8. 26 (quoted on 447 ff.). Sophocles doubtless conceived the chiefs as voting by <quote xml:lang="grc">ψῆφοι</quote> placed in urns (cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 709">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 709</ref>), and this view appears in art (Introd. § 20). Eustathius remarks the anachronism (on <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.852"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 852</ref>): though, of course, neither <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐψήφισαν</quote> in 449 nor <quote xml:lang="grc"> ψηφοποιός</quote> here necessarily excludes the supposition that the votes were given, in Homeric fashion, by voice.—For other views of <quote xml:lang="grc">ψηφοποιός</quote>, see Appendix.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοῦ_1135"> depends on the phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">κλέπτης ψηφοποιός</quote>, as it might depend on <quote xml:lang="grc">λωβητής</quote> or the like. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_δικασταῖς_1136">, at their hands. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν</quote> is said esp. of a tribunal: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 459"> <title>Ant.</title> 459</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν θεοῖσι τὴν δίκην | δώσειν</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλῶς_1137">, ‘speciously.’ This is clearly a case in which L has preserved a true reading which the other MSS. have lost. Teucer means, ‘It might <emph>seem</emph> to be the judges' doing, while it was really yours.’ The common reading </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακῶς_1137"> misses this point. For <quote xml:lang="grc">καλῶς</quote> in a bad sense, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1047"> <title>Ant.</title> 1047</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">λόγους</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχροὺς καλῶς λέγωσι τοῦ κέρδους χάριν</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλέψειας_κακά_1137">, commit furtive knaveries; <ref target="cl189">see on 189</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλέπτουσι μύθους</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_ἔρχεται_1138">, tends to it, will issue in it (somewhat as in <ref n="Hdt. 1. 120"> Her. 1. 120</ref> it is said of dreams, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς ἀσθενὲς ἔρχεται</quote>): </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τινί_1138">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοί</quote>: for this menacing <quote xml:lang="grc"> τις</quote>, see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 751"> <title>Ant.</title> 751</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανοῦσ’ ὀλεῖ τινά</quote>.—The traditional accentuation, as seen in L and in the Aldine edition, is </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔρχεται_τινί_1138">, the ground of it being that <quote xml:lang="grc">τινί</quote> is here emphatic: so in <title>Categ.</title> 5 § 7 (p. 2 <emph>b</emph> 2) <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ χρῶμα ἐν σώματι· οὐκοῦν καὶ ἐν τινὶ</quote> [not <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔν τινι</quote>] <quote xml:lang="grc">σώματι</quote>. (Cp. Chandler, <title>Accent.</title> § 942.) Some recent editors however write <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρχεταί τινι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_μᾶλλον_1139">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἀνίαν ἐμοὶ ἔρχεται</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">λυπηθησόμεθα</quote> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόνδ_θαπτέον_1140">: for the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχί</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1330">cp. 1330</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ γὰρ εἴην οὐκ ἂν εὖ φρονῶν</quote>: for the neuter verbal with acc., 1250 <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰρκτέον τάδ’ ἐστίν</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_ὡς_1141"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 549"> <title>Phil.</title> 549</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤκουσα τοὺς ναύτας ὅτι | ... εἷεν</quote> etc.: <ref n="Xen. Mem. 4. 2. 33">Xen. <title> Mem.</title> 4. 2. 33</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν Δαίδαλον..οὐκ ἀκήκοας, ὅτι..ἠναγκάζετο.. δουλεύειν;</quote> Wecklein's conjecture, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦθ_ἕν_1141"> for <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτον</quote>, is very plausible, in view of 1040 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕν σοι φράσω</quote>. We may observe, however, that <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτον</quote> answers to <quote xml:lang="grc">τόνδ’</quote> in 1040, and that the stress in Teucer's retort falls on the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντ‐</quote> in <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντακούσει</quote>, and on <quote xml:lang="grc">τεθάψεται</quote>. There is more of dignity in that retort, as it stands with <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτον</quote>, than there would be with the mocking echo, <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦθ’ ἕν</quote>. If <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦθ’ ἕν</quote> were to be read, then <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>σὺ δ’</emph> ἀντακούσει</quote> (a <foreign xml:lang="lat"> v.l.</foreign>) would be preferable to L's <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>ἀλλ’</emph> ἀντακούσει.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τεθάψεται_1141">: 577 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναύτας_πλεῖν_1143">: for the inf. with art., instead of a simple inf., cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 442"> <title>O. C.</title> 442</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ δρᾶν | οὐκ ἠθέλησαν</quote> (and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 47, n.): <ref n="Thuc. 2. 87">Thuc. 2. 87</ref>§ 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχὶ δικαίαν ἔχει τέκμαρσιν τὸ ἐκφοβῆσαι</quote> (where Classen compares this verse). Liddell and Scott, s. v. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφορμάω</quote>, remark that the dat. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="vαύταις_1143"> should be read here. It is, in fact, the reading of a few late MSS.,—having been introduced, perhaps, by Triclinius; but </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναύτας_1143"> is right. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφορμῶ</quote> takes a dat. of the person when it means to rouse or urge something <emph>against</emph> one; <emph>e.g. </emph> <ref n="Hom. Od. 7.272">Hom. Od. 7. 272</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅς μοι ἐφορμήσας ἀνέμους</quote>: Soph. fr. 619. 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾧ καὶ Ζ<*>ὺς ἐφορμήσῃ κακά</quote>. But here, where <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐφορμῶ</quote> means to urge one to do something, the person is necessarily in the acc., as after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπείγω, προτρέπω</quote>, etc. Cp. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 8. 1. 43">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 8. 1. 43</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τούτους οὔτε μελετᾶν τῶν ἐλευθερίων πόνων οὐδένα παρώρμα κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾧ_ηὗρες_1144">. Against reading <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνηῦρες</quote>, it should be noted that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνευρίσκω</quote> is post-classical, unless Dobree was right in conjecturing <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνηύρηκεν</quote> (for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνηύρηκεν</quote>) in <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 1037."> Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 1037.</ref>On the other hand, the sarcastic force of the doubled </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄν_1144"> is in place here. The dat. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾧ_1144"> is possessive: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> instead of the simple <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾧ οὐκ ἂν ἦν φθέγμα</quote>, we have <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾧ οὐκ ἂν ηὗρες φθέγμα</quote>, in the sense, ‘you would have found that he had not a word at his command.’ The emendation <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾧ φθέγμ’ <emph>ὂν</emph> οὐκ ἂν ηὗρες</quote> would make this clearer, but seems needless: it is, indeed, slightly prosaic.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_χειμῶνος_1144">: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1358"> <title>O. C.</title> 1358</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν πόνῳ | ... κακῶν.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴχετ_1144">: <ref n="Hdt. 9. 37"> Her. 9. 37</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τούτῳ τῷ κακῷ ἐχόμενος.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑφ_εἵματος_1144">: <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 81"> Aesch. <title>Ch.</title> 81</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δακρύω δ’ ὑφ’ εἱμάτων</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Hec. 346">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 346</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεξιὰν ὑφ’ εἵματος | κρύπτοντα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρυφείς_1144">. The form <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐκρύφην</quote> is not elsewhere found in classical Greek. At a later period <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκρύβην</quote> was frequent (see Veitch, <title>Gk. Verbs</title> p. 393). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατεῖν_παρεῖχε_1146">, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑαυτόν</quote>: cp. <title>Nub.</title> 422 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμέλει θαρρῶν οὕνεκα τούτων ἐπιχαλκεύειν παρέχοιμ’ ἄν</quote>. Plat. <title>Theaet.</title>p. 191 A <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐὰν δὲ πάντῃ ἀπορήσωμεν, ταπεινωθέντες, οἶμαι, τῷ λόγῳ παρέξομεν ὡς ναυτιῶντες πατεῖν τε καὶ χρῆσθαι ὅ τι ἂν βούληται</quote>. Synesius IV. <ref n="Plat. L. 163D">Plat. <title>Ep.</title> 163D</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεθῆκεν ὁ κυβερνήτης τὸ πηδάλιον καὶ καταβαλὼν ἑαυτὸν πατεῖν παρεῖχε τῷ θέλοντι ναυτίλων</quote>.—For the omission of the art. before <quote xml:lang="grc">ναυτίλων</quote>, cp. <title>I. A.</title> 340 <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ θέλοντι δημοτῶν</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Ion 1167"> <title>Ion</title> 1167</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν θέλοντ’ ἐγχωρίων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_στόμα_1147">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 573"> <title>Ant.</title> 573</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγαν γε λυπεῖς καὶ σὺ καὶ τὸ σὸν λέχος.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λάβρον_στόμα_1147">: <ref n="Aesch. PB 327"> Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 327</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδ’ ἄγαν λαβροστόμει.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σμικροῦ_ἐκπνεύσας_1147">. Greeks gave the name of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκνεφίας</quote> to a wind caused by the meeting and breaking of clouds: <title>De Mundo</title> (p. 394 <emph> b</emph> 18) <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δὲ κατὰ ῥῆξιν γινόμενοι..ἐκνεφίαι καλοῦνται</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὴν_βοήν_1149">, a new acc. serving to resume <quote xml:lang="grc">σὲ καὶ τὸ σὸν..στόμα</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1062">cp. 1062</ref> f. (<quote xml:lang="grc"> αὐτὸν..σῶμα</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ὕβριζε_1151">: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1612">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1612</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴγισθ’, ὑβρίζειν ἐν κακοῖσιν οὐ σέβω</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κᾆτ_1152">, introducing the consequence of such <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕβρις</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 1500"> <title>O. T.</title> 1500</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιαῦτ’ ὀνειδιεῖσθε· κᾆτα τίς γαμεῖ</quote> <emph>; </emph> <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1019">Ant. 1019</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κᾆτ’</quote> (‘and <emph>so</emph>,’ ‘and <emph>therefore</emph>’) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ δέχονται θυστάδας λιτὰς ἔπι | θεοὶ παρ’ ἡμῶν</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀργήν_1153">=<quote xml:lang="grc">τρόπον</quote> . <cit> <bibl n="Aeschin. 2.179">Aeschin. or. 2 § 179</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάνδρῳ καὶ γυναικείῳ ἀνθρώπῳ τὴν ὀργήν</quote> </cit>. Theognis 215 <quote xml:lang="grc">πουλύπου ὀργὴν ἴσχε πολυπλόκου</quote> . </gloss>

data.quote: ἀνάνδρῳ καὶ γυναικείῳ ἀνθρώπῳ τὴν ὀργήν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποήσεις_1155">: on the spelling, see Appendix to <ref n="Soph. Phil. 120."> <title>Ph.</title> 120.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πημανούμενος_1155">. Other examples of the passive sense in futures of middle form, from stems ending in a liquid, are <ref n="Soph. Ant. 93"> <title>Ant.</title> 93</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐχθαρεῖ</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 230 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλγυνεῖ</quote> : <ref n="Soph. OT 272"> <title>O. T.</title> 272</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φθερεῖσθαι</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Phil. 954"> <title>Ph.</title> 954</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐανοῦμαι</quote> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνολβον_1156">, of folly, as in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1026"> <title>Ant.</title> 1026</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄβουλος οὐδ’ ἄνολβος</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat"> ib.</foreign> 1265 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤμοι ἐμῶν ἄνολβα βουλευμάτων</quote> . <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1290">Cp. 1290</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύστηνε</quote> : <title>O.T.</title> 888 <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσπότμου χάριν χλιδᾶς</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, miserably perverse): <ref n="Dem. 3.21">Dem. or. 3 § 21</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ οὕτως ἄφρων οὐδ’ ἀτυχής εἰμι ἐγώ, ὥστ’ ἀπεχθάνεσθαι βούλεσθαι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρών_1156"> here serves merely to make the picture a little more vivid; he thus warned the man to his face. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 338">Cp. 338</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μῶν_ᾐνιξάμην_1158">; ‘I have not spoken too obscurely?’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">μῶν</quote>, <emph>num</emph>, as in 791.) Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 405"> <title>Ant.</title> 405</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἇρ’ ἔνδηλα καὶ σαφῆ λέγω;</quote> <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 269">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 269</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ τορῶς λέγω;</quote> In Teucer's parody of his opponent's parable there is a rising tone of scorn, which the last words accentuate. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάρα_1160"> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">πάρεστι</quote>), the reading of A, is distinctly preferable <emph>here</emph> to <quote xml:lang="grc">παρῇ</quote>, though the latter has the support of the first hand in L. With <quote xml:lang="grc">παρῇ</quote> the sense would be: ‘It were shameful if people should hear that <emph>any one who may have the power</emph> to use force is chastising only by words.’ We must not be misled by the analogy of the Latin subjunctive: <emph>qui possit vi uti</emph> could be merely an allusive way of saying <emph>qui possim vi uti:</emph> but the Greek equivalent of <emph>qui possim</emph> would be (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτῳ πάρεστι</quote>, not <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾧ παρῇ</quote>. In 1081, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπου δ’ ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν θ’ ἂ βούλεται παρῇ</quote> (<emph>wherever it may be allowed</emph>), the subjunctive is fitting: but not so here, where the reference is to a definite person who has a certain power. <quote xml:lang="grc">παρῇ</quote> is not, indeed, impossible: it is, however, so unnatural in this context that it would require much stronger authority to support it as against <quote xml:lang="grc">πάρα</quote> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔριδός_ἀγών_1160">, a trial of strength in strife: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 20"> <title>Tr.</title> 20</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἀγῶνα..συμπεσὼν μάχης</quote>: <ref n="Liv. 36. 19">Liv. 36. 19</ref> <emph>in ipso certamine pugnae.</emph> For the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">τις</quote> before its noun, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 29">cp. 29</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάπετον_1165">, a grave dug in the earth, from <quote xml:lang="grc">σκάπτω</quote> (cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">καφώρη</quote>, ‘fox,’ also <quote xml:lang="grc">σκαφώρη</quote>): among kindred words G. Curtius gives the Lithuanian <emph>ka/p-a-s</emph>, ‘grave-mound’ (<title> Etym.</title> § 109). <ref n="Hom. Il. 24.797"> <title>Il.</title> 24. 797</ref>(Hector's burial) <quote xml:lang="grc">αἶψα δ’ ἄρ’ ἐς κοίλην κάπετον θέσαν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰδεῖν_1165">, ‘look for’: <ref n="Hom. Od. 8.443"> <title>Od.</title> 8. 443</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς νῦν ἴδε πῶμα</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 15">Theocr. 15. 2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅρη δίφρον, Εὐνόα, αὐτῇ</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βροτοῖς_ἀείμνηστον_1166">=<quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν βροτοῖς ἀείμνηστον</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 714"> <title>O. C.</title> 714</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵπποισιν τὸν ἀκεστῆρα χαλινόν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 872"> <title>Tr.</title> 872</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">δῶρον</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἡρακλεῖ τὸ πόμπιμον</quote>: <ref n="Soph. OT 139"> <title>O. T.</title> 139</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖνον ὁ κτανών.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐρώεντα_1166">, from <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρώς</quote>, ‘mould’: an epithet applied in epic poetry to the nether world, where all things moulder in damp, cheerless gloom: <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.65"> <title>Il.</title> 20. 65</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκία</quote>, the home of Hades) <quote xml:lang="grc">σμερδαλἔ εὐρώεντα, τά τε στυγέουσι θεοί περ</quote>. <ref n="Hom. Od. 10.512"> <title>Od.</title> 10. 512</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀΐδεω..δόμον εὔρώεντα</quote>. Simonides illustrates this sense (fr. 4. 4), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐντάφἰον δὲ τοιοῦτον οὔτ’ εὐρὼς | οὔθ’ ὁ πανδαμάτωρ ἀμαυρώσει χρόνος</quote>: and Vergil reproduces it ( <ref n="Verg. A. 6. 462"> <title>Aen.</title> 6. 462</ref>) in his <emph>loca senta situ</emph>, the ‘rough and mouldering wilderness’ of the underworld. Quintus Smyrnaeus 14. 241 has <quote xml:lang="grc">τύμβον ἐπ’ εὐρώεντα</quote>. But in later antiquity a false etymology connected <quote xml:lang="grc"> εὐρώεις</quote> with <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρύς</quote>: thus Hesychius, <emph>s.v.</emph> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρώεντα</quote>, gives <quote xml:lang="grc">πλατέα</quote> as one explanation of it. Oppian (<foreign xml:lang="lat">circ.</foreign> 180 A.D. ) actually uses the word in the sense of ‘wide,’ <ref n="Opp. H. 5. 3">Opp. <title>Hal.</title> 5. 3</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κόλπον ἀν’ εὐρώεντα θαλάσσης</quote>: and so too Nonnus (5th cent. A.D. ) <title>Dionys.</title> 25. 476. [In <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.65"> <title>Il.</title> 20. 65</ref>Döderlein and others would change <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρώεντα</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐερόεντα</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">αὐήρ</quote> =<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀήρ</quote>), or <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠερόεντα</quote>, ‘murky’: while Nauck goes so far as to pronounce <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρώεις</quote> ‘a wholly apocryphal word.’]</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_1168">, marking the entrance of a person: 1223: <ref n="Soph. OC 549"> <title>O. C.</title> 549</ref>(n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐς_καιρὸν_1168">: so <ref n="Soph. Ant. 386"> <title>Ant.</title> 386</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς δέον περᾷ</quote> : <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 899">Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 899</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παῖς σὸς ἐς καιρὸν πάρα.— <emph>πλησίοι</emph> </quote>, as in <ref n="Eur. El. 640">Eur. <title>El.</title> 640</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">παρούσης τῆσδε πλησίας ἐμοί</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 896">Soph. <title>Tr.</title> 896</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παροῦσα πλησία</quote>. The <foreign xml:lang="lat"> v.l.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλησίον_1168"> is equally correct ( <ref n="Soph. El. 927">Soph. <title>El.</title> 927</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ πλησίον παρόντος</quote>, etc.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάφον_περιστελοῦντε_1168">, here a general phrase for rendering funeral rites. Among these rites would be the washing and dressing of the corpse ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 901"> <title>Ant.</title> 901</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλουσα κἀκόσμησα</quote> etc.), in which Tecmessa would naturally bear part, and the pouring of <quote xml:lang="grc">χοαί</quote>, in which Eurysaces also would share. The dual <quote xml:lang="grc">περιστελοῦντε</quote> is therefore right: Wakefield's conjecture </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περιστελοῦντι_1168">, which Nauck adopts, implies that the work was to be Teucer's alone. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 24.292"> <title>Od.</title> 24. 292</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέ ἑ μήτηρ | κλαῦσε περιστείλασα</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 902"> <title>Ant.</title> 902</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ σὸν | δέμας περιστέλλουσα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱκέτης_1172">: an anapaest in the first foot, as in verse 1302. This licence occurs in every play except the <title> Antigone</title>: it is most frequent in the <title>Philoctetes</title> (Introd. <title>Ph.</title>, p. xliv).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅς_ἐγείνατο_1172">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1296">cp. 1296</ref>: <ref n="Eur. El. 261"> <title>El.</title> 261</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μητρὸς ἥ μ’ ἐγείνατο</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θάκει_προστρόπαιος_1173">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 41">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 41</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕδραν ἔχοντα προστρόπαιον</quote>. Here <quote xml:lang="grc">θάκει</quote> denotes a kneeling posture (<quote xml:lang="grc">προσπεσών</quote> 1181): cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 293">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 293</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γονυπετεῖς ἕδρας προσπίτνω ς’</quote>, <title>O.T.</title> 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕδρας..θοάζετε</quote> (n.). The offerings in the child's hands will show that he formally supplicates (<quote xml:lang="grc">προστρέπεται</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 831">cp. 831</ref>) the <quote xml:lang="grc">χθόνιοι θεοί</quote> and the spirit of the dead man to avert outrage from the corpse.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κόμας_1173">, offerings to the dead, as in <ref n="Hom. Il. 23.135"> <title>Il.</title> 23. 135</ref>, where the locks of hair are laid on the corpse (<quote xml:lang="grc">θριξὶ δὲ πάντα νέκυν καταείνυσαν, ἃς ἐπέβαλλον | κειρόμενοι</quote>). So in <ref n="Eur. El. 449"> <title>El.</title> 449</ref> f. Chrysothemis is told to lay locks of her own hair and her sister's on Agamemnon's tomb,—the significance of the act being marked by the prayer which is to follow the gift: <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰτοῦ δὲ προσπίτνουσα γῆθεν εὐμενῆ | ἡμῖν ἀρωγὸν αὐτὸν εἰς ἐχθροὺς μολεῖν</quote> (453 f.). In its primitive symbolism the severed hair meant that the person from whose head it was cut devoted himself to the dead, and (as it were) escorted him to the shades; the gift of hair being a substitute for self-immolation at the grave.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρίτου_1173">, marking the completion of the lucky number; <ref n="Soph. OC 7"> <title>O. C.</title> 7</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">αἱ πάθαι..χὡ χρόνος</quote>.. | ..<quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τὸ γενναῖον τρίτον</quote> : <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 758">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 758</ref> ff. <quote xml:lang="grc">Παλλάδος καὶ Λοξίου | ἕκατι καὶ τοῦ πάντα κραίνοντος τρίτου | Σωτῆρος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱκτήριον_θησαυρόν_1175">, ‘the suppliant's <emph> store</emph>’; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the efficacy of the supplication is stored up in, resides in, these gifts of hair, which symbolise the appeal of the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱκέτης</quote> to the spirit of the dead.—G. Wolff takes the phrase as pathetic,—‘the suppliant's only wealth,’ ‘all that he has to offer,’—as Electra says of the gifts of hair, <quote xml:lang="grc">σμικρὰ μὲν τάδ’, ἀλλ’ ὅμως | ἅχω</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. El. 450"> <title>El.</title> 450</ref>). But it is rather the <emph>power</emph> than the poverty of the offering which is expressed by <quote xml:lang="grc">θησαυρόν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὸς_κακῶς_1177">, as in 1391, <title>O.T.</title> 248, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1369."> <title>Ph.</title> 1369.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄθαπτος_χθονός_1177">, ‘may he be cast out of the land, unburied’: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, may he perish, and may his body then be cast beyond the boundaries of his country. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1629">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 1629</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Πολυνείκους νέκυν | ἐκβάλετ’ ἄθαπτον τῆσδ’ ὅρων ἔξω χθονός</quote>. Under Athenian law a person put to death for treason (<quote xml:lang="grc">προδοσία</quote>) or sacrilege was not to be buried in Attica ( <title>H.</title> 1. 7. 22): thus when Phocion was executed in 317 C.B. , <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔδοξε καὶ τὸ σῶμα..ἐξορίσαι</quote> ( <ref n="Plut. Phoc. 37">Plut. <title>Phoc.</title> 37</ref>). Teucer's curse is worded as if the supposed offender were at home in Greece, and not at Troy.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκπέσοι_1177">: cp. <title>O.C.</title> 766 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτ’ ἦν μοι τέρψις ἐκπεσεῖν χθονός</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γένους_ἅπαντος_1178">: <ref n="Dem. 19.71">Dem. or. 19 § 71</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς θεοῖς</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔχεσθ’ ἐξώλη ποιεῖν αὐτὸν καὶ γένος καὶ οἰκίαν</quote> . <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 12.10">Lys. or. 12 § 10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤμοσεν ἐξώλειαν ἑαυτῷ καὶ τοῖς παισὶν ἐπαρώμενος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὤμοσεν ἐξώλειαν ἑαυτῷ καὶ τοῖς παισὶν
							ἐπαρώμενος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥίζαν_ἐξημημένος_1178">, with his race extirpated from the root,—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, may there be no survivor to continue it. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 765"> <title>El.</title> 765</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόρριζον..ἔφθαρται γένος</quote>: Lucian <ref n="Lucian Tyr. 13"> <title>Tyr.</title> 13</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πανωλεθρία παντὸς τοῦ γένους καὶ ῥιζόθεν τὸ δεινὸν ἅπαν ἐκκεκομμένον</quote>. So Antigone and her sister are the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσχάτη ῥίζα</quote> of their house ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 599"> <title>Ant.</title> 599</ref> f.). For the constr. of the pass. verb with acc., cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 157"> <title>Tr.</title> 157</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέλτον ἐγγεγραμμένην | ξυνθήμαθ’</quote> (n.): <ref n="Xen. Anab. 2. 6. 1"> Xen. <title>An.</title> 2. 6. 1</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποτμηθέντες τὰς κεφαλάς</quote>: <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 5. 2. 32">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 5. 2. 32</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τραύματα ἐπιδεδεμένους</quote>. For the use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξαμᾶν</quote>, cp. <ref n="Paus. 8. 7. 7">Paus. 8. 7. 7</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμελλε δὲ ἄρα ὁ δαίμων καὶ τὸ γένος τὸ Κασσάνδρου κακῶς ἐξαμήσειν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὔτως_1179">: as to the breathing, see on <ref n="Soph. OT 931."> <title>O. T.</title> 931.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπωσπερ_πλόκον_1179">. The primary meaning of this act was self-dedication (1173 n.), but Teucer here gives it a further significance, suggested by the circumstances of the moment; exactly as in <ref n="Hom. Il. 3.300"> <title>Il.</title> 3. 300</ref> the <quote xml:lang="grc">σπονδαί</quote> at the truce are turned into a symbol of death for those who break the truce,—<quote xml:lang="grc">ὧδέ σφ’ ἐγκέφαλος χαμάδις ῥέοι ὡς ὅδε οἶνος</quote>. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Liv. 1. 24">Liv. 1. 24</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">si prior defexit...tu illo die, Iuppiter, populum Romanum sic ferito ut ego hunc porcum hic hodie feriam.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Theoc. 2">Theocr. 2. 28</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc"> <l>ὡς τοῦτον τὸν καρὸν ἐγὼ σὺν δαίμονι τάκω </l> <l>ὣς τάκοιθ’ ὑπ’ ἔρωτος ὁ Μύνδιος αὐτίκα Δέλφις</l> </quote> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote:
si prior defexit...tu illo die, Iuppiter,
							populum Romanum sic ferito ut ego hunc porcum hic hodie feriam.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κινησάτω_1181">: the 3rd pers. of the aor. imper. with <quote xml:lang="grc">μή</quote>, though somewhat rare, occurs in good prose ( <ref n="Plat. Apol. 17C">Plat. <title>Apol.</title> 17C</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδεὶς...προσδοκησάτω</quote>). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1334">Cp. 1334</ref>.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσπεσὼν_1181"> , <emph>kneeling</emph> beside the body, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχου_1181"> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοῦ</quote>), cling to it. So <ref n="Soph. Trach. 904"> <title>Tr.</title> 904</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βωμοῖσι προσπίπτουσα</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 485"> <title>Ph.</title> 485</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προσπίτνω σε γόνασι</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑμεῖς_τε_1182">, the Chorus. It has been proposed to read </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὲ_1182"> instead of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τε_1182">, but needlessly. <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote> would mark the change in the persons addressed; <quote xml:lang="grc">τε</quote> marks the continuity of the precepts. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 421"> <title>El.</title> 421</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔκ τε τοῦδ’ ἄνω</quote> ), <ref n="Soph. Trach. 462"> <title>Tr.</title> 462</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἥδε τ’</quote>), where the reason for retaining <quote xml:lang="grc">τε</quote> is similar.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντ_ἀνδρῶν_1182">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1020">cp. 1020</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦλος.. ἀντ’ ἐλευθέρου</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔστ_1183">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔστ’ ἄν</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Aj. 555">cp. 555</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως.. μάθῃς.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάφου_μεληθεὶς_1183">, after choosing and preparing a place of burial (1165). This aor. of the simple <quote xml:lang="grc">μέλομαι</quote> does not elsewhere occur in a middle sense (in <title>Anthol.</title> 5. 201 <quote xml:lang="grc">μεληθέν</quote> in pass.), but <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεμελήθην</quote> as an aor. middle is frequent in </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἂν_ἐᾷ_1183">=<quote xml:lang="grc">κἂν πάντες μὴ‐ἐῶσιν</quote>, though all men forbid (<quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐῶ</quote> =<emph>veto</emph>). Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 443"> <title>Ph.</title> 443</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπου | μηδεὶς ἐῴη</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέατος_1185"> should be followed by a comma (as in some MSS.): the sense is, <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς νέατος ἐτέων ἀριθμὸς</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔσται</quote>), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς πότε λήξει ἐτέων ἀριθμός;</quote> ‘what will be the <emph>last number</emph> (the completed <emph>total</emph> of the years),—when will the <emph>series</emph> of the years end?’—<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀριθμός</quote> having a slightly different sense with <quote xml:lang="grc">νέατος</quote> from that which it bears with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς πότε</quote>. This difference is the reason against taking the sentence as two questions combined in one (like <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς πόθεν εἶς ἀνδρῶν;</quote>). The scholiast in L understood the construction aright:—<quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ἄρα ἡμῖν ὁ ἔσχατος τῶν ἐτῶν ἀριθμὸς τῶν πολυπλάγκτων;</quote> [Remark that he does not supply <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔσται</quote>—thus indicating that it is to be understood in the text also.] <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">πότε λήξει ὁ ἀριθμὸς τῶν ἐτῶν ἐμοὶ πόνους παρασκευάζων;</quote> For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέατος_1185_2"> in this sense, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 807"> <title>Ant.</title> 807</ref> f.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολυπλάγκτων_1185">, ‘muchwandering,’ ‘restless,’ refers to the toils of the campaign beyond sea; the epithet of the men is transferred to the years; cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 17.425"> <title>Od.</title> 17. 425</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λῃστῆρσι πολυπλάγκτοισιν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰν_ἄπαυστον_1187">: for the art. (‘<emph>that</emph> ceaseless misery’), cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 166"> <title>El.</title> 166</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἀνήνυτον | οἶτον ἔχουσα κακῶν</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δορυσσοήτων_1188">, ‘spear-hurling,’ here=‘martial.’ <quote xml:lang="grc">δορυσσόης</quote> occurs nowhere else, but is related to <quote xml:lang="grc">δορυσσόος</quote> as <quote xml:lang="grc">γυμνής</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">γυμνός, κουρῆτες</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">κοῦροι</quote>, and it would certainly be rash to deny that metrical convenience could have suggested such a by-form. Blaydes and Wecklein change it to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δορυσσόων_1188">, reading <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔδειξ’</quote> (instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔδειξεν</quote>) in 1195. Nauck gives </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δορυσσῶν_1188"> (further changing <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄπαυστον</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπαύσταν</quote>), and in 1196 omits the word <quote xml:lang="grc">κοινόν</quote>. (Cp. <title> O.C.</title> 1313 <quote xml:lang="grc">δορυσσοῦς Ἀμφιάρεως</quote>.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀν_Τρωΐαν_1190">. This, the emendation of Ahrens, is very close to the MS. text, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνὰ τὰν εὐρώδη Τροίαν</quote>. There is no reason to doubt the metrical soundness of the antistrophic verse, 1197 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ πόνοι πρόγονοι πόνων</quote>. Hence the correction of <quote xml:lang="grc">Τροίαν</quote> to <quote xml:lang="grc">Τρωΐαν</quote> has strong probability. Lobeck compares <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρώδης</quote> (from <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐρύς</quote>) with the late forms <quote xml:lang="grc">βραχώδης, τραχώδης</quote>. With regard to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀν_1190"> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνά</quote>), it should be noted that Sophocles uses this apocopè elsewhere only in compounds (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 416">cp. 416</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1275"> <title>Ant.</title> 1275</ref>, n. on <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀντρέπων</quote>).—For other emendations, see Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύστανον_Ἑλλάνων_1191">, acc. in appos. with the sentence: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 559">cp. 559</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χαρμονήν</quote> (n.), 1210 <quote xml:lang="grc"> μνήματα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄφελε_1192">: the unaugmented form is frequent in Homer: <emph>e.g. </emph> <ref n="Hom. Od. 5.308"> Od. 5. 308</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς δὴ ἐγώ γ’ ὄφελον θανέειν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰθέρα_μέγαν_1192">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, vanish into the depths of the sky, as if caught up by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅρπυιαι</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1375">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1375</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾷ φύγω, ξέναι</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">πολιὸν αἰθέρ’ ἀμπτάμενος ἢ πόντον;</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολύκοινον_Ἅιδαν_1192">: <ref n="Eur. El. 137"> <title>El.</title> 137</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀΐδα | παγκοίνου λίμνας</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεῖνος_ἁνὴρ_1195">, not Paris, but an indefinite person, the supposed inventor of war: cp. Tibull. 1. 10. 1 <quote xml:lang="lat">Quis fuit, horrendos primus qui protulit enses? | Quam ferus et vere ferreus ille fuit!</quote> <title>C.</title> 1. 3. 9 <quote xml:lang="lat">Illi robur et aes triplex | Circa pectus erat qui fragilem truci | Commisit pelago ratem | Primus.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔδειξεν_1195">, taught: <ref n="Aesch. PB 457"> Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 457</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔστε δή σφιν ἀντολὰς ἐγὼ | ἄστρων ἔδειξα.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοινὸν_Ἄρη_1195">, ‘public’ warfare, in which all the Greeks make common cause (as against the Trojans): <ref n="Thuc. 1. 3">Thuc. 1. 3</ref>§ 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸ γὰρ τῶν Τρωϊκῶν οὐδὲν φαίνεται πρότερον κοινῇ ἐργασαμένη ἡ Ἑλλάς</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰὼ_πόνων_1197">. This is a parenthetic exclamation (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 173">cp. 173</ref> f.): ‘Alas, those warlike toils (of the man who invented war), from which so many toils have sprung.’ Cp. the phrase in <title>Legg.</title> 928 E <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυμφοραὶ..ἔχθρας ἔκγονοι</quote>.—Dindorf writes <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ πόνοι <emph>πρόπονοι</emph> </quote> (omitting <quote xml:lang="grc">πόνων</quote>, as in 1190 he reads <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀν’ εὐρώδη Τροΐαν</quote>), ‘toils pre-eminent among toils’: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 987">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 987</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακὰ πρόκακα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτε_στεφάνων_1199">. <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε</quote>, the reading of the MSS., is sound; the fault is in the antistrophe (1211), where they give <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ πρὶν μὲν ἐννυχίου</quote>, but this is satisfactorily cured by G. Wolff's correction; see n. on 1211.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στεφάνων_1199">, the wreaths, usually of myrtle (<quote xml:lang="grc">μυρρίναι</quote>), with which the guests at a banquet crowned their heads before the <quote xml:lang="grc">σπονδαί</quote> were poured and the <quote xml:lang="grc">πότος</quote> began: Athen. p. 685 C <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ δὲ τῶν στεφάνων καὶ μύρων πρότερον εἴσοδος εἰς τὰ συμπόσια ἡγεῖτο τῆς δευτέρας τραπέζας</quote>. <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 1145">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 1145</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πίνειν στεφανωσαμένῳ</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Ba. 376"> Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 376</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὰ καλλιστεφάνοις | εὐφροσύναις</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαθειᾶν_1200">, ‘copious’: see on <quote xml:lang="grc">βάθει</quote> in 130.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυλίκων_1200">. The <quote xml:lang="grc">κύλιξ</quote> was the commonest form of drinking-cup at Athens (cp. <ref n="Plat. Sym. 214B">Plat. <title>Symp.</title> 214B</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ τῇ κύλικι λέγειν</quote>). It was usually of earthenware (<quote xml:lang="grc">κύλικα κεραμέαν</quote>, <ref n="Plat. Lysis 219E"> <title>Lys.</title> 219 E</ref>), with a broad and relatively shallow bow] (hence compared to an <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀσπίς</quote>, Athen. p. 472 C), a stem, and handles (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὦτα</quote>) projecting horizontally from the sides. The average <quote xml:lang="grc">κύλιξ</quote> seems to have held about three <quote xml:lang="grc">κοτύλαι</quote>, or between 1 1/3 and 1 1/2 pint. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νεῖμεν_1201"> governs </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέρψιν_1201">, to which </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμιλεῖν_1201"> is added as epexegetic inf., ‘for me to consort with’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμιλεῖν αὐτῇ</quote>): cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 10">Pind. <title>N.</title> 10. 72</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">χαλεπὰ δ’ ἔρις ἀνθρώποις ὁμιλεῖν κρεσσόνων</quote> (a strife with more than mortal foe is hard for men to encounter): id. <ref n="Pind. I. 2">Pind. <title>I.</title> 2. 37</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰδοῖος μὲν ἦν ἀστοῖς ὁμιλεῖν</quote>.— Others take <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμιλεῖν</quote> as depending on <quote xml:lang="grc"> νεῖμεν</quote>, and <quote xml:lang="grc">τέρψιν</quote> as cogn. acc. (or ‘acc. of the inner object’): ‘gave me <emph>companionship in</emph> the joy of the wine-cup.’ But this somewhat forces the word <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμιλεῖν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐλῶν_1202">, the flutes played at banquets by <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐλητρίδες.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄτοβον_1202">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. PB 574">Aesch. <title>P. V.</title> 574</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κηρόπλαστος ὀτοβεῖ δόναξ</quote>. The word usu. denotes a loud noise, as the rattling of chariots ( <ref n="Aesch. Seven 151">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 151</ref>), or the crash of thunder (<title>O.C.</title> 1479). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύσμορος_1203">, ‘that wretch’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1290">cp. 1290</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύστηνε.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐννυχίαν_ἰαύειν_1203">, ‘to pass the night in sweet repose.’ The inf. depends on <quote xml:lang="grc">νεῖμεν</quote>, with <quote xml:lang="grc">τέρψιν</quote> as cogn. acc.—The Homeric <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰαύω</quote> means, not ‘to <emph>sleep</emph>,’ but ‘to <emph>pass the night</emph>’ or ‘<emph>bivouac</emph>’: see, <emph> e.g. </emph> <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.325"> Il. 9. 325</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀυ‐/πνους νύκτας ἴαυον</quote>. It used to be connected with the rt. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀv</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἄω</quote>), ‘breathe’: but Leo Meyer, who converted G. Curtius on this point, has shown that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰαύω</quote> should be referred to a rt. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀvες</quote>, equivalent to the Sanskrit rt. <foreign xml:lang="sanskrit">vas</foreign> (‘dwell’), whence the aorist <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄεσα</quote>, <ref n="Hom. Od. 3.151"> <title>Od.</title> 3. 151</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νύκτα μὲν ἀέσαμεν</quote> (‘we abode’) <quote xml:lang="grc">χαλεπὰ φρεσὶν ὁρμαίνοντες</quote>. In the present <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰαύω ι</quote> is the reduplication. Curtius compares <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰ‐ά‐σκειν</quote>, an inchoative present from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγ</quote>, which Hesychius explains by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄγειν</quote>. (See Curtius <title>Gk. Verb</title> pp. 197, 520, 543.)—<quote xml:lang="grc">ἰαύω</quote> occurs in postHomeric Greek of the classical age only here and in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1537">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 1537</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">δεμνίοις | ... ἰαύων</quote>. [Eur. ] <title>Rhes.</title> 740 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ὑπασπίδιον κοῖτον ἰαύει</quote>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέρψιν_1203"> (after 1201): it recurs in 1216. See n. on <title>O.C.</title> 554. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρώτων_ἐρώτων_1205">: for the iteration, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 621">cp. 621</ref> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμέριμνος_1206">, ‘uncared for’: the pass. sense occurs only here, but may be illustrated by the use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκηδής</quote>, which can be either passive or active; and by the passive sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμελής</quote> in <title>H.</title> 6. 5. 41, where it means, ‘neglected.’ Those who make <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμέριμνος</quote> active here explain it as=‘without occupation,’ ‘without any interest in life’; but this is clearly untenable.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὕτως_1206"> strengthens the adj. (‘thus utterly uncared for’); cp. <ref n="Aesch. Seven 1056">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 1056</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γένος ὠλέσατε πρέμνοθεν οὕτως</quote>. This is better than to take it as=‘simply,’ as in <ref n="Plat. Gorg. 506D">Plat. <title>Gorg.</title> 506D</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὕτως εἰκῇ</quote> [<foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ τῷ εἰκῇ</quote>], like <emph>iacentes sic temere</emph> in <title>C.</title> 2. 11. 14. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρόσοις_1207">: the <quote xml:lang="grc">λειμώνιαι δρόσοι</quote> of <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 560">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 560</ref>(quoted above on 601 ff.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μνήματα_1210">, acc. in appos. with the sentence: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1191">cp. 1191</ref> n. The miseries of the nightly bivouac never allow them to forget that they are in the dreary Troad. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰὲν_νυχίου_1211">, G. Wolff's excellent emendation of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐννυχίου</quote>, brings the verse into metrical agreement with 1199 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖνος οὔτε στεφάνων</quote> (n.). The corruption could easily arise from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐννυχίαν</quote> above (1203). Keeping <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐννυχίου</quote>, Dindorf inserts <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ</quote> before it; but this remedy (though better than the Triclinian <quote xml:lang="grc">οὖν</quote>) gives an unusual constr. to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προβολὰ_1211">, which regularly takes a simple genitive,—either of the thing defended (as <quote xml:lang="grc">χώρας</quote>, <title>M.</title> 3. 5. 27), or of the thing which is warded off, as <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1488">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 1488</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανάτου προβολάν</quote>: <ref n="Plat. Tim. 74B">Plat. <title>Tim.</title> 74B</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προβολὴ..καυμάτων.— <emph>θούριος</emph> </quote>, as in 212. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνεῖται_δαίμονι_1214">, has been <emph> consecrated</emph>, <emph>devoted</emph>, to it; <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, has become its victim. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 947"> Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 947</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτος δὲ πῶλος</quote> (Menoeceus), <quote xml:lang="grc">τῇδ’ ἀνειμένος πόλει</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">θανὼν πατρῴαν γαῖαν ἐκσώσειεν ἄν</quote>. The word <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνειμένος</quote> was properly said of animals which, having been consecrated to a god, were allowed to roam at liberty in the pastures; <ref n="Hdt. 2. 65"> Her. 2. 65</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν δὲ εἵνεκεν ἀνεῖται τὰ ἱρὰ</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">θηρία</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ λέγοιμι, καταβαίην ἂν τῷ λόγῳ εἰς τὰ θεῖα πρήγματα</quote>: then the term was extended to inanimate things; <title>Legg.</title> 761 C <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ τί που ἄλσος ἢ τέμενος περὶ ταῦτα ἀνειμένον ᾖ</quote>. The young Ionin the Delphic temple is said to be <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἄφετος</quote>, ‘consecrated’ to the god ( <ref n="Eur. Ion 822">Eur. <title> Ion</title> 822</ref>: cp. <title>Critias</title> 119 D <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀφέτων ὄντων ταύρων ἐν τῷ τοῦ Ποσειδῶνος ἱερῷ</quote>). Similarly the sacred horses of the German tribes <cit> <quote xml:lang="lat">publice aluntur..nullo mortali opere contacti</quote> <bibl n="Tac. Ger. 10">(Tac. <title>Germ.</title> 10)</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπέσται_1216">, will ‘attend upon’ me; cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1467"> <title>El.</title> 1467</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἔπεστι νέμεσις</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γενοίμαν_1217">: cp. <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 732"> Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 732</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλιβάτοις ὑπὸ κευθμῶσι γενοίμαν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑλᾶεν_1217">. Colonel William Mure (the author of the well-known History of Greek Literature) remarks:—‘Sophocles calls Sunium a woody promontory, a description no longer applicable. But a few stunted fir bushes, straggling over the declivity below the temple, would seem still to vouch for its propriety in his own age.’ (<title>Tour in Greece</title>, vol. II. p. 123: 1842.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπεστι_πρόβλημ_1217">: the genitive goes with <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόβλημα</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1455"> <title>Ph.</title> 1455</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόντου προβολῆς</quote>: Quintus Smyrn. 9. 378 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ προβολῇσι θαλάσσης</quote>. The scholiast confirms the reading of the MSS.: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα ὑλώδης ἐξοχὴ τῆς θαλάττης ἐστί</quote>. With </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπεστι_1217"> we understand <quote xml:lang="grc">πόντῳ</quote> from <quote xml:lang="grc">πόντου</quote>. For <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπεστι</quote> after <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέσται</quote> in 1216, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 73"> <title>Ant.</title> 73</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 76"> Ant. 76</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">κείσομαι</quote>), <ref n="Soph. Ant. 613"> Ant. 613</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 618"> Ant. 618</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἕρπει</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπὸ_Σουνίου_1220">: for the <quote xml:lang="grc">ο—</quote> of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπὸ</quote> before <quote xml:lang="grc">πλ</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 612"> <title>Ant.</title> 612</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ πρίν</quote>.—Sunium, the S. E. promontory of Attica, is, in Leake's words, ‘lofty, steep, and rugged on every side, except the south-west, where there is a beach and a small bay, with an island at the entrance’ (<title>Demi of Attica</title>, vol. II. p. 63). On the highest point stood the Doric temple of Athena, built probably about the middle of the 5th century B.C. The modern name of the cape, <title>Colonna</title> (<quote xml:lang="grc">Κολόνναις</quote>), is derived from the remaining columns of the temple, which are of a brilliant whiteness, the marble of which they are made being of a much lighter colour than the Pentelic. ‘As seen from a distance, glittering in the sun across the blue sea, they look like pillars of snow or salt, rather than stone’ (Mure, <title>Tour</title> II. p. 123). Cp. <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 293">Eur. <title>Cycl.</title> 293</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥ τε Σουνίου | δίας Ἀθάνας σῶς ὑπάργυρος πέτρα</quote> (where the epithet alludes to the silver-mines of Laurium). Poseidon also was worshipped at Sunium (<quote xml:lang="grc">Σουνιάρατε</quote>, <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 560">Ar. <title>Eq.</title> 560</ref>): but Leake was disposed to think that he can have had an altar only, as the sole buildings traceable were the temple of Athena and the fortress erected on Sunium <foreign xml:lang="lat">circ.</foreign> 413 B.C. (<title>Demi</title> II. p. 64). Wordsworth, however, saw remains which, he thought, might be those of a Poseidonion (<title>Athens and Attica</title>, p. 177). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰς_ἱερὰς_1221">: so Pind. fr. 75. 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ταῖς ἱεραῖς Ἀθάναις</quote>. <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 1319">Ar. <title>Eq.</title> 1319</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ ταῖς ἱεραῖς φέγγος Ἀθήναις</quote>: Timocreon fr. I. 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱερᾶν ἀπ’ Ἀθηνᾶν</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 707"> <title>El.</title> 707</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀθηνῶν τῶν θεοδμήτων.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπως_προσείποιμεν_1221">, after the optative <quote xml:lang="grc">γενοίμαν</quote> (1217): <ref n="Soph. Phil. 324"> <title>Ph.</title> 324</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θυμὸν γένοιτο χειρὶ πληρῶσαί ποτε</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵν’ αἱ Μυκῆναι γνοῖεν κ.τ.λ.</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 297">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 297</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλθοι</quote>... | <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως γένοιτο κ.τ.λ.</quote> (Sometimes, however, we find the subjunct. after such an optative: <ref n="Eur. Orest. 982">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 982</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μόλοιμι...ἵν’ ἐν θρήνοισιν ἀμβοάσω</quote>.) For the custom of greeting the land to which one comes, cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 503">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 503</ref>: <ref n="Verg. A. 3. 524">Verg. <title>Aen.</title> 3. 524</ref> <title>Italiam laeto socii clamore salutant.</title> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_1223">: 1168 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμῖν_1223">, a ‘dativus incommodi,’—‘to trouble us.’— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δῆλος_1223">, in the personal constr. with partic., as <title>O.T.</title> 673, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1011."> <title>Ph.</title> 1011.</ref>(With <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς</quote> added, above, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 326"> Ph. 326</ref> n.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοὐστὶ_1223">: for the crasis, cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 812"> <title>Ph.</title> 812</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς οὐ θέμις γ’ ἐμοὔστι σοῦ μολεῖν ἄτερ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκαιὸν_στόμα_1223">. The notion of <quote xml:lang="grc">σκαιός</quote> here is that of headstrong perversity, unrestrained by good sense or good feeling; cp. <ref>Eur. fr. 290</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀεὶ γὰρ ἄνδρα σκαιόν, ἰσχυρὸν φύσει</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἧσσον δέδοικα τἀσθενοῦς τε καὶ σοφοῦ</quote>. <ref n="Dem. 18.120">Dem. or. 18 § 120</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκαιὸς..καὶ ἀναίσθητος.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκλύσων_1223">: <ref n="Isoc. 12.96">Isocr. or. 12 § 96</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπελήλυθέ μοι τὸ παρρησιάζεσθαι καὶ λέλυκα τὸ στόμα</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 1060">Eur. <title>Hipp.</title> 1060</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δῆτα τοὐμὸν οὐ λύω στόμα;</quote> Cp. <ref n="Eur. Ba. 385">Eur. <title>Bacch.</title> 385</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀχαλίνων στομάτων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὲ_δὴ_1226">: the abrupt acc., roughly calling the attention of the person addressed, is sometimes used even without a governing verb, as in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 441"> <title>Ant.</title> 441</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὲ δή, σὲ τὴν νεύουσαν ἐς πέδον κάρα</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">φής, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ῥήματ_1226">, ‘<emph>those</emph> terrible words’: 312 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνοιμωκτὶ_1226">, <emph>impune</emph>, like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκλαύστῳ</quote> in <ref n="Eur. El. 912."> <title>El.</title> 912.</ref>Cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 178">Ar. <title> Ran.</title> 178</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ οἰμώξεται;</quote> The adverb ends in </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ι_1226">, not </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ει_1226">, as presupposing an adj. in <quote xml:lang="grc">‐ος</quote>: for these adverbial forms, see n. on <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1251"> <title>O.C.</title> 1251</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀστακτί.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χανεῖν_ῥήματα_1226">, like <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 920">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 920</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βόαμα προσχάνῃς</quote>: <title>Vesp.</title> 341 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτ’ ἐτόλμησ’ ὁ μιαρὸς χανεῖν;</quote> Attius <title>Armorum Iudicium</title> fr. 11 <title>Hem</title>, <emph>vereor plus quam fas est captivum hiscere.</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σέ_τοι_1228">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1445"> <title>El.</title> 1445</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σέ τοι, σὲ κρίνω</quote> : <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 274">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 274</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτος, ὦ σέ τοι.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_τῆς_1228"> is better than the <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὲ τὸν τῆς</quote>, since <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</quote> lays an intentionally scornful emphasis on Teucer's origin. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τραφεὶς_1229"> = <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ ἐτράφης.— <emph>μητρὸς … ἄπο</emph> </quote>: <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</quote> is usu. said of parents, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπό</quote> (as in 202) of ancestors; but cp. <title> O.C.</title> 571 <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀφ’ ὅτου πατρὸς γεγώς</quote>. ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 192"> <title>Ant.</title> 192</ref> f., n.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑψήλ_ἐφώνεις_1229"> is a choicer phrase, and marks the irony better, than the <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑψήλ’ ἐκόμπεις.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀπ_ὡδοιπόρεις_1229">: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπ’ ἄκρων δακτύλων ἔβαινες γαυριῶν</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Ion 1166">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 1166</ref> f. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν δ’ ἄκροισι βὰς ποσὶν | κῆρυξ ἀνεῖπε</quote> (describing the proud gait of the herald). Lobeck compares Libanius 4. 162 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπ’ ἄκρων πορεύεσθαι</quote>, and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκροβατεῖν</quote> ‘to strut’ in Philo <title>De Somn.</title> 1. 60. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτε_1231"> in its causal sense,=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπειδή</quote> (<title>O.T.</title> 918 n.).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲν_ὢν_1231">, ‘being naught’ (a simple statement): </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_ὕπερ_1231">, ‘for him who is <emph>as</emph> naught.’ The only difference between the two expressions is that the phrase with <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδέν</quote> is, in effect, somewhat more emphatic, and (here) more bitter, since it implies a mental act of comparison, with the result of deciding that this particular person is <emph>no more than</emph> a nonentity. The angry king scorns Teucer, but his bitterness is against the dead Ajax. The phrase with <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν</quote> is, of course, equally applicable to the dead ( <ref n="Eur. El. 244"> <title>El.</title> 244</ref>, <ref n="Eur. El. 1129"> El. 1129</ref>), and that with <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲν</quote> to the living (above, <ref n="Eur. El. 767"> El. 767</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1275">cp. 1275</ref> ). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1114">Cp. 1114</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς μηδένας</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοὔτε_στρατηγοὺς_1232"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> Agamemnon speaks throughout of ‘<emph>us</emph>,’ meaning Menelaüs and himself. Teucer had implicitly acknowledged that Agamemnon was commander-in-chief (1105). But he denied that Menelaüs had any authority over Ajax (1100), and also that either of the two Atreidae had a right to forbid the burial (1109).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτε_ναυάρχους_1232">: alluding to Teucer's denial that Ajax had sailed from Salamis at the summons, or under the command, of Menelaüs (1097, 1111 f.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀχαιῶν_σοῦ_1232">: another <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε</quote> is understood before <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀχαιῶν</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 266"> <title>Ant.</title> 266</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ μήτε δρᾶσαι μήτε τῳ ξυνειδέναι | τὸ πρᾶγμα βουλεύσαντι μήτ’ εἰργασμένῳ</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> (<quote xml:lang="grc">μήτε</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">βουλεύσαντι</quote> etc. (cp. <title>O.T.</title> 239 n.): <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 532">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 532</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Πάρις γὰρ οὔτε συντελὴς πόλις</quote>. It is needless to read <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ σοῦ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διωμόσω_1232">; the prep. gives emphasis, as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 378"> <title>Tr.</title> 378</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">διώμνυτο</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸς_ἔπλει_1234">: the imperf. serves to mark the position which Ajax <emph>was holding</emph> at the time when he was setting forth. Similarly in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 572"> <title>Ph.</title> 572</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ποῖον αὖ τόνδ’ αὐτὸς οὑδυσσεὺς ἔπλει;</quote> the imperf. refers to the motive which was actuating him. (Cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀπεμπόμην</quote> in <ref n="Soph. El. 680"> <title>El.</title> 680</ref>, and n. in append. there, p. 213.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δούλων_1235">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, Teucer as the son of an <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰχμαλωτίς</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1020">cp. 1020</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦλος.. φανείς</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποίου_ἀνδρὸς_1236">: for the gen., cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 317"> <title>El.</title> 317</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ κασιγνήτου τί φής;</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῖ_βάντος_1237">. <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ βάντος</quote> has the better MS. authority; in a question, however, between <quote xml:lang="grc">ι</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">υ</quote>, little weight can be claimed for our MSS. If <quote xml:lang="grc"> βάντος</quote> meant, ‘having taken his stand,’ then <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ βάντος</quote> would be as correct as <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ βεβηκότος</quote>.
