But when, as here, <quote xml:lang="grc">βάντος</quote> is opposed to <quote xml:lang="grc"> στάντος</quote>, it is very improbable that a writer of the classical age would have used <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ</quote> rather than <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖ</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 833"> <title>Ph.</title> 833</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ στάσει</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖ δέ μοι...βάσει</quote>. It cannot be argued from such an example as <ref n="Eur. Hec. 1057">Eur. <title>Hec.</title> 1057</ref>, <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾷ βῶ, πᾷ στῶ</quote>, that there was a tendency to repeat the same word, since <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾷ</quote> (unlike <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖ</quote>) suits both verbs alike. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρες_1238">, emphatic, like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνὴρ</quote> in 77. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πικροὺς_1239">, to our cost: <ref n="Eur. El. 470"> <title>El.</title> 470</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πικρὰν | δοκῶ με πεῖραν τήνδε τολμήσειν ἔτι</quote> (n.).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔοιγμεν_1239">, for <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐοίκαμεν</quote>, occurs also in <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 681">Eur. <title> Heracl.</title> 681</ref>, <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 99.">Eur. <title>Cycl.</title> 99.</ref> Eur. Itis not found in the Homeric poems, but may be compared with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέπιθμεν</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 2.341"> <title>Il.</title> 2. 341</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰλήλουθμεν</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.49"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 49</ref>), and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνωγμεν</quote> (<title>Hom. hymn. Apoll. Pyth.</title> 350).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπλων_ἀγῶνας_1239">: the objective gen. here denotes the prize: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 936">cp. 936</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπλων ἔκειτ’ ἀγὼν πέρι.— <emph>κηρῦξαι</emph> </quote>, instead of the usual <quote xml:lang="grc">θεῖναι</quote>: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 690"> <title>El.</title> 690</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσων γὰρ εἰσεκήρυξαν βραβῆς κ.τ.λ. </quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τότε_1239">: 650 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πανταχοῦ_1241">, ‘in every case,’— <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, whenever the result of the contest is disappointing to Teucer. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1052"> <title>Ph.</title> 1052</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νικᾶν γε μέντοι πανταχοῦ χρῄζων ἔφυν.— <emph>φανούμεθ’</emph> </quote>: 1020 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_Τεύκρου_1241">, on his part: cp. <title>O.C.</title> 51 <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐκ ἄτιμος ἔκ γ’ ἐμοῦ φανεῖ</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοὐκ_ἀρκέσει_1242">, not <quote xml:lang="grc"> μηδ’</quote>, though </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_1242"> precedes, for <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἀρκέσει</quote> is felt rather as a statement of that which is sure to happen, than as a hypothesis. Similarly <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ</quote> often stands in the second of two clauses after <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινὸν εἰ</quote> or the like: <ref n="Thuc. 1. 121">Thuc. 1. 121</ref>§ 5 <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινὸν ἂν εἴη εἰ...οὐκ ἄρα δαπανήσομεν</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 10.13">Lys. or. 10 § 13</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ οὖν δεινόν, εἰ...οὐκ ἀξιοῖς</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴκειν_ἤρεσκεν_1243">. The antecedent to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅ</quote> is <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα</quote>, a cognate acc.,—‘to yield <emph>in regard to</emph>’ what the judges decided: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1178"> <title>O. C.</title> 1178</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τάδ’ εἰκαθεῖν</quote> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 172 <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴκοντας ἃ δεῖ</quote>.—Others suppose the antecedent to be <quote xml:lang="grc"> τούτοις</quote> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1050">cp. 1050</ref>). But, for Greek idiom, such a dat. ought to denote the judges, not the judgment. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοῖς_βαλεῖτε_1244">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 724">cp. 724</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀνείδεσιν | ἤρασσον</quote> (n.): <ref n="Soph. Trach. 940"> <title>Tr.</title> 940</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥς νιν ματαίως αἰτίᾳ βάλοι κακῇ.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_δόλῳ_1244">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 641"> <title>El.</title> 641</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν φθόνῳ</quote> : <ref n="Soph. Phil. 842"> <title>Ph.</title> 842</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν ψεύδεσιν. </quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεντήσεθ_1244">. In <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1030"> <title>Ant.</title> 1030</ref>, too, <quote xml:lang="grc">κέντει</quote> is figurative,—meaning to inflict a base wrong (on the dead).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_λελειμμένοι_1244">, ye who have been left behind in the race. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 266"> <title>Tr.</title> 266</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ὧν τέκνων λείποιτο πρὸς τόξου κρίσιν</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 339">Aesch. <title> Pers.</title> 339</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῇδε λειφθῆναι μάχῃ</quote>. Polyb. 1. 62 § 6 <quote xml:lang="grc">βλέπειν τόν τε τοῦ νικᾶν ὁμοίως δὲ καὶ τὸν τοῦ λείπεσθαι καιρόν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_τρόπων_1246">, as a result of them.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατάστασις_1246">: there may be <quote xml:lang="grc">νομοθεσία</quote>, but no firm <emph>establishment</emph> of a law can come to pass. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1074">Cp. 1074</ref>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1113"> <title>Ant.</title> 1113</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς καθεστῶτας νόμους</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_νικῶντας_1248">: for the pres. partic., cp. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 8. 2. 27">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 8. 2. 27</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δὲ μὴ νικῶν τοῖς μὲν νικῶσιν ἐφθόνει.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξωθήσομεν_1248">, thrust him out of the honourable place which he has fairly wo<*> The fut. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠθήσω</quote> occurs also in <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 592"> Eur. <title>Cycl.</title> 592</ref>, <ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 300">Ar. <title> Eccl.</title> 300</ref>, but the ordinary future of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠθέω</quote> is <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤσω</quote> (as if from <quote xml:lang="grc">ὤθω</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_ὄπισθεν_1248">: a metaphor from rear and front rank suits the speaker. Cp. <ref n="Hdt. 8. 89"> Her. 8. 89</ref>(describing the confusion in the Persian fleet at Salamis), <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ ὄπισθε τεταγμένοι ἐς τὸ πρόσθε τῇσι νηυσὶ παριέναι πειρώμενοι</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰρκτέον_τάδ_1250">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1140">cp. 1140</ref>.— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλατεῖς_1250">, ‘burly,’ ‘big’; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐρύνωτοι_1250"> ‘broadshouldered.’ Ajax was <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξοχος Ἀργείων κεφαλήν τε καὶ εὐρέας ὤμους</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 3.227"> <title>Il.</title> 3. 227</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱ_εὖ_1252">: for the place of <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖ</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 723"> <title>Ant.</title> 723</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τῶν λεγόντων εὖ καλὸν τὸ μανθάνειν</quote>.—As to the verse which the paroemiographer Apostolius subjoins to this, see Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπὸ_πορεύεται_1253">: so <ref n="Soph. Trach. 391"> <title>Tr.</title> 391</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐμῶν ὑπ’ ἀγγέλων | ἀλλ’ αὐτόκλητος ἐκ δόμων πορεύεται.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σμικρᾶς_1253">, in contrast with the ‘large ribs.’ Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 477"> <title>Ant.</title> 477</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σμικρῷ χαλινῷ δ’ οἶδα τοὺς θυμουμένους | ἵππους καταρτυθέντας.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρθὸς_1253">, ‘it is brought straight into the road’ (from which it has strayed): cp. <title>Helen.</title> 1555 <quote xml:lang="grc">ταύρειος δὲ ποὺς | οὐκ ἤθελ’ ὀρθὸς σανίδα προσβῆναι κάτα</quote>, ‘to advance straight across the plank’ (into the ship). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φάρμακον_1255">, ‘corrective,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν μάστιγα</quote>. Cp. <title>O.C.</title> 714 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵπποισιν τὸν ἀκεστῆρα χαλινόν</quote>. So the bit for Pegasus, given by Athena to Bellerophon, is <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλτρον τόδ’ ἵππειον</quote> ( <ref n="Pind. O. 13">Pind. <title>O.</title> 13. 68</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">φάρμακον πραυ—/</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 85).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νοῦν_κατακτήσει_1255">: cp. <ref n="Plat. Rep. 591B">Plat. <title>Rep.</title> 591B</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ψυχὴ</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">σωφροσύνην.. κτωμένη</quote>. So <quote xml:lang="grc">κτῆμα</quote> is said of moral or mental attributes (<title>O.T.</title> 549, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1050"> <title>Ant.</title> 1050</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τινά_1255">, ironical, some small measure of it. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνδρὸς_ὄντος_1257">, genitive absolute. The genitive could not depend on </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑβρίζεις_1257">, in the sense of ‘uttering insults <emph>about</emph> him’ (like <quote xml:lang="grc">ποίου κέκραγας ἀνδρὸς</quote> in 1236). The constr. with gen. absolute (‘<emph>when</emph> he is dead’) is also more forcible. Reiske's conjecture (<quote xml:lang="grc"> ἄνδρας..ὄντας..σκιάς</quote>) is ingenious; but here the plural is evidently less fitting than in a general allusion like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν θανοῦσιν ὑβριστής</quote> (1092).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκιᾶς_1257">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1158"> <title>El.</title> 1158</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντὶ φιλτάτης | μορφῆς σποδόν τε καὶ σκιὰν ἀνωφελῆ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_σωφρονήσεις_1259">; Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1259"> <title>Ph.</title> 1259</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσωφρόνησας</quote> (‘thou hast come to thy senses’).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθὼν_φύσιν_1259">, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦλος</quote>. In <title>O.T.</title> 1068 <quote xml:lang="grc">μήποτε γνοίης ὃς εἶ</quote>, and <title>O.C.</title> 1171 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔξοιδ’ ἀκούων τῶνδ’ ὅς ἐσθ’ ὁ προστάτης</quote>, where <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅς</quote> stands, as here, for <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις</quote>, the reference is to the person's <emph> identity</emph>; here it is to his <emph>quality</emph> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">οἷος εἶ</quote>), as in <ref n="Eur. Alc. 640">Eur. <title> Alc.</title> 640</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔδειξας εἰς ἔλεγχον ἐξελθὼν ὃς εἶ</quote>: <ref n="Plat. Euthyd. 283D">Plat. <title>Euthyd.</title> 283D</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">βούλεσθε γενέσθαι αὐτὸν σοφόν, ἀμαθῆ δὲ μὴ εἶναι;...οὐκοῦν ὃς μὲν οὐκ ἔστι, βούλεσθε αὐτὸν γενέσθαι, ὃς δ’ ἔστι νῦν, μηκέτι εἶναι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλον_ἐλεύθερον_1260">, some one else, who (unlike thee) is a free man. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 6.84"> <title>Od.</title> 6. 84</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅμα τῇ γε</quote> (with their mistress) <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἀμφίπολοι κίον ἄλλαι</quote> . <ref n="Plat. Gorg. 473C">Plat. <title>Gorg.</title> 473C</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν πολιτῶν καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ξένων</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντὶ_σά_1261">. At Athens, as elsewhere, a slave had no <emph>locus standi</emph> in a law-court, and could plead to a charge only through his master. Cp. frag. adesp. 304 (Nauck p. 897) <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦλος πέφυκας, οὐ μέτεστί σοι λόγου</quote>. In <ref n="Plat. Gorg. 483B">Plat. <title>Gorg.</title> 483B</ref> incapacity for self-defence generally (<quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς αὑτῷ βοηθεῖν</quote>) is noted as characteristic of the servile condition. Cp. <title>O.T.</title> 410 f. (n.), where Teiresias says that he is not the <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦλος</quote> of Oedipus, and therefore has the right <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴσ’ ἀντιλέξαι</quote>, instead of pleading only by Creon's mouth. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_λέγοντος_1262"> could depend on </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάθοιμ_1262"> as=‘understand’ ( <ref n="Plat. Gorg. 463D">Plat. <title>Gorg.</title> 463D</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρ’ οὖν ἂν μάθοις ἀποκριναμένου;</quote>), but is better taken as gen. abs., since thus we obtain a clearer sense for </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκέτ_1262">: ‘when <emph>thou</emph> beginnest to speak, my power of comprehension ceases.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάρβαρον_1263">, because Teucer's mother Hesionè was Trojan.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπαΐω_1263">, a current word in Attic ( <title> Nub.</title> 650 etc.), is used in this sense by Plato both with acc. and with gen. The simple <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀΐω</quote>, which is poetical only, has a like sense in <title>O.C.</title> 181, <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ γὰρ ἀΐεις</quote> (‘for thou understandest’). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φράσαι_1265">, <emph>monstrare</emph>, or <emph> suadere</emph>; cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 53"> <title>Tr.</title> 53</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φράσαι τὸ σόν</quote>, to indicate thy duty. So of a teacher's directions, <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 6.13">Antiphon or. 6 § 13</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ τι φράζοι ὁ διδάσκαλος</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_τις_1266">, ‘in what quick fashion’ (with what strange quickness): cp. <title>O.T.</title> 618 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν ταχύς τις οὑπιβουλεύων λάθρᾳ | χωρῇ</quote>, ‘when the stealthy plotter is advancing in quick fashion.’</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βροτοῖς_1266">, ethic dat., ‘in the minds of men.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διαρρεῖ_1266">: said in fr. 787. 9 of the waning moon; <quote xml:lang="grc">διαρρεῖ κἀπὶ μηδὲν ἔρχεται</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 523">Cp. 523</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπορρεῖ μνῆστις.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προδοῦσ_ἁλίσκεται_1266">. Here <quote xml:lang="grc">χάρις τοῦ θανόντος</quote> is that grateful memory of the dead which ought to abide in men's minds. When this memory deserts them, it is a traitor to the dead. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 46"> <title>Ant.</title> 46</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ δὴ προδοῦσ’ ἁλώσομαι</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδ_λόγων_1268">. In <ref n="Eur. El. 415"> <title>El.</title> 415</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σμικροὶ λόγοι</quote> mean ‘few’ or ‘brief’ words. Probably the sense here is, ‘not even in brief words.’ This use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπί</quote> with the genitive is illustrated by two passages which Wolff has quoted; <ref n="Plat. Sym. 192C">Plat. <title>Symp.</title> 192C</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕτερος ἑτέρῳ χαίρει ξυνὼν οὕτως ἐπὶ μεγάλης σπουδῆς</quote> (‘<emph>with</emph> such great eagerness’): <ref n="Dem. 18.17">Dem. or. 18 § 17</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε δικαίως οὔτ’ ἐπ’ ἀληθείας οὐδεμιᾶς εἰρημένα</quote> (‘nor <emph>with</emph> any truth’). Julian or. 3. 128 A (quoted by Lobeck) has <quote xml:lang="grc">τούτων ἐπὶ σμικρῶν μνημονεύει</quote>, meaning by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ σμικρῶν</quote> ‘in brief words only.’ (In <ref n="Eur. El. 414"> <title>El.</title> 414</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ σμικρὸν</quote>=‘to a small extent only’: the <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ σμικρῶν</quote> is there an error.) I formerly took <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ σμικρῶν λόγων</quote> as=‘not even in slight <emph>respects</emph>,’ ‘on slight accounts,’ but now doubt whether this sense can be given to the plural of <quote xml:lang="grc"> λόγος</quote>.—The best emendation, if any were needed, would be <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἐπὶ σμικρὸν λόγον</quote>, ‘not even to the extent of a brief mention’; but, though <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ σμικρὸν</quote> can bear this sense ( <ref n="Eur. El. 414"> <title>El.</title> 414</ref>), the phrase is hardly satisfactory when <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγον</quote> is added. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗ_1269"> depends on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προὔκαμες_1269">: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δορί_1269"> should be taken with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προτείνων_1269">. Cp. [Eur. ] <title>Rhes.</title> 183 <quote xml:lang="grc">ψυχὴν προβάλλοντ’ ἐν κύβοισι δαίμονος</quote>. There is a reminiscence of the words of Achilles, <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰὲν ἐμὴν ψυχὴν παραβαλλόμενος πολεμίζειν</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.322"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 322</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρριμμένα_1271">, contemptuously flung aside: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 215">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 215</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Κύπρις δ’ ἄτιμος τῷδ’ ἀπέρριπται λόγῳ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀνόητ_1272"> seems fitter here than <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀνόνητ’</quote>: though its superiority is not so clear as that of <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀνόνητα</quote> over <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀνόητα</quote> in 758. The balance of manuscript authority, too, is here on the side of <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀνόητ’</quote>, though there is no such unanimity as supports <quote xml:lang="grc"> κἀνόνητα</quote> in 758,—a difference which the nature of the two passages sufficiently explains. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_οὐδέν_1273"> (adv.), </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡνίκα_1273">, as we say, ‘remember when...’: so <ref n="Thuc. 2. 21">Thuc. 2. 21</ref>§ 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμνημένοι καὶ Πλειστοάνακτα..ὅτε ἐσβαλὼν..ἀνεχώρησε πάλιν</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Tro. 70">Eur. <title>Tro.</title> 70</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶδ’ ἡνίκ’ Αἴας εἷλκε Κασσάνδραν βία</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑρκέων_ἐγκεκλῃμένους_1274">, ‘shut within your lines.’ Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 451">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 451</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τόνδ’ εἰσεδέξω τειχέων</quote>=<quote xml:lang="grc">εἴσω τειχέων ἐδέξω</quote>. There, as here, the genitive would probably be felt in the first instance as a genitive of place (‘<emph>at</emph> the walls,’ like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσχάτης.. πυρᾶς</quote> in <ref n="Soph. El. 900">Soph. <title>El.</title> 900</ref> f.); and the special sense required by the context (‘within’) would be suggested by the compound verb <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰσεδέξω</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑρκέων_1274">: the wall, surrounded by a fosse, which the Greeks at Troy built to protect their ships, drawn up on the shore of the Hellespont. <ref n="Hom. Il. 12.4"> <title>Il.</title> 12. 4</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τεῖχος ὕπερθεν | εὐρύ, τὸ ποιήσαντο νεῶν ὕπερ, ἀμφὶ δὲ τάφρον | ἤλασαν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ὄντας_1275">: so <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1107"> <title>Tr.</title> 1107</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἂν τὸ μηδὲν ὦ</quote>, ‘though I am as naught.’ <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1281">Cp. 1281</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_δορός_1275">, at the moment when your battle had been turned back,—when you had been routed. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 674"> <title>Ant.</title> 674</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀναρχία</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">συμμάχου δορὸς | τροπὰς καταρρήγνυσι</quote>. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1237">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1237</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν μάχης τροπῇ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφὶ_ἑδωλίοις_1276">: ‘when fire was now blazing around the quarter-decks of the ships at their sterns (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκροισιν</quote>).’ Three points should be noted.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄκροισιν_1276"> denotes the position of the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑδώλια</quote> at the extremities, or sterns, of the ships. Though the <title>Iliad</title> is not closely followed here, Sophocles may probably have had in mind how the Trojans fired the ship of Protesilaüs <emph>at the stern: </emph> <ref n="Hom. Il. 16.124"> Il. 16. 124</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὣς τὴν μὲν πρύμνην πῦρ ἄμφεπεν</quote>. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.241"> <title>Il.</title> 9. 241</ref> it is said of Hector, <quote xml:lang="grc">στεῦται γὰρ νηῶν ἀποκόψειν ἄκρα κόρυμβα</quote>,—the ‘crowning ensigns’ (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἄφλαστα</quote>, <emph> aplustria</emph>) at the sterns. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκροισιν</quote> might also mean ‘topmost,’—the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑδώλια</quote> being a <emph>raised</emph> deck. This, however, would suggest rather flames <emph>shooting up</emph> to a great height; but in <ref n="Hom. Il. 15.716"> <title>Il.</title> 15. 716</ref> f., where Hector grasps the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄφλαστον</quote>, it appears that even this can have been only some 7 to 9 feet from the ground, and that the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴκρια</quote> at the stern (the Homeric equivalent of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑδώλια</quote> here) can have stood only about 5 feet from the ground. (See Dr Warre E. in Smith's <title>Dict. of Ant.</title>, 3rd ed., vol. II. p. 211 <emph>b</emph>, art. <title>Navis.</title>)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναυτικοῖς_1276">, after <quote xml:lang="grc"> νεῶν</quote>, is pleonastic, if <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑδώλια</quote> be explained as above; whereas, if <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑδώλια</quote> meant the rowers' seats, <quote xml:lang="grc">ναυτικοῖς</quote> could mean, belonging to the <quote xml:lang="grc">ναῦται</quote>. This is a fair objection to the interpretation given above. But in reply to it we may observe:—(1) the word <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑδώλια</quote> means ‘dwellings,’ ‘abodes’ in <ref n="Eur. El. 1393"> <title>El.</title> 1393</ref>, <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 71">Aesch. <title> Ch.</title> 71</ref>, <ref n="Aesch. Seven 455.">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 455.</ref>The nautical sense occurs (apart from <ref n="Hdt. 1. 24"> Her. 1. 24</ref>) only here, and in <title>Helen.</title> 1571, <ref n="Eur. Cycl. 238."> <title>Cycl.</title> 238.</ref>Hence the distinctive epithet is intelligible. (2) Further, as the purport of the passage is to mark the urgency of the danger to the ships, on which the ultimate safety of the Greeks depended, there is excuse for the emphatic iteration, <quote xml:lang="grc">νεῶν —ναυτικοῖς—ναυτικά</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_ὕπερ_1277">. The situation described here does not exactly correspond with anything in the <title>Iliad.</title> Ajax, indeed, distinguishes himself in repulsing the Trojans after they have come over the wall, and on one occasion wounds their leader Hector ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 14.409"> <title>Il.</title> 14. 409</ref> ff.); but this happens before any ship has been set on fire. The supreme crisis in this part of the <title> Iliad</title> is the moment when the Trojans set fire to the ship of Protesilaüs (16. 122); but just then Ajax is driven back (<quote xml:lang="grc">χάζετο δ’ ἐκ βελέων</quote> <foreign xml:lang="lat"> ib.</foreign>); it is Patroclus who, urged by Achilles, then comes to the front, and finally beats back the foe. Nor has the <title>Iliad</title> directly furnished the picture of Hector ‘leaping high’ over the trench.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗ_ποδί_1281">. This excellent emendation (by Madvig) of the obscure </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲσυμβῆναι_ποδί_1281"> is irresistibly commended by those very words of Agamemnon to which Teucer refers (1237), <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖ βάντος ἢ ποῦ στάντος, οὗπερ οὐκ ἐγώ;</quote> The origin of the corruption may have been the effacement of the H in MH, giving rise to <quote xml:lang="grc">ΣΥΜΒΗΝΑΙ</quote>, when <quote xml:lang="grc">ΟΥ</quote> would be altered into <quote xml:lang="grc">ΟΥΔΕ</quote> to satisfy the metre. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συμβῆναι_ποδί_1281"> has been explained: (1) ‘to come and join thee’ on the field of danger. But, even if <quote xml:lang="grc">συμβῆναι ποδί</quote> could bear this sense, Agam. could not say that Ajax had never fought on his side at Troy. (2) ‘To meet’ the foe, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς πολεμίοις</quote>: which is plainly untenable. Agamemnon had asked merely, ‘what has Ajax done <emph>that I have not done?</emph>’ Teucer has replied by referring to the crisis at the ships; and now drives his point home. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑμὶν_ἔνδικα_1282">, just in your eyes (ethic dat.): cp. <title>O.C.</title> 1446 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάξιαι γὰρ πᾶσίν ἐστε δυστυχεῖν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 495">Soph. <title>Ph.</title> 495</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοφοῖς | καὶ τοῖσι φαύλοις ἔνδιχ’, ὡς ἐμοὶ δοκεῖ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸς_1283">, ‘by himself,’ ‘alone’: cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 504">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 504</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτοὶ γάρ ἐσμεν.— <emph>μόνος μόνου</emph> </quote>: though <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτός</quote> has preceded, <quote xml:lang="grc">μόνος</quote> is added to emphasise the idea of single combat. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 467">Cp. 467</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μόνος μόνοις</quote>: <ref n="Dem. 18.137">Dem. or. 18 § 137</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ ὑπὸ τῶν πολεμίων πεμφθέντι μόνος μόνῳ συνῄει</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαχών_κἀκέλευστος_1283">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, simply because, among the Greek warriors who had <emph>offered</emph> to meet Hector, he was the one who drew the lot; not because he had been <emph>urged</emph> to undertake the task. <quote xml:lang="grc">λαχών</quote> implies <quote xml:lang="grc">ἑκών</quote>, since lots were drawn only for those who had volunteered.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_δραπέτην_1285"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The ordinary <quote xml:lang="grc">κλῆρος</quote> was a stone or a potsherd, which its owner marked ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.175"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 175</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλῆρον ἐσημήναντο ἕκαστος</quote>). Ajax did not seek to avoid being drawn by putting in, as his <quote xml:lang="grc">κλῆρος</quote>, a piece of damp earth, which would stick to the bottom of the helmet or fall to pieces. Such a <quote xml:lang="grc">κλῆρος</quote> is called <quote xml:lang="grc">δραπέτης</quote>, ‘a <emph>runaway</emph>,’ because it eludes the ordeal. The allusion is to the story of Cresphontes. After the Dorian conquest of the Peloponnesus, he, Temenus, and the heirs of Aristodemus agreed to cast lots. The first was to have Argos; the second, Lacedaemon; the third, Messenia. Cresphontes wished to have Messenia. He therefore put a lump of earth, as his <quote xml:lang="grc"> κλῆρος</quote>, into the voting urn. It broke to pieces, so that only the two other <quote xml:lang="grc">κλῆροι</quote> came out. ( <ref n="Apollod. 2.8.4">Apollod. 2. 8. 4</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆς ἐνέβαλε βῶλον, ταύτης δὲ διαλυθείσης ἔδει τοὺς δύο κλήρους ἀναφανῆναι</quote>.) The scholiast remarks on the anachronism (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνῆκται τοῖς χρόνοις ἡ ἱστορία ἡ περὶ Κρεσφόντου</quote>): so, too, does Eustathius (p. 361. 26).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυνῆς_1285">: <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.182"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 182</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ δ’ ἔθορεν κλῆρος κυνέης, ὃν ἄρ’ ἤθελον αὐτοί</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc"> Αἴαντος.— <emph>ἅλμα κουφιεῖν</emph> </quote> =<quote xml:lang="grc">ἅλμα κοῦφον ἁλεῖσθαι</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 860">Eur. <title>El.</title> 860</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐράνιον | πήδημα κουφίζουσα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_παρών_1288">. <quote xml:lang="grc"> ταῦτα</quote> includes the combat with Hector, in which Teucer, of course, had no part; but he was the comrade of Ajax in the <quote xml:lang="grc">τειχομαχία</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 15.436"> <title>Il.</title> 15. 436</ref> ff.), as often on other occasions (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, <ref n="Hom. Il. 7.266"> <title>Il.</title> 7. 266</ref> ff.). For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_1288"> as adv., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 959">cp. 959</ref>.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_δοῦλος_1288">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1260">cp. 1260</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύστηνε_1290">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1203">cp. 1203</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύσμορος.— <emph>ποῖ βλέπων</emph> </quote>, ‘whither canst thou be looking?’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, ‘how canst thou be so blind?’ [Not: ‘<emph>in reliance on</emph> what?’—like <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς ὅ τι βλέπω</quote> in 514.] We should distinguish this <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>ποῖ</emph> βλέπων</quote> from <quote xml:lang="grc"> <emph>πῶς</emph> βλέπων</quote>, ‘with what face?’ ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 110"> <title>Ph.</title> 110</ref>: <title>O.T.</title> 1371 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄμμασιν ποίοις βλέπων</quote>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_θροεῖς_1290">: <quote xml:lang="grc">καί</quote> emphasizes the verb: ‘how <emph>canst</emph> thou utter the words?’ Cp. <title> O.T.</title> 1129 <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῖον ἄνδρα καὶ λέγεις;</quote> <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 12.29">Lys. or. 12 § 29</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὰ τοῦ ποτε καὶ λήψεσθε δίκην;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: παρὰ τοῦ ποτε καὶ λήψεσθε δίκην;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φρύγα_1291">: the term is used invidiously, but is not incorrect. Sipylus, the legendary seat of Tantalus, father of Pelops, was in Maeonia, afterwards called Lydia; but Phrygia, in the older and larger sense, included that region. (Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 824"> <title>Ant.</title> 824</ref> where Niobe, daughter of Tantalus, is <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰν Φρυγίαν</quote>.) In <ref n="Hdt. 7. 11"> Her. 7. 11</ref>Xerxes speaks of <quote xml:lang="grc">Πέλοψ ὁ Φρύξ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσσεβέστατον_1293"> could go with (1) <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀτρέα</quote>, (2) <quote xml:lang="grc">σε</quote>, or (3) <quote xml:lang="grc">δεῖπνον</quote>. As the guilt of <title> Atreus</title> is the point, (2) is less relevant, and (3) is perhaps best.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀδελφῷ_1293"> Thyestes. Atreus, seeking revenge for certain grievous wrongs, feigned to have forgiven him, and bade him to a feast at Mycenae. There the flesh of three of his sons was set before Thyestes. In <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1591">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1591</ref>Aegisthus (a son of Thyestes) says: <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀτρεὺς προθύμως μᾶλλον ἢ φίλως πατρὶ | τὠμῷ, κρεουργὸν ἦμαρ εὐθύμως ἄγειν | δοκῶν, παρέσχε δαῖτα παιδείων κρεῶν</quote>. Schol. <ref n="Eur. Orest. 812">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 812</ref>(alluding to the <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀτρεὺς ἢ Μυκηναῖαι</quote> of Sophocles), <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς τρεῖς υἱοὺς τοῦ Θυέστου, Ἀγλαὸν Ὀρχόμενον καὶ Κάλεον, ἀποκτείνας παρέθηκεν εἰς τράπεζαν τῷ πατρί</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Κρήσσης_1295">: Aëropè, daughter of Catreus, king of Crete, a descendant of Minos. According to the legend which Sophocles follows here, Catreus found Aëropè with a paramour (a slave), and sent her to Nauplius, king of Euboea, charging him to drown her. Nauplius, however, spared her life, and she afterwards married Atreus. The scholiast on 1297 says that this was the story treated by Euripides in the <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρῆσσαι</quote> (Nauck <title>Trag. Frag.</title> p. 501); with the difference, however, that Aëropè married Pleisthenes, not Atreus. The <quote xml:lang="grc">Κρῆσσαι</quote> was produced in 438 B.C. (<title>Argum.</title> Eur. <title>Alc.</title>) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπακτὸν_1296">, ‘imported,’ ‘alien’; <ref n="Soph. Trach. 259"> <title>Tr.</title> 259</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατὸν..ἐπακτόν</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1525"> <title>O. C.</title> 1525</ref> n.: <ref n="Eur. Ion 592">Eur. <title> Ion</title> 592</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πατρός τ’ ἐπακτοῦ καὐτὸς ὢν νοθαγενής</quote> (bastard son of the alien Xuthus): here, a paramour, as opposed to a lawful husband.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_πατήρ_1296"> can mean only the father of Aëropè, Catreus. Now, according to the schol. on <ref n="Eur. Orest. 812">Eur. <title>Or.</title> 812</ref>, Sophocles (in a play not named there, but which was probably the <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀτρεὺς ἢ Μυκηναῖαι</quote>) somewhere described <title> Atreus</title> himself as drowning his false wife for a twofold crime,—adultery with Thyestes, and the theft of the golden lamb: <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν γυναῖκα Ἀερόπην τιμωρεῖται κατ’ ἄμφω...ῥίψας αὐτὴν εἰς τὴν θάλασσαν, ὡς φησὶ Σοφοκλῆς</quote>. Hence it has been proposed to change </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατὴρ_1296"> into </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σ_Ἀτρεὺς_1296"> (Hermann), or </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σἀνὴρ_1296"> (Wolff). A simpler correction would be, <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ σ’ ἐκφύσας πατήρ</quote>. But it cannot be assumed that Sophocles must have followed here the same version which he used elsewhere. In his <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀλήτης</quote>, for example, he appears to have modified the version of the <quote xml:lang="grc"> Ὀρεστεία</quote> which he adopts in his <title>Electra</title> (see <title> El.</title>, Introd., p. xliii, n. 4). The story of Aëropè's detection by Catreus is effective for the purpose here, which is to represent Agamemnon as born of a mother who had sinned before his birth. Nor is that story necessarily inconsistent with the other, that she was false to Atreus, and was drowned by him. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐφῆκεν_διαφθοράν_1297">, ‘<emph>consigned</emph> her as a prey,’ since he charged Nauplius to drown her,—though the charge was not executed. Schol.: <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ πατὴρ Ναυπλίῳ παρέδωκεν, ἐντειλάμενος ἀποποντῶσαι· ὁ δὲ οὐκ ἐποίησεν</quote>.—Cp. <ref n="Eur. Her. 458">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 458</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐτέκ‐</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">ομεν ὑμᾶς· πολεμίοις δ’ ἐθρεψάμην | ὕβρισμα κἀπίχαρμα καὶ διαφθοράν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλλοῖς_1297">, traditionally explained as ‘mute,’ is a word of unknown origin. In Athen. 277 C this verse is quoted, and the question is raised whether any one before Sophocles had used the word: the answer is a quotation from a <quote xml:lang="grc">Τιτανομαχία</quote> (variously ascribed to Eumêlus or Arctînus), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν δ’ αὐτῇ πλωτοὶ χρυσώπιδες ἰχθύες ἐλλοί</quote>: with the comment, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχαιρε δὲ Σοφοκλῆς τῷ Ἐπικῷ κύκλῳ</quote>. The form <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλλοψ</quote> occurs in <title>Scut.</title> 212 (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλλοπας ἰχθῦς</quote>), and as a subst. (‘fish’) in the Alexandrian poets (Lycophron 598, 1375: <ref n="Nic. Alex. 481"> Nicander <title>Alex.</title> 481</ref>). A third form, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλλοπος</quote>, is the epithet of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰχθύς</quote> in Empedocles, v. 12. A desperate etymology is suggested in Athen. 307 C, from <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἴλλεσθαι</quote> (as=<quote xml:lang="grc">εἴργεσθαι</quote>) and <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄψ</quote>, ‘debarred from utterance.’ Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 578">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 578</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκύλλονται πρὸς ἀναύδων, ἐή</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">παίδων τᾶς ἀμιάντου</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_μὲν_1299">, as if <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ δὲ μητρὸς</quote> were to follow, but the constr. changes; cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 6"> <title>Tr.</title> 6</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥτις πατρὸς μὲν κ.τ.λ.</quote> (where no <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ</quote> follows). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅστις_1300"> with causal force, ‘one who..’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_πρῶτ_1300">, an adverbial cognate acc., like <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντ’ ἀριστεύσας</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 195"> <title>Ant.</title> 195</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴσχει_1301">, historic pres., referring to a well-known fact (cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 560"> <title>O. T.</title> 560</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρρει</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 727"> <title>Ph.</title> 727</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοῖς πλάθει</quote> ).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φύσει_μὲν_1301">: the antithesis is with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔκκριτον δέ</quote>: as her <emph>birth</emph> was royal, so her <emph>beauty</emph> marked her out to be his prize. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βασίλεια_1302">: for the initial anapaest, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1172">cp. 1172</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λαομέδοντος_1302">, his daughter; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 172">cp. 172</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Διὸς Ἄρτεμις</quote> (n.). For the anapaest in the proper name, cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 11"> <title>Ant.</title> 11</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OC 507."> <title>O. C.</title> 507.</ref>—Apollo and Poseidon having been defrauded by Laomedon of their recompense for building the walls of Troy, the sea-god sent a dragon into the Troad. Hesionè, the false king's daughter, was doomed to be sacrificed to the monster, when Heracles slew it, and saved her. He, too, was cheated by Laomedon of his promised reward (the horses given to Tros by Zeus); he sacked Troy, and gave Hesionè to Telamon. ( <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.638"> <title>Il.</title> 5. 638</ref> ff.: <ref n="Pind. I. 5">Pind. <title> I.</title> 5. 27</ref> ff.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔκκριτον_1302">, chosen out of the spoil, and reserved as a special meed of honour: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 954"> Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 954</ref>(of Cassandra) <quote xml:lang="grc">αὕτη δέ, πολλῶν χρημάτων ἐξαίρετον | ἄνθος, στρατοῦ δώρημ’, ἐμοὶ ξυνέσπετο</quote>. So in Latin <emph>exsors</emph>, <ref n="Verg. A. 8. 552">Verg. <title> Aen.</title> 8. 552</ref> <title>Ducunt exsortem Aeneae</title> (equum). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄριστος_1304"> combines the ideas of <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ γενναῖον</quote> and <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ εὐγενές</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 636">cp. 636</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</quote> <quote xml:lang="grc">πατρῴας ἥκων γενεᾶς ἄριστος</quote>. The conjecture </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀριστεὺς_1304"> is needless, and is also less suitable, since it would imply a recognised rank which Teucer did not actually hold.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀριστέοιν_1304"> is probably right; but <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀριστέων</quote> (see cr. n.) would be tenable (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 237">cp. 237</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύο..κριούς</quote> , <ref n="Eur. El. 701"> <title>El.</title> 701</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύο | Λίβυες</quote> ).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_αἵματος_1304">: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 1125"> <title>El.</title> 1125</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ φίλων τις ἢ πρὸς αἵματος</quote> (n.). Agamemnon had told Teucer to bring some free man to plead the cause of Ajax (1260 f.). Teucer asks, ‘Why should it dishonour Ajax to have his cause pleaded by the son of Telamon and Hesionè?’ For the allusive plur., <ref n="Soph. Aj. 734">cp. 734</ref>, 1092. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιοῖσδ_κειμένους_1306">, ‘laid low (dead), amidst such troubles,’—<foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, self-slain, under circumstances of such horror. For <quote xml:lang="grc">κειμένους</quote> cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1174"> <title>Ant.</title> 1174</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τίς φονεύει; τίς δ’ ὁ κείμενος;</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠθεῖς_1306">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1064">cp. 1064</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφὶ χλωρὰν ψάμαθον ἐκβεβλημένος.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδ_λέγων_1306">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι ὠθεῖς</quote>. Agamemnon had not expressly repeated the prohibition of burial, but the whole drift of his speech was to confirm the doom pronounced by Menelaüs. It seems strange, then, that <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγων</quote> should have been so much suspected (cr. n.).—Cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 929"> <title>Ph.</title> 929</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἐπαισχύνει μ’ ὁρῶν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαλεῖτέ_που_1308">. Though <quote xml:lang="grc"> ποι</quote> would better bring out the notion of ‘casting <emph>forth</emph> ,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">που</quote> is also correct; cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 481"> <title>Ph.</title> 481</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμβαλοῦ μ’ ὅπῃ θέλεις</quote> (not <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅποι</quote>, though <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἀντλίαν</quote> etc. follows).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χἡμᾶς_τρεῖς_1308">, Tecmessa, Eurysaces, and himself; all three are ready to perish in defence of the corpse. The child is still kneeling as a suppliant beside the body, and clinging to it (1180); his mother is near him. A scholiast in L understands the ‘three’ to be Agamemnon, Menelaüs, and Teucer— a theory which the word <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμᾶς</quote> itself refutes. One of the later scholia, however, gives the right explanation.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συγκειμένους_1308">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> prostrate in death at his side (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1306">cp. 1306</ref> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλόν_μοι_1310">, as in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 72"> <title>Ant.</title> 72</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">θάψω· καλόν μοι τοῦτο ποιούσῃ θανεῖν.— <emph>ὑπερπονουμένῳ</emph> </quote>: the only instance of this compound in the middle (as <quote xml:lang="grc">προπονουμένας</quote> in <ref n="Soph. OT 685"> <title>O. T.</title> 685</ref> is also unique). The active <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπερπονεῖν</quote> occurs in <ref n="Soph. OC 345."> <title>O. C.</title> 345.</ref>— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προδήλως_1310"> : <ref n="Soph. Aj. 229">cp. 229</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> περίφαντος..θανεῖται</quote>. It is better to die in making a public protest against the wrong to Ajax, than to fall in battle for Helen's sake.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_λέγω_1310">; ‘thy wife—or should I rather (<quote xml:lang="grc">γε</quote>) say, thy brother's?’ Teucer speaks, with bitter scorn, as if he did not know or care to which of the brothers Helen belonged: at any rate, it is <emph> their</emph> war, and she is the pretext of it. Eustathius (p. 754. 21) thinks that this touch was suggested to Sophocles by the scornful phrases in which Achilles refers to the Atreidae, when he speaks of himself as <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδράσι μαρνάμενος ὀάρων ἕνεκα σφετεράων</quote>, ‘for their lady-loves' sakes,’—and asks, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ μοῦνοι φιλέουσ’ ἀλόχους μερόπων ἀνθρώπων | Ἀτρεῖδαι;</quote> Teucer speaks, at any rate, in the same vein. The words of Eustathius prove that he read <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς σῆς</quote>, and that he understood the text in the manner explained above: <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ Σοφοκλῆς... ποιεῖ τὸν Τεῦκρον λέγοντα τῷ Ἀγαμέμνονι ὅτι ὁ Αἴας διὰ τὴν αὐτοῦ γυναῖκα ἐν Τροίᾳ ἐμάχετο, ταὐτόν τι λογισάμενος τὸ διὰ τὴν αὐτοῦ καὶ διὰ τὴν τοῦ Μενελάου τοῦ ἀδελφοῦ</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_λέγω_1310"> (subjunct.), cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 1073">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 1073</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’ αὖ τρίτος ἦλθέ ποθεν σωτήρ</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ μόρον εἴπω;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὐμόν_1313">, ‘my interest’: cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 251"> <title>El.</title> 251</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ σὸν σπεύδουσ’ ἅμα | καὶ τοὐμόν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ἐμοί_1315">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1092">cp. 1092</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν θανοῦσιν ὑβριστής</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καιρὸν_1316">, adv.: 34 f.—The sense of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνάψων_1316"> here is shown by that of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συλλύσων_1316">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, the one means ‘to help in tying a knot’; the other, ‘to help in loosing it.’ ‘If thou hast come, not <emph>to make the tangle worse</emph>—not to embroil the feud—but to aid in solving it.’ <quote xml:lang="grc"> συνάπτειν</quote> is also said of bringing opponents <emph>into conflict;</emph> <title>Suppl.</title> 479 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπὶς βροτοῖς κάκιστον, ἣ πολλὰς πόλεις | ξυνῆψε</quote>: but here the metaphor is from a knot. Our word ‘embroil’ exactly fits <quote xml:lang="grc">συνάπτειν</quote> here, since its primary sense is ‘to entangle’ or ‘perplex’ (<emph>embrouiller</emph>, <emph>imbrogliare</emph>). (The phrase in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 40"> <title>Ant.</title> 40</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λύουσ’ ..ἢ )φάπτουσα</quote> cannot properly be compared: see n. there.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βοὴν_Ἀτρειδῶν_1316">: he had first heard the voice of Menelaüs (who made his exit at v. 1160), and then, after an interval, that of Agamemnon. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_γὰρ_1320"> often introduces an indignant retort: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 20"> <title>Ant.</title> 20</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΙΣ. τί δ’ ἔστι;</quote> ... | <quote xml:lang="grc">ΑΝ. οὐ γὰρ τάφου νῷν, κ.τ.λ.</quote> Cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 576">Ar. <title>Ach.</title> 576</ref>, <ref n="Aristoph. Pl. 856">Ar. <title>Pl.</title> 856</ref>, <title> Vesp.</title> 836.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλύοντές_ἐσμεν_1320">=<quote xml:lang="grc"> κλύομεν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1062">cp. 1062</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐστὶ.. σθένων</quote>: 1324 <quote xml:lang="grc"> δρῶν..ἦν</quote>: 1330 <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴην..φρονῶν.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρτίως_1320"> is joined with the present tense as in <ref n="Eur. El. 347"> <title>El.</title> 347</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγεις..ἀρτίως</quote> (‘you have just been saying’). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φλαῦρα_1323">. In phrases denoting censure or disparagement, writers of the classical age regularly use the form <quote xml:lang="grc">φλαῦρος</quote>, not <quote xml:lang="grc">φαῦλος</quote> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, <ref n="Hdt. 7. 10"> Her. 7. 10</ref>§ 7 <quote xml:lang="grc">φλαύρως ἀκούειν</quote>: <title>Nub.</title> 834 <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μηδὲν εἴπῃς φλαῦρον ἄνδρας δεξιούς</quote> , <ref n="Aristoph. Lys. 1044"> <title>Lys.</title> 1044</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">φλαῦρον εἰπεῖν οὐδεέν</quote>: <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.30">Antiphon or. 5 § 30</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτος μὲν οὐδὲν εἶπε περὶ ἐμοῦ φλαῦρον</quote> </cit> : <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 8. 2. 12">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 8. 2. 12</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μνησθῆναι..περὶ Κύρου φλαῦρόν τι</quote>: <ref n="Isoc. 5.76">Isocr. or. 5 § 76</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν ἂν λέγοι περὶ αὐτοῦ φλαῦρον</quote>: <ref n="Dem. 20.13">Dem. or. 20 § 13</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ οἶδα οὐδὲ λέγω φλαῦρον οὐδέν</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> § 102 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν γὰρ φλαῦρον ἐρῶ δε</quote>: or. 21 § 208 <quote xml:lang="grc">περὶ ὧν οὐδὲν ἂν εἴποιμι πρὸς ὑμᾶς φλαῦρον ἐγώ</quote>: or. 22 § 12 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵνα μηδὲν εἴπω φλαῦρον.</quote> </gloss>

data.quote: οὗτος μὲν οὐδὲν εἶπε περὶ ἐμοῦ φλαῦρον

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συμβαλεῖν_κακά_1323">, to pit taunts against taunts, like <quote xml:lang="grc">συμβάλλειν μάχην, ἔριν</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. Med. 522">Eur. <title>Med.</title> 522</ref>), etc. Cp. <ref n="Eur. IA 830">Eur. <title>I.A.</title> 830</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχρὸν δέ μοι γυναιξὶ συμβάλλειν λόγους.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακά_1323">, instead of repeating <quote xml:lang="grc">φλαῦρα</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 22">cp. 22</ref> n.: <title>O.C.</title> 1501 <quote xml:lang="grc">σαφὴς μὲν ἀστῶν, ἐμφανὴς δὲ τοῦ ξένου</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤκουσεν_αἰσχρά_1324">: so <ref n="Soph. Phil. 607"> <title>Ph.</title> 607</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ πάντ’ ἀκούων αἰσχρὰ καὶ λωβήτ’ ἔπη.— <emph>δρῶν γὰρ ἦν τοιαῦτά με</emph> </quote> : <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχρὰ ἔλεγέ με</quote>, since <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤκουσεν αἰσχρά</quote> implies <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ αἰσχρὰ ἔλεγον αὐτόν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥστε_ἔχειν_1325"> (<quote xml:lang="grc">σε</quote>), so that you have actually been injured: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 799">Aesch. <title>Eum.</title> 799</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ταῦτ’ Ὀρέστην δρῶντα μὴ βλάβας ἔχειν</quote>.—Not: ‘What has he done so bad that it is fraught with harm?’ (like <ref n="Eur. Ion 1350">Eur. <title>Ion</title> 1350</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχει δέ μοι τί κέρδος ἢ τίνα βλάβην;</quote>) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἐάσειν_1326">..</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλὰ_θάψειν_1326">: cp. <ref n="Hdt. 7. 104"> Her. 7. 104</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐῶν φεύγειν.. ἀλλὰ μένοντας..ἐπικρατέειν</quote>. So in <title>O.T.</title> 241 <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠθεῖν</quote> depends on <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐδῶ</quote> supplied from <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπαυδῶ</quote> (<emph>veto</emph>) in 236.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταφῆς_ἄμοιρον_1326">, without its due <quote xml:lang="grc">μοῖρα</quote> of funeral rites. In <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1071"> <title>Ant.</title> 1071</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄμοιρος</quote> (without <quote xml:lang="grc">ταφῆς</quote>) has this sense, the context sufficing to define it,— <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄμοιρον, ἀκτέριστον, ἀνόσιον νέκυν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνηρετεῖν_1329"> is Lobeck's certain correction of the MS. reading, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνηρετμεῖν_1329">. The latter would be formed from an adj. <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνήρετμος</quote>, which does not occur, but which would be like <quote xml:lang="grc"> εὐήρετμος</quote>, etc. (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρετμόν</quote>, oar). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνηρετεῖν_1329_2"> is formed from <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνηρέτης</quote> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρέτης</quote>, oarsman), a word recorded by Photius, who explains it by <quote xml:lang="grc">σύμφωνος</quote>, and compares <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἀντηρέτης</quote> ( <ref n="Aesch. Seven 245">Aesch. <title>Theb.</title> 283</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντηρέτας ἐχθροῖσι</quote>). In Eur. fr. 776. 3 (from Stobaeus <title>Flor.</title> 93. 2), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρ’ ὄλβος αὐτοῖς ὅτι τυφλὸς συνηρεφεῖ</quote>, Meineke restored <quote xml:lang="grc">συνηρετεῖ</quote>. In Eur. fr. 282. 7 the best texts of Athenaeus (413 D) have <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ αὖ πένεσθαι καὶ ξυνηρετεῖν τύχαις</quote>, though Schweighäuser, following Valckenär, gave <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνηρετμεῖν</quote>: the true reading there, however, is found in Galen's quotation of the verse (vol. 1. p. 23), viz., <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀξυπηρετεῖν</quote>. [Hesychius gives <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνηρετίσεις· συνήσεις. συζυγήσεις</quote>. Lobeck proposed to read <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνηρετήσεις</quote>: but the interpretation by <quote xml:lang="grc">συζυγήσεις</quote> seems rather to favour a conjecture (Ruhnken's?) mentioned in Alberti's ed. of Hesychius, vol. II. p. 707, <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυναρτίσεις</quote>.]</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_φρονῶν_1330">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ ἐξείη σοι εἰπεῖν</quote>. For the elliptical use of <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάρ</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 82"> <title>O. T.</title> 82</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OT 318"> O. T. 318</ref>(and Append. to <title>O. T.</title>, p. 221): I. <ref n="Thuc. 11.">Thuc. 11.</ref>§ 4 <quote xml:lang="grc">δῆλον δέ</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτι μάχῃ ἐκράτησαν</quote> )<quote xml:lang="grc">· τὸ γὰρ ἔρυμα..οὐκ ἂν ἐτειχίσαντο</quote>.—For the place of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_1330"> after <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴην</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1140">cp. 1140</ref> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φίλον_μέγιστον_1331">, as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 585"> <title>Ph.</title> 585</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτος δέ μοι | φίλος μέγιστος</quote>: <ref n="Soph. El. 46"> <title>El.</title> 46</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> μέγιστος..δορυξένων</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τλῇς_1333">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 411">cp. 411</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔτλη</quote>, and 1384.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαλεῖν_1333">=<quote xml:lang="grc">προβαλεῖν</quote>, as in 1308. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡ_βία_1334">. The definite article indicates that <quote xml:lang="grc">βία</quote> is a half-personified agency, as </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νικησάτω_1334"> also implies: ‘violence’ is here the impulse which may tempt a strong man to abuse his strength. A parallel to this use of <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ βία</quote> occurs in a fragment of the tragic poet Moschion (fr. 6. v. 15 in Nauck <title>Trag. Frag.</title> p. 814), where he is describing the primitive life of mankind;—<quote xml:lang="grc">ἦν δ’ ὁ μὲν νόμος | ταπεινός, ἡ βία δὲ σύνθρονος Διΐ.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατεῖν_1334">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 745"> <title>Ant.</title> 745</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τιμάς γε τὰς θεῶν πατῶν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχθιστος_1336">, ‘my worst foe,’— the active and passive senses being blended.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κράτησα_1336">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 308">cp. 308</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">)θώϋξεν</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔμπας_1338">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ὅμως</quote>, as in 122, where <quote xml:lang="grc">καίπερ</quote> is added to the participle.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντατιμάσαιμ_1338">. The choice lies between this correction by Bothe of L's <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν ἀτιμάσαιμ’</quote>, and Elmsley's </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔ_ἀτιμάσαιμ_1338">. The best reason for preferring <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντατιμάσαιμ’</quote> is a palaeographical one, viz., that a change of <quote xml:lang="grc">ΟΥΤΑΝ</quote> into <quote xml:lang="grc">ΟΥΚΑΝ</quote> (T into K) is rather less probable than a loss of T in <quote xml:lang="grc">ΟΥΚΑΝ</quote>(<quote xml:lang="grc">Τ</quote>)<quote xml:lang="grc">ΑΤΙΜΑΣΑΙΜ</quote>, seeing that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτιμάζω</quote> was a familiar word, while <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντατιμάζω</quote> was unfamiliar. There is no force in the objection that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντ‐</quote> in the compound is unfitting (since Ajax had not ‘dishonoured’ Odysseus); the reciprocity marked by <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντ‐</quote> is simply that of overt hostility. As to the </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔκουν_1338"> (or </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_οὖν_1338">) of the later MSS., it was evidently a makeshift, only less feeble than the Triclinian <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἄν γ’.— ἀντατιμάζω</quote> occurs nowhere else, but is formed like <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνταδικεῖν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕν_ἄριστον_1340">: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1344"> <title>Ph.</title> 1344</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἑλλήνων ἕνα | κριθέντ’ ἄριστον</quote>. See also <ref n="Soph. OT 1380"> <title>O. T.</title> 1380</ref>(n.), <title>O.C.</title> 563 (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλὴν_Ἀχιλλέως_1341">. The rank of <cit> <quote xml:lang="lat">heros ab Achille secundus</quote> <bibl n="Hor. S. 2.3.193">(Hor. <title>Sat.</title> 2. 3. 193)</bibl> </cit> is ascribed to Ajax in the <title>Iliad</title> (<ref n="Hom. Il. 2.768">2. 768 f.</ref>, <ref n="Hom. Il. 17.279">17. 279 f.</ref>), and by later poets; Alcaeus fr. 48 <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴαν, τὸν ἄριστον πέδ’ Ἀχίλλεα</quote>: <ref n="Pind. N. 7">Pind. <title>N.</title> 7. 27</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κράτιστον Ἀχιλλέος ἄτερ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_νόμους_1343">. The injury done will not be to the senseless clay, but rather to the <quote xml:lang="grc">νέρτεροι θεοί</quote>, to whom the dead belong ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1070"> <title>Ant.</title> 1070</ref>), and to their unwritten laws, ‘which live for ever’ (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 456). <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1129">Cp. 1129</ref> f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἄνδρα_1344"> is object to <quote xml:lang="grc">βλάπτειν</quote>. Some take <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἐσθλὸν</quote> as subject, and <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρα</quote> alone as object. But (<emph>a</emph>) the <emph>merit</emph> of the dead man comes into account here; <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1355">cp. 1355</ref>: and (<emph> b</emph>) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ δίκαιον</quote> puts the precept on the broadest ground; it is not merely a point of honour for the <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσθλός.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_θάνοι_1344">: for the opt. in general statement, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 521">cp. 521</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> εἰ..πάθοι</quote> (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταῦτ_1346">, adverbial cognate acc. with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπερμαχεῖς_1346">: so <ref n="Soph. OT 264"> <title>O. T.</title> 264</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνθ’ ὧν ἐγὼ τάδ’, ὡσπερεὶ τοὐμοῦ πατρός</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc"> ὑπερμαχοῦμαι</quote> (where <quote xml:lang="grc">τάδ’</quote> is the reading of the MSS., and <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦδ’</quote> only a conjecture). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔγωγ_1347"> <ref n="Soph. Aj. 104">cp. 104</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡνίκ_καλόν_1347">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, while he was a living and a sane foe. Even before his death, the demented Ajax had won the pity of Odysseus (121). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_γὰρ_1348">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1320">cp. 1320</ref> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσεμβῆναι_1348">: <quote xml:lang="grc">προς‐</quote> refers to <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμίσουν</quote>: ‘in addition to’—in continuation of—that former enmity. Cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 456"> <title>El.</title> 456</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐχθροῖσιν αὐτοῦ ζῶντ’ ἐπεμβῆναι ποδί</quote>. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 884">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 884</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστε σύγγονον | βροτοῖσι τὸν πεσόντα λακτίσαι πλέον</quote>. Sopater (in Walz <title>Rhet. Graec.</title> IV. 550) remarks that it is characteristic of Athenians, <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς πρότερον ἠδικηκόσι κειμένοις ὕστερον μὴ ἐπεμβαίνειν</quote>: as Aristophanes says of himself (alluding to Cleon), <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐκ’ ἐτόλμησ’ αὖθις ἐπεμπηδῆσ’ αὐτῷ κειμένῳ</quote>. So <ref n="Plut. Flam. 21">Plut. <title>Flam.</title> 21</ref>(speaking of Scipio's conduct towards Hannibal after Zama) <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν ἐπετόλμησεν, οὐδ’ ἐπενέβη τῇ τύχῃ τοῦ ἀνδρός</quote> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀτρείδη_1349"> is propitiatory (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1319">cp. 1319</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κέρδεσιν_καλοῖς_1349">. The <quote xml:lang="grc">κέρδη</quote> meant are unworthy personal triumphs,—assertions of power which violate some higher law. It is in the same sense that Teiresias replies to Creon's taunt against the <quote xml:lang="grc">μαντικὸν γένος,—τὸ δ’ ἐκ τυράννων αἰσχροκέρδειαν φιλεῖ</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1056"> <title>Ant.</title> 1056</ref>). Cp. Moschion fr. 7. 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">τί κέρδος οὐκέτ’ ὄντας ὑβρίζειν νεκρούς;</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόν_ῥᾴδιον_1350">. This is the first symptom that Agamemnon's resolve has been shaken: he feels dimly that there is a conflict of duties. As a king, he must uphold the common weal, and punish treason (such as Ajax seemed guilty of). It is <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐσεβές</quote> to do that. But what if, in doing so, he violates <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐσέβεια</quote> on another side,—that represented by the <quote xml:lang="grc">θεῶν νόμοι</quote> of which Odysseus spoke (1343)? A somewhat similar utterance of Agamemnon, when perplexed by the demands upon him, occurs in fr. 481: <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάρ τις ἂν δύναιτο πρῳράτης στρατοῦ | τοῖς πᾶσιν εἶξαι καὶ προσαρκέσαι χάριν</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_λέγουσι_1351">. If it is not easy for a king to see his course of duty clearly, he can at least pay regard to his friends, when they offer good advice; as Haemon says to Creon, <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τῶν λεγόντων εὖ καλὸν τὸ μανθάνειν</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Ant. 723"> <title>Ant.</title> 723</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τιμὰς_νέμειν_1351">: for the plur., cp. <ref n="Eur. El. 355"> <title>El.</title> 355</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ τεθνηκότι | τιμὰς προσάπτειν</quote> (where the sense is simply ‘to honour,’ not, ‘to render rites’). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλύειν_ἄνδρα_1352">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> ‘An <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐσθλὸς ἀνήρ</quote>, such as thou art, ought to defer to his king, instead of seeking to overrule him.’ The words seem also to glance at the alleged disloyalty of Ajax. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 666"> <title>Ant.</title> 666</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὃν πόλις στήσειε, τοῦδε χρὴ κλύειν</quote>. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 925"> <title>Ph.</title> 925</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν γὰρ ἐν τέλει κλύειν | τό τ’ ἔνδικόν με καὶ τὸ συμφέρον ποεῖ</quote>.—For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῶν_τέλει_1352">, see <ref n="Soph. Ant. 67"> <title>Ant.</title> 67</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παῦσαι_1353"> is said in a gentle and kindly tone; ‘Be content; you have the best of it,—it is your own true interest that prevails,—when you allow yourself to be overruled by a prudent friend.’ <ref n="Soph. Aj. 330">Cp. 330</ref>, 484: <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 941">Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 941</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΚΛ. τοῖς δ’ ὀλβίοις γε καὶ τὸ νικᾶσθαι πρέπει</quote>. | <quote xml:lang="grc">ΑΓ. ἦ καὶ σὺ νίκην τήνδε δήριος τίεις; | ΚΛ. πιθοῦ· κρατεῖς μέντοι παρεὶς ἑκὼν ἐμοί</quote> [vulg. <quote xml:lang="grc">κράτος..πάρες γ’</quote>]. <ref n="Isoc. 9.44">Isocr. or. 9 § 44</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλὰ μὲν τῶν χρωμένων ἡττώμενος</quote> (often yielding to his familiar friends), <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντα δὲ τῶν ἐχθρῶν περιγιγνόμενος.— <emph>τῶν φίλων</emph> </quote>: for the gen., cp. <ref n="Eur. Med. 315">Eur. <title>Med.</title> 315</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρεισσόνων νικώμενοι</quote>: <title>Nub.</title> 1087 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢν τοῦτο νικηθῇς ἐμοῦ</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποτέ_1355"> refers to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐχθρὸς_1355"> as well as </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γενναῖος_1355">. The feud dated, indeed, only from the <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπλων κρίσις</quote> (1337): but <quote xml:lang="grc">ποτέ</quote> means merely, ‘in his lifetime.’ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐχθρὸν_νέκυν_1356">; Agamemnon's case is now hopeless; he has allowed Odysseus to narrow the argument down to a personal question,—just as Teucer did with Menelaüs (1134 n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νικᾷ_γὰρ_1357">: ‘Yes, for with me his worth is far more potent—weighs far more—than his enmity.’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆςἔχθρας_1357"> is a genitive of comparison, depending on the notion of superiority contained in </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νικᾷ_1357">: =<quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ἀρετὴ πολὺ κρείσσων ἐστί μοι τῆς ἔχθρας</quote>. There is no parallel for such a genitive after <quote xml:lang="grc"> νικᾷ</quote>: but it is quite intelligible, and seems not too bold for the poet's style. (Eustathius p. 842. 10 takes <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἔχθρας</quote> as depending on <quote xml:lang="grc">πολύ</quote>:—<quote xml:lang="grc">καινῶς τὸ πολὺ ἀντὶ τοῦ πλέον ληφθέν</quote>.)</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιοίδε_1358">..</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φῶτες_βροτῶν_1358">: ‘such men, however, are the unstable of mankind’;—such, namely, as relent like Odysseus. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βροτῶν_1358">, L's reading, is strongly confirmed by the exactly similar pleonasm in <ref n="Soph. OC 280"> <title>O. C.</title> 280</ref> f., <quote xml:lang="grc">φυγὴν δέ του | μήπω γενέσθαι φωτὸς ἀνοσίου βροτῶν</quote>. Cp. also <ref n="Hom. Od. 17.587"> <title>Od.</title> 17. 587</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάρ πώ τινες ὧδε καταθνητῶν ἀνθρώπων | ἀνέρες κ.τ.λ.</quote>: 23. 187 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρῶν δ’ οὔ κέν τις ζωὸς βροτός</quote>. The <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βροτοῖς_1358"> would be an ethic dat., ‘in men's judgment’ (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1363">cp. 1363</ref>). It has more point than its rival: but this seems a case in which a tenable reading, with the stronger evidence on its side, should be preferred to a more attractive variant.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔμπληκτοι_1358"> (from <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐμπλήσσω</quote>, to ‘rush’ or ‘dash’ in), ‘impulsive,’ with the notion of ‘inconstant’: <ref n="Eur. Tro. 1205">Eur. <title>Tro.</title> 1205</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">αἱ τύχαι</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμπληκτος ὡς ἄνθρωπος, ἄλλοτ’ ἄλλοσε | πηδῶσι</quote>. <ref n="Plat. Lysis 214C"> <title>Lys.</title> 214 C</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδέποτε ὁμοίους μηδ’ αὐτοὺς αὑτοῖς εἶναι, ἀλλ’ ἐμπλήκτους τε καὶ ἀσταθμήτους</quote> . <title>Eumenes</title> 3 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμπληκτον ὄντα καὶ φορᾶς μεστὸν ἀβεβαίου καὶ ὀξείας</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὖθις_1359">: <quote xml:lang="grc">αὖθις</quote>=‘afterwards,’ as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 270"> <title>Tr.</title> 270</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1204."> <title>Ant.</title> 1204.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πικροί_1359">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">infensi:</foreign> <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 234">Aesch. <title>Cho.</title> 234</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς φιλτάτους γὰρ οἶδα νῷν ὄντας πικρούς</quote>. Cp. <title>O.C.</title> 615 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ τερπνὰ πικρὰ γίγνεται καὖθις φίλα</quote>: and above, 679 ff.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιούσδ_1360">. Agamemnon retorts: ‘Do you recommend, then, friends who change as Ajax did?’—<quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐπαινῶ</quote> with inf., as in <ref n="Eur. El. 1322"> <title>El.</title> 1322</ref>, <ref n="Soph. OC 664"> <title>O. C.</title> 664</ref> f. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπαινεῖν_1361">: Odysseus borrows the other's word only in order to parry his question.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκληρὰν_ψυχὴν_1361">: this phrase denotes the stubborn <emph>fortitude</emph> of Heracles in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1260"> <title>Tr.</title> 1260</ref>(n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δειλοὺς_φανεῖς_1362">, make us appear so to men. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1020">Cp. 1020</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc"> φανείς</quote> (n.).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῇδε_θἡμέρᾳ_1362">: 756 n. He is now ready to yield, and hesitates only from fear of public opinion. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὲν_οὖν_1363">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">immo</foreign> : <ref n="Soph. OT 705."> <title>O. T.</title> 705.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἑλλησι_1363">, ethic dat.: 1282 (n.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔγωγε_1365">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 104">cp. 104</ref>, 1347.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνθάδ_1365"> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵξομαι_1365"> , <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ θάπτεσθαι</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1158"> <title>O. T.</title> 1158</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ εἰς τόδ’ ἥξεις</quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς τὸ ὀλέσθαι</quote>. <ref n="Eur. Her. 1356">Eur. <title>H. F.</title> 1356</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς τοῦθ’ ἱκέσθαι, δάκρὐ ἀπ’ ὀμμάτων βαλεῖν</quote>. Here </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνθάδε_1365">=<quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖσε</quote>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 304">Soph. <title> Ph.</title> 304</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐνθάδ’ οἱ πλοῖ</quote> (=<quote xml:lang="grc">δεῦρο</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_ὅμοια_1366">. Many editors place a colon after <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅμοια</quote>, explaining the phrase as a proverb: ‘It is always so: every man works for himself.’ One of the later scholia gives this view: <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄντως πάντα τὰ ἀνθρώπινα ὅμοια· πᾶς γὰρ ἄνθρωπος τὴν ἑαυτοῦ πραγματεύεται σωτηρίαν</quote>. (Cp. Terence <title>Phormio</title> 264 <quote xml:lang="lat">ecce autem similia omnia: omnes congruont</quote> etc.) This may be right; but the somewhat homely proverb seems rather too abrupt here for Sophocles. I still prefer the simpler view that <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅμοια</quote> is adverbial: ‘in all things alike every man works for himself.’ Even in the matter of giving burial to another man a selfish motive enters. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὑτῷ_1366"> as dat. of interest with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πονεῖ_1366">, cp. <title>H.F.</title> 388 <quote xml:lang="grc">Μυκηναίῳ πονῶν τυράννῳ</quote>.—Some understand, ‘every man does deeds like himself,’—works in his characteristic way,—meaning that Odysseus is, as usual, <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλαυτος</quote>. This seems too artificial. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷ_μᾶλλον_1367"> <quote xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</quote> Odysseus frankly accepts the imputation of selfishness, which helps his cause by making the favour seem done to <emph>him.</emph> Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 736"> <title>Ant.</title> 736</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλῳ γὰρ ἢ )μοὶ χρή με τῆσδ’ ἄρχειν χθονός;</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὸν_1368"> appears better than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σόν_γ_1368"> here: the <quote xml:lang="grc">σὸν γὰρ ἄρα</quote> in a few of the inferior MSS. was probably a conjectural attempt to restore the metre, when <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρα</quote> had become <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄρα</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ποήσῃς_1369">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, whether you make the deed your own, or merely consent to others doing it. For <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἂν</quote>, ‘in whatever way,’ cp. <title> Legg.</title> 881 D <quote xml:lang="grc">κολαζόντων αὐτὸν..ὡς ἂν ἐθέλωσι</quote>: <ref n="Plat. Sym. 181"> <title>Symp.</title> 181</ref>A <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῇ πράξει, ὡς ἂν πραχθῇ, τοιοῦτο ἀπέβη</quote>: <ref n="Plat. Crat. 424"> <title>Crat.</title> 424</ref>E <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἄν, οἶμαι, δοκῇ ἑκάστη ἡ εἰκὼν δεῖσθαι ἑκάστου φαρμάκου</quote>. Apoll. Rhod. 2. 345 <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τὰ μὲν ὥς κε πέλῃ, τὼς ἔσσεται</quote>. Elsewhere in Sophocles <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἄν</quote>=‘in order that’: 655; <ref n="Soph. OT 329"> <title>O. T.</title> 329</ref>; <title>O.C.</title> 72; <ref n="Soph. Ant. 215"> <title>Ant.</title> 215</ref>; <ref n="Soph. Phil. 129"> <title>Ph.</title> 129</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 826"> Ph. 826</ref>; fr. 816; fr. 1019. 11.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πανταχῇ_1369">, ‘in every case’: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1241">cp. 1241</ref>; <ref n="Soph. Ant. 634"> <title>Ant.</title> 634</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πανταχῇ δρῶντες</quote>, ‘however we act’ (n.).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρηστός_γ_1369">, good and kind, <emph>at least</emph>,—even if only passive in the matter. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_μέντοι_1370">. Here <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλά</quote> =‘well,’ <quote xml:lang="grc">μέντοι</quote>=‘however,’ and <quote xml:lang="grc">γε</quote> emphasises <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖ</quote>. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1107"> <title>Tr.</title> 1107</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ εὖ γέ τοι τόδ’ ἴστε</quote>. We find <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ..μέντοι</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 524."> <title>Ph.</title> 524.</ref>The combination <quote xml:lang="grc">γε μέντοι</quote> is frequent ( <ref n="Soph. OT 442"> <title>O. T.</title> 442</ref> n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀκεῖ_ὢν_1372">, in the shades, as upon earth: for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖ</quote>, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 855">cp. 855</ref> (n.). <ref n="Soph. Ant. 75"> <title>Ant.</title> 75</ref>(<quote xml:lang="grc">πλείων χρόνος</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃν δεῖ μ’ ἀρέσκειν τοῖς κάτω τῶν ἐνθάδε</quote>. For the parataxis (= ‘there, <emph>as he was</emph> here’), cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 82">Ar. <title>Ran.</title> 82</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δ’ εὔκολος μὲν ἐνθάδ’ εὔκολος δ’ ἐκεῖ</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρῇς_1373">. For <quote xml:lang="grc">χρῇ, χρῇς</quote>, see on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 887"> <title>Ant.</title> 887</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴτε χρῇ θανεῖν | εἴτ’ ἐν τοιαύτῃ ζῶσα τυμβεύειν στέγῃ</quote> (where <quote xml:lang="grc">ζῶσα</quote> excludes <quote xml:lang="grc">χρή</quote>). Here, as in <ref n="Soph. El. 606"> <title>El.</title> 606</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κήρυσσέ μ’ εἰς ἅπαντας, εἴτε χρῇς κακήν, χρή</quote> is not impossible, but is so much less suitable than <quote xml:lang="grc">χρῇς</quote> that the latter may be considered certain. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἀπὸ_τοῦδ_1376">=<quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ ἀπὸ τοῦδε</quote>: so <ref n="Thuc. 2. 15">Thuc. 2. 15</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ..πρὸ τούτου</quote> (‘formerly’): <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 512e">Plat. <title>Gorg.</title> 512 E</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ ἐπὶ τούτῳ</quote> </cit> (‘next’).— </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγγέλλομαι_1376"> (midd.)...</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶναι_φίλος_1376">, announce that I am ready to be a friend. This use of the simple verb does not occur elsewhere; but cp. Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 531 <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀξαγγέλλομαι | θνῄσκειν</quote>, ‘offer to die.’ In <title>O. T.</title> 148 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξαγγέλλεται</quote> (with acc.)=to offer a thing spontaneously. The ordinary word in this sense was <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἐπαγγέλλομαι.— <emph>τότ’</emph> </quote>, <foreign xml:lang="lat">olim:</foreign> 650 n.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_1376">, the older Attic form (for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔα</quote>): <title>O. T.</title> 1123. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυμπονεῖν_1379">, in preparing and conducting the obsequies.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδὲν_ὅσων_1379">=<quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲν τούτων, ὅσα</quote>: for <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλλείπω</quote> with acc., cp. Plat. <title>Politicus</title> 269 C <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγε μηδὲν ἐλλείπων</quote>: Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> I. 2. 14 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤν τις..ἐλλίπῃ τι τῶν νομίμων</quote>. (<quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲν</quote> could also be adv., ‘in nothing,’ as in 115 <quote xml:lang="grc">φείδου μηδὲν ὧνπερ ἐννοεῖς</quote>, since <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλλείπειν</quote> with gen. could mean, ‘to fall short in’; but that constr. is less fitting in this context.)—The reading of the MSS., </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅσον_1379">, is clearly an error; the plural number is needed here. Cp. <title>Ant.</title> 196 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ πάντ’ ἐφαγνίσαι | ἃ τοῖς ἀρίστοις ἔρχεται κάτω νεκροῖς</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄριστ_1381">: the first word marks his gratitude. (Nauck, however, would change it to <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἄναξ</quote>.)</gloss>
