<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγοισι_1381">, causal dat., ‘for thy words.’ Cp. <title> Tr.</title> 1127 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ δῆτα</quote> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">σιγᾶν πρέπει</quote> ) <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς γε πρόσθεν ἡμαρτημένοις</quote>, ‘in view of her past crimes.’ Thuc. 3. 98 § 5 <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς πεπραγμένοις φοβούμενος τοὺς Ἀθηναίους</quote> (on account of what had occurred).—The objection to taking <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγοισι</quote> as =‘in my <emph>words</emph>’ is that the implied reservation (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἔργοις δέ σε τιμᾶν οὐκ ἔχω</quote>) would be premature and ungraceful here. It would foreshadow the exclusion of Odysseus from an active part in the funeral rites (1394). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔψευσας_ἐλπίδος_1383">, cheated me of (agreeably disappointed me in) my foreboding: cp. <title>O. T.</title> 1432 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπίδος μ’ ἀπέσπασας</quote> (n.), where, as here, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπὶς</quote> is a dark presentiment. Xen. <title>H.</title> 7. 5. 24 <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐψεύσθη τῆς ἐλπίδος</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρέστης_χερσίν_1384">: schol. <quote xml:lang="grc">συνεμάχησας ἔργῳ, οὐ λόγῳ</quote>. He has given <emph> active</emph> help by coming to the spot, and withstanding the resolve of the Atreidae. The peculiarity consists in the figurative sense of <quote xml:lang="grc">χερσίν</quote> (=‘effectually’): but to a Greek the word would at once suggest <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔργοις</quote>, as opp. to <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγοις.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτλης_1384">: 411, 1333.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρὼν_1384">, in the presence of the dead: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1156">cp. 1156</ref> n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανόντι_ἐφυβρίσαι_1384">: the dat. as with <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεγγελᾶν</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 180">Soph. <title> Ph.</title> 180</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ δ’ ὃς τὰ δεινὰ τῇδ’ ἐφυβρίζει πόλει.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζῶν_1384">: for the antithesis with <quote xml:lang="grc">θανόντι</quote>, cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1163"> <title>Tr.</title> 1163</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ζῶντά μ’ ἔκτεινεν θανών</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἠθελησάτην_1386">, instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς..ἔτλησαν, ἐθέλοντες</quote>. Such compression is frequent, esp. after <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ὥσπερ</quote>: <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign> <ref n="Plat. Gorg. 522A">Plat. <title> Gorg.</title> 522A</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πεινῆν καὶ διψῆν ἀναγκάζων, οὐχ ὥσπερ ἐγὼ πολλὰ καὶ ἡδέα καὶ παντοδαπὰ εὐώχουν ὑμᾶς</quote> : <ref n="Plat. Sym. 179E">Plat. <title>Symp.</title> 179E</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐποίησαν τὸν θάνατον αὐτοῦ ὑπὸ γυναικῶν γενέσθαι, οὐχ ὥσπερ Ἀχιλλέα τὸν τῆς Θέτιδος υἱὸν ἐτίμησαν</quote>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὑπιβρόντητος_1386">, crazy with arrogance (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1225">cp. 1225</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκαιὸν</quote> ). <ref n="Dem. 19.231">Dem. or. 19 § 231</ref> (<quote xml:lang="grc">ἡγοῦντο</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμβεβροντῆσθαι</quote>, they thought him crazed: id. or. 18 § 243 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμβρόντητε, ε<*>=τα νῦν λέγεις;</quote> <ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 793">Ar. <title> Eccl.</title> 793</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠμβρόντητε σύ</quote>. <ref n="Xen. Anab. 3. 4. 12">Xen. <title>An.</title> 3. 4. 12</ref>(of a besieged city) <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεὺς δὲ ἐμβροντήτους ποιεῖ τοὺς ἐνοικοῦντας, καὶ οὕτως ἑάλω</quote>. <title>P.V.</title> 361 (of Typhon) <quote xml:lang="grc">φρένας γὰρ εἰς αὐτὰς τυπεὶς | ἐφεψαλώθη κἀξεβροντήθη σθένος</quote>. (The form <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιβρόντητος</quote> occurs only here.)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μολὼν_1386">, though a dual verb follows: cp. <ref n="Eur. Alc. 734">Eur. <title>Alc.</title> 734</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρρων</quote> (so schol., <quote xml:lang="grc"> ἔρροις</quote> vulg.) <quote xml:lang="grc">νυν αὐτὸς χἡ συνοικήσασά σοι | ... γηράσκετε</quote>: <ref n="Xen. Anab. 7. 1. 40">Xen. <title>An.</title> 7. 1. 40</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">προσελθὼν δὲ Τιμασίων..καὶ Νέων..ἔλεγον.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτός_ξύναιμος_1386">: this redundant <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτός τε</quote> often occurs when the mention of the other person or persons is an afterthought: <title>O.C.</title> 462 <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτός τε παῖδές θ’ αἵδε</quote> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ὀλύμπου_τοῦδ_1389">: cp. <title>O.C.</title> 1654 <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆν τε προσκυνοῦνθ’ ἅμα | καὶ τὸν θεῶν Ὄλυμπον</quote>: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 758"> <title>Ant.</title> 758</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τόνδ’ Ὄλυμπον</quote> (‘by the heaven above us’).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρεσβεύων_1389">: cp. fr. 248 (<quote xml:lang="grc">Ἴναχε</quote>) <quote xml:lang="grc">μέγα πρεσβεύων | Ἄργους τε γύαις Ἥρας τε πάγοις</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μνήμων_1390">: so <title>P.V.</title> 516 <quote xml:lang="grc">μνήμονές τ’ Ἐρινύες</quote>: <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 381"> <title>Eum.</title> 381</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐμήχανοί τε καὶ τέλειοι κακῶν | τε μνήμονες Σεμναί. </quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Δίκη_1390"> the avenger is here associated with the Erinys, as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 808"> <title>Tr.</title> 808</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧν σε ποίνιμος Δίκη | τείσαιτ’ Ἐρινύς τ’</quote>, and <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1432">Aesch. <title> Ag.</title> 1432</ref> f.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τελεσφόρος_1390">, the epithet of <quote xml:lang="grc">Μοῖρα</quote> in <title>P.V.</title> 511. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακοὺς_κακῶς_1391">: 1177 n.— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἄνδρα_1391">. It seems needless to write <quote xml:lang="grc">τόνδ’</quote>, since a reference to Ajax has just preceded (v. 1388 <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτόν</quote>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λώβαις_1391">, a modal dat. like <quote xml:lang="grc">φοναῖς</quote> in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1003."> <title>Ant.</title> 1003.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λαέρτου_1393">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1">cp. 1</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Λαρτίου</quote> (n.). The mode of address is honorific, like <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀτρείδη</quote> in 1349. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάφου_ἐπιψαύειν_1394">. Odysseus cannot be allowed to touch the body, or to assist in carrying it to the grave, or to join in pouring the <quote xml:lang="grc">χοαί</quote> at the time of interment. It is this intimate participation which is poetically expressed by the phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">τάφου ἐπιψαύειν</quote>. (Morstadt wished to read <quote xml:lang="grc">νεκροῦ</quote> instead of <quote xml:lang="grc">τάφου</quote>, but this would unduly narrow the sense.)</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κομίζειν_1394">) any one he pleases. This is what seems to be meant by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ξύμπρασσε_1394">: where it should be noted that <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> is not ‘both’ (as if answering to the <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> in <quote xml:lang="grc">κεἴ τινα στρατοῦ</quote>), but emphasises the verb,—‘in all else <emph>do</emph> cooperate’—as you wish to do. That is, <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύμπρασσε</quote> alludes to the request of Odysseus in 1378 f., <quote xml:lang="grc">συνθάπτειν..καὶ ξυμπονεῖν</quote>, and must therefore refer, in part at least, to something connected with the obsequies —not <emph>solely</emph> to friendly offices of a different kind, such as care for Tecmessa and Eurysaces; though it may include these.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_θανόντι_1394"> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κ.τ.λ.</foreign> It might be unpleasing to the spirit of the dead if Odysseus were allowed to touch the body, or to have any active part in the rites. So in <ref n="Eur. El. 442"> <title>El.</title> 442</ref> ff. the spirit of Agamemnon is conceived as refusing Clytaemnestra's <quote xml:lang="grc">χοαί</quote> at his grave; and in the same play, when (1123) Electra is allowed to handle the funeral urn, the pretended Phocian justifies the boon by saying that she is evidently not <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσμενὴς</quote> to the dead. The wrath of Ajax against Odysseus was conceived as enduring in the world below: <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴη δ’ Αἴαντος ψυχὴ Τελαμωνιάδαο | νόσφιν ἀφεστήκει</quote> ( <ref n="Hom. Od. 11.543"> <title>Od.</title> 11. 543</ref>)—when Odysseus approached. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἄλλα_πάντα_1398">: all that pertains to the funeral rites (including the preparations described in vv. 1402 ff.). The phrase is purposely brief and vague, to avoid a second mention of the <quote xml:lang="grc">τάφος. </quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καθ_ἡμᾶς_1398">, in regard to us; <ref n="Hdt. 7. 158"> Her. 7. 158</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τό τε κατ’ ὑμέας</quote> (‘as far as you are concerned’): <ref n="Eur. Andr. 740"> Eur. <title>Andr.</title> 740</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἂν..τὸ λοιπὸν ᾖ | σώφρων καθ’ ἡμᾶς, σώφρον’ ἀντιλήψεται</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_μέν_1400">: <foreign xml:lang="lat"> sc.</foreign> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξεῖναί μοι συνθάπτειν</quote>. This impf. (without <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄν</quote>) states a wish which has not been fulfilled; <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, a wish that something were now true which is not true. It is usually joined with <quote xml:lang="grc">μέν</quote> (implying the contrast with the actual fact): so <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 866">Ar. <title>Ran.</title> 866</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐβουλόμην μὲν οὐκ ἐρίζειν ἐνθάδε</quote> (‘I would that I were not contending here—as I am’): Andoc. or. 5 § 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐβουλόμην μέν, ὦ ἄνδρες, τὴν δύναμιν τοῦ λέγειν..ἐξἴσου μοι καθεστάναι τῇ..συμφορᾷ</quote>: Isae. or. 10 § 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐβουλόμην μέν, ὦ ἄνδρες,..τἀληθῆ πρὸς ὑμᾶς..εἰπεῖν δυνηθῆναι</quote>: <ref n="Aeschin. 3.2">Aeschin. or. 3 § 2</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐβουλόμην μὲν οὖν, ὦ Ἀθηναῖοι, καὶ τὴν βουλὴν..ὀρθῶς διοικεῖσθαι</quote>. So <quote xml:lang="grc">μάλιστα μὲν ἐβουλόμην</quote>, Isae. fr. 4 (Scheibe). This usage is analogous to that of the impers. <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔδει, χρῆν</quote>, etc., with inf. ( <ref n="Soph. OT 256"> <title>O. T.</title> 256</ref> n.). On the other hand, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤθελον ἄν</quote> (88 n.), <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐβουλόμην ἄν</quote>, with inf., means that the wish would have been (or would now be) formed, if it had not been (or were not now) vain to form it. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπαινέσας_1401">: cp. <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 1616">Ar. <title>Av.</title> 1616</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπαινεῖ χοὗτος</quote> (‘assents’): <ref n="Thuc. 4. 65">Thuc. 4. 65</ref>§ 2 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπαινεσάντων δὲ αὐτῶν ἐποιοῦντο τὴν ὁμολογίαν</quote>. So <quote xml:lang="grc"> αἰνεῖν</quote> in poetry, as <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 469">Aesch. <title> Eum.</title> 469</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πράξας γὰρ ἐν σοὶ πανταχῇ τάδ’ αἰνέσω.</quote> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_σόν_1401">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 99">cp. 99</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς τὸ σὸν ξυνῆκ ἐγώ</quote> (‘thy saying’). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅλις_γὰρ_1402"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> During his brief absence from the scene (vv. 1185—1222), Teucer has fulfilled the charge given by the Chorus (1165), and has chosen the spot where Ajax is to be buried. He now directs some of the Salaminian sailors to go and dig the grave; others are to place the tripod near it; a third detachment is to bring thither the hero's armour from the tent. Tecmessa and Eurysaces are still kneeling beside the corpse (1171 ff.). Verses 1409 ff. mark the moment when the body is lifted from the ground. Then it is borne forth (probably by Teucer and one or more <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσπολοι</quote>), the Chorus following, before they separate to their several tasks.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολὺς_χρόνος_1402">, the delay caused by the Atreidae. Cp. <title>Suppl.</title> 1109 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτείνειν βίον</quote>: <ref n="Eur. Ion 625"> <title>Ion</title> 625</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰῶνα τείνει</quote>. ( Itis difficult to comprehend why the phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">χρόνος ἐκτέταται</quote> should be thought suspicious, as by Morstadt and Nauck: the former proposed <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγος</quote>.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_μὲν_1403"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> The threefold command (<quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ μὲν—τοὶ δ)—μία δ’..ἀνδρῶν ἴλη</quote>) may have been the signal for some corresponding movement on the part of the Chorus; perhaps for the usual change from the formation in three <emph>ranks</emph> (<quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ ζυγά</quote>), facing the actors, to that in three <emph>files</emph> (<quote xml:lang="grc">κατὰ στοίχους</quote>), preparatory to the final exit. Wecklein thinks that the three divisions of the Chorus made separate exits (right, left, and in front of the spectators). This seems less probable, as the closing scene would be more effective if the whole Chorus went out in procession after the body of Ajax.</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάπετον_1403">: 1165 n.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταχύνετε_1403"> has better MS. authority than <quote xml:lang="grc">ταχύνατε</quote>. The latter may, indeed, have been read by the scholiast (<quote xml:lang="grc">μετὰ σπουδῆς ὀρύξατε</quote>); but it can derive no support from <quote xml:lang="grc">θέσθε</quote> (1406), since the <emph>process</emph> of digging is fitly expressed by the pres. imper., while the aor. imper. better suits the <emph>act</emph> of placing. <quote xml:lang="grc">ταχύνω</quote> is not elsewhere transitive. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὶ_δ_1404">. The Doric (and Homeric) <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὶ</quote> occurs in tragic lyrics ( <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 584">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 584</ref> etc.), and once in a trimeter, <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 424">Aesch. <title>Pers.</title> 424</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὶ δ’ ὥστε θύννους κ.τ.λ.</quote>, where it is a trait of epic style in the narrative. Sophocles uses it only here. The <foreign xml:lang="lat">v.l.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_δ_1404"> is not only weaker, but untenable, since a pronoun is needed which shall answer to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἱμέν_1404">: the <quote xml:lang="grc">λουτρά</quote> are to be prepared while the grave is being dug.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑψίβατον_τρίποδ_1404">, the caldron, supported on a high three-legged stand. (Cp. <ref n="Pind. N. 10">Pind. <title>N.</title> 10. 47</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀχαιῶν ὑψίβατοι πόλιες</quote>, built on lofty sites.) The stand was the <quote xml:lang="grc">τρίπους</quote> proper, while the caldron was <quote xml:lang="grc">λέβης</quote>, but the former term is often used so as to include the latter: Aesch. fr. 1 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν μὲν τρίπους ἐδέξατ’, οἰκεῖος λέβης</quote>, | <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰεὶ φυλάσσων τὴν ὑπὲρ πυρὸς στάσιν</quote>. The fire was kindled in a brazier under the <quote xml:lang="grc">λέβης</quote>, as may be seen on a vase in the British Museum, which represents Medea boiling a ram in a lebes or <quote xml:lang="grc">χύτρα</quote> (Smith's <title>Dict. Ant.</title>, new ed., vol. I. p. 426).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφίπυρον_θέσθε_1404">, place it so that the fire shall rise all round it from beneath: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.344"> <title>Il.</title> 18. 344</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφὶ πυρὶ στῆσαι τρίποδα μέγαν</quote>, and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 348 <quote xml:lang="grc">γάστρην μὲν τρίποδος πῦρ ἄμφεπε</quote>. <ref n="Hom. Il. 23.702"> <title>Il.</title> 23. 702</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρίποδ’ ἐμπυριβήτην.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λουτρῶν_ἐπίκαιρον_1404">: a genitive of relation; cp. <ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 4. 6. 9">Xen. <title>Cyr.</title> 4. 6. 9</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">γάμου ἤδη ὡραία</quote>. So <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκεῖος</quote> or <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλότριός τινος. </quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁσίων_1404">, <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, prescribed by piety ( <ref n="Eur. El. 433"> <title>El.</title> 433</ref> n.). Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1201"> <title>Ant.</title> 1201</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">λούσαντες ἁγνὸν λουτρόν</quote>: and <foreign xml:lang="lat">ib.</foreign> 901 (n.). The caldron used for this purpose is called <quote xml:lang="grc">λοετροχόος τρίπους</quote> in <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.346."> <title>Il.</title> 18. 346.</ref>After the washing of the dead, unguents were usually applied (as in the case of Patroclus, <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.350"> <title>Il.</title> 18. 350</ref>). <ref n="Verg. A. 6. 218">Verg. <title> Aen.</title> 6. 218</ref> <quote xml:lang="lat">Pars calidos latices et aëna undantia flammis | Expediunt, corpusque lavant frigentis et ungunt.</quote> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴλη_1407">, band, troop, from rt. <quote xml:lang="grc">vελ, εἴλω</quote>, to press: cp. <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅμ‐ιλο‐ς</quote> (Curt. <title>Etym.</title> § 660). The Ionic form is <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴλη</quote> ( <ref n="Hdt. 1. 73"> Her. 1. 73</ref> etc.). Its poetical use is as free as that of Lat. <foreign xml:lang="lat">manus</foreign> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, <ref n="Pind. N. 5">Pind. <title>N.</title> 5. 38</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὔφρονες ἶλαι</quote>): but it had also a technical military sense, <ref n="Xen. Anab. 1. 2. 16">Xen. <title> An.</title> 1. 2. 16</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">κατ’ ἴλας καὶ κατὰ τάξεις</quote> (‘troops’ of cavalry and ‘companies’ of infantry).— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_κόσμον_1407">, the armour ‘under the shield,’ <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign> the body-armour, as the <quote xml:lang="grc">θώραξ</quote> and the <quote xml:lang="grc">κνημῖδες</quote>. Ajax had directed that all his armour except his shield should be buried with him (577). <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπασπίδιος</quote> occurs only here and in [Eur. ] <title>Rhes.</title> 740 <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ὑπασπίδιον κοῖτον</quote>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παῖ_γ_1409">: for <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δέ</quote> after the vocative, cp. <ref n="Soph. OT 1097"> <title>O. T.</title> 1097</ref>, <ref n="Soph. El. 150"> <title>El.</title> 150</ref>: for the combination <quote xml:lang="grc">δέ..γε</quote>, <ref n="Soph. OT 1030"> <title>O. T.</title> 1030</ref>(n.). The emphasis of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_1409"> belongs here to the whole clause (‘do thou, <emph>too</emph>, raise’), and not to the word </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατρός_1409">. For other instances, in which the stress of <quote xml:lang="grc">γε</quote> does not fall on the word next before it, but on a whole phrase or clause, see <ref n="Soph. Ant. 213"> <title>Ant.</title> 213</ref>, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 648"> Ant. 648</ref> , <ref n="Soph. Ant. 747"> Ant. 747</ref>; <ref n="Soph. OC 1278"> <title>O. C.</title> 1278</ref>; <ref n="Soph. El. 1506."> <title>El.</title> 1506.</ref>— </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλευρὰς_1409">: Elmsley (on <ref n="Eur. Heraclid. 824">Eur. <title>Heracl.</title> 824</ref>) held that the fem. plur. <quote xml:lang="grc">πλευραὶ</quote> was not used in tragedy: here he wished to read <quote xml:lang="grc">πλευρὰ</quote> (dual), or <quote xml:lang="grc">πλευράν</quote>. But, as Hermann observed, this view would involve some very improbable changes; <foreign xml:lang="lat">e.g.</foreign>, in <title>I. T.</title> 298 <quote xml:lang="grc">παίει σιδήρῳ λαγόνας, εἰς πλευρὰς ἱείς</quote> (where Elmsley suggested <quote xml:lang="grc">λαγόνας εἰς μέσας</quote>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτι_θερμαὶ_1411"> <quote xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</quote> In vv. 918 f. blood was said to be issuing from his nostrils, and from the wound. There, in the phrase <quote xml:lang="grc">φυσῶντ’ ἄνω πρὸς ῥῖνας</quote>, the context shows that <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνω</quote> means ‘upward (from the lower part of the body) to the nostrils.’ Here, however, <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνω</quote> seems to have a more general sense,—‘upward to the surface’ (whether through the nostrils, or from the mouth of the wound). As Ajax must now have been dead for about an hour, the thing described seems impossible.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύριγγες_1411">, a vague term (=‘channels’), seems to mean <quote xml:lang="grc">φλέβες</quote>, a word which down to the time of Aristotle (and later) denoted <emph>arteries</emph> as well as <emph>veins</emph>;—<quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρτηρίαι</quote> meaning the <emph>bronchial tubes.</emph> (See Append. on <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1054."> <title>Tr.</title> 1054.</ref>) Now in Empedocles 344 <quote xml:lang="grc">σύριγγες</quote> certainly mean air-passages; <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧδε δ’ ἀναπνεῖ πάντα καὶ ἐκπνεῖ· πᾶσι λίφαιμοι | σαρκῶν σύριγγες πύματον κατὰ σῶμα τέτανται</quote>,—where the epithet ‘bloodless’ points to the reason why the ancients took the arteries for air-passages,—viz. because, after death, they were found empty, while the veins were filled with blood returning from the heart. But here Sophocles cannot have meant by <quote xml:lang="grc">σύριγγες</quote> the bronchial tubes; the epithet <quote xml:lang="grc">θερμαί</quote> clearly points to <quote xml:lang="grc">φλέβες</quote>. In Apoll. Rhod. 4. 1647 <quote xml:lang="grc">σῦριγξ αἱματόεσσα κατὰ σφυρόν</quote> means ‘a vein.’ Another explanation of <quote xml:lang="grc">σύριγγες</quote>, viz. the ‘nostrils,’ may be rejected. Aristotle uses <quote xml:lang="grc">σύριγγες</quote> for the pores of the lungs: <quote xml:lang="grc">αἴτιον τοῦ ἀναπνεῖν ὁ πνεύμων σομφὸς ὢν</quote> (‘porous’) <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ συρίγγων πλήρης</quote>, <title>De respir.</title> 15 (p. 478 a 13).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέλαν_μένος_1411">: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1067"> Aesch. <title>Ag.</title> 1067</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὶν αἱματηρὸν ἐξαφρίζεσθαι μένος</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φησὶ_1414">: <foreign xml:lang="lat">i.e.</foreign>, if he says that he is a friend, let him now prove it.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σούσθω_1414">: for the form, see on <ref n="Soph. Trach. 645"> <title>Tr.</title> 645</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοῦται.— <emph> βάτω</emph> </quote>: of this 2nd aor. imperat. we find also <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔμβα—</quote> ( <ref n="Eur. El. 113">Eur. <title>El.</title> 113</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">κατάβα—</quote> ( <title>Vesp.</title> 979), <quote xml:lang="grc">βᾶθι</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1196">Soph. <title> Ph.</title> 1196</ref>), <quote xml:lang="grc">βᾶτε</quote> ( <ref n="Soph. OC 1547">Soph. <title>O. C.</title> 1547</ref>).</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάντ_ἀγαθῷ_1414">: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 910">cp. 910</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ πάντα κωφός</quote>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοὐδενί_θνητῶν_1416">. If the text is sound, we must supply <quote xml:lang="grc">πονήσας</quote>, as </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πω_1416"> indicates: lit., ‘toiling for this heroic man, and never yet (having toiled) for a worthier.’ This is a harsh kind of compression; but, as the general sense is so clear, it might be tolerated. The phrase cannot be explained by ‘attraction,’ as if <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντ’ ἀγαθῷ, κοὐδενί πω λῴονι θνητῶν</quote>, could mean, <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντ’ ἀγαθῷ, καὶ οὗ οὐδείς πω λῴων ἦν θνητῶν</quote>. Blaydes writes, <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐδενὸς οὐ λῴονι θνητῶν</quote>. As to metre, the verse is a correct paroemiac, <foreign xml:lang="lat"> i.e.</foreign>, an anapaestic dimeter short of one syllable (‘catalectic’); the only peculiarity is the dactyl in the first foot, which in that place of a paroemiac is less usual than a spondee or an anapaest. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Αἴαντος_φωνῶ_1417">.] Either this verse is spurious (as is now generally thought), or else both it and verse 1416 are corrupt. If v. 1416 is a paroemiac, it cannot be followed by a paroemiac. If, then, v. 1417 is to be retained, v. 1416 must be made into an anapaestic dimeter. Further, v. 1417, as it stands, yields no satisfactory sense. It must be taken in one of two ways: (1) by itself, a colon or stop being placed after <quote xml:lang="grc">θνητῶν</quote>:—‘I speak of Ajax, in the days when he lived’: for the genitive, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1236">cp. 1236</ref>. Or (2) in connexion with v. 1416, a colon being placed after <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἴαντος</quote>, but no point after <quote xml:lang="grc">θνητῶν</quote>:—‘and never yet (having toiled) for a worthier man than Ajax;—I speak of the time when he lived.’ (Cp. Meleager <emph>epigr.</emph> 22 <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦν καλὸς Ἡράκλειτος, ὅτ’ ἦν ποτε</quote>.) The interpolation of v. 1417 may have been prompted by the comparative <quote xml:lang="grc">λῴονι</quote>, and by a wish to find the name of the hero at the close of the play. No emendation yet proposed is probable: see Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰδοῦσιν_1418">, by experience: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. El. 205"> <title>El.</title> 205</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς ἐμὸς ἴδε πατὴρ | θανάτους.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάντις_1418">: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1160"> <title>Ant.</title> 1160</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μάντις οὐδεὶς τῶν καθεστώτων βροτοῖς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: καὶ μάντις οὐδεὶς τῶν καθεστώτων βροτοῖς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅ_πράξει_1418">, how he (himself) will fare: <cit> <bibl>fr. 531</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc"> <lg type="anapests"> <l>τοῦτο κατειδότας ὡς οὐκ ἔστιν</l> <l>πλὴν Διὸς οὐδεὶς τῶν μελλόντων</l> <l>ταμίας ὅ τι χρὴ τετελέσθαι</l> </lg> </quote> </cit> (verses which probably closed the poet's <title>Tereus</title>). </gloss>
